1442145_11_ITEM1_P0_S0	Verisk Analytics, Inc. enables risk-bearing businesses to better understand and manage their risks.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P0_S1	We provide value to our customers by supplying proprietary data that, combined with our analytic methods, creates embedded decision support solutions.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P0_S2	We are the largest aggregator and provider of detailed actuarial and underwriting data pertaining to United States, or U.S., property and casualty, or P C, insurance risks.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P0_S3	We offer solutions for detecting fraud in the U.S. P C insurance, healthcare and mortgage industries, and sophisticated methods to predict and quantify loss in diverse contexts ranging from natural catastrophes to health insurance.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P1_S0	Our customers use our solutions to make better risk decisions with greater efficiency and discipline.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P1_S1	We refer to these products and services as solutions due to the integration among our services and the flexibility that enables our customers to purchase components or the comprehensive package.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P1_S2	These solutions take various forms, including data, statistical models or tailored analytics, all designed to allow our clients to make more logical decisions.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P1_S3	We believe our solutions for analyzing risk positively impact our customers revenues and help them better manage their costs.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P2_S0	In 2010, our U.S. customers included all of the top 100 P C insurance providers, numerous health plans and third-party administrators, five of the six leading mortgage insurers, and 16 of the top 20 mortgage lenders.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P2_S1	We believe that our commitment to our customers and the embedded nature of our solutions serve to strengthen and extend our relationships.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P3_S0	We help those businesses address what we believe are the four primary decision making processes essential for managing risk as set forth below in the Verisk Risk Analysis Framework:
1442145_11_ITEM1_P4_S0	These four processes correspond to various functional areas inside our customers operations:
1442145_11_ITEM1_P5_S0	our tools to quantify loss are primarily used by claims departments, independent adjustors and contractors.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P6_S0	We add value by linking our solutions across these four key processes; for example, we use the same modeling methods to support the pricing of homeowner s insurance policies and to quantify the actual losses when damage occurs to insured homes.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P7_S0	We offer our solutions and services primarily through annual subscriptions or long-term agreements, which are typically pre-paid and represented approximately 70.0% of our revenues in 2010.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P7_S1	For the year ended December 31, 2010, we had revenues of $1,138.3 million and net income of $242.6 million.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P7_S2	For the five year period ended December 31, 2010, our revenues and net income grew at a Compound Annual Growth Rate, or CAGR, of 11.7% and 14.9%, respectively.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P8_S0	We trace our history to 1971, when Insurance Services Office, Inc., or ISO, started operations as a not-for-profit advisory and rating organization providing services for the U.S. P C insurance industry.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P8_S1	ISO was formed as an association of insurance companies to gather statistical data and other information from insurers and report to regulators, as required by law.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P8_S2	ISO s original functions also included developing programs to help insurers define and manage insurance products and providing information to help insurers determine their own independent premium rates.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P8_S3	Insurers used and continue to use our offerings primarily in their product development, underwriting and rating functions.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P8_S4	Today, those businesses form the core of our Risk Assessment segment.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P9_S0	Over the past decade, we have transformed our business beyond its original functions by deepening and broadening our data assets, developing a set of integrated risk management solutions and services and addressing new markets through our Decision Analytics segment.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P10_S0	Our expansion into analytics began when we acquired the American Insurance Services Group, or AISG, and certain operations and assets of the National Insurance Crime Bureau in 1997 and 1998, respectively.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P10_S1	Those organizations brought to the company large databases of insurance claims, as well as expertise in detecting and preventing claims fraud.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P11_S0	To further expand our Decision Analytics segment, we acquired AIR Worldwide, or AIR, in 2002, the technological leader in catastrophe modeling.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P11_S1	In 2004, we entered the healthcare space by acquiring several businesses that now offer web-based analytical and reporting systems for health insurers, provider organizations and self-insured employers.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P12_S0	compliance and decision support solutions for the U.S. mortgage industry.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P12_S1	In 2006, to bolster our position in the claims field we acquired Xactware, a leading supplier of estimating software for professionals involved in building repair and reconstruction.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P12_S2	In 2010, we acquired 3E Company, creating a scale presence in supply chain and environmental health and safety.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P13_S0	These acquisitions have added scale, geographic reach, highly skilled workforces, and a wide array of new capabilities to our Decision Analytics segment.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P13_S1	They have helped to make us a leading provider of information and decision analytics for customers involved in the business of risk in the U.S. and selectively around the world.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P14_S0	Our senior management operating team, which includes our chief executive officer, chief financial officer, chief operating officer, general counsel, and three senior officers who lead our business units, have been with us for an average of almost twenty years.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P14_S1	This team has led our transformation to a successful for-profit entity, focused on growth with our U.S. P C insurer customers and expansion into a variety of new markets.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P15_S0	On May 23, 2008, in contemplation of our initial public offering, or IPO, ISO formed Verisk Analytics, Inc., or Verisk, a Delaware corporation, to be the holding company for our business.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P15_S1	Verisk was initially formed as a wholly-owned subsidiary of ISO.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P15_S2	On October 6, 2009, in connection with our IPO, the company effected a reorganization whereby ISO became a wholly-owned subsidiary of Verisk.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P15_S3	Verisk Class A common stock began trading on the NASDAQ Global Select Market on October 7, 2009 under the symbol VRSK.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P16_S0	We organize our business in two segments: Risk Assessment and Decision Analytics.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P17_S0	Our Risk Assessment segment serves our P C insurance customers and focuses on the first two decision making processes in our Risk Analysis Framework: loss prediction and selection and pricing of risk.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P17_S1	Within this segment, we also provide solutions to help our insurance customers comply with their reporting requirements in each U.S. state in which they operate.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P17_S2	Our customers include most of the P C insurance providers in the U.S.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P18_S0	We are the recognized leader in the U.S. for industry-standard insurance programs that help P C insurers define coverages and issue policies.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P18_S1	Our policy language, prospective loss cost information and policy writing rules can serve as integrated turnkey insurance programs for our customers.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P19_S0	Insurance companies need to ensure that their policy language, rules, and rates comply with all applicable legal and regulatory requirements.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P19_S1	Insurers must also make sure their policies remain competitive by promptly changing coverages in response to changes in statutes or case law.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P19_S2	To meet their needs, we process and interface with state regulators on average over 4,000 filings each year, ensuring smooth implementation of our rules and forms.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P19_S3	When insurers choose to develop their own alternative programs, our industry-standard insurance programs also help regulators make sure that such insurers policies meet basic coverage requirements.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P20_S0	Standardized coverage language, which has been tested in litigation and tailored to reflect judicial interpretation, helps to ensure consistent treatment of claimants.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P20_S1	As a result, our industry-standard language also simplifies claim settlements and can reduce the occurrence of costly litigation, because our language causes the meaning of coverage terminology to become established and known.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P20_S2	Our policy language includes standard coverage language, endorsements and policy writing support language that assist our customers in understanding the risks they assume and the coverages they are offering.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P20_S3	With these policy programs, insurers also benefit from economies of scale.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P21_S0	1,100 regulatory actions and 2,000 court cases per year, to make any required changes to our policy language and rating information.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P22_S0	To cover the wide variety of risks in the marketplace, we offer a broad range of policy programs.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P22_S1	For example, in the homeowner s line of insurance, we maintain policy language and rules for six basic coverages, 178 national endorsements, and 495 state-specific endorsements.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P22_S2	Overall, we provide policy language, prospective loss costs, policy writing rules, and a variety of other solutions for 25 lines of insurance.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P23_S0	We gather information on individual properties and communities so that insurers can use our information to evaluate and price personal and commercial property insurance, as well as commercial liability insurance.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P23_S1	Our property-specific rating and underwriting information allow our customers to understand, quantify, underwrite, mitigate, and avoid potential loss for residential and commercial properties.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P23_S2	Our database contains loss costs and other vital information on approximately 3.0 million commercial buildings in the United States and also holds information on approximately 5.8 million individual businesses occupying those buildings.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P23_S3	We have a staff of approximately 600 field representatives strategically located around the United States who observe and report on conditions at commercial and residential properties, evaluate community fire-protection capabilities and assess the effectiveness of municipal building-code enforcement.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P23_S4	Each year, our field staff visits over 350,000 commercial properties to collect information on new buildings and verify building attributes.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P24_S0	We also provide proprietary analytic measures of the ability of individual communities to mitigate losses from important perils.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P24_S1	Nearly every property insurer in the U.S. uses our evaluations of community firefighting capabilities to help determine premiums for fire insurance throughout the country.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P24_S2	We provide field-verified and validated data on the fire protection services for more than 46,000 fire response jurisdictions.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P24_S3	We also offer services to evaluate the effectiveness of community enforcement of building codes and the efforts of communities to mitigate damage from flooding.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P24_S4	Further, we provide information on the insurance rating territories, premium taxes, crime risk, and hazards of windstorm, earthquake, wildfire, and other perils.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P24_S5	To supplement our data on specific commercial properties and individual communities, we have assembled, from a variety of internal and third-party sources, information on hazards related to geographic locations representing every postal address in the U.S. Insurers use this information not only for policy quoting but also for analyzing risk concentration in geographical areas.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P25_S0	The P C insurance industry is heavily regulated in the U.S. P C insurers are required to collect statistical data about their premiums and losses and to report that data to regulators in every state in which they operate.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P25_S1	Our statistical agent services have enabled P C insurers to meet these regulatory requirements for over 30 years.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P25_S2	We aggregate the data and, as a licensed statistical agent in all 50 states, Puerto Rico and the District of Columbia, we report these statistics to insurance regulators.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P25_S3	We are able to capture significant economies of scale given the level of penetration of this service within the U.S. P C insurance industry.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P26_S0	To provide our customers and the regulators the information they require, we maintain one of the largest private databases in the world.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P26_S1	Over the past four decades, we have developed core expertise in acquiring, processing, managing, and operating large and comprehensive databases that are the foundation of our Risk Assessment segment.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P26_S2	We use our proprietary technology to assemble, organize and update vast amounts of detailed information submitted by our customers.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P26_S3	We supplement this data with publicly available information.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P27_S0	Each year, P C insurers send us approximately 2.8 billion detailed individual records of insurance transactions, such as insurance premiums collected or losses incurred.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P27_S1	We maintain a database of over 15.8 billion statistical records, including approximately 5.9 billion commercial lines records and approximately 9.9 billion personal lines records.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P27_S2	We collect unit-transaction detail of each premium and loss record, which enhances the validity, reliability and accuracy of our data sets and our actuarial analyses.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P27_S3	Our proprietary quality process includes almost 2,500 separate checks to ensure that data meet our high standards of quality.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P28_S0	We provide actuarial services to help our customers price their risks as they underwrite.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P28_S1	We project future losses and loss expenses utilizing a broad set of data.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P28_S2	These projections tend to be more reliable than if our customers used solely their own data.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P28_S3	We provide loss costs by coverage, class, territory, and many other categories.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P28_S4	Our customers can use our estimates of future loss costs in making independent decisions about the prices charged for their policies.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P28_S5	For most P C insurers, in most lines of business, we believe our loss costs are an essential input to rating decisions.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P28_S6	We make a number of actuarial adjustments, including loss development and loss adjustment expenses before the data is used to estimate future loss costs.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P28_S7	Our actuarial services are also used to create the analytics underlying our industry-standard insurance programs described below.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P29_S0	Using our large database of premium and loss data, our actuaries are able to perform sophisticated analyses using our predictive models and analytic methods to help our P C insurance customers with pricing, loss reserving, and marketing.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P29_S1	We distribute a number of actuarial products and offer flexible services to meet our customers needs.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P29_S2	In addition, our actuarial consultants provide customized services for our clients that include assisting them with the development of independent insurance programs, analysis of their own underwriting experience, development of classification systems and rating plans, and a wide variety of other business decisions.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P29_S3	We also supply information to a wide variety of customers in other markets including reinsurance, government agencies and real estate.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P30_S0	In the Decision Analytics segment, we support all four phases of our Risk Analysis Framework.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P30_S1	We develop predictive models to forecast scenarios and produce both standard and customized analytics that help our customers better predict loss, select and price risk, detect fraud before and after a loss event, and quantify losses.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P31_S0	As we develop our models to quantify loss and detect fraud, we improve our ability to predict the loss and prevent the fraud from happening.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P31_S1	We believe this provides us with a significant competitive advantage over firms that do not offer solutions which operate both before and after loss events.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P32_S0	We are a leading provider of fraud-detection tools for the P C insurance industry.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P32_S1	Our fraud solutions improve our customers profitability by both predicting the likelihood that fraud is occurring and detecting suspicious activity after it has occurred.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P33_S0	claimants or insurers) that help our customers determine if fraud has occurred.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P33_S1	The system searches for matches in identifying information fields, such as name, address, Social Security number, vehicle identification number, driver s license number, tax identification number, or other parties to the loss.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P33_S2	Our system also includes advanced name and address searching to perform intelligent searches and improve the overall quality of the matches.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P34_S0	Information from match reports speeds payment of meritorious claims while providing a defense against fraud and can lead to denial of a claim, negotiation of a reduced award or further investigation by the insurer or law enforcement.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P35_S0	We have a comprehensive system used by claims adjusters and investigations professionals to process claims and fight fraud.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P36_S0	Claims databases are one of the key tools in the fight against insurance fraud.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P36_S1	The benefits of a single all-claims database include improved efficiency in reporting data and searching for information, enhanced capabilities for detecting suspicious claims and superior information for investigating fraudulent claims, suspicious individuals and possible fraud rings.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P37_S0	Our database contains information on more than 700 million claims and is the world s largest database of claims information.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P38_S0	Insurers and other participants submit new claim reports, more than 239,000 a day on average, across all categories of the U.S. P C insurance industry.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P39_S0	We also provide a service allowing insurers to report thefts of automobiles and property, improving the chances of recovering those items; a service that helps owners and insurers recover stolen heavy construction and agricultural equipment; an expert scoring system that helps distinguish between suspicious and meritorious claims; and products that use link-analysis technology to help visualize and fight insurance fraud.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P40_S0	We are a leading provider of automated fraud detection, compliance and decision-support tools for the mortgage industry.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P40_S1	Utilizing our own loan level application database combined with actual mortgage loan performance data, we have established a risk scoring system which increases our customers ability to detect fraud.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P40_S2	We provide solutions that detect fraud through each step of the mortgage lifecycle and provide regulatory compliance solutions that perform instant compliance reviews of each mortgage application.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P40_S3	Our fraud solutions can improve our customers profitability by predicting the likelihood that a customer account is experiencing fraud.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P40_S4	Our solution analyzes customer transactions in real time and generates recommendations for immediate action which are critical to stopping fraud and abuse.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P40_S5	These applications can also detect some organized fraud schemes that are too complex and well-hidden to be identified by other methods.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P41_S0	Effective fraud detection relies on pattern identification, which in turn requires us to identify, isolate and track mortgage applications through time.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P42_S0	Histories of multiple loans, both valid and fraudulent, are required to compare a submitted loan both to actual data and heuristic analyses.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P42_S1	For this reason, unless fraud detection solutions are fueled by comprehensive data, their practicality is limited.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P43_S0	Our proprietary database contains more than 18 million current and historical loan applications collected over the past ten years.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P43_S1	This database contains data from loan applications as well as supplementary third-party data.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P44_S0	Our technology employs sophisticated models to identify patterns in the data.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P44_S1	Our solution provides a score, which predicts whether the information provided by a mortgage applicant is correct.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P44_S2	Working with data obtained through our partnership with a credit bureau, we have demonstrated a strong correlation between fraudulent information in the application and the likelihood of both foreclosure and early payment default on loans.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P44_S3	We believe our solution is based upon a more comprehensive set of loan level information than any other provider in the mortgage industry.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P45_S0	We also provide forensic audit services for the mortgage origination and mortgage insurance industries.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P45_S1	Our predictive screening tools predict which defaulted loans are the most likely candidates for full audits for the purpose of detecting fraud.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P45_S2	We then generate detailed audit reports on defaulted mortgage loans.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P45_S3	Those reports serve as a key component of the loss mitigation strategies of mortgage loan insurers.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P46_S0	The recent turmoil in the mortgage industry has created an opportunity for growth in demand for our services, as we believe most mortgage insurers do not have the in-house capacity to respond to and properly review all of their defaulted loans for evidence of fraud.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P47_S0	We offer solutions that help healthcare claims payors detect fraud, abuse and overpayment.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P47_S1	Our approach combines computer-based modeling and profiling of claims with analysis performed by clinical experts.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P47_S2	We run our customers claims through our proprietary analytic system to identify potential fraud, abuse and overpayment, and then a registered nurse, physician or other clinical specialist skilled in coding and reimbursement decisions reviews all suspect claims and billing patterns.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P47_S3	This combination of system and human review is unique in the industry and we believe offers improved accuracy for paying claims.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P48_S0	We analyze the patterns of claims produced by individual physicians, physicians practices, hospitals, dentists, and pharmacies to locate the sources of fraud.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P48_S1	After a suspicious source of claims is identified, our real-time analytic solutions investigate each claim individually for particular violations, including upcoding, multiple billings, services claimed but not rendered, and billing by unlicensed providers.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P48_S2	By finding the individual claims with the most cost-recovery potential and also minimizing the number of false-positive indications of fraud, we enable the special investigation units of healthcare payors to efficiently control their claims costs while maintaining high levels of customer service to their insurers.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P49_S0	We also offer web-based reporting tools that let payors take definitive action to prevent overpayments or payment of fraudulent claims.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P49_S1	The tools provide the documentation that helps to identify, investigate and prevent abusive and fraudulent activity by providers.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P50_S0	We pioneered the field of probabilistic catastrophe modeling used by insurers, reinsurers and financial institutions to manage their catastrophe risk.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P50_S1	Our models of global natural hazards, which form the basis of our solutions, enable companies to identify, quantify and plan for the financial consequences of catastrophic events.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P50_S2	We have developed models, covering natural hazards, including hurricanes, earthquakes, winter storms, tornadoes, hailstorms, and flood, for potential loss events in more than 50 countries.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P50_S3	We have also developed and introduced a probabilistic terrorism model capable of quantifying the risk in the U.S. from this emerging threat, which supports pricing and underwriting decisions down to the level of an individual policy.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P51_S0	We are a leading provider of healthcare business intelligence and predictive modeling.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P51_S1	We provide analytical and reporting systems to health insurers, provider organizations and self-insured employers.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P51_S2	Those organizations use our solutions to review their healthcare data, including information on claims, membership, providers and utilization, and provide cost trends, forecasts and actuarial, financial and utilization analyses.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P52_S0	For example, our solutions allow our customers to predict medical costs and improve the financing and organization of health services.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P52_S1	Our predictive models help our customers identify high-cost cases for care- and disease-management intervention, compare providers adjusting for differences in health, predict resource use for individuals and populations, establish health-based and performance-based payments, negotiate payments and incentives, negotiate premium rates, and measure return on investment.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P53_S0	We also provide our customers healthcare consulting services using complex clinical analyses to uncover reasons behind cost and utilization increases.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P54_S0	Physicians and hospitals are adopting and acquiring new technologies, drugs and devices more rapidly than ever before.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P54_S1	We provide financial and actuarial consulting, clinical consulting, technical and implementation services and training services to help our customers manage costs and risks to their practices.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P55_S0	We provide data, analytic and networking products for professionals involved in estimating all phases of building repair and reconstruction.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P55_S1	We provide solutions for every phase of a building s life, including:
1442145_11_ITEM1_P56_S0	tracking the process of repair or reconstruction and facilitating communication among insurers, adjusters, contractors and policyholders.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P57_S0	To help our customers estimate repair costs, we also provide a solution that assists contractors and insurance adjusters to estimate repairs using a patented plan-sketching program.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P57_S1	The program allows our customers to sketch floor plans, roof plans and wall-framing plans and automatically calculates material and labor quantities for the construction of walls, floors, footings and roofs.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P58_S0	We also offer our customers access to wholesale and retail price lists, which include structural repair and restoration pricing for 467 separate economic areas in North America.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P58_S1	We revise this information monthly and, in the aftermath of a major disaster, we can update the price lists as often as weekly to reflect rapid price changes.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P59_S0	Our structural repair and cleaning database contains more than 13,000 unit-cost line items.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P59_S1	For each line item such as smoke cleaning, water extraction and hazardous cleanup, we provide time and material pricing, including labor, labor productivity rates (for new construction and restoration), labor burden and overhead, material costs, and equipment costs.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P59_S2	We improve our pricing data by analyzing the actual claims experience of our customers to verify our estimates.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P59_S3	We estimate that more than 75.0% of all homeowners claims settled in the U.S. annually use our solution.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P59_S4	Such a large percentage of the industry s claims leads to accurate pricing information, which we believe is unmatched in the industry.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P60_S0	Our estimates allow our customers to set loss reserves, deploy field adjusters and verify internal company estimates.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P60_S1	Our estimates also keep insurers, their customers, regulators, and other interested parties informed about the total costs of disasters.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P60_S2	We also provide our customers access to daily reports on severe weather and catastrophes and we maintain a database of information on catastrophe losses in the U.S. since 1950.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P61_S0	Over the past five years, we have grown our revenues at a CAGR of 11.7% through the successful execution of our business plan.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P61_S1	These results reflect strong organic revenue growth, new product development and selected acquisitions.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P61_S2	We have made, and continue to make, investments in people, data sets, analytic solutions, technology, and complementary businesses.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P61_S3	The key components of our strategy include:
1442145_11_ITEM1_P62_S0	We expect to expand the application of our solutions in insurance customers internal risk and underwriting processes.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P62_S1	Building on our deep knowledge of, and embedded position in, the insurance industry, we expect to sell more solutions to existing customers tailored to individual insurance segments.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P62_S2	By increasing the breadth and relevance of our offerings, we believe we can strengthen our relationships with customers and increase our value to their decision making in critical ways.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P63_S0	Develop New, Proprietary Data Sets and Predictive Analytics.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P63_S1	We work with our customers to understand their evolving needs.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P63_S2	We plan to create new solutions by enriching our mix of proprietary data sets, analytic solutions and effective decision support across the markets we serve.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P63_S3	We constantly seek to add new data sets that can further leverage our analytic methods, technology platforms and intellectual capital.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P64_S0	Leverage Our Intellectual Capital to Expand into Adjacent Markets and New Customer Sectors.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P64_S1	Our organization is built on nearly four decades of intellectual property in risk management.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P64_S2	We believe we can continue to profitably expand the use of our intellectual capital and apply our analytic methods in new markets, where significant opportunities for long-term growth exist.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P64_S3	We have already demonstrated the effectiveness of this strategy with our expansion into healthcare and non-insurance financial services.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P64_S4	We also continue to pursue growth through targeted international expansion.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P65_S0	Pursue Strategic Acquisitions that Complement Our Leadership Positions.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P65_S1	We will continue to expand our data and analytics capabilities across industries.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P65_S2	While we expect this will occur primarily through organic growth, we have and will continue to acquire assets and businesses that strengthen our value proposition to customers.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P65_S3	We have developed an internal capability to source, evaluate and integrate acquisitions that have created value for shareholders.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P66_S0	The customers in our Risk Assessment segment include the top 100 P C insurance providers in the United States.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P66_S1	Our statistical agent services are used by a substantial majority of P C insurance providers in the U.S. to report to regulators.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P66_S2	Our actuarial services and industry-standard insurance programs are used by the majority of insurers and reinsurers in the U.S.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P66_S3	In addition, certain agencies of the federal government, as well as county and state governmental agencies and organizations, use our solutions to help satisfy government needs for risk assessment and emergency response information.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P66_S4	In 2010 our largest Risk Assessment customer accounted for 4.8% of segment revenues and our top ten customers accounted for 26.9% of segment revenues.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P66_S5	Certain Relationships and Related Transactions, and Director Independence Customer Relationships for more information on our relationship with our principal stockholders.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P67_S0	In the Decision Analytics segment, we provide our P C insurance solutions to the majority of the P C insurers in the U.S.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P67_S1	Specifically, our claims database serves thousands of customers, representing nearly 93.0% of the P C insurance industry by premium volume, 26 state workers compensation insurance funds, 607 self-insurers, 455 third-party administrators, several state fraud bureaus, and many law-enforcement agencies involved in investigation and prosecution of insurance fraud.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P67_S2	Also, P C insurance companies using our building and repair solutions represent over 75.0% of the property market in the U.S.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P67_S3	We estimate that more than 80.0% of insurance repair contractors and service providers in the U.S. and Canada with computerized estimating systems use our building and repair pricing data.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P68_S0	In the U.S. healthcare industry, our customers include numerous health plans and third party administrators.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P68_S1	In the U.S. mortgage industry, we have more than 900 customers.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P68_S2	We provide our solutions to 16 of the top 20 mortgage lenders and five of the top six mortgage insurers.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P68_S3	We have been providing services to mortgage insurers for over 20 years.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P69_S0	In 2010, our largest customer in the Decision Analytics segment accounted for 9.0% of segment revenues and our top ten Decision Analytics customers accounted for 29.6% of segment revenues.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P70_S0	We believe no single competitor currently offers the same scope of services and market coverage we provide.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P70_S1	The breadth of markets we serve exposes us to a broad range of competitors.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P71_S0	Our Risk Assessment segment operates primarily in the U.S. P C insurance industry, where we enjoy a leading market presence.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P71_S1	We have a number of competitors in specific lines or services.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P72_S0	We encounter competition from a number of sources, including insurers who develop internal technology and actuarial methods for proprietary insurance programs.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P72_S1	Competitors also include other statistical agents, including the National Independent Statistical Service, the Independent Statistical Service and other advisory organizations, providing underwriting rules, prospective loss costs and coverage language such as the American Association of Insurance Services and Mutual Services Organization, although we believe none of our competitors has the breadth or depth of data we have.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P73_S0	Competitors for our property-specific rating and underwriting information are primarily limited to a number of regional providers of commercial property inspections and surveys, including Overland Solutions, Inc. and Regional Reporting, Inc.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P73_S1	We also compete with a variety of organizations that offer consulting services, primarily specialty technology and consulting firms.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P73_S2	In addition, a customer may use its own internal resources rather than engage an outside firm for these services.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P73_S3	Our competitors also include information technology product and services vendors including CDS, Inc., management and strategy consulting firms including Deloitte Consulting LLP, and smaller specialized information technology firms and analytical services firms including Pinnacle Consulting and EMB.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P74_S0	In the P C insurance claims market and catastrophe modeling market, certain products are offered by a number of companies, including Risk Management Solutions (catastrophe modeling), LexisNexis/ChoicePoint (loss histories and motor vehicle records for personal lines underwriting), MSB (property value and claims estimator), and Explore Information Services (personal automobile underwriting).
1442145_11_ITEM1_P74_S1	We believe that our P C insurance industry expertise, combined with our ability to offer multiple applications, services and integrated solutions to individual customers, enhances our competitiveness against these competitors with more limited offerings.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P75_S0	In the healthcare market, certain products are offered by a number of companies, including Computer Sciences Corporation (evaluation of bodily injury and workers compensation claims), Fair Isaac Corporation (workers compensation and healthcare claims cost containment) and Ingenix, McKesson and Medstat (healthcare predictive modeling and business intelligence).
1442145_11_ITEM1_P75_S1	Competitive factors include application features and functions, ease of delivery and integration, ability of the provider to maintain, enhance and support the applications or services and price.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P75_S2	In the mortgage analytics solutions market, our competitors include CoreLogic and DataVerify Corporation (mortgage lending fraud identification).
1442145_11_ITEM1_P75_S3	We believe that none of our competitors in the mortgage analytics market offers the same combination of expertise in fraud detection analytics and forensic audit capabilities.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P76_S0	We take a market-focused team approach to developing our solutions.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P76_S1	Our operating units are responsible for developing, reviewing and enhancing our various products and services.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P76_S2	Our data management and production team designs and manages our processes and systems for market data procurement, proprietary data production and quality control.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P76_S3	Our Enterprise Data Management, or EDM, team supports our efforts to create new information and products from available data and explores new methods of collecting data.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P76_S4	EDM is focused on understanding and documenting business-unit and corporate data assets and data issues; sharing and combining data assets across the enterprise; creating an enterprise data strategy; facilitating research and product development; and promoting cross-enterprise communication.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P77_S0	Our ISO Innovative Analytics, or IIA, team is a center of excellence inside the corporation for developing analytical methods in applying modeling techniques to predict risk outcomes.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P78_S0	Our software development team builds the technology used in many of our solutions.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P78_S1	As part of our product-development process, we continually solicit feedback from our customers on the value of our products and services and the market s needs.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P78_S2	We have established an extensive system of customer advisory panels, which meet regularly throughout the year to help us respond effectively to the needs of our markets.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P78_S3	In addition, we use frequent sales calls, executive visits, user group meetings, and other industry forums to gather information to match the needs of the market with our product development efforts.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P78_S4	We also use a variety of market research techniques to enhance our understanding of our clients and the markets in which they operate.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P79_S0	We also add to our offerings through an active acquisition program.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P79_S1	Since 2006, we have acquired 15 businesses, which have allowed us to enter new markets, offer new products and enhance the value of existing products with additional proprietary sources of data.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P80_S0	When we find it advantageous, we augment our proprietary data sources and systems by forming alliances with other leading information providers and technology companies and integrating their product offerings into our offerings.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P80_S1	This approach gives our customers the opportunity to obtain the information they need from a single source and more easily integrate the information into their workflows.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P81_S0	We sell our products and services primarily through direct interaction with our clients.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P81_S1	We employ a three-tier sales structure that includes salespeople, product specialists and sales support.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P81_S2	As of December 31, 2010, we had a sales force of 268 people.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P82_S0	Within the company, several areas have sales teams that specialize in specific products and services.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P82_S1	These specialized sales teams sell specific, highly technical product sets to targeted markets.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P83_S0	To provide account management to our largest customers, we segment the insurance carrier market into three groups.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P83_S1	Tier One or National Accounts constitutes our largest customers, Tier Two or Strategic Accounts represents both larger carrier groups and middle-market carriers.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P83_S2	Tier Three are the small insurance companies that may represent one line of business and/or regional writers for a few states.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P83_S3	A Sales Generalist is assigned to every insurer account and is responsible for our overall relationship with these insurance companies.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P83_S4	Our senior executives are also involved with the senior management of our customers.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P84_S0	Salespeople participate in both customer-service and sales activities.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P84_S1	They provide direct support, interacting frequently with assigned customers to assure a positive experience using our services.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P84_S2	Salespeople primarily seek out new sales opportunities and work with the various sales teams to coordinate sales activity and provide the best solutions for our customers.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P84_S3	We believe our salespeople s product knowledge and local presence differentiates us from our competition.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P85_S0	Product specialists are subject-matter experts and work with salespeople on specific opportunities for their assigned products.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P85_S1	Both salespeople and product specialists have responsibility for identifying new sales opportunities.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P85_S2	A team approach and a common customer relationship management system allow for effective coordination between the two groups.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P86_S0	The data we use to perform our analytics and power our solutions are sourced through six different kinds of data arrangements.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P87_S0	First, we gather data from our customers within agreements that also permit our customers to use the solutions created upon their data.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P87_S1	These agreements remain in effect unless the data contributor chooses to opt out and represent our primary method of data gathering.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P87_S2	It is very rare that contributors elect not to continue providing us data.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P87_S3	Second, we have agreements with data contributors in which we specify the particular uses of their data and provide to the data contributors their required levels of privacy, protection of data and where necessary de-identification of data.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P87_S4	These agreements represent no cost to us and generally feature a specified period of time for the data contributions and require renewal.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P87_S5	Third, we mine data found inside the transactions supported by our solutions; as an example, we utilize the claims settlement data generated inside our repair cost estimating solution to improve the cost factors used in our models.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P87_S6	Again, these arrangements represent no cost to us and we obtain the consent of our customers to make use of their data in this way.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P87_S7	Fourth, we source data generally at no cost from public sources including federal, state and local governments.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P87_S8	Fifth, we gather data about the physical characteristics of commercial properties through the direct observation of our field staff that also perform property surveys at the request of, and facilitated by, property insurers.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P87_S9	Lastly, we purchase data from data aggregators under contracts that reflect prevailing market pricing for the data elements purchased, including county tax assessor records, descriptions of hazards such as flood plains and professional licenses.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P88_S0	In all our modes of data collection, we are the owners of whatever derivative solutions we create using the data.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P88_S1	Our costs of data received from our customers were 1.7% and 1.9% of revenues for the years ended December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P89_S0	Our information technology systems are fundamental to our success.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P89_S1	They are used for the storage, processing, access and delivery of the data which forms the foundation of our business and the development and delivery of our solutions provided to our clients.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P89_S2	Much of the technology we use and provide to our customers is developed, maintained and supported by approximately 1,050 employees.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P89_S3	We generally own or have secured ongoing rights to use for the purposes of our business all the customer-facing applications which are material to our operations.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P89_S4	We support and implement a mix of technologies, focused on implementing the most efficient technology for any given business requirement or task.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P90_S0	We have two primary data centers in Jersey City, New Jersey and Orem, Utah.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P90_S1	In addition, we have data centers dedicated to certain business units, including AIR and Verisk Health in Boston and AISG Claimsearch in Israel.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P90_S2	In addition to these key data centers, we also have a number of smaller data centers located in other states.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P91_S0	We are committed to a framework for business continuity management and carry out annual reviews of the state of preparedness of each business unit.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P91_S1	All of our critical databases, systems and contracted client services are also regularly recovered.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P91_S2	We also have documented disaster recovery plans in place for each of our major data centers and each of our solutions.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P92_S0	Our primary data center recovery site is in New York State, approximately 50 miles northwest of Jersey City, New Jersey.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P93_S0	We have adopted a wide range of measures to ensure the security of our IT infrastructure and data.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P93_S1	Security measures generally cover the following key areas: physical security; logical security of the perimeter; network security such as firewalls; logical access to the operating systems; deployment of virus detection software; and appropriate policies and procedures relating to removable media such as laptops.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P93_S2	All laptops are encrypted and media leaving our premises that is sent to a third-party storage facility is also encrypted.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P93_S3	This commitment has led us to achieve certification from CyberTrust (an industry leader in information security certification) since 2002.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P94_S0	We own a significant number of intellectual property rights, including copyrights, trademarks, trade secrets and patents.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P94_S1	Specifically, our policy language, insurance manuals, software and databases are protected by both registered and common law copyrights, and the licensing of those materials to our customers for their use represents a large portion of our revenue.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P94_S2	We also own in excess of 500 trademarks in the U.S. and foreign countries, including the names of our products and services and our logos and tag lines, many of which are registered.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P94_S3	We believe many of our trademarks, trade names, service marks and logos to be of material importance to our business as they assist our customers in identifying our products and services and the quality that stands behind them.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P94_S4	We consider our intellectual property to be proprietary, and we rely on a combination of statutory (e.g., copyright, trademark, trade secret and patent) and contractual safeguards in a comprehensive intellectual property enforcement program to protect them wherever they are used.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P95_S0	We also own several software method and processing patents and have several pending patent applications in the U.S. that complement our products.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P95_S1	The patents and patent applications include claims which pertain to technology, including a patent for our Claims Outcome Advisor software, and for our Xactware Sketch product.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P95_S2	We believe the protection of our proprietary technology is important to our success and we will continue to seek to protect those intellectual property assets for which we have expended substantial research and development capital and which are material to our business.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P96_S0	In order to maintain control of our intellectual property, we enter into license agreements with our customers, granting each customer a license to use our products and services, including our software and databases.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P96_S1	This helps to maintain the integrity of our proprietary intellectual property and to protect the embedded information and technology contained in our solutions.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P96_S2	As a general practice, employees, contractors and other parties with access to our proprietary information sign agreements that prohibit the unauthorized use or disclosure of our proprietary rights, information and technology.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P97_S0	As of December 31, 2010, we employed 4,706 full-time and 184 part-time employees.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P97_S1	None of our employees are represented by unions.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P97_S2	We consider our relationship with our employees to be good and have not experienced interruptions of operations due to labor disagreements.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P98_S0	Our employees include over 200 actuarial professionals, including 43 Fellows and 27 Associates of the Casualty Actuarial Society, as well as 143 Chartered Property Casualty Underwriters, 17 Certified and 22 Associate Insurance Data Managers, and over 565 professionals with advanced degrees, including PhDs in mathematics and statistical modeling who review both the data and the models.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P99_S0	Because our business involves the distribution of certain personal, public and non-public data to businesses and governmental entities that make eligibility, service and marketing decisions based on such data, certain of our solutions and services are subject to regulation under federal, state and local laws in the United States and, to a lesser extent, foreign countries.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P99_S1	Examples of such regulation include the Fair Credit Reporting Act, which regulates the use of consumer credit report information; the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, which regulates the use of non-public personal financial information held by financial institutions and applies indirectly to companies that provide services to financial institutions; the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, which restricts the public disclosure of patient information and applies indirectly to companies that provide services to healthcare businesses; the Drivers Privacy Protection Act, which prohibits the public disclosure, use or resale by any state s department of motor vehicles of personal information about an individual that was obtained by the department in connection with a motor vehicle record, except for a permissible purpose and various other federal, state and local laws and regulations.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P100_S0	These laws generally restrict the use and disclosure of personal information and provide consumers certain rights to know the manner in which their personal information is being used, to challenge the accuracy of such information and/or to prevent the use and disclosure of such information.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P100_S1	In certain instances, these laws also impose requirements for safeguarding personal information through the issuance of data security standards or guidelines.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P100_S2	Certain state laws impose similar privacy obligations, as well as obligations to provide notification of security breaches in certain circumstances.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P101_S0	We are also licensed as a rating, rate service, advisory or statistical organization under state insurance codes in all fifty states, Puerto Rico, Guam, the Virgin Islands and the District of Columbia.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P101_S1	As such an advisory organization, we provide statistical, actuarial, policy language development and related products and services to property/casualty insurers, including advisory prospective loss costs, other prospective cost information, manual rules and policy language.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P101_S2	We also serve as an officially designated statistical agent of state insurance regulators to collect policy-writing and loss statistics of individual insurers and compile that information into reports used by the regulators.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P102_S0	Many of our products, services and operations as well as insurer use of our services are subject to state rather than federal regulation by virtue of the McCarran-Ferguson Act.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P102_S1	As a result, many of our operations and products are subject to review and/or approval by state regulators.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P102_S2	Furthermore, our operations involving licensed advisory organization activities are subject to periodic examinations conducted by state regulators and our operations and products are subject to state antitrust and trade practice statutes within or outside state insurance codes, which are typically enforced by state attorneys general and/or insurance regulators.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P103_S0	We maintain an Investor Relations website on the Internet at investor.verisk.com .
1442145_11_ITEM1_P103_S1	We make available free of charge, on or through this website, our annual, quarterly, and current reports and any amendments to those reports as soon as reasonably practicable following the time they are electronically filed with or furnished to the SEC.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P103_S2	To access these, click on the Financial Information SEC Filings link found on our Investor Relations homepage.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P104_S0	Verisk trades on the NASDAQ Global Select Market under the ticker symbol VRSK.
1442145_11_ITEM1_P104_S1	Our stock was first publicly traded on October 7, 2009.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P0_S0	You should carefully consider the following risks and all of the other information set forth in this annual report on Form 10-K before deciding to invest in shares of our Class A common stock.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P0_S1	If any of the following risks actually occurs, our business, financial condition or results of operations would likely suffer.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P0_S2	In such case, the trading price of our Class A common stock could decline due to any of these risks, and you may lose all or part of your investment.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P1_S0	We could lose our access to data from external sources which could prevent us from providing our solutions.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P2_S0	We depend upon data from external sources, including data received from customers and various government and public record services, for information used in our databases.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P2_S1	In general, we do not own the information in these databases, and the participating organizations could discontinue contributing information to the databases.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P2_S2	Our data sources could withdraw or increase the price for their data for a variety of reasons, and we could also become subject to legislative or judicial restrictions on the use of such data, in particular if such data is not collected by the third parties in a way which allows us to legally use and/or process the data.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P2_S3	In addition, some of our customers are significant stockholders of our company.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P2_S4	Specifically, all of our outstanding Class B common stock is owned by insurers who are also our customers and provide us with a significant percentage of our data.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P2_S5	If our customers percentage of ownership of our common stock decreases in the future, there can be no assurance that our customers will continue to provide data to the same extent or on the same terms.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P2_S6	If a substantial number of data sources, or certain key sources, were to withdraw or be unable to provide their data, or if we were to lose access to data due to government regulation or if the collection of data became uneconomical, our ability to provide solutions to our customers could be impacted, which could materially adversely affect our business, reputation, financial condition, operating results and cash flows.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Agreements with our data suppliers are short-term agreements.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P3_S1	Some suppliers are also competitors, which may make us vulnerable to unpredictable price increases and may cause some suppliers not to renew certain agreements.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P3_S2	Our competitors could also enter into exclusive contracts with our data sources.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P3_S3	If our competitors enter into such exclusive contracts, we may be precluded from receiving certain data from these suppliers or restricted in our use of such data, which would give our competitors an advantage.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P3_S4	Such a termination or exclusive contracts could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, and operating results if we were unable to arrange for substitute sources.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P4_S0	We derive a substantial portion of our revenues from U.S. P C primary insurers.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P4_S1	If the downturn in the U.S. insurance industry continues or that industry does not continue to accept our solutions, our revenues will decline.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Revenues derived from solutions we provide to U.S. P C primary insurers account for a substantial portion of our total revenues.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P5_S1	During the year ended December 31, 2010, approximately 57% of our revenue was derived from solutions provided to U.S. P C primary insurers.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P5_S2	Also, sales of certain of our solutions are tied to premiums in the U.S. P C insurance market, which may rise or fall in any given year due to loss experience and capital capacity and other factors in the insurance industry beyond our control.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P6_S0	revenues will decline if the insurance industry does not continue to accept our solutions.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P6_S1	Factors that might affect the acceptance of these solutions by P C primary insurers include the following:
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P7_S0	failure to execute our customer-focused selling approach.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P8_S0	A continued downturn in the insurance industry or lower acceptance of our solutions by the insurance industry could result in a decline in revenues from that industry and have a material adverse effect on our financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P9_S0	Our revenue from customers in the mortgage vertical is largely transactional and subject to changing conditions of the U.S. mortgage market.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Revenue derived from solutions we provide the U.S. mortgage and mortgage-related industries accounted for approximately 13% of our total revenue in the year ended December 31, 2010.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P10_S1	Our forensic audit business and business with government-sponsored entities in the mortgage business accounted for approximately 65% of our total mortgage and mortgage-related revenue in 2010.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P10_S2	Because our business relies on transaction volumes based on both new mortgage applications and forensic audit of funded loans, reductions in either the volume of mortgage loans originated or the number or quality of funded loans could reduce our revenue.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P11_S0	Mortgage origination volumes in 2010 declined versus 2009 and may continue to decline based on the changes in the mortgage market related to the U.S. mortgage crisis.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Recently there have been proposals to restructure or eliminate the roles of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P12_S1	The restructuring or elimination of either Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac could have a negative effect on the U. S. mortgage market and on our revenue derived from the solutions we provide to the mortgage industry.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P12_S2	If origination volumes and applications for mortgages decline, our revenue in this part of the business may decline if we are unable to increase the percentage of mortgages examined for existing customers or add new customers.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P12_S3	Our forensic audit business has benefited from the high amount of bad loans to be examined by mortgage insurers and other parties as a result of the U.S. mortgage crisis.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Two customers represent the majority of our mortgage revenue in 2010 and if their volumes decline and we are not able to replace them with new customers, our revenue may decline.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P14_S0	There may be consolidation in our end customer market, which would reduce the use of our services.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P15_S0	Mergers or consolidations among our customers could reduce the number of our customers and potential customers.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P15_S1	This could adversely affect our revenues even if these events do not reduce the aggregate number of customers or the activities of the consolidated entities.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P15_S2	If our customers merge with or are acquired by other entities that are not our customers, or that use fewer of our services, they may discontinue or reduce their use of our services.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P15_S3	The adverse effects of consolidation will be greater in sectors that we are particularly dependent upon, for example, in the P C insurance services sector.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P15_S4	Any of these developments could materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition, operating results and cash flows.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P16_S0	If we are unable to develop successful new solutions or if we experience defects, failures and delays associated with the introduction of new solutions, our business could suffer serious harm.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P17_S0	Our growth and success depends upon our ability to develop and sell new solutions.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P18_S0	In addition, significant undetected errors or delays in new solutions may affect market acceptance of our solutions and could harm our business, financial condition or results of operations.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P19_S0	In the past, we have experienced delays while developing and introducing new solutions, primarily due to difficulties in developing models, acquiring data and adapting to particular operating environments.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P19_S1	Errors or defects in our solutions that are significant, or are perceived to be significant, could result in rejection of our solutions, damage to our reputation, loss of revenues, diversion of development resources, an increase in product liability claims, and increases in service and support costs and warranty claims.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P20_S0	We will continue to rely upon proprietary technology rights, and if we are unable to protect them, our business could be harmed.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Our success depends, in part, upon our intellectual property rights.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P21_S1	To date, we have relied primarily on a combination of copyright, patent, trade secret, and trademark laws and nondisclosure and other contractual restrictions on copying and distribution to protect our proprietary technology.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P21_S2	This protection of our proprietary technology is limited, and our proprietary technology could be used by others without our consent.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P21_S3	In addition, patents may not be issued with respect to our pending or future patent applications, and our patents may not be upheld as valid or may not prevent the development of competitive products.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P21_S4	Any disclosure, loss, invalidity of, or failure to protect our intellectual property could negatively impact our competitive position, and ultimately, our business.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P21_S5	Our protection of our intellectual property rights in the United States or abroad may not be adequate and others, including our competitors, may use our proprietary technology without our consent.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P21_S6	Furthermore, litigation may be necessary to enforce our intellectual property rights, to protect our trade secrets, or to determine the validity and scope of the proprietary rights of others.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P21_S7	Such litigation could result in substantial costs and diversion of resources and could harm our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P22_S0	We could face claims for intellectual property infringement, which if successful could restrict us from using and providing our technologies and solutions to our customers.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P23_S0	There has been substantial litigation and other proceedings, particularly in the United States, regarding patent and other intellectual property rights in the information technology industry.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P23_S1	There is a risk that we are infringing, or may in the future infringe, the intellectual property rights of third parties.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P23_S2	We monitor third-party patents and patent applications that may be relevant to our technologies and solutions and we carry out freedom to operate analysis where we deem appropriate.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P23_S3	However, such monitoring and analysis has not been, and is unlikely in the future to be, comprehensive, and it may not be possible to detect all potentially relevant patents and patent applications.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P23_S4	Since the patent application process can take several years to complete, there may be currently pending applications, unknown to us, that may later result in issued patents that cover our products and technologies.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P23_S5	As a result, we may infringe existing and future third-party patents of which we are not aware.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P23_S6	As we expand our operations there is a higher risk that such activity could infringe the intellectual property rights of third parties.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P24_S0	Third-party intellectual property infringement claims and any resultant litigation against us or our technology partners or providers, could subject us to liability for damages, restrict us from using and providing our technologies and solutions or operating our business generally, or require changes to be made to our technologies and solutions.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P24_S1	Even if we prevail, litigation is time consuming and expensive to defend and would result in the diversion of management s time and attention.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P25_S0	If a successful claim of infringement is brought against us and we fail to develop non-infringing technologies and solutions or to obtain licenses on a timely and cost effective basis this could materially and adversely affect our business, reputation, financial condition, operating results and cash flows.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P26_S0	Regulatory developments could negatively impact our business.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P27_S0	Because personal, public and non-public information is stored in some of our databases, we are vulnerable to government regulation and adverse publicity concerning the use of our data.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P28_S0	European Union s Data Protection Directive and to a lesser extent, various other federal, state, and local laws and regulations.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P28_S1	These laws and regulations are designed to protect the privacy of the public and to prevent the misuse of personal information in the marketplace.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P28_S2	However, many consumer advocates, privacy advocates, and government regulators believe that the existing laws and regulations do not adequately protect privacy.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P28_S3	They have become increasingly concerned with the use of personal information, particularly social security numbers, department of motor vehicle data and dates of birth.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P28_S4	As a result, they are lobbying for further restrictions on the dissemination or commercial use of personal information to the public and private sectors.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P28_S5	Similar initiatives are under way in other countries in which we do business or from which we source data.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P28_S6	The following legal and regulatory developments also could have a material adverse affect on our business, financial position, results of operations or cash flows:
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P29_S0	failure of our solutions to adapt to changes in the regulatory environment in an efficient, cost-effective manner.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P30_S0	Fraudulent data access and other security breaches may negatively impact our business and harm our reputation.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P31_S0	Security breaches in our facilities, computer networks, and databases may cause harm to our business and reputation and result in a loss of customers.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P31_S1	Our systems may be vulnerable to physical break-ins, computer viruses, attacks by hackers and similar disruptive problems.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P31_S2	Third-party contractors also may experience security breaches involving the storage and transmission of proprietary information.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P31_S3	If users gain improper access to our databases, they may be able to steal, publish, delete or modify confidential third-party information that is stored or transmitted on our networks.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P32_S0	In addition, customers misuse of our information services could cause harm to our business and reputation and result in loss of customers.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P32_S1	Any such misappropriation and/or misuse of our information could result in us, among other things, being in breach of certain data protection and related legislation.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P33_S0	A security or privacy breach may affect us in the following ways:
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P34_S0	We may detect incidents in which consumer data has been fraudulently or improperly acquired.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P34_S1	The number of potentially affected consumers identified by any future incidents is obviously unknown.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P34_S2	Any such incident could materially and adversely affect our business, reputation, financial condition, operating results and cash flows.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P35_S0	We typically face a long selling cycle to secure new contracts that requires significant resource commitments, which result in a long lead time before we receive revenues from new relationships.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P36_S0	We typically face a long selling cycle to secure a new contract and there is generally a long preparation period in order to commence providing the services.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P36_S1	We typically incur significant business development expenses during the selling cycle and we may not succeed in winning a new customer s business, in which case we receive no revenues and may receive no reimbursement for such expenses.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P36_S2	Even if we succeed in developing a relationship with a potential new customer, we may not be successful in obtaining contractual commitments after the selling cycle or in maintaining contractual commitments after the implementation cycle, which may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P37_S0	We may lose key business assets, including loss of data center capacity or the interruption of telecommunications links, the internet, or power sources, which could significantly impede our ability to do business.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P38_S0	Our operations depend on our ability, as well as that of third-party service providers to whom we have outsourced several critical functions, to protect data centers and related technology against damage from hardware failure, fire, power loss, telecommunications failure, impacts of terrorism, breaches in security (such as the actions of computer hackers), natural disasters, or other disasters.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P38_S1	The on-line services we provide are dependent on links to telecommunications providers.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P38_S2	In addition, we generate a significant amount of our revenues through telesales centers and websites that we utilize in the acquisition of new customers, fulfillment of solutions and services and responding to customer inquiries.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P38_S3	We may not have sufficient redundant operations to cover a loss or failure in all of these areas in a timely manner.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P38_S4	Certain of our customer contracts provide that our on-line servers may not be unavailable for specified periods of time.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P38_S5	Any damage to our data centers, failure of our telecommunications links or inability to access these telesales centers or websites could cause interruptions in operations that materially adversely affect our ability to meet customers requirements, resulting in decreased revenue, operating income and earnings per share.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P39_S0	We are subject to competition in many of the markets in which we operate and we may not be able to compete effectively.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P40_S0	Some markets in which we operate or which we believe may provide growth opportunities for us are highly competitive, and are expected to remain highly competitive.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P40_S1	We compete on the basis of quality, customer service, product and service selection and price.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P40_S2	Our competitive position in various market segments depends upon the relative strength of competitors in the segment and the resources devoted to competing in that segment.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P40_S3	Due to their size, certain competitors may be able to allocate greater resources to a particular market segment than we can.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P40_S4	As a result, these competitors may be in a better position to anticipate and respond to changing customer preferences, emerging technologies and market trends.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P40_S5	In addition, new competitors and alliances may emerge to take market share away.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P40_S6	We may be unable to maintain our competitive position in our market segments, especially against larger competitors.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P40_S7	We may also invest further to upgrade our systems in order to compete.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P40_S8	If we fail to successfully compete, our business, financial position and results of operations may be adversely affected.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P41_S0	Acquisitions could result in operating difficulties, dilution and other harmful consequences.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P42_S0	Our long-term business strategy includes growth through acquisitions.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P42_S1	Future acquisitions may not be completed on acceptable terms and acquired assets, data or businesses may not be successfully integrated into our operations.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P42_S2	Any acquisitions or investments will be accompanied by the risks commonly encountered in acquisitions of businesses.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P42_S3	Such risks include, among other things:
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P43_S0	diluting the share value and voting power of existing stockholders.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P44_S0	The anticipated benefits of many of our acquisitions may not materialize.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P44_S1	Future acquisitions or dispositions could result in the incurrence of debt, contingent liabilities or amortization expenses, or write-offs of goodwill and other intangible assets, any of which could harm our financial condition.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P45_S0	We typically fund our acquisitions through our debt facilities.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P45_S1	Although we have capacity under our uncommitted facilities, lenders are not required to loan us any funds under such facilities.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P45_S2	Therefore, future acquisitions may require us to obtain additional financing, which may not be available on favorable terms or at all.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P46_S0	To the extent the availability of free or relatively inexpensive information increases, the demand for some of our solutions may decrease.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P47_S0	Public sources of free or relatively inexpensive information have become increasingly available recently, particularly through the internet, and this trend is expected to continue.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P47_S1	Governmental agencies in particular have increased the amount of information to which they provide free public access.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P47_S2	Public sources of free or relatively inexpensive information may reduce demand for our solutions.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P47_S3	To the extent that customers choose not to obtain solutions from us and instead rely on information obtained at little or no cost from these public sources, our business and results of operations may be adversely affected.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P48_S0	Our senior leadership team is critical to our continued success and the loss of such personnel could harm our business.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P49_S0	Our future success substantially depends on the continued service and performance of the members of our senior leadership team.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P49_S1	These personnel possess business and technical capabilities that are difficult to replace.
1442145_11_ITEM1A_P49_S2	Members of our senior management operating team have been with us for an average of almost twenty years.
