1442145_11_ITEM8_P194_S0	The following table reflects the Company s debt maturities:
1442145_11_ITEM8_P195_S0	Prior to the corporate reorganization on October 6, 2009, the Company followed ASC 480-10-S99-1, Presentation in Financial Statements of Preferred Redeemable Stock ( ASC 480-10-S99-1 ).
1442145_11_ITEM8_P195_S1	ASC 480-10-S99-1 required the Company to record ISO Class A common stock and vested stock options at full redemption value at each balance sheet date as the redemption of these securities was not solely within the control of the Company.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P195_S2	Subsequent changes to the redemption value of the securities was charged first to retained earnings; once retained earnings was depleted, then to additional paid-in-capital, and if additional paid-in-capital was also depleted, then to accumulated deficit.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P195_S3	Redemption value for the ISO Class A stock was determined quarterly on or about the final day of the quarter for purposes of the KSOP.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P196_S0	Prior to September 30, 2009, the valuation methodology was based on a variety of qualitative and quantitative factors including the nature of the business and history of the enterprise, the economic outlook in general and the condition of the specific industries in which the Company operates, the financial condition of the business, the Company s ability to generate free cash flow, and goodwill or other intangible asset value.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P196_S1	This determination of the fair market value employed both a comparable public company analysis, which examines the valuation multiples of companies deemed comparable, in whole or in part, to the Company, and a discounted cash flow analysis that determined a present value of the projected future cash flows of the business.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P197_S0	The Company regularly assessed the underlying assumptions used in the valuation methodologies.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P197_S1	As a result, the Company had utilized this quarterly fair value for all its ISO Class A redeemable common stock transactions, as required by terms of the KSOP and the Option Plan.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P197_S2	The fourth quarter 2008 valuation was finalized on December 31, 2008, which resulted in a fair value per share of $15.56.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P198_S0	second quarter 2009 was $17.78 per share and was used for all ISO Class A stock transactions for the three months ended September 30, 2009.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P198_S1	At September 30, 2009, the Company s fair value per share used was determined based on the subsequent observable IPO price of $22.00 on October 7, 2009.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P198_S2	The use of the IPO price rather than the valuation methodology described above was based on the short period of time between September 30, 2009 and the IPO date.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P199_S0	In connection with the corporate reorganization on October 6, 2009, the Company is no longer obligated to redeem ISO Class A shares and is therefore no longer required to record the ISO Class A stock and vested stock options at redemption value under ASC 480-10-S99-1.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P199_S1	The redemption value of the ISO Class A redeemable common stock and vested options at intrinsic value at October 6, 2009 and December 31, 2008 totaled $1,064,896 and $752,912, which includes $299,983 and $172,408, respectively, of aggregate intrinsic value of outstanding unexercised vested stock options.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P200_S0	The reversal of the redeemable common stock balance is first applied against accumulated deficit; once the accumulated deficit is depleted, then to additional paid-in-capital up to the amount equal to the additional paid-in-capital of the Company as if ASC 480-10-S99-1 was never required to be adopted.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P200_S1	Any remaining balance is credited to retained earnings.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P200_S2	The reversal of the redeemable common stock of $1,064,896 on October 6, 2009 resulted in the elimination of accumulated deficit of $440,584, an increase of $30 to Class A common stock at par value, an increase of $624,282 to additional paid-in-capital, and a reclassification of the ISO Class A unearned common stock KSOP shares balance of $1,305 to unearned KSOP contributions.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P200_S3	See Note 16 for further discussion.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P201_S0	During the years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008, 3,032,850 and 25,121,750 of ISO Class A shares were redeemed by the Company at a weighted average price of $16.18 and $17.28 per share, respectively.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P201_S1	Included in ISO Class A repurchased shares were $805 and $19,734 for shares primarily utilized to satisfy minimum tax withholdings on options exercised during the years ended December 31, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P202_S0	Additional information regarding the changes in redeemable common stock prior to the corporate reorganization effective October 6, 2009 is provided in the table below.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P203_S0	On November 18, 1996, the Company authorized 335,000,000 shares of ISO Class A redeemable common stock.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P203_S1	Effective with the corporate reorganization on October 6, 2009, the ISO Class A redeemable common stock and all Verisk Class B shares sold into the IPO were converted to Verisk Class A common stock on a one-for-one basis.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P203_S2	In addition, the Verisk Class A common stock authorized was increased to 1,200,000,000 shares.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P204_S0	The Verisk Class A common shares have rights to any dividend declared by the board of directors, subject to any preferential or other rights of any outstanding preferred stock, and voting rights to elect eight of the eleven members of the board of directors.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P204_S1	The eleventh seat on the board of directors is held by the CEO of the Company.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P205_S0	On November 18, 1996, the Company authorized 1,000,000,000 ISO Class B shares and issued 500,225,000 shares.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P206_S0	All Verisk Class B shares sold into the IPO were converted to Verisk Class A common stock on a one-for-one basis.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P206_S1	In addition, the Verisk Class B common stock authorized was reduced to 800,000,000 shares, sub-divided into 400,000,000 shares of Class B-1 and 400,000,000 of Class B-2.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P206_S2	Each share of Class B-1 common stock shall convert automatically, without any action by the stockholder, into one share of Verisk Class A common stock on April 6, 2011.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P206_S3	Each share of Class B-2 common stock shall convert automatically, without any action by the stockholder, into one share of Verisk Class A common stock on October 6, 2011.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P206_S4	The Class B shares have the same rights as Verisk Class A shares with respect to dividends and economic ownership, but have voting rights to elect three of the eleven directors.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P206_S5	The Company did not repurchase any Class B shares during the year ended December 31, 2009.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P206_S6	The Company repurchased 483,500 ISO Class B shares at an average price of $10.34 during the year ended December 31, 2008.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P207_S0	On October 6, 2009, the Company authorized 80,000,000 shares of preferred stock, par value $0.001 per shares, in connection with the reorganization.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P207_S1	The preferred shares have preferential rights over the Verisk Class A, Class B-1 and Class B-2 common shares with respect to dividends and net distribution upon liquidation.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P207_S2	The Company did not issue any preferred shares from the reorganization date through December 31, 2010.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P208_S0	As of December 31, 2010, the Company s treasury stock consisted of 7,111,202 Class A common stock, 186,102,482 Class B-1 common stock and 178,893,668 Class B-2 common stock.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P208_S1	The Company s Class B-1 and Class B-2 treasury stock will convert to Class A common stock consistent with the Class B-1 and Class B-2 common stock.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P209_S0	On April 29, 2010, the Company s board of directors authorized a $150,000 share repurchase program of the Company s common stock (the Repurchase Program ).
1442145_11_ITEM8_P209_S1	On October 19, 2010, the Company s board of directors authorized an additional $150,000 of share repurchases under the Repurchase Program.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P209_S2	Under the Repurchase Program, the Company may repurchase stock in the open market or as otherwise determined by the Company.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P209_S3	The Company has no obligation to repurchase stock under this program and intends to use this authorization as a means of offsetting dilution from the issuance of shares under the KSOP, the Verisk Analytics, Inc. 2009 Equity Incentive Plan (the Incentive Plan ) and the Insurance Services Office, Inc. 1996 Incentive Plan (the Option Plan ).
1442145_11_ITEM8_P209_S4	This authorization has no expiration date and may be suspended or terminated at any time.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P209_S5	Repurchased shares will be recorded as treasury stock and will be available for future issuance as part of the Repurchase Program.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P210_S0	During the year ended December 31, 2010, 7,111,202 shares of Verisk Class A common stock were repurchased by the Company as part of this program at a weighted average price of $29.88 per share.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P210_S1	The Company utilized borrowings from its syndicated revolving credit facility to fund these repurchases.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P210_S2	As treasury stock purchases are recorded based on trade date, the Company has included $2,266 in Accounts payable and accrued liabilities in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets for those purchases that have not settled as of December 31, 2010.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P210_S3	The Company had $87,488 available to repurchase shares under the Repurchase Program as of December 31, 2010.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P211_S0	The Company repurchased 7,583,532 and 374,718 Verisk Class B-1 and Class B-2 shares, respectively, at an average price of $26.3644 during the year ended December 31, 2010.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P211_S1	These repurchases were separately authorized and did not affect the availability under the Repurchase Program.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P212_S0	As disclosed in Note 1 Organization on October 6, 2009 Verisk became the new parent holding company for ISO.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P213_S0	As a result of the stock split, all share and per share data throughout this report has been adjusted to reflect a fifty-for-one stock split.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P214_S0	Basic earnings per common share is computed by dividing income available to common stockholders by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding during the period less the weighted average Employee Stock Ownership Plan ( ESOP ) shares of common stock that have not been committed to be released.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P214_S1	The computation of diluted EPS is similar to the computation of basic EPS except that the denominator is increased to include the number of additional common shares that would have been outstanding, using the treasury stock method, if the dilutive potential common shares, such as stock awards and stock options, had been issued.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P215_S0	The following is a reconciliation of the numerators and denominators of the basic and diluted EPS computations for the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008:
1442145_11_ITEM8_P216_S0	The potential shares of common stock that were excluded from diluted EPS were 2,095,140, 9,054,022 and 5,091,350 for the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively, because the effect of including these potential shares was antidilutive.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P217_S0	The following is a summary of accumulated other comprehensive loss:
1442145_11_ITEM8_P218_S0	The before tax and after tax amounts for these categories, and the related tax benefit/(expense) included in other comprehensive gain/(loss) are summarized below:
1442145_11_ITEM8_P219_S0	The Company has established the KSOP for the benefit of eligible employees in the U.S. and Puerto Rico.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P219_S1	The KSOP includes both an employee savings component and an employee stock ownership component.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P219_S2	The purpose of the combined plan is to enable the Company s employees to participate in a tax-deferred savings arrangement under Code Sections 401(a) and 401(k), and to provide employee equity participation in the Company through the ESOP accounts.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P220_S0	Under the KSOP, eligible employees may make pre-tax and after-tax cash contributions as a percentage of their compensation, subject to certain limitations under the applicable provisions of the Code.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P220_S1	The maximum pre-tax contribution that can be made to the 401(k) account as determined under the provisions of Code Section 401(g) is $17, $17 and $16 for 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P220_S2	Certain eligible participants (age 50 and older) may contribute an additional $6, $6 and $5 on a pre-tax basis for 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P220_S3	After-tax contributions are limited to 10% of a participant s compensation.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P220_S4	The Company provides quarterly matching contributions in Class A common stock.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P220_S5	The quarterly matching contributions are equal to 75% of the first 6% of the participant s contribution.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P221_S0	The Company established the ESOP component as a funding vehicle for the KSOP.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P221_S1	This leveraged ESOP acquired 57,190,000 shares of the Company s Class A common stock at a cost of approximately $33,170 ($0.58 per share) in January 1997.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P221_S2	The ESOP borrowed $33,170 from an unrelated third party to finance the purchase of the KSOP shares.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P221_S3	The common shares were pledged as collateral for its debt.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P221_S4	The Company made annual cash contributions to the KSOP equal to the ESOP s debt service.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P221_S5	As the debt was repaid, shares were released from collateral and were allocated to active employees in proportion to their annual salaries in relation to total participant salaries.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P222_S0	from Equity ( ASC 480-10 ).
1442145_11_ITEM8_P222_S1	As shares were committed to be released from collateral, the Company reported compensation expense at the then-current fair value of the shares, and the shares became outstanding for EPS computations.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P223_S0	In 2004, the Company renegotiated the ESOP loan to require interest only payments for the third and fourth quarters of 2004.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P223_S1	In December 2004, the Company repaid the ESOP loan and issued a new loan agreement between the Company and the KSOP, thereby extending the allocation of the remaining unreleased shares as of July 1, 2004 through 2013.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P224_S0	On October 6, 2009, the Company accelerated the release of 2,623,600 shares to the ESOP account.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P224_S1	This resulted in a non-recurring non-cash charge of $57,720 in October 2009, which will primarily be non-deductible for tax purposes.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P225_S0	Effective with the IPO, the KSOP trustee sold 5,000,000 shares of Verisk Class A common stock, of which 2,754,600 shares were released-unallocated shares and 2,245,400 were unreleased shares pledged as collateral against the intercompany ESOP loan.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P225_S1	The sale of the released-unallocated shares resulted in cash proceeds to the KSOP of $58,177.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P225_S2	The sale of the unreleased shares resulted in cash proceeds to the KSOP of $47,423, all of which is pledged as collateral against the intercompany ESOP loan.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P225_S3	The cash proceeds received by the KSOP can be used to repurchase shares diversified or distributed by KSOP participants subsequent to the IPO.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P225_S4	All shares repurchased during this period will be repurchased first from the cash proceeds from the sale of the released-unallocated shares; once these proceeds are depleted and replaced with shares of Verisk Class A common stock, then all further share diversifications or distributions will be repurchased from the proceeds received from the sale of the unreleased shares.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P226_S0	In accordance with ASC 718-40, the balance of the Class A common stock unearned KSOP shares was reclassified from redeemable common stock to Unearned KSOP contributions , a contra-equity account within the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P227_S0	As the intercompany ESOP loan is repaid, a percentage of the ESOP loan collateral will be released and allocated to active participants in proportion to their annual salaries in relation to total participant salaries.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P227_S1	As of December 31, 2010, the intercompany ESOP loan collateral consisted of cash equivalents totaling $669 and 1,242,481 shares of Verisk Class A common stock valued at $42,344.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P227_S2	As of December 31, 2010, the Company had 20,237,069 and 47,355 allocated and released-unallocated ESOP shares, respectively.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P228_S0	In 2005, the Company established the ISO Profit Sharing Plan (the Profit Sharing Plan ), a defined contribution plan, to replace the pension plan for all eligible employees hired on or after March 1, 2005.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P228_S1	The Profit Sharing Plan is a component of the KSOP.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P228_S2	Eligible employees will participate in the Profit Sharing Plan if they complete 1,000 hours of service each plan year and are employed on December 31 of that year.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P228_S3	The Company will make an annual contribution to the Profit Sharing Plan based on the Company s performance.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P228_S4	Participants vest once they have completed four years and 1,000 hours of service.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P228_S5	For all periods presented, the profit sharing contribution was funded using Class A common stock.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P229_S0	Prior to the IPO, the fair value of the Class A shares was determined quarterly as determined for purposes of the KSOP.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P229_S1	At December 31, 2010 and 2009, the fair value was $34.08 and $30.28 per share, respectively.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P229_S2	KSOP compensation expense for 2010, 2009 and 2008 was approximately $11,573, $76,065 and $22,274, respectively.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P230_S0	All of the Company s outstanding stock options are covered under the Incentive Plan or the Option Plan.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P230_S1	Awards under the Incentive Plan may include one or more of the following types: (i) stock options (both nonqualified and incentive stock options), (ii) stock appreciation rights, (iii) restricted stock, (iv) restricted stock units, (v) performance awards, (vi) other share-based awards, and (vii) cash.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P230_S2	Employees, directors and consultants are eligible for awards under the Incentive Plan.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P230_S3	Cash received from stock option exercises for the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008 was $35,482, $7,709 and $892, respectively.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P231_S0	to key employees with an exercise price equal to the closing price of the Company s Class A common stock on March 31, 2010 and May 28, 2010, with a ten-year contractual term and a service vesting period of four years.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P231_S1	On July 1, 2010, the Company granted 31,906 nonqualified stock options that were immediately vested, 138,120 nonqualified stock options with a one-year service vesting period and 4,554 shares of Class A common stock, to the directors of the Company.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P231_S2	The stock options have an exercise price equal to the closing price of the Company s Class A common stock on the grant date and a ten-year contractual term.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P231_S3	As of December 31, 2010, there are 8,683,159 shares of Class A common stock reserved and available for future issuance.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P232_S0	The fair value of the stock options granted during the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008 were estimated on the date of grant using a Black-Scholes option valuation model that uses the weighted-average assumptions noted in the following table.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P233_S0	The expected term for a majority of the awards granted was estimated based on studies of historical experience and projected exercise behavior.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P233_S1	However, for certain awards granted, for which no historical exercise pattern exist, the expected term was estimated using the simplified method.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P234_S0	The risk-free interest rate is based on the yield of U.S. Treasury zero coupon securities with a maturity equal to the expected term of the equity award.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P234_S1	The volatility factor was based on the average volatility of the Company s peers, calculated using historical daily closing prices over the most recent period that commensurates with the expected term of the stock option award.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P234_S2	The expected dividend yield was based on the Company s expected annual dividend rate on the date of grant.

1442145_11_ITEM8_P238_S0	Intrinsic value for stock options is calculated based on the exercise price of the underlying awards and the quoted price of Verisk s common stock as of the reporting date.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P238_S1	The aggregate intrinsic value of stock options outstanding and exercisable at December 31, 2010 was $478,014 and $368,466, respectively.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P239_S0	In accordance with ASC 718, excess tax benefit from exercised stock options is recorded as an increase to additional-paid-in capital and a corresponding reduction in taxes payable.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P239_S1	This tax benefit is calculated as the excess of the intrinsic value of options exercised in excess of compensation recognized for financial reporting purposes.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P239_S2	The amount of the tax benefit that has been realized, as a result of those excess tax benefits, is presented in the statement of cash flows as a financing cash inflow.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P240_S0	For the year ended December 31, 2010, certain employees exercised stock options and covered the statutory minimum tax withholdings of $15,051 through a net settlement of 503,043 shares.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P240_S1	The payment of taxes related to these exercises were recorded as a reduction to additional-paid-in capital.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P240_S2	This transaction is reflected within Net share settlement of taxes upon exercise of stock options within cash flows from financing activities in the accompanying consolidated statements of cash flows.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P241_S0	The Company estimates expected forfeitures of equity awards at the date of grant and recognizes compensation expense only for those awards that the Company expects to vest.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P241_S1	The forfeiture assumption is ultimately adjusted to the actual forfeiture rate.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P241_S2	Changes in the forfeiture assumptions may impact the total amount of expense ultimately recognized over the requisite service period and may impact the timing of expense recognized over the requisite service period.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P242_S0	Stock-based compensation expense for 2010, 2009 and 2008 was $21,298, $12,744 and $9,881, respectively.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P243_S0	As of December 31, 2010, there was $39,920 of total unrecognized compensation cost related to nonvested share-based compensation arrangements granted under the Incentive Plan and the Option Plan.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P243_S1	That cost is expected to be recognized over a weighted-average period of 3.0 years.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P244_S0	As of December 31, 2010, there were 8,237,410 nonvested stock options, of which 7,094,840 are expected to vest.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P244_S1	The total grant date fair value of options vested during the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008 was $17,677, $9,918 and $11,803, respectively.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P245_S0	Prior to January 1, 2002, the Company maintained a qualified defined benefit pension plan for substantially all of its employees through membership in the Pension Plan for Insurance Organizations (the Pension Plan ), a multiple-employer trust.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P245_S1	The Company has applied the projected unit credit cost method for its pension plan, which attributes an equal portion of total projected benefits to each year of employee service.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P245_S2	Effective January 1, 2002, the Company amended the Pension Plan to determine future benefits using a cash balance formula.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P245_S3	Under the cash balance formula, each participant has an account, which is credited annually based on salary rates determined by years of service, as well as the interest earned on their previous year-end cash balance.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P246_S0	Prior to December 31, 2001, pension plan benefits were based on years of service and the average of the five highest consecutive years earnings of the last ten years.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P247_S0	Effective March 1, 2005, the Company established the Profit Sharing Plan, a defined contribution plan, to replace the Pension Plan for all eligible employees hired on or after March 1, 2005.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P247_S1	The Company also has a non-qualified supplemental cash balance plan ( SERP ) for certain employees.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P247_S2	The SERP is funded from the general assets of the Company.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P248_S0	The Pension Plan s funding policy is to contribute annually at an amount between the minimum funding requirements set forth in the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 and the maximum amount that can be deducted for federal income tax purposes.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P248_S1	The Company contributed $313, $292 and $542 to the SERP in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively, and expects to contribute $533 in 2011.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P248_S2	The minimum required funding for the Pension Plan for the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008 was $20,444, $5,471 and $5,029, respectively.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P248_S3	The Company expects to contribute $25,312 to the Pension Plan in 2011.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P249_S0	forecast adjusted based on the its target investment allocation, and the current economic environment.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P249_S1	The Company s investment guidelines target investment allocation of 60% equity securities and 40% debt securities.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P249_S2	The Pension Plan assets consist primarily of investments in various fixed income and equity funds.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P249_S3	Investment guidelines are established with each investment manager.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P249_S4	These guidelines provide the parameters within which the investment managers agree to operate, including criteria that determine eligible and ineligible securities, diversification requirements and credit quality standards, where applicable.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P249_S5	Investment managers are prohibited from entering into any speculative hedging transactions.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P250_S0	The investment objective is to achieve a maximum total return with strong emphasis on preservation of capital in real terms.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P250_S1	The domestic equity portion of the total portfolio should range between 40% and 60%.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P250_S2	The international equity portion of the total portfolio should range between 10% and 20%.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P250_S3	The fixed income portion of the total portfolio should range between 20% and 40%.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P250_S4	The asset allocation at December 31, 2010 and 2009, and target allocation for 2011 by asset category are as follows:
1442145_11_ITEM8_P251_S0	The Company has used the target investment allocation to derive the expected return as the Company believes this allocation will be retained on an ongoing basis that will commensurate with the projected cash flows of the plan.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P252_S0	The expected return for each investment category within the target investment allocation is developed using average historical rates of return for each targeted investment category, considering the projected cash flow of the pension plan.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P252_S1	The difference between this expected return and the actual return on plan assets is generally deferred and recognized over subsequent periods through future net periodic benefit costs.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P252_S2	The Company believes that the use of the average historical rates of returns is consistent with the timing and amounts of expected contributions to the plans and benefit payments to plan participants.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P252_S3	The Company believes that these considerations provide the basis for reasonable assumptions with respect to the expected long-term rate of return on plan assets.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P253_S0	The Company also provides certain healthcare and life insurance benefits for both active and retired employees.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P253_S1	The Postretirement Health and Life Insurance Plan (the Postretirement Plan ) is contributory, requiring participants to pay a stated percentage of the premium for coverage.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P253_S2	As of October 1, 2001, the Postretirement Plan was amended to freeze benefits for current retirees and certain other employees at the January 1, 2002 level.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P253_S3	Also, as of October 1, 2001, the Postretirement Plan had a curtailment, which eliminated retiree life insurance for all active employees and healthcare benefits for almost all future retirees, effective January 1, 2002.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P253_S4	The Company expects to contribute $4,227 to the Postretirement Plan in 2011.

1442145_11_ITEM8_P262_S0	The following table summarizes the fair value measurements by level of the Pension Plan assets at December 31, 2010:
1442145_11_ITEM8_P263_S0	Valued at the closing price of shares for domestic stocks within the managed equity accounts, and valued at the net asset value ( NAV ) of shares for mutual funds at either the closing price reported in the active market or based on yields currently available on comparable securities of issuers with similar credit ratings for corporate bonds held by the Plan in these managed accounts.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P264_S0	The pooled separate accounts invest in domestic and foreign stocks, bonds and mutual funds.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P264_S1	The fair values of these stocks, bonds and mutual funds are publicly quoted and are used in determining the NAV of the pooled separate account, which is not publicly quoted.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P265_S0	Within managed equity accounts, when quoted prices are not available for identical or similar bonds, the bond is valued under a discounted cash flows approach that maximizes observable inputs, such as current yields of similar instruments, but includes adjustments for certain risks that may not be observable, such as credit and liquidity risks.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P266_S0	Investments for which readily determinable prices do not exist are valued by the General Partner using either the market or income approach.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P267_S0	the underlying portfolio company, nature of investment, restrictions on marketability, holding period, market conditions, foreign currency exposures, and other factors the General Partner deems appropriate.

1442145_11_ITEM8_P269_S0	ASC 280-10, Disclosures About Segments of an Enterprise and Related Information ( ASC 280-10 ), establishes standards for reporting information about operating segments.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P269_S1	ASC 280-10 requires that a public business enterprise report financial and descriptive information about its reportable operating segments.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P270_S0	Operating segments are components of an enterprise for which separate financial information is available that is evaluated regularly by the chief operating decision maker ( CODM ) in deciding how to allocate resources and in assessing performance.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P270_S1	The Company s CEO and Chairman of the Board is identified as the CODM as defined by ASC 280-10.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P270_S2	To align with the internal management of the Company s business operations based on service offerings, the Company is organized into the following two operating segments, which are also the Company s reportable segments:
1442145_11_ITEM8_P271_S0	Risk Assessment: The Company is the leading provider of statistical, actuarial and underwriting data for the U.S. P C insurance industry.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P271_S1	The Company s databases include cleansed and standardized records describing premiums and losses in insurance transactions, casualty and property risk attributes for commercial buildings and their occupants and fire suppression capabilities of municipalities.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P271_S2	The Company uses this data to create policy language and proprietary risk classifications that are industry standards and to generate prospective loss cost estimates used to price insurance policies.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P272_S0	Decision Analytics: The Company develops solutions that its customers use to analyze the three key processes in managing risk: loss prediction, fraud identification and detection and loss quantification.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P272_S1	The Company s combination of algorithms and analytic methods incorporates its proprietary data to generate solutions in each of these three categories.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P272_S2	In most cases, the Company s customers integrate the solutions into their models, formulas or underwriting criteria in order to predict potential loss events, ranging from hurricanes and earthquakes to unanticipated healthcare claims.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P273_S0	The Company develops catastrophe and extreme event models and offers solutions covering natural and man-made risks, including acts of terrorism.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P273_S1	The Company also develops solutions that allow customers to quantify costs after loss events occur.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P273_S2	Fraud solutions include data on claim histories, analysis of mortgage applications to identify misinformation, analysis of claims to find emerging patterns of fraud, and identification of suspicious claims in the insurance, mortgage and healthcare sectors.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P274_S0	The two aforementioned operating segments represent the segments for which separate discrete financial information is available and upon which operating results are regularly evaluated by the CODM in order to assess performance and allocate resources.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P274_S1	The Company uses segment EBITDA as the profitability measure for making decisions regarding ongoing operations.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P275_S0	Segment EBITDA is the measure of operating results used to assess corporate performance and optimal utilization of debt and acquisitions.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P275_S1	Segment operating expenses consist of direct and indirect costs principally related to personnel, facilities, software license fees, consulting, travel, and third-party information services.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P275_S2	Indirect costs are generally allocated to the segments using fixed rates established by management based upon estimated expense contribution levels and other assumptions that management considers reasonable.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P275_S3	The Company does not allocate investment income, realized gains/(losses) on securities, net, interest expense, or income tax expense, since these items are not considered in evaluating the segment s overall operating performance.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P275_S4	The CODM does not evaluate the financial performance of each segment based on assets.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P276_S0	On a geographic basis, no individual country outside of the U.S. accounted for 1% or more of the Company s consolidated revenue for any of the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 or 2008.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P276_S1	No individual country outside of the U.S. accounted for 1% or more of total consolidated long-term assets as of December 31, 2010 or 2009.

1442145_11_ITEM8_P279_S0	The Company considers its Verisk Class A and Class B stockholders that own more than 5% of the outstanding stock within the respective class to be related parties as defined within ASC 850, Related Party Disclosures .
1442145_11_ITEM8_P279_S1	At December 31, 2010, the related parties were four Class B stockholders each owning more than 5% of the outstanding Class B shares compared to six Class B stockholders at December 31, 2009.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P279_S2	At December 31, 2010, there were four Class A stockholders owning more than 5% of the outstanding Class A shares.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P279_S3	The Company s related parties had accounts receivable, net of $515 and $1,353 and fees received in advance of $1,231 and $439 as of December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P279_S4	In addition, the Company had revenues from related parties for the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008 of $49,788, $60,192 and $90,227, respectively.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P280_S0	The Company incurred expenses associated with the payment of insurance coverage premiums to certain of the related parties aggregating $41, $138 and $992 for the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P280_S1	These costs are included in Cost of revenues and Selling, general and administrative expenses in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P281_S0	The Company s operations are conducted on leased premises.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P281_S1	Approximate minimum rentals under long-term noncancelable leases for all leased premises, computer equipment and automobiles are as follows:
1442145_11_ITEM8_P282_S0	Most of the leases require payment of property taxes and utilities and, in certain cases, contain renewal options.

1442145_11_ITEM8_P283_S1	Capital leases consist of computer equipment, office equipment, and leased automobiles.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P283_S2	Rent expense on operating leases approximated $23,898, $22,985 and $21,261 in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P284_S0	In addition, the Company is a party to legal proceedings with respect to a variety of matters in the ordinary course of business, including those matters described below.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P284_S1	The Company is unable, at the present time, to determine the ultimate resolution of or provide a reasonable estimate of the range of possible loss attributable to these matters or the impact they may have on the Company s results of operations, financial position or cash flows.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P284_S2	This is primarily because many of these cases remain in their early stages and only limited discovery has taken place.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P284_S3	Although the Company believes it has strong defenses for the litigation proceedings described below, the Company could in the future incur judgments or enter into settlements of claims that could have a material adverse effect on its results of operations, financial position or cash flows.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P285_S0	Hensley, et al. v. Computer Sciences Corporation et al. was a putative nationwide class action complaint, filed in February 2005, in Miller County, Arkansas state court.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P285_S1	Defendants include numerous insurance companies and providers of software products used by insurers in paying claims.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P285_S2	The Company is among the named defendants.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P285_S3	Plaintiffs allege that certain software products, including the Company s Claims Outcome Advisor product and a competing software product sold by Computer Sciences Corporation, improperly estimated the amount to be paid by insurers to their policyholders in connection with claims for bodily injuries.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P286_S0	The Company entered into settlement agreements with plaintiffs asserting claims relating to the use of Claims Outcome Advisor by defendants Hanover Insurance Group, Progressive Car Insurance and Liberty Mutual Insurance Group.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P286_S1	Each of these settlements was granted final approval by the court and together the settlements resolve the claims asserted in this case against the Company with respect to the above insurance companies, who settled the claims against them as well.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P286_S2	A provision was made in 2006 for this proceeding and the total amount the Company paid in 2008 with respect to these settlements was less than $2,000.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P286_S3	A fourth defendant, The Automobile Club of California, which is alleged to have used Claims Outcome Advisor, was dismissed from the action.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P287_S0	On August 18, 2008, pursuant to the agreement of the parties the Court ordered that the claims against the Company be dismissed with prejudice.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P288_S0	Subsequently, Hanover Insurance Group made a demand for reimbursement, pursuant to an indemnification provision contained in a December 30, 2004 License Agreement between Hanover and the Company, of its settlement and defense costs in the Hensley class action.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P288_S1	Specifically, Hanover demanded $2,536 including $600 in attorneys fees and expenses.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P288_S2	The Company disputes that Hanover is entitled to any reimbursement pursuant to the License Agreement.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P288_S3	In July 2010, after the Company and Hanover were unable to resolve the dispute in mediation, Hanover served a summons and complaint seeking indemnity and contribution from the Company.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P288_S4	At this time, it is not possible to determine the ultimate resolution of or estimate the liability related to this matter.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P289_S0	The following two lawsuits have been filed by or on behalf of groups of Louisiana insurance policyholders who claim, among other things, that certain insurers who used products and price information supplied by the Company s Xactware subsidiary (and those of another provider) did not fully compensate policyholders for property damage covered under their insurance policies.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P289_S1	The plaintiffs seek to recover compensation for their damages in an amount equal to the difference between the amount paid by the defendants and the fair market repair/restoration costs of their damaged property.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P290_S0	Schafer v. State Farm Fire Cas. Co. , et al. was a putative class action pending against the Company and State Farm Fire Casualty Company filed in March 2007 in the Eastern District of Louisiana.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P290_S1	The complaint alleged antitrust violations, breach of contract, negligence, bad faith, and fraud.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P290_S2	The court dismissed the antitrust claim as to both defendants and dismissed all claims against the Company other than fraud, which will proceed to the discovery phase along with the remaining claims against State Farm.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P290_S3	Judge Duval denied plaintiffs motion to certify a class with respect to the fraud and breach of contract claims on August 3, 2009 and the time to appeal that decision has expired.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P290_S4	The matter, now a single action, was reassigned to Judge Africk.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P290_S5	Plaintiffs agreed to settle the matter with the Company and State Farm and a Settlement Agreement and Release was executed by all parties in June 2010.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P291_S0	Mornay v. Travelers Ins. Co. , et al. is a putative class action pending against the Company and Travelers Insurance Company filed in November 2007 in the Eastern District of Louisiana.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P291_S1	The complaint alleged antitrust violations, breach of contract, negligence, bad faith, and fraud.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P291_S2	As in Schafer, the court dismissed the antitrust claim as to both defendants and dismissed all claims against the Company other than fraud.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P291_S3	Judge Duval stayed all proceedings in the case pending an appraisal of the lead plaintiff s insurance claim.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P291_S4	The matter has been re-assigned to Judge Barbier, who on September 11, 2009 issued an order administratively closing the matter pending completion of the appraisal process.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P291_S5	At this time, it is not possible to determine the ultimate resolution of or estimate the liability related to this matter.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P292_S0	In March 2007, the Company s subsidiary, Insurance Information Exchange, or iiX, as well as other information providers and insurers in the State of Texas, were served with a summons and class action complaint filed in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Texas alleging violations of the Driver Privacy Protection Act, or the DPPA, entitled Sharon Taylor, et al. v. Acxiom Corporation, et al .
1442145_11_ITEM8_P292_S1	Plaintiffs brought the action on their own behalf and on behalf of all similarly situated individuals whose personal information is contained in any motor vehicle record maintained by the State of Texas and who have not provided express consent to the State of Texas for the distribution of their personal information for purposes not enumerated by the DPPA and whose personal information has been knowingly obtained and used by the defendants.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P292_S2	The class complaint alleges that the defendants knowingly obtained personal information for a purpose not authorized by the DPPA and seeks liquidated damages in the amount of two thousand five hundred dollars for each instance of a violation of the DPPA, punitive damages and the destruction of any illegally obtained personal information.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P292_S3	The Court granted iiX s motion to dismiss the complaint based on failure to state a claim and for lack of standing.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P292_S4	Oral arguments on the plaintiffs appeal of that dismissal were held on November 4, 2009.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P293_S0	Court s dismissal of the complaint on July 14, 2010.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P293_S1	Plaintiffs filed a petition for a Writ of Certiorari with the United States Supreme Court on October 12, 2010, which was denied on January 10, 2011.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P294_S0	Similarly, in April 2010, the Company s subsidiary, iiX, as well as other information providers in the State of Missouri were served with a summons and class action complaint filed in the United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri alleging violations of the Driver Privacy Protection Act, or the DPPA, entitled Janice Cook, et al. v. ACS State Local Solutions, et al.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P294_S1	Plaintiffs brought the action on their own behalf and on behalf of all similarly situated individuals whose personal information is contained in any motor vehicle record maintained by the State of Missouri and who have not provided express consent to the State of Missouri for the distribution of their personal information for purposes not enumerated by the DPPA and whose personal information has been knowingly obtained and used by the defendants.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P294_S2	The class complaint alleges that the defendants knowingly obtained personal information for a purpose not authorized by the DPPA and seeks liquidated damages in the amount of two thousand five hundred dollars for each instance of a violation of the DDPA, punitive damages and the destruction of any illegally obtained personal information.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P294_S3	The court granted iiX s motion to dismiss the complaint based on a failure to state a claim on November 19, 2010.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P295_S0	Plaintiffs filed a notice of appeal on December 17, 2010.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P296_S0	At this time, it is not possible to determine the ultimate resolution of or estimate the liability related to these matters.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P297_S0	In September 2009, the Company s subsidiary, Interthinx, Inc., was served with a putative class action entitled Renata Gluzman v. Interthinx, Inc.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P297_S1	The plaintiff, a former Interthinx employee, filed the class action on August 13, 2009 in the Superior Court of the State of California, County of Los Angeles on behalf of all Interthinx information technology employees for unpaid overtime and missed meals and rest breaks, as well as various related claims claiming that the information technology employees were misclassified as exempt employees and, as a result, were denied certain wages and benefits that would have been received if they were properly classified as non-exempt employees.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P297_S2	The pleadings include, among other things, a violation of Business and Professions Code 17200 for unfair business practices, which allows plaintiffs to include as class members all information technology employees employed at Interthinx for four years prior to the date of filing the complaint.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P297_S3	The complaint seeks compensatory damages, penalties that are associated with the various statutes, restitution, interest costs, and attorney fees.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P297_S4	On June 2, 2010, Plaintiffs agreed to settle their claims with Interthinx.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P297_S5	The court granted preliminary approval to the settlement on November 10, 2010 and scheduled the final approval hearing for February 23, 2011.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P298_S0	Primarily additional reserves for bad debts.
1442145_11_ITEM8_P299_S0	Primarily accounts receivable balances written off, net of recoveries, and the expiration of loss carryforwards.

1442145_11_ITEM8_P337_S0	the information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations of the Company.
1442145_11_ITEM9A_P0_S0	We are required to maintain disclosure controls and procedures (as that term is defined in Rules 13a-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the Exchange Act )) that are designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed in our reports under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized, and reported within the time periods specified in the Securities and Exchange Commission s rules and forms, and that such information is accumulated and communicated to our management, including our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, as appropriate, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosures.
1442145_11_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Any controls and procedures, no matter how well designed and operated, can provide only reasonable assurance of achieving the desired control objectives.
1442145_11_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Our management, with the participation of the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, has evaluated the effectiveness of the Company s disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e)) as of the end of the period covered by this annual report on Form 10-K. Based upon the foregoing assessments, our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer have concluded that, as of December 31, 2010, our disclosure controls and procedures were effective.

1442145_11_ITEM15_P0_S0	The following of documents are filed as part of this report.

1442145_12_ITEM1_P0_S0	Verisk Analytics is a leading provider of information about risk to professionals in insurance, healthcare, mortgage, government, supply chain, and risk management.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P0_S1	Using advanced technologies to collect and analyze billions of records, we draw on industry expertise and unique proprietary data sets to provide predictive analytics and decision-support solutions in fraud prevention, actuarial science, insurance coverages, fire protection, catastrophe and weather risk, data management, and many other fields.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P0_S2	In the United States and around the world, we help customers protect people, property, and financial assets.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P0_S3	Our customers use our solutions to make better risk decisions with greater efficiency and discipline.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P0_S4	We refer to these products and services as solutions due to the integration among our services and the flexibility that enables our customers to purchase components or the comprehensive package.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P0_S5	These solutions take various forms, including data, statistical models or tailored analytics, all designed to allow our clients to make more logical decisions.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P0_S6	We believe our solutions for analyzing risk positively impact our customers revenues and help them better manage their costs.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P1_S0	In 2011, our U.S. customers included all of the top 100 P C insurance providers, as well as numerous health plans and third party administrators, leading mortgage insurers, and mortgage lenders.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P1_S1	We believe that our commitment to our customers and the embedded nature of our solutions serve to strengthen and extend our relationships.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P2_S0	These four processes correspond to various functional areas inside our customers operations:
1442145_12_ITEM1_P3_S0	our tools to quantify loss are primarily used by claims departments, independent adjustors and contractors.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P3_S1	We add value by linking our solutions across these four key processes; for example, we use the same modeling methods to support the pricing of homeowner s insurance policies and to quantify the actual losses when damage occurs to insured homes.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P3_S2	We offer our solutions and services primarily through annual subscriptions or long-term agreements, which are typically pre-paid and represented approximately 69.0% of our revenues in 2011.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P3_S3	For the year ended December 31, 2011, we had revenues of $1,331.8 million and net income of $282.8 million.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P3_S4	For the five year period ended December 31, 2011, our revenues and net income grew at a CAGR of 13.5% and 17.1%, respectively.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P4_S0	Our History We trace our history to 1971, when Insurance Services Office, Inc., or ISO, started operations as a not-for-profit advisory and rating organization providing services for the U.S. P C insurance industry.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P4_S1	ISO was formed as an association of insurance companies to gather statistical data and other information from insurers and report to regulators, as required by law.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P4_S2	ISO s original functions also included developing programs to help insurers define and manage insurance products and providing information to help insurers determine their own independent premium rates.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P4_S3	Insurers used and continue to use our offerings primarily in their product development, underwriting and rating functions.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P4_S4	Today, those businesses form the core of our Risk Assessment segment.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P4_S5	Over the past decade, we have transformed our business beyond its original functions by deepening and broadening our data assets, developing a set of integrated risk management solutions and services and addressing new markets through our Decision Analytics segment.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P5_S0	Our expansion into analytics began when we acquired the American Insurance Services Group, or AISG, and certain operations and assets of the National Insurance Crime Bureau in 1997 and 1998, respectively.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P5_S1	Those organizations brought to the company large databases of insurance claims, as well as expertise in detecting and preventing claims fraud.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P6_S0	To further expand our Decision Analytics segment, we acquired AIR Worldwide, or AIR, in 2002, the technological leader in catastrophe modeling.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P7_S0	acquiring several businesses that now offer web-based analytical and reporting systems for health insurers, provider organizations and self-insured employers.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P7_S1	In 2005, we entered the mortgage sector, acquiring the first of several businesses that now provide automated fraud detection, compliance and decision support solutions for the U.S. mortgage industry.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P7_S2	In 2006, to bolster our position in the insurance claims field we acquired Xactware, a leading supplier of estimating software for professionals involved in building repair and reconstruction.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P7_S3	In 2010, we acquired 3E Company, creating a scale presence in supply chain and environmental health and safety.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P7_S4	In 2011, we further bolstered our healthcare solutions by acquiring Health Risk Partners, LLC, or HRP, which provides solutions to optimize revenue, which ensure compliance and improve quality of care for Medicare Advantage and Medicaid health plans, and Bloodhound Technologies, Inc., or Bloodhound, which provides real-time pre-adjudication medical claims editing.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P7_S5	These acquisitions have added scale, geographic reach, highly skilled workforces, and a wide array of new capabilities to our Decision Analytics segment.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P7_S6	They have helped to make us a leading provider of information and decision analytics for customers involved in the business of risk in the U.S. and selectively around the world.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P7_S7	Our senior management operating team, which includes our chief executive officer, chief financial officer, chief operating officer, general counsel, and three senior officers who lead our business units, have been with us for an average of over twenty years.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P7_S8	This team has led our transformation to a successful for-profit entity, focused on growth with our U.S. P C insurer customers and expansion into a variety of new markets.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P8_S0	On May 23, 2008, in contemplation of our initial public offering, or IPO, ISO formed Verisk Analytics, Inc., or Verisk, a Delaware corporation, to be the holding company for our business.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P8_S1	Verisk was initially formed as a wholly-owned subsidiary of ISO.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P8_S2	On October 6, 2009, in connection with our IPO, the company effected a reorganization whereby ISO became a wholly-owned subsidiary of Verisk.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P8_S3	Verisk Class A common stock began trading on the NASDAQ Global Select Market on October 7, 2009 under the symbol VRSK.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P9_S0	Segments We organize our business in two segments: Risk Assessment and Decision Analytics.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P9_S1	See Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations in Part II of this annual report for information regarding our segments.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P10_S0	Risk Assessment Segment Our Risk Assessment segment serves our P C insurance customers and focuses on the first two decision making processes in our Risk Analysis Framework: prediction of loss and selection and pricing of risk.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P10_S1	Within this segment, we also provide solutions to help our insurance customers comply with their reporting requirements in each U.S. state in which they operate.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P11_S0	The P C insurance industry is heavily regulated in the U.S. P C insurers are required to collect statistical data about their premiums and losses and to report that data to regulators in every state in which they operate.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P11_S1	Our statistical agent services have enabled P C insurers to meet these regulatory requirements for over 30 years.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P11_S2	We aggregate the data and, as a licensed statistical agent in all 50 states, Puerto Rico and the District of Columbia, we report these statistics to insurance regulators.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P11_S3	We are able to capture significant economies of scale given the level of penetration of this service within the U.S. P C insurance industry.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P11_S4	To provide our customers and the regulators the information they require, we maintain one of the largest private databases in the world.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P11_S5	Over the past four decades, we have developed core expertise in acquiring, processing, managing, and operating large and comprehensive databases that are the foundation of our Risk Assessment segment.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P11_S6	We use our proprietary technology to assemble, organize and update vast amounts of detailed information submitted by our customers.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P11_S7	We supplement this data with publicly available information.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P12_S0	Each year, P C insurers send us approximately 2.9 billion detailed individual records of insurance transactions, such as insurance premiums collected or losses incurred.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P12_S1	We maintain a database of over 15.8 billion statistical records, including approximately 6.1 billion commercial lines records and approximately 9.7 billion personal lines records.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P12_S2	We collect unit-transaction detail of each premium and loss record, which enhances the validity, reliability and accuracy of our data sets and our actuarial analyses.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P12_S3	Our proprietary quality process includes almost 2,500 separate checks to ensure that data meet our high standards of quality.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P12_S4	We provide actuarial services to help our customers price their risks as they underwrite.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P12_S5	We project future losses and loss expenses utilizing a broad set of data.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P12_S6	These projections tend to be more reliable than if our customers used solely their own data.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P12_S7	We provide loss costs by coverage, class, territory, and many other categories.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P12_S8	Our customers can use our estimates of future loss costs in making independent decisions about the prices charged for their policies.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P12_S9	For most P C insurers, in most lines of business, we believe our loss costs are an essential input to rating decisions.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P12_S10	We make a number of actuarial adjustments, including loss development and loss adjustment expenses before the data is used to estimate future loss costs.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P12_S11	Our actuarial services are also used to create the analytics underlying our industry-standard insurance programs described below.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P12_S12	Using our large database of premium and loss data, our actuaries are able to perform sophisticated analyses using our predictive models and analytic methods to help our P C insurance customers with pricing, loss reserving, and marketing.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P12_S13	We distribute a number of actuarial products and offer flexible services to meet our customers needs.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P12_S14	In addition, our actuarial consultants provide customized services for our clients that include assisting them with the development of independent insurance programs, analysis of their own underwriting experience, development of classification systems and rating plans, and a wide variety of other business decisions.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P12_S15	We also supply information to a wide variety of customers in other markets including reinsurance, government agencies and real estate.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P12_S16	We are the recognized leader in the U.S. for industry-standard insurance programs that help P C insurers define coverages and issue policies.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P12_S17	Our policy language, prospective loss cost information and policy writing rules can serve as integrated turnkey insurance programs for our customers.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P13_S0	Insurance companies need to ensure that their policy language, rules, and rates comply with all applicable legal and regulatory requirements.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P13_S1	Insurers must also make sure their policies remain competitive by promptly changing coverages in response to changes in statutes or case law.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P13_S2	To meet their needs, we process and interface with state regulators on average over 2,800 filings each year, ensuring smooth implementation of our rules and forms.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P13_S3	When insurers choose to develop their own alternative programs, our industry-standard insurance programs also help regulators make sure that such insurers policies meet basic coverage requirements.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P13_S4	Standardized coverage language, which has been tested in litigation and tailored to reflect judicial interpretation, helps to ensure consistent treatment of claimants.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P13_S5	As a result, our industry-standard language also simplifies claim settlements and can reduce the occurrence of costly litigation, because our language causes the meaning of coverage terminology to become established and known.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P13_S6	Our policy language includes standard coverage language, endorsements and policy writing support language that assist our customers in understanding the risks they assume and the coverages they are offering.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P13_S7	With these policy programs, insurers also benefit from economies of scale.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P13_S8	We have over 200 specialized lawyers and insurance experts reviewing changes in each state s insurance rules and regulations, including on average over 13,000 legislative bills, 1,000 regulatory actions and 2,000 court cases per year, to make any required changes to our policy language and rating information.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P14_S0	To cover the wide variety of risks in the marketplace, we offer a broad range of policy programs.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P14_S1	For example, in the homeowner s line of insurance, we maintain policy language and rules for 6 basic coverages, 254 national endorsements, and 479 state-specific endorsements.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P14_S2	Overall, we provide policy language, prospective loss costs, policy writing rules, and a variety of other solutions for 25 lines of insurance.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P14_S3	We gather information on individual properties and communities so that insurers can use our information to evaluate and price personal and commercial property insurance, as well as commercial liability insurance.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P14_S4	Our property-specific rating and underwriting information allow our customers to understand, quantify, underwrite, mitigate, and avoid potential loss for residential and commercial properties.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P14_S5	Our database contains loss costs and other vital information on more than 3.3 million commercial buildings in the United States and also holds information on more than 6 million individual businesses occupying those buildings.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P14_S6	We have a staff of approximately 600 field representatives strategically located around the United States who observe and report on conditions at commercial and residential properties, evaluate community fire-protection capabilities and assess the effectiveness of municipal building-code enforcement.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P14_S7	Each year, our field staff visits more than 350,000 commercial properties to collect information on new buildings and verify building attributes.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P14_S8	We also provide proprietary analytic measures of the ability of individual communities to mitigate losses from important perils.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P14_S9	Nearly every property insurer in the U.S. uses our evaluations of community firefighting capabilities to help determine premiums for fire insurance throughout the country.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P14_S10	We provide field-verified and validated data on the fire protection services for more than 46,000 fire response jurisdictions.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P14_S11	We also offer services to evaluate the effectiveness of community enforcement of building codes and the efforts of communities to mitigate damage from flooding.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P14_S12	Further, we provide information on the insurance rating territories, premium taxes, crime risk, and hazards of windstorm, earthquake, wildfire, and other perils.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P14_S13	To supplement our data on specific commercial properties and individual communities, we have assembled, from a variety of internal and third-party sources, information on hazards related to geographic locations representing every postal address in the U.S. Insurers use this information not only for policy quoting but also for analyzing risk concentration in geographical areas.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P15_S0	Decision Analytics Segment In the Decision Analytics segment, we support all four phases of our Risk Analysis Framework.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P15_S1	We develop predictive models to forecast scenarios and produce both standard and customized analytics that help our customers better predict loss, select and price risk, detect fraud before and after a loss event, and quantify losses.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P15_S2	Effective December 31, 2011, we provided additional disclosure about our revenue within Decision Analytics segment based on the industry vertical groupings of insurance, mortgage and financial services, healthcare and specialized markets.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P15_S3	Previously, we disclosed revenue based on the classification of our solution as fraud identification and detection solutions, loss prediction solutions and loss quantification solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P15_S4	We believe that this change enhances financial reporting transparency and helps investors better understand the themes within the Decision Analytics segment.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P16_S0	The businesses are categorized by the primary end market for their services.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P17_S0	As we develop our models to quantify loss and detect fraud, we improve our ability to predict the loss and prevent the fraud from happening.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P17_S1	We believe this provides us with a significant competitive advantage over firms that do not offer solutions which operate both before and after loss events.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P18_S0	We are a leading provider of fraud-detection tools for the P C insurance industry.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P18_S1	Our fraud solutions improve our customers profitability by both predicting the likelihood that fraud is occurring and detecting suspicious activity after it has occurred.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P18_S2	When a claim is submitted, our system searches our database and returns information about other claims filed by the same individuals or businesses (either as claimants or insurers) that help our customers determine if fraud has occurred.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P18_S3	The system searches for matches in identifying information fields, such as name, address, Social Security number, vehicle identification number, driver s license number, tax identification number, or other parties to the loss.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P18_S4	Our system also includes advanced name and address searching to perform intelligent searches and improve the overall quality of the matches.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P19_S0	Information from match reports speeds payment of meritorious claims while providing a defense against fraud and can lead to denial of a claim, negotiation of a reduced award or further investigation by the insurer or law enforcement.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P20_S0	We have a comprehensive system used by claims adjusters and investigations professionals to process claims and fight fraud.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P21_S0	Claims databases are one of the key tools in the fight against insurance fraud.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P21_S1	The benefits of a single all-claims database include improved efficiency in reporting data and searching for information, enhanced capabilities for detecting suspicious claims and superior information for investigating fraudulent claims, suspicious individuals and possible fraud rings.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P22_S0	Our database contains information on nearly 800 million claims and is the world s largest database of claims information used for claims and investigations.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P23_S0	Insurers and other participants submit new claim reports, more than 239,000 a day on average, across all categories of the U.S. P C insurance industry.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P24_S0	We also provide a service allowing insurers to report thefts of automobiles and property, improving the chances of recovering those items; a service that helps owners and insurers recover stolen heavy construction and agricultural equipment; an expert scoring system that helps distinguish between suspicious and meritorious claims; and products that use link-analysis technology to help visualize and fight insurance fraud.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P25_S0	Loss Prediction: We pioneered the field of probabilistic catastrophe modeling used by insurers, reinsurers and financial institutions to manage their catastrophe risk.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P25_S1	Our models of global natural hazards, which form the basis of our solutions, enable companies to identify, quantify and plan for the financial consequences of catastrophic events.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P25_S2	We have developed models, covering natural hazards, including hurricanes, earthquakes, winter storms, tornadoes, hailstorms, and flood, for potential loss events in more than 80 countries.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P25_S3	We have also developed and introduced a probabilistic terrorism model capable of quantifying the risk in the U.S. from this emerging threat, which supports pricing and underwriting decisions down to the level of an individual policy Loss Quantification:
1442145_12_ITEM1_P26_S0	We provide data, analytic and networking products for professionals involved in estimating all phases of building repair and reconstruction.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P26_S1	We provide solutions for every phase of a building s life, including:
1442145_12_ITEM1_P27_S0	tracking the process of repair or reconstruction and facilitating communication among insurers, adjusters, contractors and policyholders.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P28_S0	To help our customers estimate repair costs, we provide a solution that assists contractors and insurance adjusters to estimate repairs using a patented plan-sketching program.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P28_S1	The program allows our customers to sketch floor plans, roof plans and wall-framing plans and automatically calculates material and labor quantities for the construction of walls, floors, footings and roofs.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P28_S2	We also offer our customers access to wholesale and retail price lists, which include structural repair and restoration pricing for 467 separate economic areas in North America.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P28_S3	We revise this information monthly and, in the aftermath of a major disaster, we can update the price lists as often as weekly to reflect rapid price changes.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P29_S0	Our structural repair and cleaning database contains more than 13,000 unit-cost line items.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P29_S1	For each line item such as smoke cleaning, water extraction and hazardous cleanup, we report time and material pricing, including labor, labor productivity rates (for new construction and restoration), labor burden and overhead, material costs, and equipment costs.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P29_S2	We improve our reported pricing data by several methods including direct market surveys, and an analysis of the actual claims experience of our customers.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P29_S3	We estimate that about 80.0% of all homeowners claims settled in the U.S. annually use our solution.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P29_S4	Utilization of such a large percentage of the industry s claims leads to accurate reporting of pricing information, which we believe is unmatched in the industry.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P29_S5	Our estimates allow our customers to set loss reserves, deploy field adjusters and verify internal company estimates.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P29_S6	Our estimates also keep insurers, their customers, regulators, and other interested parties informed about the total costs of disasters.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P29_S7	We also provide our customers access to daily reports on severe weather and catastrophes and we maintain a database of information on catastrophe losses in the U.S. since 1950.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P30_S0	Mortgage and Financial Services Fraud Detection and Prevention: We are a leading provider of automated fraud detection, compliance and decision-support tools for the mortgage industry.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P30_S1	Utilizing our own loan level application database combined with actual mortgage loan performance data, we have established a risk scoring system which increases our customers ability to detect fraud.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P30_S2	We provide solutions that detect fraud through each step of the mortgage lifecycle and provide regulatory compliance solutions that perform instant compliance reviews of each mortgage application.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P30_S3	Our fraud solutions can improve our customers profitability by predicting the likelihood that a customer account is experiencing fraud.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P31_S0	immediate action which are critical to stopping fraud and abuse.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P31_S1	These applications can also detect some organized fraud schemes that are too complex and well-hidden to be identified by other methods.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P32_S0	Effective fraud detection relies on pattern identification, which in turn requires us to identify, isolate and track mortgage applications through time.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P33_S0	Histories of multiple loans, both valid and fraudulent, are required to compare a submitted loan both to actual data and heuristic analyses.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P33_S1	For this reason, unless fraud detection solutions are fueled by comprehensive data, their practicality is limited.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P34_S0	Our proprietary database contains more than 21 million current and historical loan applications collected over the past ten years.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P34_S1	This database contains data from loan applications as well as supplementary third-party data.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P34_S2	Our technology employs sophisticated models to identify patterns in the data.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P34_S3	Our solution provides a score, which predicts whether the information provided by a mortgage applicant is correct.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P34_S4	Working with data obtained through our partnership with a credit bureau, we have demonstrated a strong correlation between fraudulent information in the application and the likelihood of both foreclosure and early payment default on loans.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P34_S5	We believe our solution is based upon a more comprehensive set of loan level information than any other provider in the mortgage industry.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P34_S6	We also provide forensic audit services for the mortgage origination and mortgage insurance industries.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P34_S7	Our predictive screening tools predict which defaulted loans are the most likely candidates for full audits for the purpose of detecting fraud.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P34_S8	We then generate detailed audit reports on defaulted mortgage loans.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P34_S9	Those reports serve as a key component of the loss mitigation strategies of mortgage loan insurers.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P35_S0	The recent turmoil in the mortgage industry has created an opportunity for growth in demand for our services, as we believe most mortgage insurers do not have the in-house capacity to respond to and properly review all of their defaulted loans for evidence of fraud.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P35_S1	We offer solutions that help healthcare claims payors detect fraud, abuse and overpayment.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P35_S2	Our approach combines computer-based modeling and profiling of claims with analysis performed by clinical experts.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P35_S3	We run our customers claims through our proprietary analytic system to identify potential fraud, abuse and overpayment, and then a registered nurse, physician or other clinical specialist skilled in coding and reimbursement decisions reviews all suspect claims and billing patterns.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P35_S4	This combination of system and human review is unique in the industry and we believe offers improved accuracy for paying claims.
