1442145_12_ITEM1_P36_S0	We analyze the patterns of claims produced by individual physicians, physicians practices, hospitals, dentists, and pharmacies to locate the sources of fraud.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P36_S1	After a suspicious source of claims is identified, our real-time analytic solutions investigate each claim individually for particular violations, including upcoding, multiple billings, services claimed but not rendered, and billing by unlicensed providers.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P36_S2	By finding the individual claims with the most cost-recovery potential and also minimizing the number of false-positive indications of fraud, we enable the special investigation units of healthcare payors to efficiently control their claims costs while maintaining high levels of customer service to their insurers.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P36_S3	We also offer web-based reporting tools that let payors take definitive action to prevent overpayments or payment of fraudulent claims.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P36_S4	The tools provide the documentation that helps to identify, investigate and prevent abusive and fraudulent activity by providers.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P37_S0	Loss Prediction: We are a leading provider of healthcare business intelligence and predictive modeling.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P37_S1	We provide analytical and reporting systems to health insurers, provider organizations and self-insured employers.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P37_S2	Those organizations use our solutions to review their healthcare data, including information on claims, membership, providers and utilization, and provide cost trends, forecasts and actuarial, financial and utilization analyses.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P37_S3	For example, our solutions allow our customers to predict medical costs and improve the financing and organization of health services.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P38_S0	disease-management intervention, compare providers adjusting for differences in health, predict resource use for individuals and populations, establish health-based and performance-based payments, negotiate payments and incentives, negotiate premium rates, and measure return on investment.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P38_S1	We also provide our customers healthcare services using complex clinical analyses to uncover reasons behind cost and utilization increases.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P39_S0	Physicians and hospitals are adopting and acquiring new technologies, drugs and devices more rapidly than ever before.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P39_S1	We provide financial and actuarial analyses, clinical, technical and implementation services and training services to help our customers manage costs and risks to their practices.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P40_S0	Specialized Markets Loss Prediction: We help businesses and governments better anticipate and manage climate- and weather-related risks.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P40_S1	We prepare certain agencies and companies to anticipate, manage, react to and profit from weather and climate related risk.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P40_S2	We serve our clients by providing state-of-the-art research, development and analysis delivered in reports, databases and software solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P40_S3	We are dedicated to the advancement of scientific understanding of the atmospheric, climate and weather, ocean, and planetary sciences.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P40_S4	Through research conducted by our in-house scientific staff, and often in collaboration with world-renowned scientists at academic and other research institutions, we have developed analytical tools to help measure and observe the properties of the environment and to translate these measurements into useful information to take action.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P40_S5	We also offer a comprehensive suite of data and information services that enables improved compliance with global Environmental Health Safety, or EH S requirements related to the safe manufacturing, distribution, transportation, usage and disposal of chemicals and products.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P40_S6	From the supply chain or solutions lifecycle, we deliver a program specific to the EH S compliance information and management needs of our customers.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P40_S7	We have a full solutions lifecycle and cross-supply chain approach that provide a single, integrated solution for managing EH S capabilities, resulting in reduced cost, risk and liability while improving process.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P40_S8	Our Growth Strategy Over the past five years, we have grown our revenues at a CAGR of 13.5% through the successful execution of our business plan.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P40_S9	These results reflect strong organic revenue growth, new product development and selected acquisitions.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P40_S10	We have made, and continue to make, investments in people, data sets, analytic solutions, technology, and complementary businesses.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P40_S11	The key components of our strategy include: Increase Sales to Insurance Customers.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P40_S12	We expect to expand the application of our solutions in insurance customers internal risk and underwriting processes.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P40_S13	Building on our deep knowledge of, and embedded position in, the insurance industry, we expect to sell more solutions to existing customers tailored to individual insurance segments.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P40_S14	By increasing the breadth and relevance of our offerings, we believe we can strengthen our relationships with customers and increase our value to their decision making in critical ways.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P41_S0	Develop New, Proprietary Data Sets and Predictive Analytics.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P41_S1	We work with our customers to understand their evolving needs.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P41_S2	We plan to create new solutions by enriching our mix of proprietary data sets, analytic solutions and effective decision support across the markets we serve.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P41_S3	We constantly seek to add new data sets that can further leverage our analytic methods, technology platforms and intellectual capital.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P41_S4	Leverage Our Intellectual Capital to Expand into Adjacent Markets and New Customer Sectors.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P41_S5	Our organization is built on nearly four decades of intellectual property in risk management.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P41_S6	We believe we can continue to profitably expand the use of our intellectual capital and apply our analytic methods in new markets, where significant opportunities for long-term growth exist.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P41_S7	We also continue to pursue growth through targeted international expansion.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P41_S8	We have already demonstrated the effectiveness of this strategy with our expansion into healthcare and non-insurance financial services.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P42_S0	Pursue Strategic Acquisitions that Complement Our Leadership Positions.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P42_S1	We will continue to expand our data and analytics capabilities across industries.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P42_S2	While we expect this will occur primarily through organic growth, we have and will continue to acquire assets and businesses that strengthen our value proposition to customers.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P42_S3	We have developed an internal capability to source, evaluate and integrate acquisitions that have created value for shareholders.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P42_S4	The customers in our Risk Assessment segment include the top 100 P C insurance providers in the United States.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P42_S5	Our statistical agent services are used by a substantial majority of P C insurance providers in the U.S. to report to regulators.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P42_S6	Our actuarial services and industry-standard insurance programs are used by the majority of insurers and reinsurers in the U.S.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P42_S7	In addition, certain agencies of the federal government, as well as county and state governmental agencies and organizations, use our solutions to help satisfy government needs for risk assessment and emergency response information.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P42_S8	Certain Relationships and Related Transactions, and Director Independence Customer Relationships for more information on our relationship with our principal stockholders.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P43_S0	Decision Analytics Customers In the Decision Analytics segment, we provide our P C insurance solutions to the majority of the P C insurers in the U.S.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P43_S1	Specifically, our claims database serves thousands of customers, representing nearly 93.0% of the P C insurance industry by premium volume, 26 state workers compensation insurance funds, 592 self-insurers, 454 third-party administrators, several state fraud bureaus, and many law-enforcement agencies involved in investigation and prosecution of insurance fraud.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P43_S2	Also, P C insurance companies using our building and repair solutions represent about 80.0% of the property market in the U.S.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P43_S3	We estimate that more than 80.0% of insurance repair contractors and service providers in the U.S. and Canada with computerized estimating systems use our building and repair pricing data.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P43_S4	In the U.S. healthcare industry, our customers include numerous health plans and third party administrators.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P43_S5	In the U.S. mortgage industry, we have more than 750 customers.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P43_S6	We provide our solutions to leading mortgage lenders and mortgage insurers.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P43_S7	We have been providing services to mortgage insurers for over 20 years.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P43_S8	Our Competitors We believe no single competitor currently offers the same scope of services and market coverage we provide.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P43_S9	The breadth of markets we serve exposes us to a broad range of competitors.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P44_S0	Risk Assessment Competitors Our Risk Assessment segment operates primarily in the U.S. P C insurance industry, where we enjoy a leading market presence.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P44_S1	We have a number of competitors in specific lines or services.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P44_S2	We encounter competition from a number of sources, including insurers who develop internal technology and actuarial methods for proprietary insurance programs.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P44_S3	Competitors also include other statistical agents, including the National Independent Statistical Service, the Independent Statistical Service and other advisory organizations, providing underwriting rules, prospective loss costs and coverage language such as the American Association of Insurance Services and Mutual Services Organization, although we believe none of our competitors has the breadth or depth of data we have.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P44_S4	Competitors for our property-specific rating and underwriting information are primarily limited to a number of regional providers of commercial property inspections and surveys, including Overland Solutions, Inc. and Regional Reporting, Inc.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P45_S0	primarily specialty technology and consulting firms.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P45_S1	In addition, a customer may use its own internal resources rather than engage an outside firm for these services.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P45_S2	Our competitors also include information technology product and services vendors including CDS, Inc., management and strategy consulting firms including Deloitte Consulting LLP, and smaller specialized information technology firms and analytical services firms including Pinnacle Consulting and EMB.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P45_S3	Decision Analytics Competitors In the P C insurance claims market and catastrophe modeling market, certain products are offered by a number of companies, including Risk Management Solutions (catastrophe modeling), LexisNexis Risk Solutions (loss histories and motor vehicle records for personal lines underwriting), MSB (property value and claims estimator), and Solera (personal automobile underwriting).
1442145_12_ITEM1_P45_S4	We believe that our P C insurance industry expertise, combined with our ability to offer multiple applications, services and integrated solutions to individual customers, enhances our competitiveness against these competitors with more limited offerings.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P46_S0	In the healthcare market, certain products are offered by a number of companies, including Computer Sciences Corporation (evaluation of bodily injury and workers compensation claims), Fair Isaac Corporation (workers compensation and healthcare claims cost containment) and OptumInsight, McKesson, Medstat, MedAssurant, and iHealth (healthcare predictive modeling and business intelligence).
1442145_12_ITEM1_P46_S1	Competitive factors include application features and functions, ease of delivery and integration, ability of the provider to maintain, enhance and support the applications or services and price.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P46_S2	In the mortgage analytics solutions market, our competitors include CoreLogic and DataVerify Corporation (mortgage lending fraud identification).
1442145_12_ITEM1_P46_S3	We believe that none of our competitors in the mortgage analytics market offers the same combination of expertise in fraud detection analytics and forensic audit capabilities.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P47_S0	Development of New Solutions We take a market-focused team approach to developing our solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P47_S1	Our operating units are responsible for developing, reviewing and enhancing our various products and services.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P47_S2	Our data management and production team designs and manages our processes and systems for market data procurement, proprietary data production and quality control.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P47_S3	Our Enterprise Data Management, or EDM, team supports our efforts to create new information and products from available data and explores new methods of collecting data.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P47_S4	EDM is focused on understanding and documenting business-unit and corporate data assets and data issues; sharing and combining data assets across the enterprise; creating an enterprise data strategy; facilitating research and product development; and promoting cross-enterprise communication.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P48_S0	Our ISO Innovative Analytics, or IIA, team is a corporate center of excellence for analytical methods in applying modeling techniques to predict risk outcomes.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P48_S1	Our software development team builds the technology used in many of our solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P48_S2	As part of our product-development process, we continually solicit feedback from our customers on the value of our products and services and the market s needs.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P48_S3	We have established an extensive system of customer advisory panels, which meet regularly throughout the year to help us respond effectively to the needs of our markets.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P48_S4	In addition, we use frequent sales calls, executive visits, user group meetings, and other industry forums to gather information to match the needs of the market with our product development efforts.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P48_S5	We also use a variety of market research techniques to enhance our understanding of our clients and the markets in which they operate.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P48_S6	We also add to our offerings through an active acquisition program.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P48_S7	Since 2007, we have acquired 13 businesses, which have allowed us to enter new markets, offer new products and enhance the value of existing products with additional proprietary sources of data.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P48_S8	When we find it advantageous, we augment our proprietary data sources and systems by forming alliances with other leading information providers and technology companies and integrating their product offerings into our offerings.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P48_S9	This approach gives our customers the opportunity to obtain the information they need from a single source and more easily integrate the information into their workflows.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P49_S0	Sales, Marketing and Customer Support We sell our products and services primarily through direct interaction with our clients.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P49_S1	We employ a three-tier sales structure that includes salespeople, product specialists and sales support.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P49_S2	As of December 31, 2011, we had a sales force of 286 people.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P50_S0	Within the company, several areas have sales teams that specialize in specific products and services.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P50_S1	These specialized sales teams sell specific, highly technical product sets to targeted markets.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P51_S0	To provide account management to our largest customers, we segment the insurance carrier market into three groups.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P51_S1	Tier One or National Accounts constitutes our largest customers, Tier Two or Strategic Accounts represents both larger carrier groups and middle-market carriers.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P51_S2	Tier Three are the small insurance companies that may represent one line of business and/or be one-state or regional writers.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P51_S3	A Sales Generalist is assigned to every insurer account and is responsible for our overall relationship with these insurance companies.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P51_S4	Our senior executives are also involved with the senior management of our customers.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P52_S0	Sales people participate in both customer-service and sales activities.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P52_S1	They provide direct support, interacting frequently with assigned customers to assure a positive experience using our services.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P52_S2	Salespeople primarily seek out new sales opportunities and work with the various sales teams to coordinate sales activity and provide the best solutions for our customers.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P52_S3	We believe our salespeople s product knowledge and local presence differentiates us from our competition.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P53_S0	Product specialists are subject-matter experts and work with salespeople on specific opportunities for their assigned products.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P53_S1	Both salespeople and product specialists have responsibility for identifying new sales opportunities.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P53_S2	A team approach and a common customer relationship management system allow for effective coordination between the two groups.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P54_S0	The data we use to perform our analytics and power our solutions are sourced through six different kinds of data arrangements.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P55_S0	First, we gather data from our customers within agreements that also permit our customers to use the solutions created upon their data.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P55_S1	These agreements remain in effect unless the data contributor chooses to opt out and represent our primary method of data gathering.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P55_S2	It is very rare that contributors elect not to continue providing us data.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P55_S3	Second, we have agreements with data contributors in which we specify the particular uses of their data and provide to the data contributors their required levels of privacy, protection of data and where necessary de-identification of data.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P55_S4	These agreements represent no cost to us and generally feature a specified period of time for the data contributions and require renewal.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P55_S5	Third, we mine data found inside the transactions supported by our solutions; as an example, we utilize the claims settlement data generated inside our repair cost estimating solution to improve the cost factors used in our models.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P55_S6	Again, these arrangements represent no cost to us and we obtain the consent of our customers to make use of their data in this way.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P55_S7	Fourth, we source data generally at no cost from public sources including federal, state and local governments.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P55_S8	Fifth, we gather data about the physical characteristics of commercial properties through the direct observation of our field staff that also perform property surveys at the request of, and facilitated by, property insurers.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P55_S9	Lastly, we purchase data from data aggregators under contracts that reflect prevailing market pricing for the data elements purchased, including county tax assessor records, descriptions of hazards such as flood plains and professional licenses.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P56_S0	In all our modes of data collection, we are the owners of whatever derivative solutions we create using the data.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P56_S1	Our costs of data received from our customers were 1.5% and 1.7% of revenues for the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P56_S2	Our information technology systems are fundamental to our success.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P56_S3	They are used for the storage, processing, access and delivery of the data which forms the foundation of our business and the development and delivery of our solutions provided to our clients.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P57_S0	developed, maintained and supported by approximately 1,020 employees.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P58_S0	We generally own or have secured ongoing rights to use for the purposes of our business all the customer-facing applications which are material to our operations.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P58_S1	We support and implement a mix of technologies, focused on implementing the most efficient technology for any given business requirement or task.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P58_S2	We have two primary data centers in Jersey City, New Jersey and Orem, Utah.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P58_S3	In addition, we have data centers dedicated to certain business units, including AIR and Verisk Health in Boston and AISG Claimsearch in Israel.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P58_S4	In addition to these key data centers, we also have a number of smaller data centers located in other states.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P58_S5	We are committed to a framework for business continuity management and carry out annual reviews of the state of preparedness of each business unit.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P58_S6	All of our critical databases, systems and contracted client services are also regularly recovered.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P58_S7	We also have documented disaster recovery plans in place for each of our major data centers and each of our solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P59_S0	Our primary data center recovery site is in New York State, approximately 50 miles northwest of Jersey City, New Jersey.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P60_S0	We have adopted a wide range of measures to ensure the security of our IT infrastructure and data.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P60_S1	Security measures generally cover the following key areas: physical security; logical security of the perimeter; network security such as firewalls; logical access to the operating systems; deployment of virus detection software; and appropriate policies and procedures relating to removable media such as laptops.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P60_S2	All laptops are encrypted and media leaving our premises that is sent to a third-party storage facility is also encrypted.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P60_S3	This commitment has led us to achieve certification from CyberTrust (an industry leader in information security certification) since 2002.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P61_S0	We own a significant number of intellectual property rights, including copyrights, trademarks, trade secrets and patents.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P61_S1	Specifically, our policy language, insurance manuals, software and databases are protected by both registered and common law copyrights, and the licensing of those materials to our customers for their use represents a large portion of our revenue.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P61_S2	We also own in excess of 500 trademarks in the U.S. and foreign countries, including the names of our products and services and our logos and tag lines, many of which are registered.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P61_S3	We believe many of our trademarks, trade names, service marks and logos to be of material importance to our business as they assist our customers in identifying our products and services and the quality that stands behind them.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P61_S4	We consider our intellectual property to be proprietary, and we rely on a combination of statutory (e.g., copyright, trademark, trade secret and patent) and contractual safeguards in a comprehensive intellectual property enforcement program to protect them wherever they are used.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P61_S5	We also own several software method and processing patents and have several pending patent applications in the U.S. that complement our products.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P61_S6	The patents and patent applications include claims which pertain to technology, including a patent for our Claims Outcome Advisor software, and for our Xactware Sketch product.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P61_S7	We believe the protection of our proprietary technology is important to our success and we will continue to seek to protect those intellectual property assets for which we have expended substantial research and development capital and which are material to our business.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P61_S8	In order to maintain control of our intellectual property, we enter into license agreements with our customers, granting each customer a license to use our products and services, including our software and databases.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P62_S0	embedded information and technology contained in our solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P62_S1	As a general practice, employees, contractors and other parties with access to our proprietary information sign agreements that prohibit the unauthorized use or disclosure of our proprietary rights, information and technology.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P63_S0	As of December 31, 2011, we employed 5,200 full-time and 201 part-time employees.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P63_S1	None of our employees are represented by unions.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P63_S2	We consider our relationship with our employees to be good and have not experienced interruptions of operations due to labor disagreements.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P64_S0	Our employees include over 200 actuarial professionals, including 43 Fellows and 25 Associates of the Casualty Actuarial Society, as well as 147 Chartered Property Casualty Underwriters, 19 Certified and 23 Associate Insurance Data Managers, and over 500 professionals with advanced degrees, including PhDs in mathematics and statistical modeling who review both the data and the models.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P65_S0	Regulation Because our business involves the distribution of certain personal, public and non-public data to businesses and governmental entities that make eligibility, service and marketing decisions based on such data, certain of our solutions and services are subject to regulation under federal, state and local laws in the United States and, to a lesser extent, foreign countries.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P65_S1	Examples of such regulation include the Fair Credit Reporting Act, which regulates the use of consumer credit report information; the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, which regulates the use of non-public personal financial information held by financial institutions and applies indirectly to companies that provide services to financial institutions; the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, which restricts the public disclosure of patient information and applies indirectly to companies that provide services to healthcare businesses; the Drivers Privacy Protection Act, which prohibits the public disclosure, use or resale by any state s department of motor vehicles of personal information about an individual that was obtained by the department in connection with a motor vehicle record, except for a permissible purpose and various other federal, state and local laws and regulations.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P65_S2	These laws generally restrict the use and disclosure of personal information and provide consumers certain rights to know the manner in which their personal information is being used, to challenge the accuracy of such information and/or to prevent the use and disclosure of such information.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P65_S3	In certain instances, these laws also impose requirements for safeguarding personal information through the issuance of data security standards or guidelines.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P65_S4	Certain state laws impose similar privacy obligations, as well as obligations to provide notification of security breaches in certain circumstances.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P65_S5	We are also licensed as a rating, rate service, advisory or statistical organization under state insurance codes in all fifty states, Puerto Rico, Guam, the Virgin Islands and the District of Columbia.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P65_S6	As such an advisory organization, we provide statistical, actuarial, policy language development and related products and services to property/casualty insurers, including advisory prospective loss costs, other prospective cost information, manual rules and policy language.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P65_S7	We also serve as an officially designated statistical agent of state insurance regulators to collect policy-writing and loss statistics of individual insurers and compile that information into reports used by the regulators.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P66_S0	Many of our products, services and operations as well as insurer use of our services are subject to state rather than federal regulation by virtue of the McCarran-Ferguson Act.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P66_S1	As a result, many of our operations and products are subject to review and/or approval by state regulators.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P66_S2	Furthermore, our operations involving licensed advisory organization activities are subject to periodic examinations conducted by state regulators and our operations and products are subject to state antitrust and trade practice statutes within or outside state insurance codes, which are typically enforced by state attorneys general and/or insurance regulators.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P67_S0	We maintain an Investor Relations website on the Internet at investor.verisk.com.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P67_S1	We make available free of charge, on or through this website, our annual, quarterly, and current reports and any amendments to those reports as soon as reasonably practicable following the time they are electronically filed with or furnished to the SEC.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P67_S2	To access these, click on the Financial Information SEC Filings link found on our Investor Relations homepage.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P68_S0	Verisk trades on the NASDAQ Global Select Market under the ticker symbol VRSK.
1442145_12_ITEM1_P68_S1	Our stock was first publicly traded on October 7, 2009.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P0_S0	should carefully consider the following risks and all of the other information set forth in this annual report on Form 10-K before deciding to invest in shares of our Class A common stock.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P0_S1	If any of the following risks actually occurs, our business, financial condition or results of operations would likely suffer.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P0_S2	In such case, the trading price of our Class A common stock could decline due to any of these risks, and you may lose all or part of your investment.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P0_S3	We could lose our access to data from external sources which could prevent us from providing our solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P0_S4	We depend upon data from external sources, including data received from customers and various government and public record services, for information used in our databases.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P0_S5	In general, we do not own the information in these databases, and the participating organizations could discontinue contributing information to the databases.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P0_S6	Our data sources could withdraw or increase the price for their data for a variety of reasons, and we could also become subject to legislative or judicial restrictions on the use of such data, in particular if such data is not collected by the third parties in a way which allows us to legally use and/or process the data.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P0_S7	In addition, some of our customers are significant stockholders of our company.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P0_S8	Specifically, a portion of Class A common stock is owned by insurers who are also our customers.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P0_S9	If our customers percentage of ownership of our common stock decreases in the future, there can be no assurance that our customers will continue to provide data to the same extent or on the same terms.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P0_S10	If a substantial number of data sources, or certain key sources, were to withdraw or be unable to provide their data, or if we were to lose access to data due to government regulation or if the collection of data became uneconomical, our ability to provide solutions to our customers could be impacted, which could materially adversely affect our business, reputation, financial condition, operating results and cash flows.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P1_S0	Agreements with our data suppliers are short-term agreements.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P1_S1	Some suppliers are also competitors, which may make us vulnerable to unpredictable price increases and may cause some suppliers not to renew certain agreements.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P1_S2	Our competitors could also enter into exclusive contracts with our data sources.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P1_S3	If our competitors enter into such exclusive contracts, we may be precluded from receiving certain data from these suppliers or restricted in our use of such data, which would give our competitors an advantage.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P1_S4	Such a termination or exclusive contracts could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, and operating results if we were unable to arrange for substitute sources.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P2_S0	We derive a substantial portion of our revenues from U.S. P C primary insurers.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P2_S1	If the downturn in the U.S. insurance industry continues or that industry does not continue to accept our solutions, our revenues will decline.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P2_S2	Revenues derived from solutions we provide to U.S. P C primary insurers account for a substantial portion of our total revenues.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P2_S3	During the year ended December 31, 2011, approximately 52.0 % of our revenue was derived from solutions provided to U.S. P C primary insurers.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P2_S4	Also, sales of certain of our solutions are tied to premiums in the U.S. P C insurance market, which may rise or fall in any given year due to loss experience and capital capacity and other factors in the insurance industry beyond our control.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P3_S0	decline if the insurance industry does not continue to accept our solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P3_S1	Factors that might affect the acceptance of these solutions by P C primary insurers include the following:
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P4_S0	failure to execute our customer-focused selling approach.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P4_S1	A continued downturn in the insurance industry or lower acceptance of our solutions by the insurance industry could result in a decline in revenues from that industry and have a material adverse effect on our financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P4_S2	Our revenues from customers in the mortgage vertical is largely transactional and subject to changing conditions of the U.S mortgage market.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P4_S3	Revenue derived from solutions we provide the U.S. mortgage and mortgage-related industries accounted for approximately 10.0% of our total revenue in the year ended December 31, 2011.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P4_S4	Our forensic audits business and business with government-sponsored entities in the mortgage business accounted for approximately 67.0% of our total mortgage and mortgage-related revenue in 2011.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P4_S5	Because our business relies on transaction volumes based on both new mortgage applications and forensic audit of funded loans, reductions in either the volume of mortgage loans originated or the number or quality of funded loans could reduce our revenue.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P4_S6	Mortgage origination volumes in 2011 declined versus 2010.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P4_S7	This decline may continue based on changes in the mortgage market related to the U.S. mortgage crisis.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Recently there have been proposals to restructure or eliminate the roles of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P5_S1	The restructuring or elimination of either Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac could have a negative effect on the U. S. mortgage market and on our revenue derived from the solutions we provide to the mortgage industry.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P5_S2	If origination volumes and applications for mortgages decline, our revenue in this part of the business may decline if we are unable to increase the percentage of mortgages examined for existing customers or add new customers.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P5_S3	Our forensic audit business has benefited from the high amount of bad loans to be examined by mortgage insurers and other parties as a result of the U.S. mortgage crisis.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Certain mortgage insurers who have been operating under regulatory waivers of capital sufficiency requirements have announced that they are currently unable to write new mortgage insurance policies unless regulatory relief is provided.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P6_S1	Such a development could impact the volume of loans to be examined in our forensic audit business and could reduce our revenue and profitability.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P6_S2	Additionally, a withdrawal of mortgage insurers from the mortgage loan market could potentially reduce the volume of loan originations, which could reduce the revenue in our origination-related business.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P6_S3	Two customers represented the majority of our mortgage revenue in 2011 and if their volumes decline and we are not able to replace such volumes with new customers, our revenue may decline.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P6_S4	There may be consolidation in our end customer market, which would reduce the use of our services.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P6_S5	Mergers or consolidations among our customers could reduce the number of our customers and potential customers.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P6_S6	This could adversely affect our revenues even if these events do not reduce the aggregate number of customers or the activities of the consolidated entities.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P6_S7	If our customers merge with or are acquired by other entities that are not our customers, or that use fewer of our services, they may discontinue or reduce their use of our services.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P6_S8	The adverse effects of consolidation will be greater in sectors that we are particularly dependent upon, for example, in the P C insurance services sector.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P6_S9	Any of these developments could materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition, operating results and cash flows.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P7_S0	If we are unable to develop successful new solutions or if we experience defects, failures and delays associated with the introduction of new solutions, our business could suffer serious harm.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P7_S1	Our growth and success depends upon our ability to develop and sell new solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P7_S2	If we are unable to develop new solutions, or if we are not successful in introducing and/or obtaining regulatory approval or acceptance for new solutions, we may not be able to grow our business, or growth may occur more slowly than we anticipate.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P7_S3	In addition, significant undetected errors or delays in new solutions may affect market acceptance of our solutions and could harm our business, financial condition or results of operations.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P8_S0	In the past, we have experienced delays while developing and introducing new solutions, primarily due to difficulties in developing models, acquiring data and adapting to particular operating environments.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P8_S1	Errors or defects in our solutions that are significant, or are perceived to be significant, could result in rejection of our solutions, damage to our reputation, loss of revenues, diversion of development resources, an increase in product liability claims, and increases in service and support costs and warranty claims.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P8_S2	We will continue to rely upon proprietary technology rights, and if we are unable to protect them, our business could be harmed.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P8_S3	Our success depends, in part, upon our intellectual property rights.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P8_S4	To date, we have relied primarily on a combination of copyright, patent, trade secret, and trademark laws and nondisclosure and other contractual restrictions on copying and distribution to protect our proprietary technology.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P8_S5	This protection of our proprietary technology is limited, and our proprietary technology could be used by others without our consent.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P8_S6	In addition, patents may not be issued with respect to our pending or future patent applications, and our patents may not be upheld as valid or may not prevent the development of competitive products.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P8_S7	Any disclosure, loss, invalidity of, or failure to protect our intellectual property could negatively impact our competitive position, and ultimately, our business.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P8_S8	Our protection of our intellectual property rights in the United States or abroad may not be adequate and others, including our competitors, may use our proprietary technology without our consent.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P8_S9	Furthermore, litigation may be necessary to enforce our intellectual property rights, to protect our trade secrets, or to determine the validity and scope of the proprietary rights of others.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P8_S10	Such litigation could result in substantial costs and diversion of resources and could harm our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P8_S11	We could face claims for intellectual property infringement, which if successful could restrict us from using and providing our technologies and solutions to our customers.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P9_S0	There has been substantial litigation and other proceedings, particularly in the United States, regarding patent and other intellectual property rights in the information technology industry.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P9_S1	There is a risk that we are infringing, or may in the future infringe, the intellectual property rights of third parties.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P9_S2	We monitor third-party patents and patent applications that may be relevant to our technologies and solutions and we carry out freedom to operate analyses where we deem appropriate.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P9_S3	However, such monitoring and analysis has not been, and is unlikely in the future to be, comprehensive, and it may not be possible to detect all potentially relevant patents and patent applications.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P9_S4	Since the patent application process can take several years to complete, there may be currently pending applications, unknown to us, that may later result in issued patents that cover our products and technologies.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P9_S5	As a result, we may infringe existing and future third-party patents of which we are not aware.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P9_S6	As we expand our operations there is a higher risk that such activity could infringe the intellectual property rights of third parties.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P9_S7	Third-party intellectual property infringement claims and any resultant litigation against us or our technology partners or providers, could subject us to liability for damages, restrict us from using and providing our technologies and solutions or operating our business generally, or require changes to be made to our technologies and solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P9_S8	Even if we prevail, litigation is time consuming and expensive to defend and would result in the diversion of management s time and attention.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P10_S0	If a successful claim of infringement is brought against us and we fail to develop non-infringing technologies and solutions or to obtain licenses on a timely and cost effective basis this could materially and adversely affect our business, reputation, financial condition, operating results and cash flows.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P10_S1	Regulatory developments could negatively impact our business.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P10_S2	Because personal, public and non-public information is stored in some of our databases, we are vulnerable to government regulation and adverse publicity concerning the use of our data.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P10_S3	We provide many types of data and services that already are subject to regulation under the Fair Credit Reporting Act, Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, Driver s Privacy Protection Act, Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, the European Union s Data Protection Directive and to a lesser extent, various other federal, state, and local laws and regulations.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P10_S4	These laws and regulations are designed to protect the privacy of the public and to prevent the misuse of personal information in the marketplace.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P10_S5	However, many consumer advocates, privacy advocates, and government regulators believe that the existing laws and regulations do not adequately protect privacy.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P10_S6	They have become increasingly concerned with the use of personal information, particularly social security numbers, department of motor vehicle data and dates of birth.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P10_S7	As a result, they are lobbying for further restrictions on the dissemination or commercial use of personal information to the public and private sectors.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P10_S8	Similar initiatives are under way in other countries in which we do business or from which we source data.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P10_S9	The following legal and regulatory developments also could have a material adverse affect on our business, financial position, results of operations or cash flows:
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P11_S0	failure of our solutions to adapt to changes in the regulatory environment in an efficient, cost-effective manner.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P11_S1	Fraudulent data access and other security breaches may negatively impact our business and harm our reputation.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P11_S2	Security breaches in our facilities, computer networks, and databases may cause harm to our business and reputation and result in a loss of customers.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P11_S3	Our systems may be vulnerable to physical break-ins, computer viruses, attacks by hackers and similar disruptive problems.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P11_S4	Third-party contractors also may experience security breaches involving the storage and transmission of proprietary information.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P11_S5	If users gain improper access to our databases, they may be able to steal, publish, delete or modify confidential third-party information that is stored or transmitted on our networks.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P11_S6	In addition, customers misuse of our information services could cause harm to our business and reputation and result in loss of customers.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P11_S7	Any such misappropriation and/or misuse of our information could result in us, among other things, being in breach of certain data protection and related legislation.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P11_S8	A security or privacy breach may affect us in the following ways:
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Incidents in which consumer data has been fraudulently or improperly acquired, or any other security or privacy breaches, may occur and could go undetected.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P12_S1	The number of potentially affected consumers identified by any future incidents is obviously unknown.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P12_S2	Any such incident could materially and adversely affect our business, reputation, financial condition, operating results and cash flows.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P13_S0	We typically face a long selling cycle to secure new contracts that requires significant resource commitments, which result in a long lead time before we receive revenues from new relationships.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P14_S0	We typically face a long selling cycle to secure a new contract and there is generally a long preparation period in order to commence providing the services.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P14_S1	We typically incur significant business development expenses during the selling cycle and we may not succeed in winning a new customer s business, in which case we receive no revenues and may receive no reimbursement for such expenses.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P14_S2	Even if we succeed in developing a relationship with a potential new customer, we may not be successful in obtaining contractual commitments after the selling cycle or in maintaining contractual commitments after the implementation cycle, which may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P14_S3	We may lose key business assets, including loss of data center capacity or the interruption of telecommunications links, the internet, or power sources, which could significantly impede our ability to do business.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P14_S4	Our operations depend on our ability, as well as that of third-party service providers to whom we have outsourced several critical functions, to protect data centers and related technology against damage from hardware failure, fire, power loss, telecommunications failure, impacts of terrorism, breaches in security (such as the actions of computer hackers), natural disasters, or other disasters.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P14_S5	The on-line services we provide are dependent on links to telecommunications providers.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P14_S6	In addition, we generate a significant amount of our revenues through telesales centers and websites that we utilize in the acquisition of new customers, fulfillment of solutions and services and responding to customer inquiries.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P14_S7	We may not have sufficient redundant operations to cover a loss or failure in all of these areas in a timely manner.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P14_S8	Certain of our customer contracts provide that our on-line servers may not be unavailable for specified periods of time.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P14_S9	Any damage to our data centers, failure of our telecommunications links or inability to access these telesales centers or websites could cause interruptions in operations that materially adversely affect our ability to meet customers requirements, resulting in decreased revenue, operating income and earnings per share.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P15_S0	We are subject to competition in many of the markets in which we operate and we may not be able to compete effectively.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P15_S1	Some markets in which we operate or which we believe may provide growth opportunities for us are highly competitive, and are expected to remain highly competitive.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P15_S2	We compete on the basis of quality, customer service, product and service selection and price.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P15_S3	Our competitive position in various market segments depends upon the relative strength of competitors in the segment and the resources devoted to competing in that segment.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P15_S4	Due to their size, certain competitors may be able to allocate greater resources to a particular market segment than we can.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P15_S5	As a result, these competitors may be in a better position to anticipate and respond to changing customer preferences, emerging technologies and market trends.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P15_S6	In addition, new competitors and alliances may emerge to take market share away.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P15_S7	We may be unable to maintain our competitive position in our market segments, especially against larger competitors.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P15_S8	We may also invest further to upgrade our systems in order to compete.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P15_S9	If we fail to successfully compete, our business, financial position and results of operations may be adversely affected.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P16_S0	Acquisitions could result in operating difficulties, dilution and other harmful consequences.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P17_S0	Our long-term business strategy includes growth through acquisitions.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P17_S1	Future acquisitions may not be completed on acceptable terms and acquired assets, data or businesses may not be successfully integrated into our operations.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P17_S2	Any acquisitions or investments will be accompanied by the risks commonly encountered in acquisitions of businesses.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P17_S3	Such risks include, among other things:
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P18_S0	diluting the share value and voting power of existing stockholders.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P18_S1	The anticipated benefits of many of our acquisitions may not materialize.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P18_S2	Future acquisitions or dispositions could result in the incurrence of debt, contingent liabilities or amortization expenses, or write-offs of goodwill and other intangible assets, any of which could harm our financial condition.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P18_S3	We typically fund our acquisitions through our debt facilities.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P18_S4	Although we have capacity under our uncommitted facilities, lenders are not required to loan us any funds under such facilities.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P18_S5	Therefore, future acquisitions may require us to obtain additional financing, which may not be available on favorable terms or at all.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P19_S0	To the extent the availability of free or relatively inexpensive information increases, the demand for some of our solutions may decrease.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P19_S1	Public sources of free or relatively inexpensive information have become increasingly available recently, particularly through the internet, and this trend is expected to continue.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P19_S2	Governmental agencies in particular have increased the amount of information to which they provide free public access.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P19_S3	Public sources of free or relatively inexpensive information may reduce demand for our solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P19_S4	To the extent that customers choose not to obtain solutions from us and instead rely on information obtained at little or no cost from these public sources, our business and results of operations may be adversely affected.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P19_S5	Our senior leadership team is critical to our continued success and the loss of such personnel could harm our business.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P19_S6	Our future success substantially depends on the continued service and performance of the members of our senior leadership team.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P19_S7	These personnel possess business and technical capabilities that are difficult to replace.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P19_S8	Members of our senior management operating team have been with us for an average of over twenty years.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P20_S0	However, with the exception of Frank J. Coyne, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, we do not have employee contracts with the members of our senior management operating team.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P20_S1	If we lose key members of our senior management operating team, we may not be able to effectively manage our current operations or meet ongoing and future business challenges, and this may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P20_S2	We may fail to attract and retain enough qualified employees to support our operations, which could have an adverse effect on our ability to expand our business and service our customers.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P20_S3	Our business relies on large numbers of skilled employees and our success depends on our ability to attract, train and retain a sufficient number of qualified employees.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P20_S4	If our attrition rate increases, our operating efficiency and productivity may decrease.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P20_S5	We compete for employees not only with other companies in our industry but also with companies in other industries, such as software services, engineering services and financial services companies, and there is a limited pool of employees who have the skills and training needed to do our work.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P20_S6	If our business continues to grow, the number of people we will need to hire will increase.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P20_S7	We will also need to increase our hiring if we are not able to maintain our attrition rate through our current recruiting and retention policies.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P20_S8	Increased competition for employees could have an adverse effect on our ability to expand our business and service our customers, as well as cause us to incur greater personnel expenses and training costs.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P20_S9	We are subject to antitrust and other litigation, and may in the future become subject to further such litigation; an adverse outcome in such litigation could have a material adverse effect on our financial condition, revenues and profitability.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P21_S0	We participate in businesses (particularly insurance-related businesses and services) that are subject to substantial litigation, including antitrust litigation.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P21_S1	We are subject to the provisions of a 1995 settlement agreement in an antitrust lawsuit brought by various state Attorneys General and private plaintiffs which imposes certain constraints with respect to insurer involvement in our governance and business.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P21_S2	We currently are defending against putative class action lawsuits in which it is alleged that certain of our subsidiaries unlawfully have conspired with insurers with respect to their payment of insurance claims.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P21_S3	Our failure to successfully defend or settle such litigation could result in liability that, to the extent not covered by our insurance, could have a material adverse effect on our financial condition, revenues and profitability.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P21_S4	Given the nature of our business, we may be subject to similar litigation in the future.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P21_S5	Even if the direct financial impact of such litigation is not material, settlements or judgments arising out of such litigation could include further restrictions on our ability to conduct business, including potentially the elimination of entire lines of business, which could increase our cost of doing business and limit our prospects for future growth.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P21_S6	Our liquidity, financial position and profitability could be adversely affected by further deterioration in U.S. and international credit markets and economic conditions.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P22_S0	Deterioration in the global capital markets has caused financial institutions to seek additional capital, merge with larger financial institutions and, in some cases, fail.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P22_S1	These conditions have led to concerns by market participants about the stability of financial markets generally and the strength of counterparties, resulting in a contraction of available credit, even for the most credit-worthy borrowers.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P22_S2	Due to recent market events, our liquidity and our ability to obtain financing may be negatively impacted if one of our lenders under our revolving credit facilities or existing shelf arrangements fails to meet its funding obligations.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P22_S3	In such an event, we may not be able to draw on all, or a substantial portion, of our uncommitted credit facilities, which would adversely affect our liquidity.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P22_S4	Also, if we attempt to obtain future financing in addition to, or replacement of, our existing credit facilities to finance our continued growth through acquisitions or otherwise, the credit market turmoil could negatively impact our ability to obtain such financing.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P23_S0	General economic, political and market forces and dislocations beyond our control could reduce demand for our solutions and harm our business.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P23_S1	The demand for our solutions may be impacted by domestic and international factors that are beyond our control, including macroeconomic, political and market conditions, the availability of short-term and long-term funding and capital, the level and volatility of interest rates, currency exchange rates and inflation.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P23_S2	The United States economy recently experienced periods of contraction and both the future domestic and global economic environments may continue to be less favorable than those of prior years.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P23_S3	Any one or more of these factors may contribute to reduced activity and prices in the securities markets generally and could result in a reduction in demand for our solutions, which could have an adverse effect on our results of operations and financial condition.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P23_S4	A significant additional decline in the value of assets for which risk is transferred in market transactions could have an adverse impact on the demand for our solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P23_S5	In addition, the decline of the credit markets has reduced the number of mortgage originators, and therefore, the immediate demand for our related mortgage solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P23_S6	Specifically, certain of our fraud detection and prevention solutions are directed at the mortgage market.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P23_S7	This decline in asset value and originations and an increase in foreclosure levels has also created greater regulatory scrutiny of mortgage originations and securitizations.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P23_S8	Any new regulatory regime may change the utility of our solutions for mortgage lenders and other participants in the mortgage lending industry and related derivative markets or increase our costs as we adapt our solutions to new regulation.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P24_S0	If there are substantial sales of our common stock, our stock price could decline.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P24_S1	The market price of our common stock could decline as a result of sales of a large number of shares of common stock in the market, or the perception that these sales could occur.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P24_S2	These sales, or the possibility that these sales may occur, also might make it more difficult for us to sell equity securities in the future at a time and at a price that we deem attractive.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P25_S0	As of December 31, 2011, our stockholders, who owned our shares prior to the IPO and follow-on offering, continue to beneficially own a portion of our Class A common stock, primarily owned by our Employee Stock Ownership Plan or ESOP, representing in aggregate approximately 13.1 % of our outstanding common stock.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P25_S1	Such stockholders will be able to sell their common stock in the public market from time to time without registration, and subject to limitations on the timing, amount and method of those sales imposed by securities laws.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P25_S2	If any of these stockholders were to sell a large number of their common stock, the market price of our common stock could decline significantly.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P25_S3	In addition, the perception in the public markets that sales by them might occur could also adversely affect the market price of our common stock.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P26_S0	Pursuant to our equity incentive plans, options to purchase approximately 17,834,361 shares of Class A common stock were outstanding as of February 24, 2012 .
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P26_S1	We filed a registration statement under the Securities Act, which covers the shares available for issuance under our equity incentive plans (including for such outstanding options) as well as shares held for resale by our existing stockholders that were previously issued under our equity incentive plans.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P26_S2	Such further issuance and resale of our common stock could cause the price of our common stock to decline.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P26_S3	Also, in the future, we may issue our securities in connection with investments and acquisitions.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P26_S4	The amount of our common stock issued in connection with an investment or acquisition could constitute a material portion of our then outstanding common stock.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P26_S5	Our capital structure, level of indebtedness and the terms of anti-takeover provisions under Delaware law and in our amended and restated certificate of incorporation and bylaws could diminish the value of our common stock and could make a merger, tender offer or proxy contest difficult or could impede an attempt to replace or remove our directors.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P27_S0	stockholder, even if a change of control would be beneficial to our existing stockholders.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P27_S1	In addition, our certificate of incorporation and bylaws may discourage, delay or prevent a change in our management or control over us that stockholders may consider favorable or make it more difficult for stockholders to replace directors even if stockholders consider it beneficial to do so.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P27_S2	Our certificate of incorporation and bylaws:
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P28_S0	establish advance notice requirements for nominating candidates for election to the board of directors or for proposing matters that can be acted upon by stockholders at stockholder meetings.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P28_S1	In addition, Section 203 of the Delaware General Corporation Law may inhibit potential acquisition bids for us.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P28_S2	As a public company, we are subject to Section 203, which regulates corporate acquisitions and limits the ability of a holder of 15.0% or more of our stock from acquiring the rest of our stock.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P28_S3	Under Delaware law a corporation may opt out of the anti-takeover provisions, but we do not intend to do so.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P28_S4	These provisions may prevent a stockholder from receiving the benefit from any premium over the market price of our common stock offered by a bidder in a potential takeover.
1442145_12_ITEM1A_P28_S5	Even in the absence of an attempt to effect a change in management or a takeover attempt, these provisions may adversely affect the prevailing market price of our common stock if they are viewed as discouraging takeover attempts in the future.

1442145_12_ITEM2_P0_S1	As of December 31, 2011, our principal offices consisted of the following properties:
1442145_12_ITEM2_P1_S0	We also lease offices in 22 states in the United States and the District of Columbia, and offices outside the United States to support our international operations in Canada, China, Denmark, England, Germany, India, Israel, Japan, and Nepal.
1442145_12_ITEM2_P1_S1	We believe that our properties are in good operating condition and adequately serve our current business operations.
1442145_12_ITEM2_P1_S2	We also anticipate that suitable additional or alternative space, including those under lease options, will be available at commercially reasonable terms for future expansion.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P0_S0	party to legal proceedings with respect to a variety of matters in the ordinary course of business, including those matters described below.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P1_S0	With respect to the ongoing matter, we are unable, at the present time, to determine the ultimate resolution of or provide a reasonable estimate of the range of possible loss attributable to this matter or the impact it may have on our results of operations, financial position or cash flows.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P1_S1	This is primarily because this case remains in its early stages and discovery has not yet commenced.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P1_S2	Although we believe we have strong defenses and intend to vigorously defend this matter, we could in the future incur judgments or enter into settlements of claims that could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial position or cash flows.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P2_S0	Claims Outcome Advisor Litigation Hensley, et al.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P2_S1	v. Computer Sciences Corporation et al. was a putative nationwide class action complaint, filed in February 2005, in Miller County, Arkansas state court.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P2_S2	Defendants included numerous insurance companies and providers of software products used by insurers in paying claims.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P2_S3	We were among the named defendants.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P3_S0	Plaintiffs alleged that certain software products, including our Claims Outcome Advisor product and a competing software product sold by Computer Sciences Corporation, improperly estimated the amount to be paid by insurers to their policyholders in connection with claims for bodily injuries.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P3_S1	We entered into settlement agreements with plaintiffs asserting claims relating to the use of Claims Outcome Advisor by defendants Hanover Insurance Group, Progressive Car Insurance and Liberty Mutual Insurance Group.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P3_S2	Each of these settlements was granted final approval by the court and together the settlements resolve the claims asserted in this case against us with respect to the above insurance companies, who settled the claims against them as well.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P3_S3	A provision was made in 2006 for this proceeding and the total amount we paid in 2008 with respect to these settlements was less than $2.0 million.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P3_S4	A fourth defendant, The Automobile Club of California, which is alleged to have used Claims Outcome Advisor, was dismissed from the action.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P4_S0	On August 18, 2008, pursuant to the agreement of the parties the Court ordered that the claims against us be dismissed with prejudice.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P4_S1	Subsequently, Hanover Insurance Group made a demand for reimbursement, pursuant to an indemnification provision contained in a December 30, 2004 License Agreement between Hanover and us, of its settlement and defense costs in the Hensley class action.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P4_S2	Specifically, Hanover demanded $2.5 million including $0.6 million in attorneys fees and expenses.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P4_S3	We disputed that Hanover is entitled to any reimbursement pursuant to the License Agreement.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P4_S4	In July 2010, after Hanover and us were unable to resolve the dispute in mediation, Hanover served a summons and complaint seeking indemnity and contribution from us.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P4_S5	The parties resolved this matter with no material adverse consequences to us in a Settlement Agreement and Release executed on August 25, 2011.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P5_S0	The plaintiffs seek to recover compensation for their damages in an amount equal to the difference between the amount paid by the defendants and the fair market repair/restoration costs of their damaged property.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P6_S0	Schafer v. State Farm Fire Cas. Co., et al. was a putative class action pending against us and State Farm Fire Casualty Company filed in March 2007 in the Eastern District of Louisiana.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P6_S1	The complaint alleged antitrust violations, breach of contract, negligence, bad faith, and fraud.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P6_S2	The court dismissed the antitrust claim as to both defendants and dismissed all claims against us other than fraud.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P6_S3	Judge Duval denied plaintiffs motion to certify a class with respect to the fraud and breach of contract claims on August 3, 2009.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P6_S4	After the single action was re-assigned to Judge Africk, plaintiffs agreed to settle the matter with us and State Farm and a Settlement Agreement and Release was executed by all parties in June 2010.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P6_S5	The terms of the settlement were not considered material to us.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P7_S0	Mornay v. Travelers Ins. Co., et al. was a putative class action pending against us and Travelers Insurance Company filed in November 2007 in the Eastern District of Louisiana.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P7_S1	The complaint alleged antitrust violations, breach of contract, negligence, bad faith, and fraud.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P7_S2	As in Schafer, the court dismissed the antitrust claim as to both defendants and dismissed all claims against us other than fraud.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P7_S3	Judge Duval stayed all proceedings in the case pending an appraisal of the lead plaintiff s insurance claim.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P7_S4	The matter was re-assigned to Judge Barbier, who on September 11, 2009 issued an order administratively closing the matter pending completion of the appraisal process.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P8_S0	After the appraisal process was completed and the court lifted the stay, defendants filed a motion to strike the class allegations and dismiss the fraud claim.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P8_S1	The plaintiffs agreed to settle the matter and a Settlement Agreement and Release were executed by all parties on January 5, 2012.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P9_S0	The terms of the settlement were not considered material to us.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P10_S0	In April 2010, our subsidiary, Insurance Information Exchange or iiX, as well as other information providers in the State of Missouri were served with a summons and class action complaint filed in the United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri alleging violations of the Driver Privacy Protection Act, or the DPPA, entitled Janice Cook, et al. v. ACS State Local Solutions, et al.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P10_S1	Plaintiffs brought the action on their own behalf and on behalf of all similarly situated individuals whose personal information is contained in any motor vehicle record maintained by the State of Missouri and who have not provided express consent to the State of Missouri for the distribution of their personal information for purposes not enumerated by the DPPA and whose personal information has been knowingly obtained and used by the defendants.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P10_S2	The class complaint alleged that the defendants knowingly obtained personal information for a purpose not authorized by the DPPA and sought liquidated damages in the amount of two thousand five hundred dollars for each instance of a violation of the DPPA, punitive damages and the destruction of any illegally obtained personal information.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P10_S3	The court granted iiX s motion to dismiss the complaint based on a failure to state a claim on November 19, 2010.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P11_S0	Plaintiffs filed a notice of appeal on December 17, 2010 and oral argument was heard by the Eighth Circuit on September 18, 2011.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P11_S1	The Eighth Circuit affirmed the District Court s dismissal on December 15, 2011.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P12_S0	In September 2009, our subsidiary, Interthinx, Inc., was served with a putative class action entitled Renata Gluzman v. Interthinx, Inc .
1442145_12_ITEM3_P12_S1	The plaintiff, a former Interthinx employee, filed the class action on August 13, 2009 in the Superior Court of the State of California, County of Los Angeles on behalf of all Interthinx information technology employees for unpaid overtime and missed meals and rest breaks, as well as various related claims claiming that the information technology employees were misclassified as exempt employees and, as a result, were denied certain wages and benefits that would have been received if they were properly classified as non-exempt employees.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P13_S0	The complaint sought compensatory damages, penalties that are associated with the various statutes, restitution, interest costs, and attorney fees.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P13_S1	On June 2, 2010, plaintiffs agreed to settle their claims with Interthinx and the court granted final approval to the settlement on February 23, 2011.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P13_S2	The terms of the settlement were not considered material to us.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P14_S0	We have received notice of a complaint filed on February 7, 2012 in the Florida State Circuit Court for Pasco County naming Citizens Property Insurance Corporation ( Citizens ) and the Company s Xactware subsidiary.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P14_S1	The complaint does not seek monetary relief against Xactware.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P14_S2	It alleges a class action seeking declaratory relief against defendants and is brought on behalf of all individuals who have purchased a new or renewed a property casualty insurance policy from Citizens where Citizens used an Xactware product to determine replacement value of the property.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P14_S3	The complaint has not yet been served on Xactware.
1442145_12_ITEM3_P14_S4	At this time, it is not possible to determine the ultimate resolution of or estimate the liability related to this matter.
1442145_12_ITEM5_P0_S0	Market Information Verisk trades under the ticker symbol VRSK on the NASDAQ Global Select Market.
1442145_12_ITEM5_P0_S1	Our common stock was first publicly traded on October 7, 2009.
1442145_12_ITEM5_P0_S2	As of February 24, 2012, the closing price of our Class A common stock was $42.00 per share, as reported by the NASDAQ Global Select Market.
1442145_12_ITEM5_P0_S3	As of February 24, 2012, there were approximately 33 Class A stockholders of record.
1442145_12_ITEM5_P0_S4	We believe the number of beneficial owners is substantially greater than the number of record holders for Class A, because a large portion of Class A common stock is held in street name by brokers.
1442145_12_ITEM5_P0_S5	We converted all Class B shares to Class A shares in 2011 and currently have no outstanding Class B shares.
1442145_12_ITEM5_P0_S6	We have not paid or declared any cash dividends on our Class A, Class B-1, or Class B-2 common stock during the two most recent fiscal years and we currently do not intend to pay dividends on our Class A, Class B-1, or Class B-2 common stock.
1442145_12_ITEM5_P0_S7	We do have a publicly announced share repurchase plan and have repurchased 26,396,076 shares since our IPO.
1442145_12_ITEM5_P0_S8	As of December 31, 2011, we had 379,717,811 shares of treasury stock.

1442145_12_ITEM5_P2_S2	Each peer issuer was weighted according to its respective market capitalization on October 7, 2009.

The consolidated statement of operations data for the years ended December 31, 2008 and 2007 and the consolidated balance sheet data as of December 31, 2009, 2008 and 2007 are derived from audited consolidated financial statements that are not included in this annual report on Form 10-K. Results for the year ended December 31, 2011 are not necessarily indicative of results that may be expected in any other future period.
1442145_12_ITEM6_P1_S0	Between January 1, 2007 and December 31, 2011 we acquired 13 businesses, which may affect the comparability of our consolidated financial statements.
1442145_12_ITEM6_P2_S0	The financial operating data below sets forth the information we believe is useful for investors in evaluating our overall financial performance: The following table sets forth our consolidated balance sheet data as of December 31:
