1442145_12_ITEM6_P4_S0	During the third quarter of 2010, we reevaluated the probability of TierMed achieving the specified predetermined EBITDA and revenue targets and reversed its contingent consideration related to this acquisition.
1442145_12_ITEM6_P5_S0	(3) In conjunction with the IPO, the stock of Insurance Services Office, Inc. converted to stock of Verisk Analytics, Inc, which effected a fifty-to-one stock split of its common stock.
1442145_12_ITEM6_P5_S1	The numbers in the above table reflect this stock split.
1442145_12_ITEM6_P6_S0	(4) EBITDA is the financial measure, which management uses to evaluate the performance of our segments.
1442145_12_ITEM6_P6_S1	EBITDA is defined as net income before investment income and realized (gain)/loss on securities, net, interest expense, provision for income taxes, depreciation and amortization of fixed and intangible assets.
1442145_12_ITEM6_P6_S2	Beginning in 2011 our EBITDA includes acquisition related liability adjustments for all periods presented.
1442145_12_ITEM6_P6_S3	In addition, this Management s Discussion and Analysis includes references to EBITDA margin, which is computed as EBITDA divided by revenues.
1442145_12_ITEM6_P6_S4	See Note 18 of our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K.
1442145_12_ITEM6_P7_S0	Although EBITDA is a non-GAAP financial measure, EBITDA is frequently used by securities analysts, lenders and others in their evaluation of companies, EBITDA has limitations as an analytical tool, and should not be considered in isolation, or as a substitute for an analysis of our results of operations or cash flow from operating activities reported under GAAP.
1442145_12_ITEM6_P7_S1	Management uses EBITDA in conjunction with traditional GAAP operating performance measures as part of its overall assessment of company performance.
1442145_12_ITEM6_P8_S0	Other companies in our industry may calculate EBITDA differently than we do, limiting its usefulness as a comparative measure.
1442145_12_ITEM6_P9_S0	(6) Prior to our corporate reorganization, we were required to record our Class A common stock and vested options at redemption value at each balance sheet date as the redemption of these securities was not solely within our control, due to our contractual obligations to redeem these shares.
1442145_12_ITEM6_P9_S1	We classified this redemption value as redeemable common stock.
1442145_12_ITEM6_P9_S2	After our IPO, we were no longer obligated to redeem these shares and therefore we reversed the redeemable common stock balance.
1442145_12_ITEM6_P9_S3	See Note 14 to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K for further information.
1442145_12_ITEM6_P10_S0	(7) Subsequent to our corporate reorganization, share repurchases are recorded as treasury stock within stockholders deficit, as we intend to reissue shares from treasury stock in the future.
1442145_12_ITEM6_P10_S1	For the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2010, we repurchased $380.7 million and $422.3 million, respectively, of treasury stock.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P0_S0	The following discussion should be read in conjunction with our historical financial statements and the related notes included elsewhere in this annual report on Form 10-K, as well as the discussion under Selected Consolidated Financial Data.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P1_S0	This discussion contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P1_S1	Our actual results may differ materially from those discussed in or implied by any of the forward-looking statements as a result of various factors, including but not limited to those listed under Risk Factors and Special Note Regarding Forward-Looking Statements.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P2_S0	We enable risk-bearing businesses to better understand and manage their risks.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P2_S1	We provide value to our customers by supplying proprietary data that, combined with our analytic methods, creates embedded decision support solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P2_S2	We are the largest aggregator and provider of data pertaining to U.S. property and casualty, or P C, insurance risks.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P2_S3	We offer solutions for detecting fraud in the U.S. P C insurance, mortgage and healthcare industries and sophisticated methods to predict and quantify loss in diverse contexts ranging from natural catastrophes to supply chain to health insurance.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P2_S4	Our customers use our solutions to make better risk decisions with greater efficiency and discipline.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P2_S5	We refer to these products and services as solutions due to the integration among our products and the flexibility that enables our customers to purchase components or the comprehensive package of products.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P2_S6	These solutions take various forms, including data, statistical models or tailored analytics, all designed to allow our clients to make more logical decisions.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P2_S7	We believe our solutions for analyzing risk positively impact our customers revenues and help them better manage their costs.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P3_S0	On May 23, 2008, in contemplation of our IPO, Insurance Service Office, Inc., or ISO, formed Verisk Analytics, Inc., or Verisk, a Delaware corporation, to be the holding company for our business.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P3_S1	Verisk was initially formed as a wholly-owned subsidiary of ISO.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P3_S2	On October 6, 2009 in connection with our IPO, we effected a reorganization whereby ISO became a wholly-owned subsidiary of Verisk.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P3_S3	On October 1, 2010, we completed a follow-on public offering.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P3_S4	We did not receive any proceeds from the sale of common stock in the offering.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P4_S0	The primary purpose of the offering was to manage and organize the sale by Class B insurance company shareholders while providing incremental public float.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P4_S1	Concurrently with the closing of the offering, we repurchased shares of common stock, for an aggregate purchase price of $192.5 million, directly from selling shareholders owning Class B common stock.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P4_S2	We converted all Class B shares to Class A shares in 2011 and currently have no outstanding Class B shares.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P4_S3	We organize our business in two segments: Risk Assessment and Decision Analytics.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P5_S0	Our Risk Assessment segment provides statistical, actuarial and underwriting data for the U.S. P C insurance industry.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P5_S1	Our Risk Assessment segment revenues represented approximately 42.3 % and 47.6% of our revenues for the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P6_S0	Our Decision Analytics segment provides solutions our customers use to analyze the processes of the Verisk Risk Analysis Framework: Prediction of Loss, Detection and Prevention of Fraud, and Quantification of Loss.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P6_S1	Effective December 31, 2011, we realigned the revenue categories within Decision Analytics segment, including fraud identification and detection solutions, loss prediction solutions and loss quantification solutions, into four vertical market-related groupings of insurance, mortgage and financial services, healthcare, and specialized markets.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P6_S2	We believe that this enhances financial reporting transparency and helps investors better understand the themes within the Decision Analytics segment.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P6_S3	Our Decision Analytics segment revenues represented approximately 57.7% and 52.4% of our revenues for the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P6_S4	We believe our business s ability to generate recurring revenue and positive cash flow is the key indicator of the successful execution of our business strategy.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P7_S0	as metrics to measure our performance.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P7_S1	EBITDA and EBITDA margin are non-GAAP financial measures (see Note 4.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P7_S2	Selected Financial Data section of Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations).
1442145_12_ITEM7_P8_S0	We use year over year revenue growth as a key performance metric.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P8_S1	We assess revenue growth based on our ability to generate increased revenue through increased sales to existing customers, sales to new customers, sales of new or expanded solutions to existing and new customers and strategic acquisitions of new businesses.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P8_S2	We use EBITDA margin as a metric to assess segment performance and scalability of our business.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P9_S0	We assess EBITDA margin based on our ability to increase revenues while controlling expense growth.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P9_S1	Revenues We earn revenues through subscriptions, long-term agreements and on a transactional basis.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P9_S2	Subscriptions for our solutions are generally paid in advance of rendering services either quarterly or in full upon commencement of the subscription period, which is usually for one year and automatically renewed each year.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P9_S3	As a result, the timing of our cash flows generally precedes our recognition of revenues and income and our cash flow from operations tends to be higher in the first quarter as we receive subscription payments.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P9_S4	Examples of these arrangements include subscriptions that allow our customers to access our standardized coverage language, our claims fraud database or our actuarial services throughout the subscription period.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P10_S0	In general, we experience minimal revenue seasonality within the business.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P10_S1	Our long-term agreements are generally for periods of three to seven years.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P10_S2	We recognize revenue from subscriptions ratably over the term of the subscription and most long-term agreements are recognized ratably over the term of the agreement.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P10_S3	Certain of our solutions are also paid for by our customers on a transactional basis.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P10_S4	For example, we have solutions that allow our customers to access fraud detection tools in the context of an individual mortgage application or loan, obtain property-specific rating and underwriting information to price a policy on a commercial building, or compare a P C insurance, medical or workers compensation claim with information in our databases.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P10_S5	For the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2010, 31.1% and 30.2% of our revenues, respectively, were derived from providing transactional solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P10_S6	We earn transactional revenues as our solutions are delivered or services performed.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P10_S7	In general, transactions are billed monthly at the end of each month.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P10_S8	Approximately 85.7% and 84.0% of the revenues in our Risk Assessment segment for the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively, were derived from subscriptions and long-term agreements for our solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P10_S9	Our customers in this segment include most of the P C insurance providers in the United States.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P10_S10	Approximately 56.6% and 56.8% of the revenues in our Decision Analytics segment, for the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively, were derived from subscriptions and long-term agreements for our solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P10_S11	Principal Operating Costs and Expenses Personnel expenses are the major component of both our cost of revenues and selling, general and administrative expenses.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P10_S12	Personnel expenses include salaries, benefits, incentive compensation, equity compensation costs (described under Equity Compensation Costs below), sales commissions, employment taxes, recruiting costs, and outsourced temporary agency costs, which represented 65.3% and 65.4% of our total expenses for the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P10_S13	We allocate personnel expenses between two categories, cost of revenues and selling, general and administrative costs, based on the actual costs associated with each employee.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P11_S0	marketing, business development, finance, legal, human resources, and administrative services, as selling, general and administrative expenses.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P11_S1	A significant portion of our other operating costs, such as facilities and communications, are also either captured within cost of revenues or selling, general and administrative expense based on the nature of the work being performed.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P11_S2	While we expect to grow our headcount over time to take advantage of our market opportunities, we believe that the economies of scale in our operating model will allow us to grow our personnel expenses at a lower rate than revenues.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P11_S3	Historically, our EBITDA margin has improved because we have been able to increase revenues without a proportionate corresponding increase in expenses.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P11_S4	Our cost of revenues consists primarily of personnel expenses.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P11_S5	Cost of revenues also includes the expenses associated with the acquisition and verification of data, the maintenance of our existing solutions and the development and enhancement of our next-generation solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P11_S6	Our cost of revenues excludes depreciation and amortization.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P11_S7	Our selling, general and administrative expense also consists primarily of personnel costs.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P11_S8	A portion of the other operating costs such as facilities, insurance and communications are also allocated to selling, general and administrative costs based on the nature of the work being performed by the employee.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P11_S9	Our selling, general and administrative expenses excludes depreciation and amortization.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P11_S10	Description of Acquisitions We acquired eight businesses since January 1, 2009.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P11_S11	As a result of these acquisitions, our consolidated results of operations may not be comparable between periods.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P12_S0	On June 17, 2011, we acquired the net assets of Health Risk Partners, LLC, or HRP, a provider of solutions to optimize revenue, ensure compliance and improve quality of care for Medicare Advantage and Medicaid health plans.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P12_S1	Within our Decision Analytics segment, this acquisition further advances our position as a major provider of data, analytics, and decision-support solutions to the healthcare industry.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P12_S2	See Note 10 to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K for the preliminary purchase allocation.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P13_S0	On April 27, 2011, we acquired 100% of the common stock of Bloodhound Technologies, Inc. or Bloodhound, a provider of real-time pre-adjudication medical claims editing.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P13_S1	Within our Decision Analytics segment, Bloodhound addresses the need of healthcare payers to control fraud and waste in a real-time claims-processing environment, and these capabilities align with our existing fraud identification tools.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P14_S0	See Note 10 to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K for the preliminary purchase allocation.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P15_S0	On December 16, 2010, we acquired 100% of the common stock of 3E Company, or 3E, a global source for a comprehensive suite of environmental health and safety compliance solutions .Within our Decision Analytics segment, we believe that 3E s platform is consistent with our historical expertise in regulatory and compliance matters.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P15_S1	On December 14, 2010, we acquired 100% of the common stock of Crowe Paradis Services Corporation, or CP, a leading provider of claims analysis and compliance solutions to the property/casualty insurance industry.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P15_S2	Within our Decision Analytics segment, CP offers solutions for complying with the Medicare Secondary Payer (MSP) Act, provides services to many of the largest worker s compensation insurers, third-party administrators (TPAs), and self-insured companies which enhances solutions we currently offer.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P16_S0	On February 26, 2010, we acquired 100% of the common stock of Strategic Analytics, Inc., or SA, a privately owned provider of credit risk and capital management solutions to consumer and mortgage lenders.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P16_S1	Within our Decision Analytics segment, SA s solutions and application set will allow our customers to take advantage of state-of-the-art loss forecasting, stress testing, and economic capital requirement tools to better understand and forecast the risk associated within their credit portfolios.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P17_S0	On October 30, 2009, we acquired the net assets of Enabl-u Technology Corporation, Inc, or Enabl-u, a privately owned provider of data management, training and communication solutions to companies with regional, national or global work forces.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P17_S1	We believe this acquisition will enhance our ability to provide solutions for customers to measure loss prevention and improve asset management through the use of software and software services.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P18_S0	On July 24, 2009, we acquired the net assets of TierMed Systems, LLC, or TierMed, a privately owned provider of Healthcare Effectiveness Data and Information Set, or HEDIS, solutions to healthcare organizations that have HEDIS or quality-reporting needs.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P18_S1	We believe this acquisition will enhance our ability to provide solutions for customers to measure and improve healthcare quality and financial performance through the use of software and software services.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P19_S0	On January 14, 2009, we acquired 100% of the stock of D2 Hawkeye, Inc., or D2, a privately-owned provider of data mining, decision support, clinical quality analysis, and risk analysis tools for the healthcare industry.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P19_S1	We believe this acquisition will enhance our position in the healthcare analytics and predictive modeling market by providing new market, cross-sell, and diversification opportunities for the Company s expanding healthcare solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P20_S0	Equity Compensation Costs We have a leveraged ESOP, funded with intercompany debt that includes 401(k), ESOP and profit sharing components to provide employees with equity participation.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P20_S1	We make quarterly cash contributions to the plan equal to the debt service requirements.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P20_S2	As the debt is repaid, shares are released to the ESOP to fund 401(k) matching and profit sharing contributions and the remainder is allocated annually to active employees in proportion to their eligible compensation in relation to total participants eligible compensation.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P21_S0	We accrue compensation expense over the reporting period equal to the fair value of the shares to be released to the ESOP.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P21_S1	Depending on the number of shares released to the plan during the quarter and the fluctuation in the fair value of the shares, a corresponding increase or decrease in compensation expense will occur.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P21_S2	The amount of our equity compensation costs recognized for the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009 are as follows:
1442145_12_ITEM7_P22_S0	In connection with our IPO, on October 6, 2009, we accelerated our future ESOP allocation contribution through the end of the ESOP in 2013, to all participants eligible for a contribution in 2009.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P22_S1	This resulted in a non-recurring, non-cash charge of approximately $57.7 million in the fourth quarter of 2009.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P22_S2	As a result, subsequent to the offering, the non-cash ESOP allocation expense was substantially reduced.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P22_S3	Excluding the ESOP allocation, expense relating specifically to our 401(k) and profit sharing plans were $12.6 million, $11.6 million and $8.7 million for the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P22_S4	In addition, the portion of the ESOP allocation expense related to the appreciation of the value of the shares in the ESOP above the value of those shares when the ESOP was first established is not tax deductible.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P23_S0	Prior to our IPO, our Class A stock and vested stock options were recorded within redeemable common stock at full redemption value at each balance sheet date, as the redemption of these securities was not solely within the control of the Company (see Note 14 of our consolidated financial statements).
1442145_12_ITEM7_P23_S1	Effective with the corporate reorganization that occurred on October 6, 2009, we are no longer obligated to redeem Class A stock and therefore are not required to present our Class A stock and vested stock options at redemption value.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P23_S2	Our financial results for the fourth quarter of 2009 reflect a reversal of the redeemable common stock.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P23_S3	The reversal of the redeemable common stock of $1,064.9 million on October 6, 2009 resulted in the elimination of accumulated deficit of $440.6 million, an increase of $0.1 million to Class A common stock at par value, an increase of $624.3 million to additional paid-in-capital, and a reclassification of the ISO Class A unearned common stock KSOP shares balance of $1.3 million to unearned KSOP contribution.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P24_S0	See Note 14 in our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K. 1442145_12_ITEM7_P25_S0	In 2011 and in 2010, we acquired five companies, HRP, Bloodhound, CP, 3E, and SA, collectively referred to as recent acquisitions, which we define as acquisitions not owned for a significant portion of both the current period and/or prior period and would therefore impact the comparability of the financial results.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P25_S1	Recent acquisitions were within our Decision Analytics segment and provided an increase of $106.9 million in revenues for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P25_S2	Excluding recent acquisitions, revenues increased $86.6 million, which included an increase in our Risk Assessment segment of $21.2 million and an increase in our Decision Analytics segment of $65.4 million.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P25_S3	Refer to the Results of Operations by Segment within this section for further information regarding our revenues.

1442145_12_ITEM7_P25_S5	Recent acquisitions caused an increase of $46.6 million in cost for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P25_S6	Excluding the impact of our recent acquisitions, our cost of revenues increased $23.6 million or 5.1%.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P25_S7	The increase was primarily due to increases in salaries and employee benefits cost of $16.6 million.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P25_S8	Other increases include leased software expenses of $3.4 million, travel and travel related costs of $1.3 million, office maintenance expense of $0.4 million and other operating costs of $4.1 million.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P25_S9	These increases in costs were partially offset by a $2.2 million decrease in data costs primarily within in our Decision Analytics segment.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P25_S10	The increase in salaries and employee benefits of $16.6 million includes an increase of $19.4 million in annual salaries and employee benefits such as medical costs and equity incentive plan, and was partially offset by a decrease of $2.8 million in pension costs.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P25_S11	The pension cost decreased primarily due to the partial recovery in 2010 of the fair value of our pension investments.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P26_S0	Selling, General and Administrative Expenses Selling, general and administrative expenses, or SGA, were $209.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 compared to $166.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2010, an increase of $43.1 million or 25.9%.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P26_S1	Excluding costs associated with our recent acquisitions of $31.6 million, SGA increased $11.5 million or 7.0%.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P26_S2	The increase was primarily due to an increase in salaries and employee benefits of $8.8 million which includes annual salary increases, medical costs, commissions, and equity compensation.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P26_S3	Other increases were cost related to travel and travel related items of $1.1 million, rent and maintenance of $0.4 million and other general expenses of $1.2 million.

1442145_12_ITEM7_P27_S0	Depreciation and amortization of fixed assets includes depreciation of furniture and equipment, software, computer hardware, and related equipment.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P27_S1	The majority of the increase relates to software and hardware costs to support data capacity expansion and revenue growth.

1442145_12_ITEM7_P27_S3	The increase was primarily related to amortization of intangible assets associated with recent acquisitions of $13.4 million, partially offset by $6.0 million of amortization of intangible assets associated with prior acquisitions that have been fully amortized.

1442145_12_ITEM7_P27_S5	This benefit was a result of a reduction of $3.4 million to contingent consideration due to the reduced probability of the D2 and SA acquisitions achieving the EBITDA and revenue earnout targets for exceptional performance in fiscal year 2011 established at the time of acquisition.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P27_S6	In 2010, we reevaluated the probability of TierMed achieving the specified predetermined EBITDA and revenue targets and reversed $0.5 million of contingent consideration related to this acquisition.

1442145_12_ITEM7_P30_S6	These increases were partially offset by a decrease in our mortgage and financial services of $3.7 million, excluding recent acquisitions, primarily due to lower volumes within our underwriting and forensic solutions due to the continued challenges within the mortgage market.

1442145_12_ITEM7_P40_S2	This decrease was primarily due to reduced interest costs as a result of a decrease in average debt outstanding of approximately $605 million in 2010 compared to approximately $650 million in 2009, coupled with a decrease in our interest rate on borrowings from our syndicated revolving credit facility from LIBOR plus 2.50% to LIBOR plus 1.75%.

1442145_12_ITEM7_P43_S7	Our revenue by category for the periods presented is set forth below: Cost of Revenues Cost of revenues for our Decision Analytics segment was $268.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2010 compared to $260.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2009, an increase of $8.0 million or 3.0%.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P43_S8	Excluding the impact of the accelerated ESOP allocation in 2009 of $22.2 million and costs associated with recent acquisitions of $6.4 million, our cost of revenues increased by $23.8 million or 10.0%.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P43_S9	This increase is primarily due to an increase in salary and employee benefits of $20.0 million; data and consultant costs of $3.1 million incurred primarily related to the revenue growth in our fraud identification and detection solutions; other general expenses of $1.0 million; and office maintenance expense of $0.2 million offset by a $0.5 million increase in state employment tax credit.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P44_S0	The increase in salaries and employee benefits of $20.0 million includes $21.2 million increase in salaries and employee benefit costs, medical expense, and long-term incentive plans, including the IPO stock option grant; and is partially offset by decreases in pension of $1.2 million.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P44_S1	The increase in salaries and benefit costs is related to a modest increase in employee headcount relative to the 18.5% revenue growth in our Decision Analytic revenues.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P44_S2	Selling, General and Administrative Expenses Selling, general and administrative expenses for our Decision Analytics segment were $87.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2010 compared to $80.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2009, an increase of $7.3 million or 9.2%.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P44_S3	Excluding the impact of the accelerated ESOP allocation in 2009 of $6.7 million and cost associated with recent acquisitions of $4.8 million, SGA increased $9.2 million or 12.5%.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P44_S4	The increase was primarily due to an increase in salaries and employee benefits of $8.3 million, which includes annual salary increases, medical costs, commissions, and long-term incentive plan.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P44_S5	Other increases were costs related to advertising and marketing of $2.4 million and an increase in other general expenses of $0.8 million.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P44_S6	These increases were partially offset by a decrease in legal costs primarily related to our IPO of $1.9 million and decreased pension cost of $0.4 million.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P45_S0	The EBITDA margin for our Decision Analytics segment was 40.4% for the year ended December 31, 2010 compared to 32.3% for the year ended December 31, 2009.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P45_S1	The impact of the accelerated ESOP allocation of $28.9 million in 2009 negatively affected our margin by approximately 5.8%.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P45_S2	In addition, included in our 2009 EBITDA margin are IPO related costs of $3.0 million, which negatively impacted our margin by 0.6%.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P45_S3	Risk Assessment Revenues Revenues were $542.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2010 as compared to $524.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2009, an increase of $18.1 million or 3.5%.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P45_S4	The overall increase within this segment primarily resulted from an increase in prices derived from continued enhancements to the content of our industry-standard insurance programs solutions and the addition of new customers.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P45_S5	The increase of $5.0 million or 3.8% within property-specific rating and underwriting information revenues is due partially to growth in property appraisal solutions and community rating services.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P45_S6	Our revenue by category for the periods presented is set forth below: Cost of Revenues Cost of revenues for our Risk Assessment segment was $194.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2010 compared to $230.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2009, a decrease of $35.8 million or 15.5%.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P46_S0	This decrease was primarily due to decrease in salaries and employee benefits costs of $3.1 million, a $2.2 million increase in state employment tax credit, office maintenance expense of $1.1 million and $0.7 million of other general expenses.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P46_S1	These decreases were partially offset by an increase in data and consultant costs of $1.0 million incurred primarily in connection with the revenues from our property-specific rating and underwriting information solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P46_S2	The decrease in salaries and employee benefits of $3.1 million includes $6.5 million reduction in pension costs and was partially offset by an increase of $3.4 million in salary and employee benefit costs, which include annual salary increases and long-term incentive plans across a relatively constant employee headcount.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P47_S0	Selling, General and Administrative Selling, general and administrative expenses for our Risk Assessment segment were $79.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2010 compared to $82.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2009, a decrease of $3.5 million or 4.3%.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P47_S1	Excluding the impact of the accelerated ESOP allocation in 2009 of $8.7 million, SGA increased $5.2 million or 7.0%.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P47_S2	The increase was primarily due to an increase in salaries and employee benefits of $6.1 million, which includes annual salary increases, medical costs, commissions, and long-term incentive plan expense and an increase in other general expenses of $1.4 million.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P47_S3	These increases were partially offset by a decrease in pension cost of $1.4 million and decrease in legal costs primarily related to our IPO in 2009 of $0.9 million.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P48_S0	The EBITDA margin for our Risk Assessment segment was 49.5% for the year ended December 31, 2010 compared to 40.3% for the year ended December 31, 2009.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P48_S1	The impact of the accelerated ESOP allocation of $38.4 million in 2009 negatively affected our margin by approximately 7.3%.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P48_S2	In addition, included in our 2009 EBITDA margin are costs of $4.0 million associated with the preparation of our IPO for the year ended December 31, 2009, which negatively impacted our margin of 0.8%.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P48_S3	For our 2010 EBITDA margin, decreased pension costs of $7.9 million positively impacted our margin by approximately 1.5%.

1442145_12_ITEM7_P51_S0	Liquidity and Capital Resources As of December 31, 2011 and 2010, we had cash and cash equivalents and available-for-sale securities of $196.7 million and $60.6 million, respectively.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P52_S0	advance of rendering services either quarterly or in full upon commencement of the subscription period, which is usually for one year.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P52_S1	Subscriptions are automatically renewed at the beginning of each calendar year.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P53_S0	We have historically generated significant cash flows from operations.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P53_S1	As a result of this factor, as well as the availability of funds under our syndicated revolving credit facility, we believe we will have sufficient cash to meet our working capital and capital expenditure needs, and to fuel our future growth plans.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P54_S0	We have historically managed the business with a working capital deficit due to the fact that, as described above, we offer our solutions and services primarily through annual subscriptions or long-term contracts, which are generally prepaid quarterly or annually in advance of the services being rendered.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P55_S0	When cash is received for prepayment of invoices, we record an asset (cash and cash equivalents) on our balance sheet with the offset recorded as a current liability (fees received in advance).
1442145_12_ITEM7_P55_S1	This current liability is deferred revenue that does not require a direct cash outflow since our customers have prepaid and are obligated to purchase the services.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P56_S0	In most businesses, growth in revenue typically leads to an increase in the accounts receivable balance causing a use of cash as a company grows.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P56_S1	Unlike these businesses, our cash position is favorably affected by revenue growth, which results in a source of cash due to our customers prepaying for most of our services.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P56_S2	Our capital expenditures, which include non-cash purchases of fixed assets and capital lease obligations, as a percentage of revenues for the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2010, were 5.1% and 3.6%, respectively.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P56_S3	We estimate our capital expenditures for 2012 will be approximately $75.0 million, which primarily include expenditures on our technology infrastructure and our continuing investments in developing and enhancing our solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P56_S4	Expenditures related to developing and enhancing our solutions are predominately related to internal use software and are capitalized in accordance with ASC 350-40, Accounting for Costs of Computer Software Developed or Obtained for Internal Use.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P56_S5	We also capitalize amounts in accordance with ASC 985-20, Software to be Sold, Leased or Otherwise Marketed .
1442145_12_ITEM7_P56_S6	We have also historically used a portion of our cash for repurchases of our common stock from our stockholders.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P56_S7	For the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009 we repurchased $380.7 million, $422.3 million and redeemed $46.7 million, respectively, of our common stock.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P56_S8	Included in the 2010 share repurchases are repurchases of $209.8 million of Class B, including $199.9 million and $9.9 million of Verisk Class B-1 and Class B-2, respectively, which were not a part of the Repurchase Program.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P57_S0	A portion of the share redemptions in 2009 included in the total above was completed pursuant to the terms of the Insurance Service Office, Inc. 1996 Incentive Plan, or the Option Plan.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P58_S0	We provide pension and postretirement benefits to certain qualifying active employees and retirees.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P58_S1	On January 12, 2012, we announced a hard freeze, which will eliminate all future compensation and service credits, to be instituted on February 29, 2012 to all participants in the pension plans.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P58_S2	Based on the pension funding policy, we are required to contribute a minimum of approximately $28.9 million to the pension plans in 2012.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P58_S3	In addition, we are contemplating a voluntary prefunding to our qualified pension plan of an amount between $70.0 million and $90.0 million, which may occur in the first half of 2012.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P59_S0	Under the postretirement plan, we provide certain healthcare and life insurance benefits to qualifying participants; however, participants are required to pay a stated percentage of the premium coverage.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P59_S1	We expect to contribute approximately $3.4 million to the postretirement plan in 2012.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P59_S2	We had total debt, excluding capital lease and other obligations, of $1,096.7 million and $835.0 million at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P59_S3	The debt at December 31, 2011 is issued under long-term private placement loan facilities and senior notes issued in 2011 to finance our stock repurchases and acquisitions.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P59_S4	On April 6, 2011, we completed an issuance of senior notes in the aggregate principal amount of $450.0 million.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P59_S5	These senior notes are due on May 1, 2021 and accrue interest at a rate of 5.800%.

1442145_12_ITEM7_P60_S8	The senior notes are fully and unconditionally guaranteed, jointly and severally, on an unsecured and unsubordinated basis by ISO and certain subsidiaries that guarantee our syndicated revolving credit facility, ( credit facility ), or any amendment, refinancing or replacement thereof .
1442145_12_ITEM7_P60_S9	We expect to redraw from our credit facility over time as needed for our corporate strategy, including for general corporate purposes and acquisitions.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P60_S10	The indenture governing the senior notes restricts our ability and our subsidiaries ability to, among other things, create certain liens, enter into sale/leaseback transactions and consolidate with, sell, lease, convey or otherwise transfer all or substantially all of our assets, or merge with or into, any other person or entity.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P61_S0	As of December 31, 2011, our $725.0 million syndicated revolving credit facility due October 2016, is a committed facility and all of our long-term private placement loan facilities are uncommitted facilities.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P61_S1	We have financed and expect to finance our short-term working capital needs, stock repurchases and acquisition contingent payments through cash from operations and borrowings from a combination of our credit facility and long-term private placement facilities.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P61_S2	We had borrowings of $310.0 million from our credit facility outstanding as of December 31, 2010.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P61_S3	On April 8, 2011 and December 8, 2011, we repaid $295.0 million and $145.0 million respectively, of our outstanding borrowings from the credit facility from proceeds of our senior notes discussed above.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P61_S4	As of December 31, 2011, our credit facility had no outstanding borrowings and $725.0 million of borrowing capacity was available.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P62_S0	The credit facility contains certain customary financial and other covenants that, among other things, impose certain restrictions on indebtedness, liens, investments, and capital expenditures.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P62_S1	These covenants also place restrictions on mergers, asset sales, sale/leaseback transactions, payments between us and our subsidiaries, and certain transactions with affiliates.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P62_S2	The financial covenants require that, at the end of any fiscal quarter, we have a consolidated interest coverage ratio of at least 3.0 to 1.0 and that during any period of four fiscal quarters, we maintain a consolidated funded debt leverage ratio below 3.25 to 1.0.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P62_S3	We were in compliance with all debt covenants under the credit facility as of December 31, 2011.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P62_S4	Our credit facility at December 31, 2010 totaled $575.0 million and on March 16, 2011, The Northern Trust Company joined the credit facility to increase the capacity from $575.0 million to $600.0 million.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P62_S5	On March 28, 2011, we entered into amendments to our credit facility and our master shelf agreements to, among other things permit the issuance of the senior notes and guarantees noted above.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P62_S6	On October 25, 2011, we amended and restated the credit facility to increase the capacity from $600.0 million to $700.0 million, extended the credit facility through October 24, 2016 and named ISO and Verisk as co-borrowers.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P62_S7	The amended credit agreement also resulted in a decrease in the applicable interest rates.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P62_S8	The interest rates for borrowing under the amended credit agreement will now be the applicable LIBOR plus 1.250% to 1.875%, depending upon the result of certain ratios defined in the amended credit agreement.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P62_S9	On November 14, 2011, TD Bank joined the credit facility to increase the capacity from $700.0 million to $725.0 million.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P62_S10	We paid a one-time commitment fee, which will be amortized over a five year period, which is consistent with the remaining life of the credit facility.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P62_S11	We also have long-term private placement loan facilities under uncommitted master shelf agreements with New York Life and Prudential Capital Group, or Prudential.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P63_S0	On August 8, 2011, we repaid our $25.0 million Prudential Series F notes and $50.0 million Principal Series A notes.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P63_S1	As of December 31, 2011, we had available capacity of $30.0 million and $190.0 million with New York Life and Prudential, respectively.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P63_S2	The master shelf agreement with Aviva Investors North America expired on December 10, 2011 and we did not extend the agreement.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P63_S3	The notes outstanding under these long-term private placement loan facilities mature over the next five years.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P64_S0	Individual borrowings are made at a fixed rate of interest determined at the time of the borrowing and interest is payable quarterly.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P64_S1	The weighted average rate of interest with respect to our outstanding borrowings under these facilities was 5.76% and 6.07% for the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively and amounts outstanding were $8.6 and $4.6 million, respectively.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P65_S0	The uncommitted master shelf agreements contain certain covenants that limit our ability to create liens, enter into sale/leaseback transactions and consolidate, merge or sell assets to another company.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P65_S1	Our shelf agreements also contains financial covenants that require that, at the end of any fiscal quarter, we have a consolidated interest coverage ratio of at least 3.0 to 1.0 and a leverage ratio below 3.0 to 1.0 at the end of any fiscal quarter.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P65_S2	We were in compliance with all debt covenants under our master shelf agreements as of December 31, 2011.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P65_S3	The following table summarizes our cash flow data for the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009:
1442145_12_ITEM7_P66_S0	Operating Activities Net cash provided by operating activities increased to $375.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 compared to $336.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P66_S1	The increase in operating activities was primarily due to an increase in cash receipts from customers, partially offset by an increase in operating expense and tax payments during the year ended December 31, 2011.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P66_S2	Increased pension contributions of $6.0 million in 2011 mitigated the growth in our operating cash flow during the year ended December 31, 2011.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P66_S3	Net cash provided by operating activities increased to $336.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2010 compared to $326.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2009.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P66_S4	The increase in operating activities was primarily due to an increase in cash receipts from customers and a reduction in interest payments, partially offset by an increase in operating expense and tax payments during the year ended December 31, 2010.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P66_S5	Increased pension contributions of $15.0 million in 2010, as well as the timing of certain annual bonus payments, mitigated the growth in our operating cash flow during the year ended December 31, 2010.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P66_S6	Investing Activities Net cash used in investing activities was $204.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 and $243.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P66_S7	The decrease in cash used in investing activities was primarily due to a decrease in acquisitions, including escrow funding and earnout payments, of $60.8 million partially offset by an increase in fixed assets purchases of $21.2 million.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P66_S8	Net cash used in investing activities was $243.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2010 and $185.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2009.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P66_S9	The increase in cash used in investing activities was primarily due to an increase in acquisitions, including escrow funding, of $136.6 million partially offset by a decrease in earnout payments of $78.1 million.

1442145_12_ITEM7_P72_S0	The preparation of these financial statements require management to make estimates and judgments that affect reported amounts of assets and liabilities and related disclosures of contingent assets and liabilities at the dates of the financial statements and revenue and expenses during the reporting periods.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P72_S1	These estimates are based on historical experience and on other assumptions that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P72_S2	On an ongoing basis, management evaluates its estimates, including those related to revenue recognition, goodwill and intangible assets, pension and other post retirement benefits, stock based compensation, and income taxes.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P72_S3	Actual results may differ from these assumptions or conditions.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P73_S0	Revenue Recognition The Company s revenues are primarily derived from sales of services and revenue is recognized as services are performed and information is delivered to our customers.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P73_S1	Revenue is recognized when persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, delivery has occurred or services have been rendered, fees and/or price are fixed or determinable and collectability is reasonably assured.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P73_S2	Revenues for subscription services are recognized ratably over the subscription term, usually one year.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P73_S3	Revenues from transaction-based fees are recognized as information is delivered to customers, assuming all other revenue recognition criteria are met.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P73_S4	The Company also has term based software licenses where the only remaining undelivered element is post-contract customer support or PCS, including unspecified upgrade rights on a when and if available basis.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P73_S5	The Company recognizes revenue for these licenses ratably over the duration of the license term.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P73_S6	The PCS associated with these arrangements is coterminous with the duration of the license term.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P73_S7	The Company also provides hosting or software solutions that provide continuous access to information and include PCS and recognizes revenue ratably over the duration of the license term.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P73_S8	In addition, the determination of certain of our services revenues requires the use of estimates, principally related to transaction volumes in instances where these volumes are reported to us by our clients on a monthly basis in arrears.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P73_S9	In these instances, we estimate transaction volumes based on average actual volumes reported by our customers in the past.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P73_S10	Differences between our estimates and actual final volumes reported are recorded in the period in which actual volumes are reported.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P73_S11	We have not experienced significant variances between our estimates of these services revenues reported to us by our customers and actual reported volumes in the past.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P73_S12	We invoice our customers in annual, quarterly, or monthly installments.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P73_S13	Amounts billed and collected in advance are recorded as fees received in advance on the balance sheet and are recognized as the services are performed and revenue recognition criteria are met.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P74_S0	The fair value of equity awards is measured on the date of grant using a Black-Scholes option-pricing model, which requires the use of several estimates, including expected term, expected risk-free interest rate, expected volatility and expected dividend yield.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P74_S1	Stock based compensation cost is measured at the grant date, based on the fair value of the awards granted, and is recognized as expense over the requisite service period.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P74_S2	Option grants and restricted stock awards are expensed ratably over the four-year vesting period.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P74_S3	We follow the substantive vesting period approach for awards granted after January 1, 2005, which requires that stock based compensation expense be recognized over the period from the date of grant to the date when the award is no longer contingent on the employee providing additional service.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P74_S4	We estimate expected forfeitures of equity awards at the date of grant and recognize compensation expense only for those awards expected to vest.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P74_S5	The forfeiture assumption is ultimately adjusted to the actual forfeiture rate.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P75_S0	Prior to our IPO, the fair value of the common stock underlying the stock based compensation was determined quarterly on or about the final day of the quarter.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P76_S0	of qualitative and quantitative factors including the nature of the business and history of the enterprise, the economic outlook in general, the condition of the specific industries in which we operate, the financial condition of the business, our ability to generate free cash flow, and goodwill or other intangible asset value.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P77_S0	Prior to our IPO, the fair value of our common stock was determined using generally accepted valuation methodologies, including the use of the guideline company method.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P77_S1	This determination of fair market value employs both a comparable company analysis, which examines the valuation multiples of public companies deemed comparable, in whole or in part, to us and a discounted cash flow analysis that determines a present value of the projected future cash flows of the business.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P78_S0	The comparable companies are comprised of a combination of public companies in the financial services information and technology businesses.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P78_S1	These methodologies have been consistently applied since 1997.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P78_S2	We regularly assess the underlying assumptions used in the valuation methodologies, including the comparable companies to be used in the analysis, the future forecasts of revenue and earnings, and the impact of market conditions on factors such as the weighted average cost of capital.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P78_S3	These assumptions are reviewed quarterly, with a more comprehensive evaluation performed annually.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P78_S4	For the comparable company analysis, the share price and financial performance of these comparables were updated quarterly based on the most recent public information.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P79_S0	Our stock price was also impacted by the number of shares outstanding.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P79_S1	As the number of shares outstanding has declined over time, our share price has increased.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P79_S2	The determination of the fair value of our common stock required us to make judgments that were complex and inherently subjective.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P79_S3	If different assumptions are used in future periods, stock based compensation expense could be materially impacted in the future.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P80_S0	Goodwill and Intangibles Goodwill represents the excess of acquisition costs over the fair value of tangible net assets and identifiable intangible assets of the businesses acquired.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P80_S1	Goodwill and intangible assets deemed to have indefinite lives are not amortized.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P80_S2	Intangible assets determined to have definite lives are amortized over their useful lives.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P80_S3	Goodwill and intangible assets with indefinite lives are subject to impairment testing annually as of June 30, or whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount may not be fully recoverable, using the guidance and criteria described in the accounting standard for Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets .
1442145_12_ITEM7_P80_S4	This testing compares carrying values to fair values and, when appropriate, the carrying value of these assets is reduced to fair value.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P81_S0	As of December 31, 2011, we had goodwill and net intangible assets of $936.4 million, which represents 60.8% of our total assets.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P81_S1	During fiscal year 2011, we performed an impairment test as of June 30, 2011 and confirmed that no impairment charge was necessary.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P82_S0	There are many assumptions and estimates used that directly impact the results of impairment testing, including an estimate of future expected revenues, earnings and cash flows, useful lives and discount rates applied to such expected cash flows in order to estimate fair value.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P82_S1	We have the ability to influence the outcome and ultimate results based on the assumptions and estimates we choose for determining the fair value of our reporting units.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P82_S2	To mitigate undue influence, we set criteria and benchmarks that are reviewed and approved by various levels of management and reviewed by other independent parties.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P83_S0	The determination of whether or not goodwill or indefinite-lived acquired intangible assets have become impaired involves a significant level of judgment in the assumptions and estimates underlying the approach used to determine the value of our reporting units.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P83_S1	Changes in our strategy or market conditions could significantly impact these judgments and require an impairment to be recorded to intangible assets and goodwill.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P83_S2	Our valuation has not indicated any impairment of our goodwill asset of $709.9 million as of December 31, 2011.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P83_S3	For the year ended December 31, 2011, there were no impairment indicators related to our intangible assets.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P84_S0	Pension and Postretirement We account for our pension and postretirement benefit plans in accordance with the accounting standard for Employers Accounting for Defined Benefit Pension and Other Postretirement Plans .
1442145_12_ITEM7_P85_S0	comprehensive income/(loss), net of tax, the gains or losses and prior service costs or credits that arise during the period but are not recognized as components of net periodic benefit cost.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P85_S1	Additional minimum pension liabilities and related intangible assets are also derecognized upon adoption of the new standard.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P86_S0	Certain assumptions are used in the determination of our annual net period benefit cost and the disclosure of the funded status of these plans.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P86_S1	The principal assumptions concern the discount rate used to measure the projected benefit obligation, the expected return on plan assets and the expected rate of future compensation increases.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P86_S2	We revise these assumptions based on an annual evaluation of long-term trends and market conditions that may have an impact on the cost of providing retirement benefits.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P86_S3	In determining the discount rate, we utilize quoted rates from long-term bond indices, and changes in long-term bond rates over the past year, cash flow models and other data sources we consider reasonable based upon the profile of the remaining service life of eligible employees.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P86_S4	As part of our evaluation, we calculate the approximate average yields on securities that were selected to match our separate projected cash flows for both the pension and postretirement plans.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P86_S5	Our separate benefit plan cash flows are input into actuarial models that include data for corporate bonds rated AA or better at the measurement date.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P86_S6	The output from the actuarial models are assessed against the prior year s discount rate and quoted rates for long-term bond indices.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P86_S7	For our pension plans at December 31, 2011, we determined this rate to be 4.98%, a decrease of 0.51% from the 5.49% rate used at December 31, 2010.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P86_S8	Our postretirement rate is 3.50% at December 31, 2011, a decrease of 0.50% from the 4.00% used at December 31, 2010.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P87_S0	The expected return on plan assets is determined by taking into consideration our analysis of our actual historical investment returns to a broader long-term forecast adjusted based on our target investment allocation, and the current economic environment.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P87_S1	Our investment guidelines target an investment portfolio allocation of 40.0% debt securities and 60.0% equity securities.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P87_S2	As of December 31, 2011, the plan assets were allocated 47.0% debt, 51.0% equity securities, and 2.0% to other investments.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P88_S0	We have used our target investment allocation to derive the expected return as we believe this allocation will be retained on an ongoing basis that will be commensurate with the projected cash flows of the plan.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P88_S1	The expected return for each investment category within our target investment allocation is developed using average historical rates of return for each targeted investment category, considering the projected cash flow of the qualified pension plan.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P88_S2	The difference between this expected return and the actual return on plan assets is generally deferred and recognized over subsequent periods through future net periodic benefit costs.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P88_S3	We believe these considerations provide the basis for reasonable assumptions with respect to the expected long-term rate of return on plan assets.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P88_S4	The rate of compensation increase is based on our long-term plans for such increases.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P88_S5	The measurement date used to determine the benefit obligation and plan assets is December 31.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P88_S6	The future benefit payments for the postretirement plan are net of the federal medical subsidy.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P89_S0	As a result of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act and the Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act of 2010, the tax treatment of federal subsidies paid to sponsors of retiree health benefit plans that provide prescription drug benefits that are at least actuarially equivalent to the corresponding benefits provided under Medicare Part D was effectively changed.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P89_S1	This legislative change reduces future tax benefits of the coverage we provided to participants in the Postretirement Plan.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P89_S2	We are required to account for this change in the period during which the law is enacted.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P89_S3	As a result, we recorded a non-cash tax charge to the provision for income taxes of $2.4 million as of December 31, 2010.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P90_S0	On January 12, 2012, we announced a hard freeze, which will eliminate all future compensation and service credits, to be instituted on February 29, 2012 to all participants in the pension plans.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P90_S1	The freeze in 2012 will reduce the unfunded pension liability by approximately $10.2 million and we will realize a curtailment gain of approximately $0.7 million.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P91_S0	A one percent change in discount rate, future rate of return on plan assets and the rate of future compensation would have the following effects: Income Taxes In projecting future taxable income, we develop assumptions including the amount of future state, federal and foreign pretax operating income, the reversal of temporary differences, and the implementation of feasible and prudent tax planning strategies.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P91_S1	These assumptions require significant judgment about the forecasts of future taxable income and are consistent with the plans and estimates we use to manage the underlying businesses.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P92_S0	The calculation of our tax liabilities also involves dealing with uncertainties in the application and evolution of complex tax laws and regulations in other jurisdictions.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P93_S0	On January 1, 2007, we adopted Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes an interpretation of ASC 740 , which addresses the determination of whether tax benefits claimed or expected to be claimed on a tax return should be recorded in the financial statements.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P93_S1	Under this interpretation, we may recognize the tax benefit from an uncertain tax position only if it is more likely than not that the tax position will be sustained upon examination by the taxing authorities, based on the technical merits of the position.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P93_S2	As a result of the implementation of this interpretation, we recognized an increase in the liability for unrecognized tax benefits of approximately $10.3 million, which was accounted for as an increase to the January 1, 2007 balance of retained earnings/(accumulated deficit).
1442145_12_ITEM7_P94_S0	We recognize and adjust our liabilities when our judgment changes as a result of the evaluation of new information not previously available.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P94_S1	Due to the complexity of some of these uncertainties, the ultimate resolution may result in a payment that is materially different from our current estimate of the tax liabilities.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P94_S2	These differences will be reflected as increases or decreases to income tax expense in the period in which they are determined.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P95_S0	As of December 31, 2011, we have gross federal, state, and foreign income tax net operating loss carryforwards of $87.1 million, which will expire at various dates from 2012 through 2031.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P95_S1	Such net operating loss carryforwards expire as follows: We estimate unrecognized tax positions of $6.3 million that may be recognized by December 31, 2012, due to expiration of statutes of limitations and resolution of audits with taxing authorities, net of additional uncertain tax positions.
1442145_12_ITEM7_P95_S2	Recent Accounting Pronouncements For a discussion of recent accounting pronouncements, refer to Note 2(s) to the audited consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this annual report on Form 10-K.
1442145_12_ITEM7A_P0_S0	At December 31, 2011, we had no borrowings outstanding under our syndicated revolving credit facility, which bear interest at variable rates based on LIBOR plus 1.250% to 1.875% depending on certain ratios defined in the credit facility.
1442145_12_ITEM7A_P0_S1	A change in interest rates on this variable rate debt impacts our pre-tax income and cash flows, but does not impact the fair value of the instruments.
1442145_12_ITEM7A_P0_S2	Based on our overall interest rate exposure at December 31, 2011, a one percent change in interest rates would not result in a change in annual pretax interest expense based on our current level of borrowings.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P0_S0	Consolidated Financial Statements as of December 31, 2011 and 2010 and for the Years Ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P1_S0	MANAGEMENT S REPORT ON INTERNAL CONTROLS OVER FINANCIAL REPORTING Our management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as defined in Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) under the Exchange Act.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P1_S1	Our internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of the financial statements for external purposes in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P1_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, a system of internal control over financial reporting can provide only reasonable assurance and may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P1_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that internal controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P2_S0	Under the supervision and with the participation of our management, including our principal executive officer and principal financial officer, we conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting based on the framework set forth in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P2_S1	Based on this assessment, management concluded that our internal control over financial reporting was effective at December 31, 2011.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P2_S2	Deloitte Touche LLP, the independent registered public accounting firm that audited the consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K has also audited the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2011, as stated in their report which is included herein.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P3_S0	REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM To the Board of Directors and Stockholders of Verisk Analytics, Inc. Jersey City, New Jersey We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Verisk Analytics, Inc. and subsidiaries (the Company ) as of December 31, 2011 and 2010, and the related consolidated statements of operations, changes in stockholders deficit, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2011.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P3_S1	Our audits also included the financial statement schedule listed in the Index at Item 15.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P3_S2	These financial statements and financial statement schedule are the responsibility of the Company s management.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P3_S3	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the financial statements and financial statement schedules based on our audits.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P3_S4	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1442145_12_ITEM8_P3_S5	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P4_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P4_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P4_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P4_S3	In our opinion, such consolidated financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Verisk Analytics, Inc. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2011 and 2010, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2011, in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P4_S4	Also, in our opinion, such financial statement schedule, when considered in relation to the basic consolidated financial statements taken as a whole, present fairly, in all material respects, the information set forth therein.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P4_S5	We have also audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2011, based on the criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission and our report dated February 28, 2012 expressed an unqualified opinion on the Company s internal control over financial reporting.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P5_S0	REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM To the Board of Directors and Stockholders of Verisk Analytics, Inc. Jersey City, New Jersey We have audited the internal control over financial reporting of Verisk Analytics, Inc. and subsidiaries (the Company ) as of December 31, 2011, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P5_S1	The Company s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in the accompanying Management s Report on Internal Controls over Financial Reporting.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P5_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P5_S3	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1442145_12_ITEM8_P5_S4	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P5_S5	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, and performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P5_S6	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P6_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed by, or under the supervision of, the company s principal executive and principal financial officers, or persons performing similar functions, and effected by the company s board of directors, management, and other personnel to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P6_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P6_S2	Because of the inherent limitations of internal control over financial reporting, including the possibility of collusion or improper management override of controls, material misstatements due to error or fraud may not be prevented or detected on a timely basis.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P6_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of the effectiveness of the internal control over financial reporting to future periods are subject to the risk that the controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P6_S4	In our opinion, the Company maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2011, based on the criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P6_S5	We have also audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated financial statements and financial statement schedule as of and for the year ended December 31, 2011 of the Company and our report dated February 28, 2012 expressed an unqualified opinion on those financial statements and financial statement schedule.

1442145_12_ITEM8_P8_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P9_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P10_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
