1442145_12_ITEM8_P163_S0	common stock, under the Incentive Plan and the Option Plan, from the treasury shares at a weighted average price of $4.30 per share.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P164_S0	Basic earnings per common share is computed by dividing income available to common stockholders by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding during the period.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P164_S1	The computation of diluted EPS is similar to the computation of basic EPS except that the denominator is increased to include the number of additional common shares that would have been outstanding, using the treasury stock method, if the dilutive potential common shares, including stock options and nonvested restricted stock, had been issued.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P164_S2	The following is a reconciliation of the numerators and denominators of the basic and diluted EPS computations for the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009:
1442145_12_ITEM8_P165_S0	The potential shares of common stock that were excluded from diluted EPS were 1,506,440 at December 31, 2011, 2,095,140 at December 31, 2010 and 9,054,022 at December 31, 2009, because the effect of including those potential shares was anti-dilutive.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P165_S1	The following is a summary of accumulated other comprehensive losses:
1442145_12_ITEM8_P166_S0	The before tax and after tax amounts for these categories, and the related tax benefit/(expense) included in other comprehensive gain/(loss) are summarized below:
1442145_12_ITEM8_P167_S0	Compensation Plans: KSOP The Company has established the KSOP for the benefit of eligible employees in the U.S. and Puerto Rico.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P167_S1	The KSOP includes both an employee savings component and an employee stock ownership component.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P167_S2	The purpose of the combined plan is to enable the Company s employees to participate in a tax-deferred savings arrangement under Internal Revenue Service Code Sections 401(a) and 401(k) (the Code ), and to provide employee equity participation in the Company through the employee stock ownership plan ( ESOP ) accounts.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P167_S3	Under the KSOP, eligible employees may make pre-tax and after-tax cash contributions as a percentage of their compensation, subject to certain limitations under the applicable provisions of the Code.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P167_S4	The maximum pre-tax contribution that can be made to the 401(k) account as determined under the provisions of Code Section 401(g) is $17 for 2011, 2010 and 2009.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P167_S5	Certain eligible participants (age 50 and older) may contribute an additional $6 on a pre-tax basis for 2011, 2010 and 2009.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P167_S6	After-tax contributions are limited to 10% of a participant s compensation.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P167_S7	The Company provides quarterly matching contributions in Class A common stock.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P167_S8	The quarterly matching contributions are primarily equal to 75% of the first 6% of the participant s contribution.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P168_S0	The Company established the ESOP component as a funding vehicle for the KSOP.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P168_S1	This leveraged ESOP acquired 57,190,000 shares of the Company s Class A common stock at a cost of approximately $33,170 ($0.58 per share) in January 1997.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P168_S2	The ESOP borrowed $33,170 from an unrelated third party to finance the purchase of the KSOP shares.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P168_S3	The common shares were pledged as collateral for its debt.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P168_S4	The Company made annual cash contributions to the KSOP equal to the ESOP s debt service.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P169_S0	The Company accounts for its ESOP in accordance with ASC 718-40, Employee Stock Ownership Plans ( ASC 718-40 ) and ASC 480-10, Distinguishing Liabilities from Equity ( ASC 480-10 ).
1442145_12_ITEM8_P169_S1	As shares were committed to be released from collateral, the Company reported compensation expense at the then-current fair value of the shares, and the shares became outstanding for EPS computations.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P170_S0	In 2004, the Company renegotiated the ESOP loan to require interest only payments for the third and fourth quarters of 2004.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P170_S1	In December 2004, the Company repaid the ESOP loan and issued a new loan agreement between the Company and the KSOP, thereby extending the allocation of the remaining unreleased shares as of July 1, 2004 through 2013.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P170_S2	On October 6, 2009, the Company accelerated the release of 2,623,600 shares to the ESOP account.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P170_S3	This resulted in a non-recurring non-cash charge of $57,720 in October 2009, which was primarily non-deductible for tax purposes.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P171_S0	Effective with the IPO, the KSOP trustee sold 5,000,000 shares of Verisk Class A common stock, of which 2,754,600 shares were released-unallocated shares and 2,245,400 were unreleased shares pledged as collateral against the intercompany ESOP loan.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P171_S1	The sale of the released-unallocated shares resulted in cash proceeds to the KSOP of $58,177.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P171_S2	The sale of the unreleased shares resulted in cash proceeds to the KSOP of $47,423, all of which was pledged as collateral against the intercompany ESOP loan.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P171_S3	The cash proceeds received by the KSOP were used to repurchase shares diversified or distributed by KSOP participants subsequent to the IPO.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P171_S4	All shares repurchased during this period were repurchased first from the cash proceeds from the sale of the released-unallocated shares; once these proceeds were depleted and replaced with shares of Verisk Class A common stock, then all further share diversifications or distributions were repurchased from the proceeds received from the sale of the unreleased shares.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P171_S5	In accordance with ASC 718-40, the balance of the Class A common stock unearned KSOP shares was reclassified from redeemable common stock to Unearned KSOP contributions , a contra-equity account within the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P172_S0	As the intercompany ESOP loan is repaid, a percentage of the ESOP loan collateral will be released and allocated to active participants in proportion to their annual salaries in relation to total participant salaries.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P172_S1	As of December 31, 2011, the intercompany ESOP loan collateral consisted of cash equivalents totaling $481 and 892,228 shares of Verisk Class A common stock valued at $35,805.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P172_S2	As of December 31, 2011, the Company had 17,693,820 and 44,601 allocated and released-unallocated ESOP shares, respectively.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P173_S0	In 2005, the Company established the ISO Profit Sharing Plan (the Profit Sharing Plan ), a defined contribution plan, to replace the qualified pension plan for all eligible employees hired on or after March 1, 2005.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P173_S1	The Profit Sharing Plan is a component of the KSOP.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P173_S2	Eligible employees will participate in the Profit Sharing Plan if they complete 1,000 hours of service each plan year and are employed on December 31 of that year.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P173_S3	The Company will make an annual contribution to the Profit Sharing Plan based on the Company s performance.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P173_S4	Participants vest once they have completed four years and 1,000 hours of service.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P173_S5	For all periods presented, the profit sharing contribution was funded using Class A common stock.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P173_S6	Prior to the IPO, the fair value of the Class A shares was determined quarterly as determined for purposes of the KSOP.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P173_S7	At December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009, the fair value was $40.13, $34.08 and $30.28 per share, respectively.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P173_S8	KSOP compensation expense for 2011, 2010 and 2009 was approximately $12,615, $11,573 and $76,065, respectively.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P174_S0	Equity Compensation Plans All of the Company s outstanding stock options are covered under the Incentive Plan or the Option Plan.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P175_S0	nonqualified and incentive stock options), (ii) stock appreciation rights, (iii) restricted stock, (iv) restricted stock units, (v) performance awards, (vi) other share-based awards, and (vii) cash.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P175_S1	Employees, directors and consultants are eligible for awards under the Incentive Plan.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P175_S2	Cash received from stock option exercises for the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009 was $43,345, $35,482 and $7,709, respectively.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P175_S3	On July 1, 2011, the Company granted 34,011 nonqualified stock options that were immediately vested, 125,500 nonqualified stock options with a one-year service vesting period and 2,506 shares of Class A common stock, to the directors of the Company.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P175_S4	The stock options have an exercise price equal to the closing price of the Company s Class A common stock on the grant date and a ten-year contractual term.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P175_S5	In 2011, the Company granted 1,415,194 nonqualified stock options to key employees.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P175_S6	The nonqualified stock options have an exercise price equal to the closing price of the Company s Class A common stock on the grant date, with a ten-year contractual term and a service vesting period of four years.

1442145_12_ITEM8_P175_S8	The restricted stock is valued at the closing price of the Company s Class A common stock on the date of grant and has a service vesting period of four years.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P175_S9	The Company recognizes the expense of the restricted stock ratably over the periods in which the restrictions lapse.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P175_S10	The restricted stock is not assignable or transferrable until it becomes vested.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P176_S0	As of December 31, 2011, there were 6,955,761 shares of Class A common stock reserved and available for future issuance.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P176_S1	The fair value of the stock options granted during the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009 were estimated on the date of grant using a Black-Scholes option valuation model that uses the weighted-average assumptions noted in the following table.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P177_S0	The expected term for a majority of the awards granted was estimated based on studies of historical experience and projected exercise behavior.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P177_S1	However, for certain awards granted, for which no historical exercise pattern exists, the expected term was estimated using the simplified method.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P178_S0	The risk-free interest rate is based on the yield of U.S. Treasury zero coupon securities with a maturity equal to the expected term of the equity award.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P178_S1	The volatility factor was based on the average volatility of the Company s peers, calculated using historical daily closing prices over the most recent period is commensurate with the expected term of the stock option award.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P178_S2	The expected dividend yield was based on the Company s expected annual dividend rate on the date of grant.

1442145_12_ITEM8_P182_S0	Intrinsic value for stock options is calculated based on the exercise price of the underlying awards and the quoted price of Verisk s common stock as of the reporting date.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P182_S1	The aggregate intrinsic value of stock options outstanding and exercisable at December 31, 2011 was $445,510 and $337,647, respectively.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P183_S0	In accordance with ASC 718, excess tax benefit from exercised stock options is recorded as an increase to additional-paid-in capital and a corresponding reduction in taxes payable.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P183_S1	This tax benefit is calculated as the excess of the intrinsic value of options exercised in excess of compensation recognized for financial reporting purposes.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P183_S2	The amount of the tax benefit that has been realized, as a result of those excess tax benefits, is presented as a financing cash inflow within the accompanying consolidated statements of cash flows.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P183_S3	For the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009, the Company recorded excess tax benefit from stock options exercised of $57,684, $49,015 and $19,976 respectively.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P183_S4	The Company realized $53,195, $49,015 and $19,976 of tax benefit within the Company s tax payments through December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P183_S5	For the year ended December 31, 2010, certain employees exercised stock options and covered the statutory minimum tax withholdings of $15,051 through a net settlement of 503,043 shares.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P183_S6	The payment of taxes related to these exercises was recorded as a reduction to additional-paid-in capital.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P183_S7	This transaction is reflected within Net share settlement of taxes upon exercise of stock options within cash flows from financing activities in the accompanying consolidated statements of cash flows.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P184_S0	The Company estimates expected forfeitures of equity awards at the date of grant and recognizes compensation expense only for those awards that the Company expects to vest.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P184_S1	The forfeiture assumption is ultimately adjusted to the actual forfeiture rate.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P184_S2	Changes in the forfeiture assumptions may impact the total amount of expense ultimately recognized over the requisite service period and may impact the timing of expense recognized over the requisite service period.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P185_S0	Stock based compensation expense for 2011, 2010 and 2009 was $22,656, $21,298 and $12,744, respectively.

1442145_12_ITEM8_P189_S0	Pension and Postretirement Benefits: The Company maintained a qualified defined benefit pension plan for a certain of its employees through membership in the Pension Plan for Insurance Organizations (the Pension Plan ), a multiple-employer trust.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P189_S1	The Company has applied a cash balance formula to determine future benefits.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P189_S2	Under the cash balance formula, each participant has an account, which is credited annually based on salary rates determined by years of service, as well as the interest earned on the previous year-end cash balance.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P190_S0	Effective March 1, 2005, the Company established the Profit Sharing Plan, a defined contribution plan, to replace the Pension Plan for all eligible employees hired on or after March 1, 2005.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P190_S1	The Company also has a non-qualified supplemental cash balance plan ( SERP ) for certain employees.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P190_S2	The SERP is funded from the general assets of the Company.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P190_S3	On January 12, 2012, the Company announced a hard freeze, which will eliminate all future compensation and service credits, to be instituted on February 29, 2012 to all participants in the Pension Plan and SERP.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P190_S4	The freeze in 2012 will reduce the unfunded pension liability by approximately $10,200 and the Company will realize a curtailment gain of approximately $700.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P191_S0	The Pension Plan s funding policy is to contribute annually at an amount between the minimum funding requirements set forth in the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 and the maximum amount that can be deducted for federal income tax purposes.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P191_S1	The Company contributed $1,400, $313 and $292 to the SERP in 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively, and expects to contribute $679 in 2012.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P191_S2	The minimum required funding for the Pension Plan for the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009 was $25,312, $20,444 and $5,471, respectively.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P191_S3	Based on the Pension Plan s funding policy, the 2012 minimum contribution requirement is expected to be $28,206.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P191_S4	The expected return on the plan assets for 2011 and 2010 was 8.25%, which was determined by taking into consideration the Company s analysis of its actual historical investment returns to a broader long-term forecast adjusted based on the its target investment allocation, and the current economic environment.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P192_S0	The Company s investment guidelines target investment allocation of 60% equity securities and 40% debt securities.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P192_S1	The Pension Plan assets consist primarily of investments in various fixed income and equity funds.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P192_S2	Investment guidelines are established with each investment manager.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P193_S0	diversification requirements and credit quality standards, where applicable.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P194_S0	Investment managers are prohibited from entering into any speculative hedging transactions.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P195_S0	The investment objective is to achieve a maximum total return with strong emphasis on preservation of capital in real terms.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P195_S1	The domestic equity portion of the total portfolio should range between 40% and 60%.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P195_S2	The international equity portion of the total portfolio should range between 10% and 20%.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P195_S3	The fixed income portion of the total portfolio should range between 20% and 40%.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P195_S4	The asset allocation at December 31, 2011 and 2010, and target allocation for 2012 by asset category are as follows:
1442145_12_ITEM8_P196_S0	The Company has used the target investment allocation to derive the expected return as the Company believes this allocation will be retained on an ongoing basis that will commensurate with the projected cash flows of the plan.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P197_S0	The expected return for each investment category within the target investment allocation is developed using average historical rates of return for each targeted investment category, considering the projected cash flow of the Pension Plan.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P197_S1	The difference between this expected return and the actual return on plan assets is generally deferred and recognized over subsequent periods through future net periodic benefit costs.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P197_S2	The Company believes that the use of the average historical rates of returns is consistent with the timing and amounts of expected contributions to the plans and benefit payments to plan participants.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P197_S3	These considerations provide the basis for reasonable assumptions with respect to the expected long-term rate of return on plan assets.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P198_S0	The Company also provides certain healthcare and life insurance benefits for both active and retired employees.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P198_S1	The Postretirement Health and Life Insurance Plan (the Postretirement Plan ) is contributory, requiring participants to pay a stated percentage of the premium for coverage.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P198_S2	As of October 1, 2001, the Postretirement Plan was amended to freeze benefits for current retirees and certain other employees at the January 1, 2002 level.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P198_S3	Also, as of October 1, 2001, the Postretirement Plan had a curtailment, which eliminated retiree life insurance for all active employees and healthcare benefits for almost all future retirees, effective January 1, 2002.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P198_S4	The Company expects to contribute $3,407 to the Postretirement Plan in 2012.

1442145_12_ITEM8_P208_S0	(1) Valued at the closing price of shares for domestic stocks within the managed equity accounts, and valued at the net asset value ( NAV ) of shares for mutual funds at either the closing price reported in the active market or based on yields currently available on comparable securities of issuers with similar credit ratings for corporate bonds held by the Plan in these managed accounts.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P209_S0	(2) The pooled separate accounts invest in domestic and foreign stocks, bonds and mutual funds.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P209_S1	The fair values of these stocks, bonds and mutual funds are publicly quoted and are used in determining the NAV of the pooled separate account, which is not publicly quoted.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P210_S0	(3) Investments for which readily determinable prices do not exist are valued by the General Partner using either the market or income approach.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P211_S0	In establishing the estimated fair value of investments, including those without readily determinable values, the General Partner assumes a reasonable period of time for liquidation of the investment, and takes into consideration the financial condition and operating results of the underlying portfolio company, nature of investment, restrictions on marketability, holding period, market conditions, foreign currency exposures, and other factors the General Partner deems appropriate.

1442145_12_ITEM8_P213_S0	ASC 280-10, Disclosures About Segments of an Enterprise and Related Information ( ASC 280-10 ), establishes standards for reporting information about operating segments.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P213_S1	ASC 280-10 requires that a public business enterprise report financial and descriptive information about its reportable operating segments.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P214_S0	Operating segments are components of an enterprise for which separate financial information is available that is evaluated regularly by the chief operating decision maker ( CODM ) in deciding how to allocate resources and in assessing performance.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P214_S1	The Company s CEO and Chairman of the Board is identified as the CODM as defined by ASC 280-10.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P215_S0	To align with the internal management of the Company s business operations based on service offerings, the Company is organized into the following two operating segments, which are also the Company s reportable segments: Risk Assessment: The Company is the leading provider of statistical, actuarial and underwriting data for the U.S. P C insurance industry.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P215_S1	The Company s databases include cleansed and standardized records describing premiums and losses in insurance transactions, casualty and property risk attributes for commercial buildings and their occupants and fire suppression capabilities of municipalities.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P215_S2	The Company uses this data to create policy language and proprietary risk classifications that are industry standards and to generate prospective loss cost estimates used to price insurance policies.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P216_S0	Decision Analytics: The Company develops solutions that its customers use to analyze key processes in managing risk.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P216_S1	The Company s combination of algorithms and analytic methods incorporates its proprietary data to generate solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P216_S2	In most cases, the Company s customers integrate the solutions into their models, formulas or underwriting criteria in order to predict potential loss events, ranging from hurricanes and earthquakes to unanticipated healthcare claims.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P217_S0	The Company develops catastrophe and extreme event models and offers solutions covering natural and man-made risks, including acts of terrorism.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P217_S1	The Company also develops solutions that allow customers to quantify costs after loss events occur.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P217_S2	Fraud solutions include data on claim histories, analysis of mortgage applications to identify misinformation, analysis of claims to find emerging patterns of fraud, and identification of suspicious claims in the insurance, mortgage and healthcare sectors.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P217_S3	Effective December 31, 2011, the Company provided additional disclosure about its revenue within Decision Analytics segment based on the industry vertical groupings of insurance, mortgage and financial services, healthcare and specialized markets.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P217_S4	Previously, the Company disclosed revenue based on the classification of its solution as fraud identification and detection solutions, loss prediction solutions and loss quantification solutions.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P217_S5	There have been no changes in reportable segments in accordance with ASC 280-10 for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P218_S0	The two aforementioned operating segments represent the segments for which separate discrete financial information is available and upon which operating results are regularly evaluated by the CODM in order to assess performance and allocate resources.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P218_S1	The Company uses segment EBITDA as the profitability measure for making decisions regarding ongoing operations.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P219_S0	investment income and interest expense, income taxes and depreciation and amortization.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P219_S1	Beginning in 2011, the Company s definition of Segment EBITDA includes acquisition related liabilities adjustment for all periods presented.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P220_S0	Segment EBITDA is the measure of operating results used to assess corporate performance and optimal utilization of debt and acquisitions.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P220_S1	Segment operating expenses consist of direct and indirect costs principally related to personnel, facilities, software license fees, consulting, travel, and third-party information services.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P220_S2	Indirect costs are generally allocated to the segments using fixed rates established by management based upon estimated expense contribution levels and other assumptions that management considers reasonable.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P220_S3	The Company does not allocate investment income, realized gain/(loss) on securities, net, interest expense, or income tax expense, since these items are not considered in evaluating the segment s overall operating performance.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P220_S4	The CODM does not evaluate the financial performance of each segment based on assets.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P221_S0	On a geographic basis, no individual country outside of the U.S. accounted for 1% or more of the Company s consolidated revenue for any of the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 or 2009.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P221_S1	No individual country outside of the U.S. accounted for 1% or more of total consolidated long-term assets as of December 31, 2011 or 2010.

1442145_12_ITEM8_P223_S0	The Company considers its Verisk Class A and Class B stockholders that own more than 5% of the outstanding stock within the respective class to be related parties as defined within ASC 850, Related Party Disclosures .
1442145_12_ITEM8_P223_S1	In 2011, the Company s Class B-1 and Class B-2 shares converted to Class A. As a result of the conversion, the Company had no related parties owning more than 5% of the entire class of stock as of December 31, 2011.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P223_S2	At December 31, 2010, there were four Class A and four Class B stockholders, each owning more than 5% of the respective outstanding classes.

1442145_12_ITEM8_P227_S0	In addition, the Company is a party to legal proceedings with respect to a variety of matters in the ordinary course of business, including those matters described below.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P227_S1	With respect to the ongoing matter, the Company is unable, at the present time, to determine the ultimate resolution of or provide a reasonable estimate of the range of possible loss attributable to this matter or the impact it may have on the Company s results of operations, financial position or cash flows.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P227_S2	This is primarily because this case remains in its early stages and discovery has not yet commenced.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P227_S3	Although the Company believes it has strong defenses and intends to vigorously defend this matter, the Company could in the future incur judgments or enter into settlements of claims that could have a material adverse effect on its results of operations, financial position or cash flows.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P228_S0	Claims Outcome Advisor Litigation Hensley, et al.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P228_S1	v. Computer Sciences Corporation et al. was a putative nationwide class action complaint, filed in February 2005, in Miller County, Arkansas state court.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P228_S2	Defendants included numerous insurance companies and providers of software products used by insurers in paying claims.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P228_S3	The Company was among the named defendants.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P229_S0	Plaintiffs alleged that certain software products, including the Company s Claims Outcome Advisor product and a competing software product sold by Computer Sciences Corporation, improperly estimated the amount to be paid by insurers to their policyholders in connection with claims for bodily injuries.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P229_S1	The Company entered into settlement agreements with plaintiffs asserting claims relating to the use of Claims Outcome Advisor by defendants Hanover Insurance Group, Progressive Car Insurance and Liberty Mutual Insurance Group.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P229_S2	Each of these settlements was granted final approval by the court and together the settlements resolve the claims asserted in this case against the Company with respect to the above insurance companies, who settled the claims against them as well.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P229_S3	A provision was made in 2006 for this proceeding and the total amount the Company paid in 2008 with respect to these settlements was less than $2,000.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P229_S4	A fourth defendant, The Automobile Club of California, which is alleged to have used Claims Outcome Advisor, was dismissed from the action.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P230_S0	On August 18, 2008, pursuant to the agreement of the parties the Court ordered that the claims against the Company be dismissed with prejudice.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P231_S0	Subsequently, Hanover Insurance Group made a demand for reimbursement, pursuant to an indemnification provision contained in a December 30, 2004 License Agreement between Hanover and the Company, of its settlement and defense costs in the Hensley class action.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P231_S1	Specifically, Hanover demanded $2,536 including $600 in attorneys fees and expenses.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P231_S2	The Company disputed that Hanover is entitled to any reimbursement pursuant to the License Agreement.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P231_S3	In July 2010, after the Company and Hanover were unable to resolve the dispute in mediation, Hanover served a summons and complaint seeking indemnity and contribution from the Company.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P231_S4	The parties resolved this matter with no material adverse consequences to the Company in a Settlement Agreement and Release executed on August 25, 2011.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P232_S0	The following two lawsuits were filed by or on behalf of groups of Louisiana insurance policyholders who claim, among other things, that certain insurers who used products and price information supplied by the Company s Xactware subsidiary (and those of another provider) did not fully compensate policyholders for property damage covered under their insurance policies.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P232_S1	The plaintiffs seek to recover compensation for their damages in an amount equal to the difference between the amount paid by the defendants and the fair market repair/restoration costs of their damaged property.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P233_S0	Schafer v. State Farm Fire Cas. Co., et al. was a putative class action pending against the Company and State Farm Fire Casualty Company filed in March 2007 in the Eastern District of Louisiana.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P233_S1	The complaint alleged antitrust violations, breach of contract, negligence, bad faith, and fraud.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P233_S2	The court dismissed the antitrust claim as to both defendants and dismissed all claims against the Company other than fraud.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P233_S3	Judge Duval denied plaintiffs motion to certify a class with respect to the fraud and breach of contract claims on August 3, 2009.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P233_S4	After the single action was reassigned to Judge Africk plaintiffs agreed to settle the matter with the Company and State Farm and a Settlement Agreement and Release was executed by all parties in June 2010.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P233_S5	The terms of the settlement were not considered material to the Company.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P234_S0	Mornay v. Travelers Ins. Co., et al. was a putative class action pending against the Company and Travelers Insurance Company filed in November 2007 in the Eastern District of Louisiana.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P234_S1	The complaint alleged antitrust violations, breach of contract, negligence, bad faith, and fraud.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P234_S2	As in Schafer, the court dismissed the antitrust claim as to both defendants and dismissed all claims against the Company other than fraud.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P234_S3	Judge Duval stayed all proceedings in the case pending an appraisal of the lead plaintiff s insurance claim.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P234_S4	The matter was re-assigned to Judge Barbier, who on September 11, 2009 issued an order administratively closing the matter pending completion of the appraisal process.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P235_S0	After the appraisal process was completed and the court lifted the stay, defendants filed a motion to strike the class allegations and dismiss the fraud claim.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P235_S1	The plaintiffs agreed to settle the matter and a Settlement Agreement and Release were executed by all parties on January 5, 2012.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P235_S2	The terms of the settlement were not considered material to the Company.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P236_S0	In April 2010, the Company s subsidiary, Insurance Information Exchange or iiX, as well as other information providers in the State of Missouri were served with a summons and class action complaint filed in the United States District Court for the Western District of Missouri alleging violations of the Driver Privacy Protection Act, or the DPPA, entitled Janice Cook, et al. v. ACS State Local Solutions, et al .
1442145_12_ITEM8_P236_S1	Plaintiffs brought the action on their own behalf and on behalf of all similarly situated individuals whose personal information is contained in any motor vehicle record maintained by the State of Missouri and who have not provided express consent to the State of Missouri for the distribution of their personal information for purposes not enumerated by the DPPA and whose personal information has been knowingly obtained and used by the defendants.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P237_S0	complaint alleged that the defendants knowingly obtained personal information for a purpose not authorized by the DPPA and sought liquidated damages in the amount of two thousand five hundred dollars for each instance of a violation of the DPPA, punitive damages and the destruction of any illegally obtained personal information.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P237_S1	The court granted iiX s motion to dismiss the complaint based on a failure to state a claim on November 19, 2010.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P238_S0	Plaintiffs filed a notice of appeal on December 17, 2010 and oral argument was heard by the Eighth Circuit on September 18, 2011.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P238_S1	The Eighth Circuit affirmed the District Court s dismissal on December 15, 2011.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P239_S0	In September 2009, the Company s subsidiary, Interthinx, Inc., was served with a putative class action entitled Renata Gluzman v. Interthinx, Inc .
1442145_12_ITEM8_P239_S1	The plaintiff, a former Interthinx employee, filed the class action on August 13, 2009 in the Superior Court of the State of California, County of Los Angeles on behalf of all Interthinx information technology employees for unpaid overtime and missed meals and rest breaks, as well as various related claims claiming that the information technology employees were misclassified as exempt employees and, as a result, were denied certain wages and benefits that would have been received if they were properly classified as non-exempt employees.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P239_S2	The pleadings included, among other things, a violation of Business and Professions Code 17200 for unfair business practices, which allowed plaintiffs to include as class members all information technology employees employed at Interthinx for four years prior to the date of filing the complaint.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P239_S3	The complaint sought compensatory damages, penalties that are associated with the various statutes, restitution, interest costs, and attorney fees.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P239_S4	On June 2, 2010, plaintiffs agreed to settle their claims with Interthinx and the court granted final approval to the settlement on February 23, 2011.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P239_S5	The terms of the settlement were not considered material to the Company.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P240_S0	The Company has received notice of a complaint filed on February 7, 2012 in the Florida State Circuit Court for Pasco County naming Citizens Property Insurance Corporation ( Citizens ) and the Company s Xactware subsidiary.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P240_S1	The complaint does not seek monetary relief against Xactware.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P240_S2	It alleges a class action seeking declaratory relief against defendants and is brought on behalf of all individuals who have purchased a new or renewed a property casualty insurance policy from Citizens where Citizens used an Xactware product to determine replacement value of the property.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P240_S3	The complaint has not yet been served on Xactware.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P240_S4	At this time, it is not possible to determine the ultimate resolution of or estimate the liability related to this matter.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P241_S0	In April and December 2011, Verisk Analytics, Inc. (the Parent Company ) registered senior notes with full and unconditional and joint and several guarantees by certain of its 100 percent wholly-owned subsidiaries and issued certain other debt securities with full and unconditional and joint and several guarantees by certain of its subsidiaries.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P241_S1	Accordingly, presented below is condensed consolidating financial information for (i) the Parent Company, (ii) the guarantor subsidiaries of the Parent Company on a combined basis, and (iii) all other non-guarantor subsidiaries of the Parent Company on a combined basis, as of December 31, 2011 and 2010 and for the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P241_S2	The condensed consolidating financial information has been presented using the equity method of accounting, to show the nature of assets held, results of operations and cash flows of the Parent Company, the guarantor subsidiaries and the non-guarantor subsidiaries assuming all guarantor subsidiaries provide both full and unconditional, and joint and several guarantees to the Parent Company at the beginning of the periods presented.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P242_S0	Effective as of December 31, 2011, ISO Staff Services, Inc. ( ISOSS ), a guarantor of the senior notes, merged with and into ISO, also a guarantor of the senior notes, pursuant to which ISO was the surviving corporation.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P242_S1	By virtue of the merger, ISO expressly assumed all of the obligations of ISOSS, including the guarantee by ISOSS of the senior notes.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P243_S0	(1) Primarily additional reserves for bad debts.
1442145_12_ITEM8_P244_S0	(2) Primarily accounts receivable balances written off, net of recoveries, and the expiration of loss carryforwards.

1442145_12_ITEM9A_P0_S0	Disclosure Controls and Procedures We are required to maintain disclosure controls and procedures (as that term is defined in Rules 13a-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the Exchange Act )) that are designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed in our reports under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized, and reported within the time periods specified in the Securities and Exchange Commission s rules and forms, and that such information is accumulated and communicated to our management, including our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, as appropriate, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosures.
1442145_12_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Any controls and procedures, no matter how well designed and operated, can provide only reasonable assurance of achieving the desired control objectives at the reasonable assurance level.
1442145_12_ITEM9A_P0_S2	Our management, with the participation of the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, has evaluated the effectiveness of the Company s disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e)) as of the end of the period covered by this annual report on Form 10-K. Based upon the foregoing assessments, our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer have concluded that, as of December 31, 2011, our disclosure controls and procedures were effective at the reasonable assurance level.

1442145_12_ITEM9A_P0_S4	Attestation Report of the Registered Public Accounting Firm The Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting as of December 31, 2011 is set forth in Item 8.
1442145_12_ITEM9A_P0_S5	Changes in Internal Control Over Financial Reporting There have been no changes in our internal control over financial reporting identified in connection with the evaluation of such internal control that occurred during the fourth quarter of 2011 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting.
1442145_12_ITEM10_P0_S0	December 31, 2011 (the Proxy Statement ).
1442145_12_ITEM11_P0_S0	The information required to be furnished by this Item 11. is incorporated herein by reference from our Proxy Statement.

1442145_12_ITEM15_P0_S0	See Index to Financial Statements and Schedules in Part II, Item 8.
1442145_12_ITEM15_P1_S0	Valuation and Qualifying Accounts and Reserves.
1442145_12_ITEM15_P2_S0	See Index to Exhibits in this annual report on Form 10-K.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P0_S0	Verisk Analytics is a leading provider of information about risk to professionals in insurance, healthcare, financial, government, supply chain, and risk management.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P0_S1	Using advanced technologies to collect and analyze billions of records, we draw on industry expertise and unique proprietary data sets to provide predictive analytics and decision-support solutions in fraud prevention, actuarial science, insurance coverages, fire protection, catastrophe and weather risk, data management, and many other fields.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P0_S2	In the United States and around the world, we help customers protect people, property, and financial assets.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P0_S3	Our customers use our solutions to make better risk decisions with greater efficiency and discipline.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P0_S4	We refer to these products and services as solutions due to the integration among our services and the flexibility that enables our customers to purchase components or the comprehensive package.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P0_S5	These solutions take various forms, including data, statistical models or tailored analytics, all designed to allow our clients to make more logical decisions.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P0_S6	We believe our solutions for analyzing risk positively impact our customers revenues and help them better manage their costs.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P0_S7	In 2012, for the lines of P C services we offer, our U.S. customers included all of the top 100 P C insurance providers, 17 of the top 20 U.S credit card issuers, as well as numerous health plans and third party administrators.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P0_S8	We believe that our commitment to our customers and the embedded nature of our solutions serve to strengthen and extend our relationships.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P1_S0	These four processes correspond to various functional areas inside our customers operations:
1442145_13_ITEM1_P2_S0	our tools to quantify loss are primarily used by claims departments, independent adjustors and contractors.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P2_S1	We add value by linking our solutions across these four key processes; for example, we use the same modeling methods to support the pricing of homeowner s insurance policies and to quantify the actual losses when damage occurs to insured homes.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P2_S2	We offer our solutions and services primarily through annual subscriptions or long-term agreements, which are typically pre-paid and represented approximately 67.2% of our revenues in 2012.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P2_S3	For the year ended December 31, 2012, we had revenues of $1,534.3 million and net income of $329.1 million.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P2_S4	For the five year period ended December 31, 2012, our revenues and net income grew at a compound annual growth rate, or CAGR, of 14.5% and 20.1%, respectively.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P3_S0	Our History We trace our history to 1971, when Insurance Services Office, Inc., or ISO, started operations as a not-for-profit advisory and rating organization providing services for the U.S. P C insurance industry.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P3_S1	ISO was formed as an association of insurance companies to gather statistical data and other information from insurers and report to regulators, as required by law.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P3_S2	ISO s original functions also included developing programs to help insurers define and manage insurance products and providing information to help insurers determine their own independent premium rates.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P3_S3	Insurers used and continue to use our offerings primarily in their product development, underwriting and rating functions.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P3_S4	Today, those businesses form the core of our Risk Assessment segment.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P3_S5	Over the past decade, we have transformed our business beyond its original functions by deepening and broadening our data assets, developing a set of integrated risk management solutions and services and addressing new markets through our Decision Analytics segment.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P4_S0	Our expansion into analytics began when we acquired the American Insurance Services Group, or AISG, and certain operations and assets of the National Insurance Crime Bureau in 1997 and 1998, respectively.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P4_S1	Those organizations brought to the company large databases of insurance claims, as well as expertise in detecting and preventing claims fraud.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P5_S0	segment, we acquired AIR Worldwide, or AIR, in 2002, the technological leader in catastrophe modeling.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P5_S1	In 2004, we entered the healthcare space by acquiring several businesses that now offer web-based analytical and reporting systems for health insurers, provider organizations and self-insured employers.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P5_S2	In 2005, we entered the mortgage sector, acquiring the first of several businesses that now provide automated fraud detection, compliance and decision support solutions for the U.S. mortgage industry.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P5_S3	In 2006, to bolster our position in the insurance claims field we acquired Xactware, a leading supplier of estimating software for professionals involved in building repair and reconstruction.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P5_S4	In 2010, we acquired 3E Company, creating a scale presence in supply chain and environmental health and safety.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P5_S5	In 2011 and 2012, we further bolstered our healthcare solutions by acquiring Health Risk Partners, LLC, or HRP, which provides solutions to optimize revenue, improve compliance and improve quality of care for Medicare Advantage health plans and MediConnect Global, Inc. or MediConnect, which provides medical record retrieval, digitization, coding, extraction, and analysis to the healthcare and property casualty industry.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P5_S6	Also in 2012, we acquired Argus Information Advisory Services, LLC, or Argus, to expand our presence in providing information, competitive benchmarking, analytics, and customized services to financial institutions in the payments space globally.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P5_S7	These acquisitions have added scale, geographic reach, highly skilled workforces, and a wide array of new capabilities to our Decision Analytics segment.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P5_S8	They have helped to make us a leading provider of information and decision analytics for customers involved in the business of risk in the U.S. and selectively around the world.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P5_S9	Our senior management operating team, which includes our chief executive officer, president, chief financial officer, general counsel, and four senior officers who lead our business and operational units, have been with us for an average of over 15 years.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P5_S10	This team has led our transformation to a successful for-profit entity, focused on growth with our U.S. P C insurer customers and expansion into a variety of new markets.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P6_S0	On May 23, 2008, in contemplation of our initial public offering, or IPO, ISO formed Verisk Analytics, Inc., or Verisk, a Delaware corporation, to be the holding company for our business.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P6_S1	Verisk was initially formed as a wholly-owned subsidiary of ISO.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P6_S2	On October 6, 2009, in connection with our IPO, the company effected a reorganization whereby ISO became a wholly-owned subsidiary of Verisk.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P6_S3	Verisk Class A common stock began trading on the NASDAQ Global Select Market on October 7, 2009 under the symbol VRSK.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P7_S0	Segments We organize our business in two segments: Risk Assessment and Decision Analytics.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P7_S1	See Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations in Part II of this annual report for information regarding our segments.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P8_S0	Risk Assessment Segment Our Risk Assessment segment serves our P C insurance customers and focuses on the first two decision making processes in our Risk Analysis Framework: prediction of loss and selection and pricing of risk.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P8_S1	Within this segment, we also provide solutions to help our insurance customers comply with their reporting requirements in each U.S. state in which they operate.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P8_S2	We are the recognized leader in the U.S. for industry-standard insurance programs that help P C insurers define coverages and issue policies.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P8_S3	Our policy language, prospective loss cost information and policy writing rules can serve as integrated turnkey insurance programs for our customers.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P9_S0	Insurance companies need to ensure that their policy language, rules, and rates comply with all applicable legal and regulatory requirements.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P9_S1	Insurers must also make sure their policies remain competitive by promptly changing coverages in response to changes in statutes or case law.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P10_S0	filings each year, ensuring smooth implementation of our rules and forms.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P10_S1	When insurers choose to develop their own alternative programs, our industry-standard insurance programs also help regulators make sure that such insurers policies meet basic coverage requirements.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P10_S2	Standardized coverage language, which has been tested in litigation and tailored to reflect judicial interpretation, helps to ensure consistent treatment of claimants.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P10_S3	As a result, our industry-standard language also simplifies claim settlements and can reduce the occurrence of costly litigation, because our language causes the meaning of coverage terminology to become established and known.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P10_S4	Our policy language includes standard coverage language, endorsements and policy writing support language that assist our customers in understanding the risks they assume and the coverages they are offering.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P10_S5	With these policy programs, insurers also benefit from economies of scale.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P10_S6	We have over 200 specialized lawyers and insurance experts reviewing changes in each state s insurance rules and regulations, including on average over 9,200 legislative bills, 1,000 regulatory actions and 2,000 court cases per year, to make any required changes to our policy language and rating information.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P10_S7	To cover the wide variety of risks in the marketplace, we offer a broad range of policy programs.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P10_S8	For example, in the homeowner s line of insurance, we maintain policy language and rules for 6 basic coverages, 255 national endorsements, and 514 state-specific endorsements.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P10_S9	Overall, we provide policy language, prospective loss costs, policy writing rules, and a variety of other solutions for 26 lines of insurance.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P11_S0	The P C insurance industry is heavily regulated in the U.S. P C insurers are required to collect statistical data about their premiums and losses and to report that data to regulators in every state in which they operate.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P11_S1	Our statistical agent services have enabled P C insurers to meet these regulatory requirements for over 40 years.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P11_S2	We aggregate the data and, as a licensed or appointed statistical agent in all 50 states, Puerto Rico, Guam, U.S. Virgin Islands and the District of Columbia, we report these statistics to insurance regulators.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P11_S3	We are able to capture significant economies of scale given the level of penetration of this service within the U.S. P C insurance industry.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P11_S4	To provide our customers and the regulators the information they require, we maintain one of the largest private databases in the world.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P11_S5	Over the past four decades, we have developed core expertise in acquiring, processing, managing, and operating large and comprehensive databases that are the foundation of our Risk Assessment segment.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P11_S6	We use our proprietary technology to assemble, organize and update vast amounts of detailed information submitted by our customers.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P11_S7	We supplement this data with publicly available information.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P11_S8	Each year, P C insurers send us approximately 2.9 billion detailed individual records of insurance transactions, such as insurance premiums collected or losses incurred.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P11_S9	We maintain a database of over 16.5 billion statistical records, including approximately 6.5 billion commercial lines records and approximately 10.0 billion personal lines records.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P11_S10	We collect unit-transaction detail of each premium and loss record, which enhances the validity, reliability and accuracy of our data sets and our actuarial analyses.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P11_S11	Our proprietary quality process includes almost 2,500 separate checks to ensure that data meet our high standards of quality.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P11_S12	We provide actuarial services to help our customers analyze and price their risks.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P11_S13	Using our large database of premium and loss data, our actuaries are able to perform sophisticated analyses using our predictive models and analytic methods to help our P C insurance customers with pricing, loss reserving, and marketing.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P11_S14	We distribute a number of actuarial solutions and offer flexible services to meet our customers needs.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P11_S15	In addition, our actuarial consultants provide customized services for our clients that include assisting them with the development of independent insurance programs, analysis of their own underwriting experience, development of classification systems and rating plans, and a wide variety of other business decisions.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P11_S16	We also supply information to a wide variety of customers in other markets including reinsurance and government agencies.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P12_S0	We project future losses and loss expenses utilizing a broad set of data.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P12_S1	These projections tend to be more reliable than if our customers used solely their own data.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P13_S0	We make a number of actuarial adjustments before the data is used to estimate future costs.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P13_S1	Our customers can use our estimates of future costs in making independent decisions about the prices charged for their policies.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P14_S0	our estimates of future costs are an essential input to rating decisions.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P14_S1	Our actuarial products and services are also used to create the analytics underlying our industry-standard insurance programs described above.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P14_S2	We gather information on individual properties and communities so that insurers can use our information to evaluate and price personal and commercial property insurance, as well as commercial liability insurance.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P14_S3	Our property-specific rating and underwriting information allow our customers to understand, quantify, underwrite, mitigate, and avoid potential loss for residential and commercial properties.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P14_S4	Our database contains loss costs and other vital information on more than 3.4 million commercial buildings in the United States and also holds information on more than 6.1 million individual businesses occupying those buildings.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P14_S5	We have a staff of more than 550 field representatives strategically located around the United States who observe and report on conditions at commercial and residential properties, evaluate community fire-protection capabilities and assess the effectiveness of municipal building-code enforcement.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P14_S6	Each year, our field staff visits more than over 300,000 commercial properties to collect information on new buildings and verify building attributes.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P14_S7	We also provide proprietary analytic measures of the ability of individual communities to mitigate losses from important perils.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P14_S8	Nearly every property insurer in the U.S. uses our evaluations of community firefighting capabilities to help determine premiums for fire insurance throughout the country.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P14_S9	We provide field-verified and validated data on the fire protection services for more than 46,000 fire response jurisdictions.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P14_S10	We also offer services to evaluate the effectiveness of community enforcement of building codes and the efforts of communities to mitigate damage from flooding.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P14_S11	Further, we provide information on the insurance rating territories, premium taxes, crime risk, and hazards of windstorm, earthquake, wildfire, and other perils.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P14_S12	To supplement our data on specific commercial properties and individual communities, we have assembled, from a variety of internal and third-party sources, information on hazards related to geographic locations representing every postal address in the U.S. Insurers use this information not only for policy quoting but also for analyzing risk concentration in geographical areas.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P15_S0	Decision Analytics Segment In the Decision Analytics segment, we support all four phases of our Risk Analysis Framework.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P15_S1	We develop predictive models to forecast scenarios and produce both standard and customized analytics that help our customers better predict loss, select and price risk, detect fraud before and after a loss event, and quantify losses.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P16_S0	The businesses are categorized by the primary end market for their services.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P17_S0	As we develop our models to quantify loss and detect fraud, we improve our ability to predict the loss and prevent the fraud from happening.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P17_S1	We believe this provides us with a significant competitive advantage over firms that do not offer solutions which operate both before and after loss events.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P18_S0	We are a leading provider of fraud-detection tools for the P C insurance industry.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P18_S1	Our fraud solutions improve our customers profitability by both predicting the likelihood that fraud is occurring and detecting suspicious activity after it has occurred.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P18_S2	When a claim is submitted, our system searches our database and returns information about other claims filed by the same individuals or businesses (either as claimants or insurers) that help our customers determine if fraud has occurred.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P18_S3	The system searches for matches in identifying information fields, such as name, address, Social Security number, vehicle identification number, driver s license number, tax identification number, or other parties to the loss.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P18_S4	Our system also includes advanced name and address searching to perform intelligent searches and improve the overall quality of the matches.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P19_S0	Information from match reports speeds payment of meritorious claims while providing a defense against fraud and can lead to denial of a claim, negotiation of a reduced award or further investigation by the insurer or law enforcement.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P20_S0	We have a comprehensive system used by claims adjusters and investigations professionals to process claims and fight fraud.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P21_S0	Claims databases are one of the key tools in the fight against insurance fraud.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P21_S1	The benefits of a single all-claims database include improved efficiency in reporting data and searching for information, enhanced capabilities for detecting suspicious claims and superior information for investigating fraudulent claims, suspicious individuals and possible fraud rings.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P22_S0	Our database contains information on approximately 844 million claims and is the world s largest database of P C claims information used for claims and investigations.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P23_S0	Insurers and other participants submit new claim records, more than 254,000 a day on average, across all categories of the U.S. P C insurance industry.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P23_S1	We also provide a service allowing insurers to report thefts of automobiles and property, improving the chances of recovering those items; a service that helps owners and insurers recover stolen heavy construction and agricultural equipment; an expert scoring system that helps distinguish between suspicious and meritorious claims; and products that use link-analysis technology to help visualize and fight insurance fraud.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P24_S0	We pioneered the field of probabilistic catastrophe modeling used by insurers, reinsurers and financial institutions to manage their catastrophe risk.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P24_S1	Our models of global natural hazards, which form the basis of our solutions, enable companies to identify, quantify and plan for the financial consequences of catastrophic events.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P24_S2	We have developed models, covering natural hazards, including hurricanes, earthquakes, winter storms, tornadoes, hailstorms, and flood, for potential loss events in more than 90 countries.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P24_S3	We have also developed and introduced a probabilistic terrorism model capable of quantifying the risk in the U.S. from this emerging threat, which supports pricing and underwriting decisions down to the level of an individual policy We provide data, analytic and networking products for professionals involved in estimating all phases of building repair and reconstruction.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P24_S4	We provide solutions for every phase of a building s life, including:
1442145_13_ITEM1_P25_S0	tracking the process of repair or reconstruction and facilitating communication among insurers, adjusters, contractors and policyholders To help our customers estimate repair costs, we provide a solution that assists contractors and insurance adjusters to estimate repairs using a patented plan-sketching program.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P25_S1	The program allows our customers to sketch floor plans, roof plans and wall-framing plans and automatically calculates material and labor quantities for the construction of walls, floors, footings and roofs.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P26_S0	We also offer our customers access to wholesale and retail price lists, which include structural repair and restoration pricing for 467 separate economic areas in North America.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P26_S1	We revise this information monthly and, in the aftermath of a major disaster, we can update the price lists as often as weekly to reflect rapid price changes.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S0	Our structural repair and cleaning database contains more than 13,000 unit-cost line items.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S1	For each line item such as smoke cleaning, water extraction and hazardous cleanup, we report time and material pricing, including labor, labor productivity rates (for new construction and restoration), labor burden and overhead, material costs, and equipment costs.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S2	We improve our reported pricing data by several methods including direct market surveys, and an analysis of the actual claims experience of our customers.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S3	We estimate that about 80.0% of all homeowners claims settled in the U.S. annually use our solution.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S4	Utilization of such a large percentage of the industry s claims leads to accurate reporting of pricing information, which we believe is unmatched in the industry.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S5	Our estimates allow our customers to set loss reserves, deploy field adjusters and verify internal company estimates.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S6	Our estimates also keep insurers, their customers, regulators, and other interested parties informed about the total costs of disasters.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S7	We also provide our customers access to daily reports on severe weather and catastrophes and we maintain a database of information on catastrophe losses in the U.S. since 1950.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S8	We focus on providing competitive benchmarking, scoring solutions, analytics, and customized services to financial services institutions in North and South America and Europe.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S9	We maintain the most comprehensive de-personalized direct observation consortia data sets for the payments industry.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S10	We leverage this consortia data and provide proprietary solutions and information that enable clients to achieve higher profitability and growth through enhanced marketing and risk management decisions.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S11	We have deployed unique technology to manage vast data sets efficiently and manage vast amount of payments data.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S12	We offer services and a suite of solutions to a client base that includes credit and debit card issuers, retail banks and other consumer financial services providers, payment processors, insurance companies, and other industry stakeholders.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S13	Our professionals have substantial industry knowledge in providing solutions to the financial services sector.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S14	We are known for our unique ability to blend the highly technical, data-centered aspects of our projects with expert communication and business knowledge.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S15	Our solutions enhance our clients ability to manage their businesses profitably and position them better to handle present day challenges (competitive, regulatory, and economic).
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S16	Specifically, we use comprehensive transaction, risk, behavioral, and bureau-sourced account data to assist clients in making better business decisions through analysis and analytical solutions.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S17	We maintain a comprehensive and granular direct observation database for credit card, debit card, and deposit transactions in the industry.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S18	Furthermore, we are a leading provider of automated fraud detection, compliance and decision-support tools for the mortgage industry.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S19	Utilizing our own loan level application database combined with actual mortgage loan performance data, we have established a risk scoring system which increases our customers ability to detect fraud.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S20	We provide solutions that detect fraud through each step of the mortgage lifecycle and provide regulatory compliance solutions that perform instant compliance reviews of each mortgage application.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S21	Our fraud solutions can improve our customers profitability by predicting the likelihood that a customer account is experiencing fraud.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S22	Our solution analyzes customer transactions in real time and generates recommendations for immediate action which are critical to stopping fraud and abuse.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P27_S23	These applications can also detect some organized fraud schemes that are too complex and well-hidden to be identified by other methods.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P28_S0	Effective fraud detection relies on pattern identification, which in turn requires us to identify, isolate and track mortgage applications through time.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P29_S0	Histories of multiple loans, both valid and fraudulent, are required to compare a submitted loan both to actual data and heuristic analyses.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P29_S1	For this reason, unless fraud detection solutions are fueled by comprehensive data, their practicality is limited.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P30_S0	Our proprietary database contains more than 23 million current and historical loan applications collected over the past ten years.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P30_S1	This database contains data from loan applications as well as supplementary third-party data.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P31_S0	Our technology employs sophisticated models to identify patterns in the data.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P31_S1	Our solution provides a score, which predicts whether the information provided by a mortgage applicant is correct.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P31_S2	Working with data obtained through our partnership with a credit bureau, we have demonstrated a strong correlation between fraudulent information in the application and the likelihood of both foreclosure and early payment default on loans.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P31_S3	We believe our solution is based upon a more comprehensive set of loan level information than any other provider in the mortgage industry.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P31_S4	We also provide forensic audit services for the mortgage origination and mortgage insurance industries.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P31_S5	Our predictive screening tools predict which defaulted loans are the most likely candidates for full audits for the purpose of detecting fraud.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P31_S6	We then generate detailed audit reports on defaulted mortgage loans.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P31_S7	Those reports serve as a key component of the loss mitigation strategies of mortgage loan insurers.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P32_S0	Healthcare We offer payment accuracy solutions that help healthcare claims payors detect fraud, abuse and overpayment.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P32_S1	Our approach combines computer-based modeling and profiling of claims with analysis performed by clinical experts.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P32_S2	We run our customers claims through our proprietary analytic system to identify potential fraud, abuse and overpayment, and then a registered nurse, physician or other clinical specialist skilled in coding and reimbursement decisions reviews all suspect claims and billing patterns.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P32_S3	This combination of system and human review is unique in the industry and we believe offers improved accuracy for paying claims.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P33_S0	We analyze the patterns of claims produced by individual physicians, physicians practices, hospitals, dentists, and pharmacies to locate the sources of fraud.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P33_S1	After a suspicious source of claims is identified, our real-time analytic solutions investigate each claim individually for particular violations, including upcoding, multiple billings, services claimed but not rendered, and billing by unlicensed providers.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P33_S2	By finding the individual claims with the most cost-recovery potential and also minimizing the number of false-positive indications of fraud, we enable the special investigation units of healthcare payors to efficiently control their claims costs while maintaining high levels of customer service to their insurers.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P33_S3	We also offer web-based reporting tools that let payors take definitive action to prevent overpayments or payment of fraudulent claims.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P33_S4	The tools provide the documentation that helps to identify, investigate and prevent abusive and fraudulent activity by providers.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P34_S0	We provide enterprise analytics and reporting systems to health insurers, provider organizations and self-insured employers.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P34_S1	Those organizations use our healthcare business intelligence solutions to review their data, including information on claims, membership, providers and utilization, and provide cost trends, forecasts and actuarial, financial and utilization analyses.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P34_S2	For example, our solutions allow our customers to predict medical costs and improve the financing and organization of health services.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P34_S3	Our predictive models help our customers identify high-cost cases for care- and disease-management intervention, compare providers adjusting for differences in health, predict resource use for individuals and populations, establish health-based and performance-based payments, negotiate payments and incentives, negotiate premium rates, and measure return on investment.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P34_S4	We also provide our customers healthcare services using complex clinical analyses to uncover reasons behind cost and utilization increases.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P35_S0	Physicians and hospitals are adopting and acquiring new technologies, drugs and devices more rapidly than ever before.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P35_S1	We provide financial and actuarial analyses, clinical, technical and implementation services and training services to help our customers manage costs and risks to their practices.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P35_S2	We are a provider of solutions for revenue quality intelligence and compliance for certain aspects of the healthcare industry.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P35_S3	We have systems, including our revenue integrity business, which analyze Medicare data for compliance with CMS (Centers for Medicare Medicaid Services) guidelines, assist payers in payment integrity, data collection, and encounter data submission.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P35_S4	By using our ReconEdge , a web-based risk adjustment reconciliation system, healthcare payers can assess their organizations opportunities and compliance in payments.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P35_S5	In addition, we offer proprietary systems and services that facilitate the aggregation, retrieval, coding, and analysis of medical records.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P35_S6	We have a repository of medical records that are digitized, indexed, and securely hosted online.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P35_S7	We use custom-built, proprietary technology to deliver medical records from facilities and provider locations.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P36_S0	the clinical data through a cloud-based workflow management system.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P36_S1	We are also a provider of HEDIS (Healthcare Effectiveness Data and Information Set) software solutions.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P36_S2	Our solution suite allows managed care organizations to calculate and submit HEDIS results to NCQA (National Committee for Quality Assurance), improve quality in covered populations, and reduce administrative overhead associated with quality reporting.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P36_S3	We help businesses and governments better anticipate and manage climate- and weather-related risks.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P36_S4	We prepare certain agencies and companies to anticipate, manage, react to and profit from weather and climate related risk.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P36_S5	We serve our clients by providing state-of-the-art research, development and analysis delivered in reports, databases and software solutions.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P36_S6	We are dedicated to the advancement of scientific understanding of the atmospheric, climate and weather, ocean, and planetary sciences.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P36_S7	Through research conducted by our in-house scientific staff, and often in collaboration with world-renowned scientists at academic and other research institutions, we have developed analytical tools to help measure and observe the properties of the environment and to translate these measurements into useful information to take action.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P36_S8	We also offer a comprehensive suite of data and information services that enables improved compliance with global Environmental Health Safety, or EH S requirements related to the safe manufacturing, distribution, transportation, usage and disposal of chemicals and products.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P36_S9	From the supply chain or solutions lifecycle, we deliver a program specific to the EH S compliance information and management needs of our customers.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P36_S10	We have a full solutions lifecycle and cross-supply chain approach that provide a single, integrated solution for managing EH S capabilities, resulting in reduced cost, risk and liability while improving process.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P36_S11	Our Growth Strategy Over the past five years, we have grown our revenues at a CAGR of 14.5% through the successful execution of our business plan.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P36_S12	These results reflect strong organic revenue growth, new product development and selected acquisitions.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P36_S13	We have made, and continue to make, investments in people, data sets, analytic solutions, technology, and complementary businesses.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P36_S14	The key components of our strategy include: Increase Solution Penetration with Insurance Customers.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P36_S15	We expect to expand the application of our solutions in insurance customers internal risk and underwriting processes.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P36_S16	Building on our deep knowledge of, and embedded position in, the insurance industry, we expect to sell more solutions to existing customers tailored to individual insurance segments.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P36_S17	By increasing the breadth and relevance of our offerings, we believe we can strengthen our relationships with customers and increase our value to their decision making in critical ways.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P37_S0	Develop New, Proprietary Data Sets and Predictive Analytics.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P37_S1	We work with our customers to understand their evolving needs.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P37_S2	We plan to create new solutions by enriching our mix of proprietary data sets, analytic solutions and effective decision support across the markets we serve.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P37_S3	We constantly seek to add new data sets that can further leverage our analytic methods, technology platforms and intellectual capital.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P37_S4	Leverage Our Intellectual Capital to Expand into Adjacent Markets and New Customer Sectors.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P37_S5	Our organization is built on nearly four decades of intellectual property in risk management.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P37_S6	We believe we can continue to profitably expand the use of our intellectual capital and apply our analytic methods in new markets, where significant opportunities for long-term growth exist.
1442145_13_ITEM1_P37_S7	We also continue to pursue growth through targeted international expansion.
