1442145_14_ITEM3_P19_S0	Litigation In October 2013, we were served with a summons and complaint filed in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York in an action titled Laurence J. Skelly and Ellen Burke v. Insurance Services Office, Inc. and the Pension Plan for Insurance Organizations.
1442145_14_ITEM3_P19_S1	The plaintiffs, former employees of our subsidiary Insurance Services Office, Inc., or ISO, bring the action on their own behalf as participants in the Pension Plan for Insurance Organizations and on the behalf of similarly situated participants of the pension plan and ask the court to declare that a certain amendment to the pension plan as of December 31, 2001, which terminated their right to calculate and define the value of their retirement benefit under the pension plan based on their compensation levels as of immediately prior to their retirement (the Unlawful Amendment ), violated the anti-cutback provisions and equitable principles of ERISA.
1442145_14_ITEM3_P19_S2	The First Amended Class Action Complaint ( the Amended Complaint ) alleges that (1) the Unlawful Amendment of the pension plan violated Section 502(a)(1)(B) of ERISA as well as the anti-cutback rules of ERISA Section 204(g) and Section 411(d)(6) of the Internal Revenue Code; (2) ISO s failure to provide an ERISA 204(h) notice in a manner calculated to be understood by the average pension plan participant was a violation of Sections 204(h) and 102(a) of ERISA and (3) the Living Pension Right was a contract right under ERISA common law and that by terminating that right through the Unlawful Amendment ISO violated plaintiffs common law contract rights under ERISA.
1442145_14_ITEM3_P19_S3	The Amended Complaint seeks declaratory, equitable and injunctive relief enjoining the enforcement of the Unlawful Amendment and ordering the pension plan and ISO retroactive to the date of the Unlawful Amendment to recalculate the accrued benefits of all class members, indemnification from ISO to the pension plan for costs and contribution requirements related to voiding the Unlawful Amendment, bonuses to the class representatives, costs and attorney s fees.
1442145_14_ITEM3_P19_S4	At this time, it is not possible to determine the ultimate resolution of, or estimate the liability related to, this matter.
1442145_14_ITEM3_P20_S0	On April 9, 2013 our subsidiary ISO was served with a First Amended Petition and Request for Disclosure filed in the District Court of Dallas County, Texas in an action titled Sidah Garner v. Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company, Carfax, Inc., General and Import Motors, Porschea Nicole Kendall, Daniel Scott Hayward and Insurance Services Office, Inc.
1442145_14_ITEM3_P20_S1	Thereafter, on June 5, 2013 and August 16, 2013 plaintiff served its Second Amended Petition and Third Amended Petition ( the Amended Petition ) on defendants.
1442145_14_ITEM3_P21_S0	This action arises from a car accident on June 6, 2011 in which the plaintiff was critically injured.
1442145_14_ITEM3_P21_S1	At the time of the accident the plaintiff was in the passenger seat of a 2004 Mazda, which the plaintiff alleges was previously involved in a total loss rollover collision on April 25, 2006.
1442145_14_ITEM3_P21_S2	The Amended Petition alleges that at the time of the April 2006 accident the Mazda was insured by Nationwide which failed to issue a Texas Salvage Title and that ISO was to provide the crash information to vehicle reporting services, including the defendant Carfax.
1442145_14_ITEM3_P21_S3	It further alleges that the Mazda was rebuilt and auctioned through a multi-state salvage reseller and sold to defendant Kendall (the driver) and that prior to purchase Kendall consulted Carfax s Vehicle History Report which guaranteed no problem with the Mazda s title and that it was not junk, neither salvage nor rebuilt.
1442145_14_ITEM3_P21_S4	As a result, the Amended Petition alleges that Carfax s report was in error and it sets forth a claim for negligence, negligent misrepresentation, gross negligence, strict liability, breach of contract and fraud against defendants Nationwide Insurance, Carfax and ISO in addition to the negligence claims against defendants General and Import Motors and Kendall and Hayward.
1442145_14_ITEM3_P21_S5	It seeks actual damages, pain and suffering, loss of past and future earnings, past and future impairment and disfigurement, costs and interest from all defendants and exemplary damages from Nationwide, ISO and Carfax.
1442145_14_ITEM3_P21_S6	The court denied the summary judgment motions of ISO and Nationwide on December 19, 2013 and January 6, 2014, respectively and granted the summary judgment motion of Carfax on January 27, 2014.
1442145_14_ITEM3_P21_S7	Trial is scheduled to commence on March 3, 2014.
1442145_14_ITEM3_P22_S0	At this time, it is not possible to determine the ultimate resolution of, or estimate the liability related to, this matter.
1442145_14_ITEM5_P0_S0	Market Information Verisk trades under the ticker symbol VRSK on the NASDAQ Global Select Market.
1442145_14_ITEM5_P0_S1	Our common stock was first publicly traded on October 7, 2009.
1442145_14_ITEM5_P0_S2	As of February 21, 2014 , the closing price of our Class A common stock was $65.53 per share, as reported by the NASDAQ Global Select Market.
1442145_14_ITEM5_P0_S3	As of February 21, 2014 , there were approximately 28 Class A stockholders of record.
1442145_14_ITEM5_P0_S4	We believe the number of beneficial owners is substantially greater than the number of record holders for Class A, because a large portion of Class A common stock is held in street name by brokers.
1442145_14_ITEM5_P0_S5	We converted all Class B shares to Class A shares in 2011 and currently have no outstanding Class B shares.
1442145_14_ITEM5_P0_S6	We have not paid or declared any cash dividends on our Class A common stock during the two most recent fiscal years and we currently do not intend to pay dividends on our Class A common stock.
1442145_14_ITEM5_P0_S7	We do have a publicly announced share repurchase plan and have repurchased 34,420,219 shares since our IPO.
1442145_14_ITEM5_P0_S8	As of December 31, 2013 , we had 376,545,111 shares of treasury stock.

1442145_14_ITEM6_P4_S0	(1) During the second quarter of 2011, we reevaluated the probability of D2Hawkeye and Strategic Analytics achieving the specified predetermined EBITDA and revenue targets for exceptional performance in fiscal year 2011 and reversed the contingent consideration related to these acquisitions.
1442145_14_ITEM6_P4_S1	During the third quarter of 2010, we reevaluated the probability of TierMed achieving the specified predetermined EBITDA and revenue targets and reversed its contingent consideration related to this acquisition.
1442145_14_ITEM6_P5_S0	(2) As of December 31, 2013, we finalized our plans to sell our mortgage services business.
1442145_14_ITEM6_P5_S1	of our consolidated financial statements included in this Annual Report Form 10-K. (3) EBITDA is the financial measure which management uses to evaluate the performance of our segments.
1442145_14_ITEM6_P5_S2	EBITDA is defined as net income before interest expense, provision for income taxes, depreciation and amortization of fixed and intangible assets.
1442145_14_ITEM6_P5_S3	In the second quarter of 2012, we changed our definition of EBITDA such that it only reflects the definition noted and no longer excludes investment income (loss) and realized gain (loss) on available-for-sale securities, net for all periods presented.
1442145_14_ITEM6_P5_S4	In addition, this Management s Discussion and Analysis includes references to EBITDA margin, which is computed as EBITDA divided by revenues from continuing and discontinued operations.
1442145_14_ITEM6_P6_S0	of our consolidated financial statements included in this Annual Report Form 10-K.
1442145_14_ITEM6_P7_S0	Although EBITDA is a non-GAAP financial measure, EBITDA is frequently used by securities analysts, lenders and others in their evaluation of companies, EBITDA has limitations as an analytical tool, and should not be considered in isolation, or as a substitute for an analysis of our results of operations or cash flow from operating activities reported under GAAP.
1442145_14_ITEM6_P7_S1	Management uses EBITDA in conjunction with traditional GAAP operating performance measures as part of its overall assessment of company performance.
1442145_14_ITEM6_P8_S0	Other companies in our industry may calculate EBITDA differently than we do, limiting its usefulness as a comparative measure.
1442145_14_ITEM6_P8_S1	Please note because EBITDA is calculated from net income, this presentation includes EBITDA from discontinued operations of our mortgage services business.
1442145_14_ITEM6_P8_S2	(5) Subsequent to our corporate reorganization on October 6, 2009, share repurchases are recorded as treasury stock within stockholders equity (deficit), as we intend to reissue shares from treasury stock in the future.
1442145_14_ITEM6_P8_S3	For the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012 , we repurchased $278.9 million and $162.6 million, respectively, of treasury stock.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P0_S0	The following discussion should be read in conjunction with our historical financial statements and the related notes included elsewhere in this annual report on Form 10-K, as well as the discussion under Selected Consolidated Financial Data.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P1_S0	This discussion contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P1_S1	Our actual results may differ materially from those discussed in or implied by any of the forward-looking statements as a result of various factors, including but not limited to those listed under Risk Factors and Special Note Regarding Forward-Looking Statements.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P2_S0	We enable risk-bearing businesses to better understand and manage their risks and opportunities associated with those risks.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P2_S1	We provide value to our customers by supplying proprietary data that, combined with our analytic methods, creates embedded decision support solutions.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P2_S2	We are the largest aggregator and provider of data pertaining to U.S. property and casualty, or P C, insurance risks.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P2_S3	We offer solutions for detecting fraud in the U.S. P C insurance, financial services and healthcare industries and sophisticated methods to predict and quantify loss in diverse contexts ranging from natural catastrophes to supply chain to health insurance.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P2_S4	Our customers use our solutions to make better risk decisions with greater efficiency and discipline.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P2_S5	We refer to these products and services as solutions due to the integration among our products and the flexibility that enables our customers to purchase components or the comprehensive package of products.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P2_S6	These solutions take various forms, including data, statistical models or tailored analytics, all designed to allow our clients to make more logical decisions.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P2_S7	We believe our solutions for analyzing risk positively impact our customers revenues and help them better manage their costs.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P3_S0	On May 23, 2008, in contemplation of our IPO, Insurance Service Office, Inc., or ISO, formed Verisk Analytics, Inc., or Verisk, a Delaware corporation, to be the holding company for our business.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P3_S1	Verisk was initially formed as a wholly-owned subsidiary of ISO.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P3_S2	On October 6, 2009 in connection with our IPO, we effected a reorganization whereby ISO became a wholly-owned subsidiary of Verisk.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P3_S3	On October 1, 2010, we completed a follow-on public offering.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P3_S4	We did not receive any proceeds from the sale of common stock in the offering.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P4_S0	The primary purpose of the offering was to manage and organize the sale by Class B insurance company shareholders while providing incremental public float.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P4_S1	Concurrently with the closing of the offering, we repurchased shares of common stock, for an aggregate purchase price of $192.5 million, directly from selling shareholders owning Class B common stock.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P4_S2	We converted all Class B shares to Class A shares in 2011 and currently have no outstanding Class B shares.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P4_S3	We organize our business in two segments: Risk Assessment and Decision Analytics.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P5_S0	Our Risk Assessment segment provides statistical, actuarial and underwriting data for the U.S. P C insurance industry.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P5_S1	Our Risk Assessment segment revenues represented approximately 38.7% and 41.2% of our revenues for the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012 , respectively.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P5_S2	Effective December 31, 2012, we combined the statistical agency and data services and actuarial services into industry-standard insurance programs within our Risk Assessment segment.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P6_S0	to analyze the processes of the Verisk Risk Analysis Framework: Prediction of Loss, Detection and Prevention of Fraud, and Quantification of Loss.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P7_S0	Effective December 31, 2011, we realigned the revenue categories within our Decision Analytics segment, including fraud identification and detection solutions, loss prediction solutions and loss quantification solutions, into four vertical market-related groupings of insurance, financial services, healthcare, and specialized markets.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P7_S1	We believe that this enhances financial reporting transparency and helps investors better understand the themes within the Decision Analytics segment.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P7_S2	Our Decision Analytics segment revenues represented approximately 61.3% and 58.8% of our revenues for the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012 , respectively.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P8_S0	In January 2014, we entered into an agreement to acquire 100% of the stock of Eagleview Technology Corporation ( EVT ), the parent company of Pictometry International Corp., and Eagle View Technologies, Inc. for a net cash purchase price of $650 million, which will be funded by the Company's operating cash and borrowings from our credit facility.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P8_S1	EVT is a provider of geo-referenced aerial image capture and visual-centric data analytics and solutions to insurers, contractors, government, and commercial customers in the United States.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P8_S2	This acquisition is expected to advance our position in the imagery analytics market, adding new municipal and commercial customers.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P8_S3	The transaction is expected to support the aerial imagery solution development in our Decision Analytics segment.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P8_S4	The parties expect the transaction to close by July 2014, subject to the completion of customary closing conditions, including receipt of regulatory and shareholder approvals.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P8_S5	Once the acquisition is completed, we plan to include EVT in the insurance vertical of our Decision Analytics segment.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P9_S0	In February 2014, we entered into an agreement to sell our mortgage services business.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P9_S1	The transaction is subject to regulatory approval and other customary closing conditions and is expected to close by March 31, 2014.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P10_S0	From 2009 to 2011, the mortgage services business was in both Risk Assessment segment within the insurance services revenue category and Decision Analytics segment in the financial services revenue category.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P10_S1	In 2012, we reclassified the appraisal mortgage tools from Risk Assessment to our Decision Analytics segment in the financial services revenue category.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P10_S2	Therefore, in 2012 and 2013, the mortgage services business is within Decision Analytics segment.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P10_S3	Results of operations for the mortgage services business are reported as a discontinued operation for the year ended December 31, 2013 and for all prior periods presented.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P10_S4	See Note 10 of our consolidated financial statements included in this Annual Report Form 10-K. As necessary, all amounts have been retroactively adjusted in all periods presented to give recognition to this discontinued operations.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P11_S0	We believe our business s ability to generate recurring revenue and positive cash flow is the key indicator of the successful execution of our business strategy.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P11_S1	We use year over year revenue growth and EBITDA margin as metrics to measure our performance.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P11_S2	EBITDA and EBITDA margin are non-GAAP financial measures (see Note 3.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P11_S3	Selected Financial Data section of Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations).
1442145_14_ITEM7_P12_S0	We use year over year revenue growth as a key performance metric.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P12_S1	We assess revenue growth based on our ability to generate increased revenue through increased sales to existing customers, sales to new customers, sales of new or expanded solutions to existing and new customers and strategic acquisitions of new businesses.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P12_S2	We use EBITDA margin as a metric to assess segment performance and scalability of our business.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P13_S0	We assess EBITDA margin based on our ability to increase revenues while controlling expense growth.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P13_S1	Revenues We earn revenues through subscriptions, long-term agreements and on a transactional basis.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P13_S2	Subscriptions for our solutions are generally paid in advance of rendering services either quarterly or in full upon commencement of the subscription period, which is usually for one year and automatically renewed each year.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P13_S3	As a result, the timing of our cash flows generally precedes our recognition of revenues and income and our cash flow from operations tends to be higher in the first quarter as we receive subscription payments.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P13_S4	Examples of these arrangements include subscriptions that allow our customers to access our standardized coverage language, our claims fraud database or our actuarial services throughout the subscription period.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P14_S0	In general, we experience minimal revenue seasonality within the business.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P14_S1	Our long-term agreements are generally for periods of three to five years.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P14_S2	We recognize revenue from subscriptions ratably over the term of the subscription and most long-term agreements are recognized ratably over the term of the agreement.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P14_S3	Certain of our solutions are also paid for by our customers on a transactional basis.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P14_S4	For example, we have solutions that allow our customers to obtain property-specific rating and underwriting information to price a policy on a commercial building, or compare a P C insurance, medical or workers compensation claim with information in our databases.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P14_S5	For the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012 , 26.4% and 27.6% of our revenues, respectively, were derived from providing transactional solutions.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P15_S0	We earn transactional revenues as our solutions are delivered or services performed.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P15_S1	In general, transactions are billed monthly at the end of each month.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P15_S2	Approximately 88.2% and 87.1% of the revenues in our Risk Assessment segment for the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012 , respectively, were derived from subscriptions and long-term agreements for our solutions.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P15_S3	Our customers in this segment include most of the P C insurance providers in the United States.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P15_S4	Approximately 64.4% and 62.1% of the revenues in our Decision Analytics segment, for the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012 , respectively, were derived from subscriptions and long-term agreements for our solutions.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P15_S5	Principal Operating Costs and Expenses Personnel expenses are the major component of both our cost of revenues and selling, general and administrative expenses.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P15_S6	Personnel expenses, which represented 59.7% and 62.6% of our total expenses for the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012 , respectively include salaries, benefits, incentive compensation, equity compensation costs, sales commissions, employment taxes, recruiting costs, and outsourced temporary agency costs.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P15_S7	We allocate personnel expenses between two categories, cost of revenues and selling, general and administrative costs, based on the actual costs associated with each employee.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P15_S8	We categorize employees who maintain our solutions as cost of revenues, and all other personnel, including executive managers, sales people, marketing, business development, finance, legal, human resources, and administrative services, as selling, general and administrative expenses.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P15_S9	A significant portion of our other operating costs, such as facilities and communications, are also either captured within cost of revenues or selling, general and administrative expense based on the nature of the work being performed.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P15_S10	While we expect to grow our headcount over time to take advantage of our market opportunities, we believe that the economies of scale in our operating model will allow us to grow our personnel expenses at a lower rate than revenues.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P15_S11	Historically, our EBITDA margin has improved because we have been able to increase revenues without a proportionate corresponding increase in expenses.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P15_S12	However, part of our corporate strategy is to invest in new solutions which may offset margin expansion.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P15_S13	Our cost of revenues consists primarily of personnel expenses.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P15_S14	Cost of revenues also includes the expenses associated with the acquisition and verification of data, the maintenance of our existing solutions and the development and enhancement of our next-generation solutions.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P15_S15	Our cost of revenues excludes depreciation and amortization.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P15_S16	Our selling, general and administrative expense also consists primarily of personnel costs.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P15_S17	A portion of the other operating costs such as facilities, insurance and communications are also allocated to selling, general and administrative costs based on the nature of the work being performed by the employee.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P15_S18	Our selling, general and administrative expenses excludes depreciation and amortization.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P15_S19	We serve customers in three primary vertical markets: property/casualty insurance, healthcare, and financial services.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P15_S20	The industry trends in each of those markets can affect our business.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P16_S0	Growth in property/casualty insurers direct written premiums is cyclical, with total industry premium growth receding from a peak of 14.7% in 2002 to a trough of negative 3.1% in 2009 and subsequently recovering to 4.4% in 2012 and 4.1% through nine-months 2013.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P16_S1	Based on reports of firming in insurance markets, and assuming modest growth in the economy, we expect premium growth near recent rates through 2014.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P16_S2	Growth or decline in premiums for the lines of insurance for which we perform services could positively or negatively affect our revenues, because premium growth can affect the volume of solutions as well as the number and types of solutions our customers buy.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P16_S3	Also, we link the invoices of certain solutions in part to an individual customer s premiums from prior years for a portion of our customers.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P16_S4	The pricing for those solutions is fixed at the beginning of each calendar year.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P16_S5	We have also signed multiyear contracts with certain customers, and for those customers, pricing is fixed at the beginning of each multiyear period.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P17_S0	Trends in catastrophe and noncatastrophe weather losses can have an effect on our customers profitability and therefore their appetite for buying analytics to help them manage their risks.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P17_S1	The apparent increase in the frequency and severity of weather events that cause losses for insurers could lead to increased demand for our catastrophe modeling, catastrophe loss information, and repair cost solutions.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P17_S2	A significant decrease in the number or severity of catastrophes could negatively affect our revenues.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P17_S3	We also have a portion of our revenue related to the number of claims processed due to losses which can be impacted by seasonal storm activity.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P17_S4	The need by our customers to fight insurance fraud both in claims and at policy inception could lead to increased demand for our underwriting and claims solutions.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P17_S5	Additionally, a significant change in insurers profitability could positively or negatively affect demand for our solutions.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P18_S0	Trends in the U.S. healthcare market can affect a portion of our revenues in the Decision Analytics segment.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P18_S1	That market is undergoing significant change as the result of healthcare reform legislation.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P18_S2	The specific trends we see affecting our current healthcare business include payment reform, expansion of insurance coverage, and efforts at cost containment.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P18_S3	Payment reform will likely drive the market to value-based reimbursement and require healthcare providers to bear increased financial risk and responsibility for quality outcomes.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P18_S4	The expansion of insurance eligibility will increase Medicaid rolls and promote participation in statewide health exchanges.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P18_S5	And as the government seeks to control fraud, waste, and abuse, efforts to contain costs will likely become more prevalent.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P18_S6	Although such changes have the potential to disrupt the healthcare marketplace, we believe the requirements for reform could increase demand for our analytic solutions in the areas of population management, quality measurement, Medicare Advantage revenue management and compliance, risk adjustment, and detection of prepayment fraud and abuse.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P18_S7	We experience seasonality in our Medicare Advantage business tied to third and fourth quarters of our fiscal year, related to CMS deadlines.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P18_S8	Description of Acquisitions We acquired six businesses since January 1, 2011.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P18_S9	As a result of these acquisitions, our consolidated results of operations may not be comparable between periods.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P19_S0	On December 20, 2012, we acquired the net assets of Insurance Risk Management Solutions, or IRMS.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P19_S1	IRMS provided integrated property risk assessment technology underlying one of our GIS (geographic information system) underwriting solutions.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P19_S2	At the end of 2012, this long-term contract (since 1992) with IRMS was expiring and precipitated a change in our business relationship.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P19_S3	Instead of continuing forward with a new services agreement, we acquired the technology and service assets of IRMS as this will enable us to better manage, enhance and continue to use the solutions as part of our Risk Assessment segment.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P19_S4	This acquisition had minimal revenue and operating expense impact for the year ending December 31, 2012, given the timing of the acquisition.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P19_S5	See Note 9. to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K for the preliminary purchase allocation.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P20_S0	On August 31, 2012, we acquired Argus Information Advisory Services, LLC, or Argus, a provider of information, competitive benchmarking, scoring solutions, analytics, and customized services to financial institutions and regulators in North America, Latin America, and Europe.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P20_S1	Argus leverages its comprehensive payment data sets and provides proprietary solutions to a client base that includes credit and debit card issuers, retail banks and other consumer financial services providers, payment processors, insurance companies, and other industry stakeholders.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P20_S2	Within our Decision Analytics segment, this acquisition enhances our position as a provider of data, analytics, and decision-support solutions to financial institutions globally.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P21_S0	to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K for the preliminary purchase allocation.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P22_S0	On July 2, 2012, we acquired the net assets of Aspect Loss Prevention, LLC, or ALP, a provider of loss prevention and analytic solutions to the retail, entertainment, and food industries.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P22_S1	Within our Decision Analytics segment, this acquisition further advances our position as a provider of data, crime analytics, and decision-support solutions.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P23_S0	to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K for the preliminary purchase allocation.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P24_S0	On March 30, 2012, we acquired 100% of the stock of MediConnect Global, Inc., or MediConnect, a service provider of medical record retrieval, digitization, coding, extraction, and analysis.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P24_S1	Within our Decision Analytics segment, MediConnect further supports our objective to be the leading provider of data, analytics, and decision-support solutions to the healthcare and property casualty industries.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P25_S0	to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K for the preliminary purchase allocation.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P26_S0	On June 17, 2011, we acquired the net assets of Health Risk Partners, LLC, or HRP, a provider of solutions to optimize revenue, improve compliance and improve quality of care for Medicare Advantage health plans.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P26_S1	Within our Decision Analytics segment, this acquisition further advances our position as a major provider of data, analytics, and decision-support solutions to the healthcare industry.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P27_S0	On April 27, 2011, we acquired 100% of the common stock of Bloodhound Technologies, Inc. or Bloodhound, a provider of real-time pre-adjudication medical claims editing.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P27_S1	Within our Decision Analytics segment, Bloodhound addresses the need of healthcare payers to control fraud and waste in a real-time claims-processing environment, and these capabilities align with our existing fraud identification tools.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P28_S0	In February 2014, we entered into an agreement to sell our mortgage services business, Interthinx, for a price of $155.0 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P28_S1	The transaction is subject to regulatory approval and other customary closing conditions and is expected to close by March 31, 2014.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P28_S2	Results of operations for the mortgage services business are reported as a discontinued operation for the year ended December 31, 2013 and for all prior periods presented.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P28_S3	of our consolidated financial statements included in this Annual Report Form 10-K.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P29_S0	Year Ended December 31, 2013 Compared to Year Ended December 31, 2012 Consolidated Results of Continuing Operations Revenues Revenues were $1,595.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to $1,407.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 , an increase of $187.9 million or 13.3%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P30_S0	In 2012 , we acquired MediConnect, ALP, and Argus, collectively referred to as recent acquisitions, which we define as acquisitions not owned for a significant portion of both the current period and/or prior period and would therefore impact the comparability of the financial results.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P30_S1	MediConnect was included as a recent acquisition only for the first quarter of 2013; ALP was included as a recent acquisition in the first and second quarters of 2013; Argus was included as a recent acquisition in the first, second and third quarters of 2013 as full quarter comparable revenues did not exist until certain quarters of 2012 due to the timing of the acquisitions.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P30_S2	These recent acquisitions were within our Decision Analytics segment and provided an increase of $68.1 million in revenues for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P30_S3	Excluding recent acquisitions, revenues increased $119.8 million or 8.5% , which included an increase in our Decision Analytics segment of $81.0 million or 9.8% and an increase in our Risk Assessment segment of $38.8 million or 6.7%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P30_S4	Revenue growth within Decision Analytics was primarily driven by increases in our healthcare revenue category and contributions from our insurance revenue category.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P30_S5	Both categories, industry-standard insurance programs and property-specific rating and underwriting information, within Risk Assessment contributed to its revenue growth.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P30_S6	Refer to the Results of Continuing Operations by Segment within this section for further information regarding our revenues.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P30_S7	Cost of Revenues Cost of revenues was $622.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to $516.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 , an increase of $105.8 million or 20.5% .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P30_S8	Recent acquisitions all within the Decision Analytics segment, accounted for an increase of $36.8 million in cost of revenues for the year ended December 31, 2013 which were primarily related to salaries and employee benefits.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P30_S9	Excluding the impact of our recent acquisitions, our cost of revenues increased $69.0 million or 13.4%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P30_S10	The increase was primarily due to increases in salaries and employee benefits cost of $36.6 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P30_S11	Other increases include data costs and data processing fees of $17.7 million, information technology expense of $7.4 million, travel and travel related costs of $3.2 million and other operating costs of $4.1 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P30_S12	Selling, General and Administrative Expenses Selling, general and administrative expenses, or SGA, were $229.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to $220.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 , an increase of $8.9 million or 4.1% .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P30_S13	Recent acquisitions accounted for an increase of $3.8 million, which was primarily related to professional fees.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P30_S14	Excluding costs associated with our recent acquisitions, SGA increased $5.1 million or 2.3%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P30_S15	The increase was primarily due to an increase in professional fees of $3.0 million, travel and travel related items of $0.8 million, salaries and employee benefits of $0.7 million, and other general and administrative expenses of $0.6 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P30_S16	The increase in salaries and benefits of $0.7 million includes an increase of $5.1 million in annual salaries increases, medical costs and commissions, offset by a decrease in our stock option expense of $4.1 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P30_S17	Our stock option expense decreased as a result of lower accelerated vesting of equity awards granted to employees at age 62.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P30_S18	Other decreases include a decrease in pension expense of $0.3 million, primarily due to our pension plan freeze.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P30_S19	Depreciation and Amortization of Fixed Assets Depreciation and amortization of fixed assets was $66.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to $46.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 , an increase of $19.6 million or 41.9%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P31_S0	Depreciation and amortization of fixed assets includes depreciation of furniture and equipment, software, computer hardware, and related equipment.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P31_S1	The majority of the increase relates to software and hardware costs to support data capacity expansion and revenue growth.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P32_S0	Amortization of Intangible Assets Amortization of intangible assets was $63.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to $52.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 , an increase of $11.5 million or 22.1%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P32_S1	The increase was primarily related to amortization of intangible assets associated with recent acquisitions of $16.0 million, partially offset by $4.5 million of amortization of intangible assets associated with prior acquisitions that have been fully amortized.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P33_S0	Investment Income and Realized (Loss) Gain on Securities, Net Investment income and realized gain on securities, net, was a gain of $0.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 as compared to a gain of $0.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 , an increase of $0.5 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P33_S1	Interest Expense Interest expense was $76.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to $72.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 , an increase of $3.6 million or 5.0%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P33_S2	This increase is primarily due to the issuance of our senior notes in September 2012 with an aggregate principal balance of $350.0 million, partially offset by the repayment of $180.0 million of private placement debt during the year.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P33_S3	Provision for Income Taxes The provision for income taxes was $196.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to $182.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 , an increase of $14.0 million or 7.7%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P33_S4	The effective tax rate was 36.5% for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to 36.5% for the year ended December 31, 2012 .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P33_S5	The EBITDA margin for our consolidated results including discontinued operations, was 44.6% for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to 45.4% for the year ended December 31, 2012 .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P33_S6	For the year ended December 31, 2013 , the recent acquisitions mitigated our margin expansion by 0.2%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P33_S7	Results of Continuing Operations by Segment Decision Analytics Revenues Revenues for our Decision Analytics segment were $977.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to $828.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 , an increase of $149.1 million or 18.0%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P33_S8	Recent acquisitions accounted for an increase of $68.1 million in revenues for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P33_S9	Excluding recent acquisitions, our Decision Analytics revenue increased $81.0 million or 9.8% .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P33_S10	As described, our results in the Decision Analytics segment give effect to discontinued operations of our mortgage services business, which was part of our financial services vertical.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P33_S11	Our revenue by category for the periods presented is set forth below for the years ended December 31:
1442145_14_ITEM7_P34_S0	Our insurance revenue increased $45.7 million or 9.3% , and excluding recent acquisitions (ALP) revenue of $1.2 million for the first and second quarters within this category, our insurance revenue increased $44.5 million or 9.0% , primarily due to an increase within our underwriting solutions, an increase in catastrophe modeling services for existing customers, as well an increase in insurance fraud solutions revenue, and an increase in loss quantification solutions.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P35_S0	Our financial services revenue increased $54.5 million or 205.3% , and excluding recent acquisitions (Argus) revenue of $50.1 million for the first, second and third quarters within this category, our financial services revenue increased $4.4 million or 20.2% .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P35_S1	This financial services revenue reflects Argus' increased solutions which became part of organic revenue in the fourth quarter.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P35_S2	Our healthcare revenue increased $48.6 million or 21.8% , and excluding the recent acquisitions ( MediConnect) revenue for the first quarter of $16.8 million within this category, our healthcare revenue increased $31.8 million or 14.3% primarily due to an increase in transactions within our revenue and quality intelligence solutions and due to an increase in payment accuracy solutions as customer contracts were implemented.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P35_S3	Our specialized markets revenue increased $0.3 million or 0.3% as a result of modest increase in our supply chain services, offset by a decrease in weather and climate risk solutions.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P35_S4	Cost of Revenues Cost of revenues for our Decision Analytics segment was $428.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to $334.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 , an increase of $93.7 million or 28.0% .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P35_S5	Excluding the impact of recent acquisitions of $36.8 million, our cost of revenues increased by $56.9 million or 17.1%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P35_S6	This increase is primarily due to a net increase in salary and employee benefits of $30.6 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P35_S7	Other increases include data costs and data processing fees of $16.7 million, information technology expenses of $4.7 million, travel and travel related costs of $1.3 million, and other general expenses of $3.6 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P35_S8	Selling, General and Administrative Expenses Selling, general and administrative expenses for our Decision Analytics segment were $151.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to $139.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 , an increase of $12.4 million or 8.9% .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P35_S9	Excluding the impact of recent acquisitions of $3.8 million, SGA increased $8.6 million or 6.2%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P35_S10	The increase was primarily due to an increase in salaries and employee benefits of $6.9 million, professional fees of $0.5 million, costs related to travel expenses of $0.4 million, and other general and administrative expenses of $0.8 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P35_S11	The EBITDA margin for our Decision Analytics segment including our discontinued operations, was 38.0% for the year ended December 31, 2013 and 39.8% for the year ended December 31, 2012 .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P35_S12	For the year ended December 31, 2013 , the recent acquisitions mitigated our margin expansion by 0.2%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P35_S13	Risk Assessment Revenues Revenues for our Risk Assessment segment were $618.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 as compared to $579.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 , an increase of $38.8 million or 6.7% .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P35_S14	The overall increase within this segment primarily resulted from an increase in prices derived from continued enhancements to the content of our industry-standard insurance programs solutions as well as selling expanded solutions to existing customers.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P35_S15	Our revenue by category for the periods presented is set forth below for the years ended December 31:
1442145_14_ITEM7_P36_S0	Cost of Revenues Cost of revenues for our Risk Assessment segment was $194.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to $182.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 , an increase of $12.1 million or 6.7% .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P36_S1	The increase was primarily due to an increase in salaries and employee benefits costs of $6.0 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P36_S2	Other increases were related to information technology expenses of $2.7 million, data and consulting costs of $1.0 million, travel expenses of $1.9 million, and other general expenses of $0.5 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P36_S3	Selling, General and Administrative Expenses Selling, general and administrative expenses for our Risk Assessment segment were $77.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to $80.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 , a decrease of $3.5 million or 4.4% .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P36_S4	The decrease was primarily due to a decrease in salaries and employee benefits of $6.2 million, primarily related our stock option expense.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P36_S5	Our stock option expense decreased as a result of lower accelerated vesting of equity awards granted to employees at age 62.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P36_S6	There was also a decrease in other general expenses of $0.2 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P36_S7	These decreases were offset by an increase in professional consulting fees of $2.5 million and travel costs of $0.4 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P37_S0	The EBITDA margin for our Risk Assessment segment was 56.1% for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to 54.6% for the year ended December 31, 2012 .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P37_S1	The increase in margin is primarily attributed to operating leverage in the segment as well as cost efficiencies.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P38_S0	Year Ended December 31, 2012 Compared to Year Ended December 31, 2011 Consolidated Results of Continuing Operations Revenues Revenues were $1,407.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 compared to $1,191.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 , an increase of $216.4 million or 18.2%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P39_S0	In 2011 and 2012 , we acquired the following companies Bloodhound, HRP, MediConnect, ALP, and Argus, collectively referred to as recent acquisitions, which we define as acquisitions not owned for a significant portion of both the current period and/or prior period and would therefore impact the comparability of the financial results.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P39_S1	Bloodhound and HRP were included as recent acquisitions only for the first and second quarters of 2012 and 2011 as full quarter comparable revenues did not exist until the third quarter of 2012 due to the timing of the acquisitions.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P39_S2	These recent acquisitions were within our Decision Analytics segment and provided an increase of $105.1 million in revenues for the year ended December 31, 2012.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P39_S3	Excluding recent acquisitions, revenues increased $111.3 million or 9.3%, which included an increase in our Decision Analytics segment of $84.1 million or 13.2% and an increase in our Risk Assessment segment of $27.2 million or 4.9%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P39_S4	Revenue growth within Decision Analytics was primarily driven by strong increases in our healthcare revenue category and contributions from our insurance revenue category.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P39_S5	Revenue growth within Risk Assessment was primarily driven by our industry-standard insurance programs.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P39_S6	Refer to the Results of Continuing Operations by Segment within this section for further information regarding our revenues.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P39_S7	Cost of Revenues Cost of revenues was $516.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 compared to $441.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 , an increase of $75.7 million or 17.2%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P39_S8	Recent acquisitions, all within the Decision Analytics segment, accounted for an increase of $51.5 million in cost of revenues for the year ended December 31, 2012 , which were primarily related to salaries and employee benefits.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P39_S9	Excluding the impact of our recent acquisitions, our cost of revenues increased $24.2 million or 5.5%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P39_S10	The increase was primarily due to increases in salaries and employee benefits cost of $16.8 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P39_S11	Other increases include information technology expense of $3.3 million, data costs of $3.0 million, travel and travel related costs of $0.4 million, rent expense of $0.4 million and other operating costs of $0.3 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P39_S12	The increase in salaries and employee benefits of $16.8 million includes an increase of $27.1 million in annual salaries and employee benefits such as medical costs and equity incentive plans, and was partially offset by a decrease of $10.3 million in pension costs.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P39_S13	The pension cost decreased primarily due to our pension plan freeze in 2012, which eliminated all future compensation and services credits to participants of our pension plan.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P40_S0	Selling, General and Administrative Expenses Selling, general and administrative expenses, or SGA, were $220.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 compared to $199.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 , an increase of $20.6 million or 10.3%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P40_S1	Recent acquisitions accounted for an increase of $11.1 million, which was primarily related to salaries and employee benefits.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P40_S2	Excluding costs associated with our recent acquisitions, SGA increased $9.5 million or 4.8%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P40_S3	The increase was primarily due to an increase in salaries and employee benefits of $7.3 million, cost related to travel and travel related items of $0.4 million, professional fees of $0.4 million and other general expenses of $1.4 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P40_S4	The increase in salaries and benefits of $7.3 million includes an increase of $10.0 million in annual salaries increases, medical costs, commissions, and long term equity compensation plan costs.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P40_S5	This was offset by a decrease of $2.7 million in pension cost, primarily due to our pension plan freeze.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P40_S6	Depreciation and Amortization of Fixed Assets Depreciation and amortization of fixed assets was $46.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 compared to $40.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 , an increase of $6.5 million or 16.2%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P41_S0	Depreciation and amortization of fixed assets includes depreciation of furniture and equipment, software, computer hardware, and related equipment.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P41_S1	The majority of the increase relates to software and hardware costs to support data capacity expansion and revenue growth.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P41_S2	Amortization of Intangible Assets Amortization of intangible assets was $52.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 compared to $33.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 1, an increase of $19.2 million or 58.2%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P41_S3	The increase was primarily related to amortization of intangible assets associated with recent acquisitions of $22.1 million, partially offset by $2.9 million of amortization of intangible assets associated with prior acquisitions that have been fully amortized.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P41_S4	Acquisition Related Liabilities Adjustment There was no acquisition related liabilities adjustment for the year ended December 31, 2012 compared to $3.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P41_S5	This benefit was a result of a reduction of $3.4 million to contingent consideration due to the reduced probability of the D2 and SA acquisitions achieving the EBITDA and revenue earnout targets for exceptional performance in fiscal year 2011 established at the time of acquisition.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P42_S0	Investment Income and Realized (Loss) Gain on Securities, Net Investment income and realized gain on securities, net, was a gain of $0.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to a gain of $0.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 , a decrease of $0.8 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P42_S1	Interest Expense Interest expense was $72.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 compared to $53.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2011, an increase of $18.7 million or 34.8%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P42_S2	This increase is primarily due to the issuance of our 5.800% senior notes in April 2011, 4.875% senior notes in December 2011 and 4.125% senior notes in September 2012 in aggregate principal amounts of $450.0 million, $250.0 million and $350.0 million, respectively.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P42_S3	Provision for Income Taxes The provision for income taxes was $182.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 compared to $165.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 , an increase of $16.7 million or 10.0%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P42_S4	The effective tax rate was 36.5% for the year ended December 31, 2012 compared to 38.7% for the year ended December 31, 2011 .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P42_S5	The effective rate for the year ended December 31, 2012 was lower due to benefits resulting from the successful execution of tax planning strategies, in which a portion was a non-recurring benefit.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P42_S6	The EBITDA margin for our consolidated results including discontinued operations, was 45.4% for the year ended December 31, 2012 compared to 44.5% for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P42_S7	For the year ended December 31, 2012 , the recent acquisitions mitigated our margin expansion by 0.5%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P42_S8	The increase in margin is primarily attributed to operating leverage as well as cost efficiencies achieved in 2012.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P42_S9	For the year ended December 31, 2011, the acquisition related liability adjustment positively impacted our EBITDA margin by 0.2%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P43_S0	Results of Continuing Operations by Segment Decision Analytics Revenues Revenues for our Decision Analytics segment were $828.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 compared to $639.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 , an increase of $189.2 million or 29.6% .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P43_S1	Recent acquisitions accounted for an increase of $105.1 million in revenues for the year ended December 31, 2012 .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P43_S2	Excluding recent acquisitions, our Decision Analytics revenue increased $84.1 million or 13.2%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P44_S0	Our insurance revenue increased $42.2 million or 9.4% , and excluding recent acquisitions (ALP) revenue of $0.8 million within this category, our insurance revenue increased $41.4 million or 9.2%, primarily due to an increase within our loss quantification solutions as a result of new customers and an increase in our catastrophe modeling services for existing customers, as well an increase in insurance fraud solutions revenue.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P44_S1	Our financial services revenue increased $21.3 million or 399.1% , and excluding recent acquisitions (Argus) revenue of $21.5 million within this category, our financial services revenue decreased $0.2 million or 3.8%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P44_S2	Our healthcare revenue increased $119.2 million or 115.0% , and excluding recent acquisitions (Bloodhound, HRP and MediConnect) revenue of $82.8 million within this category, our healthcare revenue increased $36.4 million or 36.2% primarily due to an increase in transactions within our revenue integrity solutions and due to increase fraud services as customer contracts were implemented.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P44_S3	Our specialized markets revenue increased $6.5 million or 8.3% as a result of continued penetration of existing customers within our supply chain services and weather and climate risk solutions.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P44_S4	Cost of Revenues Cost of revenues for our Decision Analytics segment was $334.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 compared to $254.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 , an increase of $80.3 million or 31.6%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P44_S5	Excluding the impact of recent acquisitions of $51.5 million, our cost of revenues increased by $28.8 million or 11.4%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P44_S6	This increase is primarily due to a net increase in salary and employee benefits of $20.3 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P44_S7	Other increases include information data costs of $4.1 million, information technology expenses of $3.2 million, travel and travel related costs of $0.7 million, rent expenses of $0.4 million and other general expenses of $0.1 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P44_S8	The increase in salaries and employee benefits of $20.3 million includes an increase of $21.9 million in annual salaries and employee benefits, medical costs, and long term equity compensation plan costs, and due to the reallocation of certain resources from Risk Assessment relating to property appraisal tools that began January 2012.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P44_S9	These increases were partially offset by a decrease of $1.6 million in pension cost primarily because of our pension plan freeze.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P44_S10	Selling, General and Administrative Expenses Selling, general and administrative expenses for our Decision Analytics segment were $139.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 compared to $117.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 , an increase of $22.0 million or 18.7%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P44_S11	Excluding the impact of recent acquisitions of $11.1 million, SGA increased $10.9 million or 9.5%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P44_S12	The increase was primarily due to an increase in salaries and employee benefits of $9.3 million, costs related to travel expenses of $0.4 million, and professional fees of $1.8 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P44_S13	These increases were offset by a decrease in other general expenses of $0.6 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P45_S0	The increase in salaries and employee benefits of $9.3 million includes an increase of $10.0 million in annual salaries and employee benefits, medical costs, commissions, and long term equity compensation plan costs, and was partially offset by a decrease of $0.7 million in pension cost, primarily due to our pension plan freeze.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P45_S1	The EBITDA margin for our Decision Analytics segment including our discontinued operations, was 39.8% for the years ended December 31, 2012 and 2011.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P45_S2	For the year ended December 31, 2012 , the recent acquisitions mitigated our margin expansion by 0.1%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P45_S3	For the year ended December 31, 2011, the acquisition related liability adjustment positively impacted our EBITDA margin by 0.4%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P45_S4	Risk Assessment Revenues Revenues for our Risk Assessment segment were $579.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 as compared to $552.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 , an increase of $27.2 million or 4.9% .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P45_S5	The overall increase within this segment primarily resulted from an increase in prices derived from continued enhancements to the content of our industry-standard insurance programs solutions as well as selling expanded solutions to existing customers.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P45_S6	Our revenue by category for the periods presented is set forth below for the years ended December 31:
1442145_14_ITEM7_P46_S0	Cost of Revenues Cost of revenues for our Risk Assessment segment was $182.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 compared to $187.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 , a decrease of $4.6 million or 2.5%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P46_S1	The decrease was primarily due to decrease in salaries and employee benefits costs of $3.5 million, primarily related to lower pension cost of $8.7 million, and a reallocation of certain resources to our Decision Analytics segment relating to property appraisal tools that occurred in 2012.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P46_S2	Other decreases were related to data and consulting costs of $1.1 million, travel and travel related expenses of $0.3 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P46_S3	These decreases were offset by an increase in other general expenses of $0.2 million and information technology expenses of $0.1 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P46_S4	Selling, General and Administrative Expenses Selling, general and administrative expenses for our Risk Assessment segment were $80.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 compared to $82.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 , a decrease of $1.4 million or 1.7%.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P46_S5	The decrease was primarily due to a decrease in salaries and employee benefits of $2.0 million, primarily related to lower pension cost.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P46_S6	Other decreases included professional fees of $1.4 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P46_S7	These decreases were offset by an increase in other general expenses of $2.0 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P47_S0	The EBITDA margin for our Risk Assessment segment was 54.6% for the year ended December 31, 2012 compared to 51.0% for the year ended December 31, 2011 .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P47_S1	The increase in margin is primarily attributed to operating leverage in the segment as well as cost efficiencies achieved in 2012.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P47_S2	In addition, we reallocated certain resources related to property appraisal tools to Decision Analytics, which partially attributed to our margin expansion.

1442145_14_ITEM7_P50_S0	The results of historical periods are not necessarily indicative of the results of operations for a full year or any future period.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P51_S0	Liquidity and Capital Resources As of December 31, 2013 and 2012 , we had cash and cash equivalents and available-for-sale securities of $169.7 million and $94.7 million, respectively.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P52_S0	Subscriptions for our solutions are billed and generally paid in advance of rendering services either quarterly or in full upon commencement of the subscription period, which is usually for one year.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P52_S1	Subscriptions are automatically renewed at the beginning of each calendar year.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P53_S0	We have historically generated significant cash flows from operations.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P53_S1	As a result of this factor, as well as the availability of funds under our syndicated revolving credit facility, we believe we will have sufficient cash to meet our working capital and capital expenditure needs, and to fuel our future growth plans.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P54_S0	We have historically managed the business with a working capital deficit due to the fact that, as described above, we offer our solutions and services primarily through annual subscriptions or long-term contracts, which are generally prepaid quarterly or annually in advance of the services being rendered.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P55_S0	When cash is received for prepayment of invoices, we record an asset (cash and cash equivalents) on our balance sheet with the offset recorded as a current liability (fees received in advance).
1442145_14_ITEM7_P55_S1	This current liability is deferred revenue that does not require a direct cash outflow since our customers have prepaid and are obligated to purchase the services.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P56_S0	In most businesses, growth in revenue typically leads to an increase in the accounts receivable balance causing a use of cash as a company grows.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P56_S1	Unlike these businesses, our cash position is favorably affected by revenue growth, which results in a source of cash due to our customers prepaying for most of our services.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P56_S2	Our capital expenditures, which include non-cash purchases of fixed assets and capital lease obligations, as a percentage of revenues for the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012 , were 9.2% and 5.2%, respectively.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P56_S3	We estimate our capital expenditures for 2014 will be approximately $147.0 million, which primarily include expenditures on our technology infrastructure and our continuing investments in developing and enhancing our solutions.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P56_S4	Expenditures related to developing and enhancing our solutions are predominately related to internal use software and are capitalized in accordance with ASC 350-40, Accounting for Costs of Computer Software Developed or Obtained for Internal Use.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P56_S5	We also capitalize amounts in accordance with ASC 985-20, Software to be Sold, Leased or Otherwise Marketed .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P56_S6	We have also historically used a portion of our cash for repurchases of our common stock from our stockholders.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P56_S7	For the years ended December 31, 2013 , 2012 and 2011 , we repurchased $278.9 million, $162.6 million and $380.7 million, respectively, of our common stock.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P57_S0	In prior years, we provided pension and postretirement benefits to certain qualifying active employees and retirees.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P57_S1	On February 29, 2012, we instituted a hard freeze, which eliminated all future compensation and service credits, to all participants in the pension plans.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P57_S2	In April 2012, we completed a voluntary prefunding to our qualified pension plan of $72.0 million, which resulted in a contribution of $78.8 million for the year, of which $28.2 million was the minimum contribution requirement for 2012.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P57_S3	As a result of the prefunding, we do not expect to make any contribution in 2014 with respect to our qualified pension plan.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P57_S4	Under the postretirement plan, we provided certain healthcare and life insurance benefits to qualifying participants; however, participants are required to pay a stated percentage of the premium coverage.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P57_S5	In March 2012, we established a voluntary employee s beneficiary association plan, or VEBA plan, to fund the postretirement plan.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P57_S6	We contributed $20.0 million to the VEBA Plan during the year ended December 31, 2012.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P57_S7	We expect to contribute approximately $1.8 million to the postretirement plan in 2014.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P57_S8	We had total debt, excluding capital lease obligations, of $1,265.1 million and $1,454.4 million at December 31, 2013 and 2012 , respectively.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P57_S9	The debt at December 31, 2013 was primarily issued under senior notes and long-term private placement loan facilities to finance our stock repurchases and acquisitions.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P58_S0	On April 6, 2011, we completed an issuance of senior notes in the aggregate principal amount of $450.0 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P58_S1	These senior notes are due on May 1, 2021 and accrue interest at a rate of 5.800% per annum.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P58_S2	Interest is payable semi-annually on May 1st and November 1st of each year.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P58_S3	On December 8, 2011, we completed a second issuance of senior notes in the aggregate principal of $250.0 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P58_S4	These senior notes are due on January 15, 2019 and accrue interest at a rate of 4.875% per annum.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P58_S5	Interest is payable semi-annually on January 15th and July 15th of each year.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P58_S6	On September 12, 2012, we completed a third issuance of senior notes in the aggregate principal amount of $350.0 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P58_S7	These senior notes are due on September 12, 2022 and accrue interest at a rate of 4.125% per annum.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P58_S8	Interest is payable semi-annually on March 12th and September 12th of each year.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P59_S0	We expect to redraw from our credit facility over time as needed for our corporate strategy, including for general corporate purposes and acquisitions.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P59_S1	The indenture governing the senior notes restricts our ability and our subsidiaries ability to, among other things, create certain liens, enter into sale/leaseback transactions and consolidate with, sell, lease, convey or otherwise transfer all or substantially all of our assets, or merge with or into, any other person or entity.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P59_S2	On October 25, 2013, we amended our committed senior unsecured credit facility with a syndicate of banks to increase the borrowing capacity under the credit facility from $850.0 million to $975.0 million and extend the maturity date from October 24, 2017 to October 24, 2018.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P59_S3	We amortize all one-time fees and third party costs associated with the execution and amendment of this credit facility through the maturity date.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P60_S0	Interest is payable at a maturity rate of LIBOR plus 1.125% to 1.875%, depending on the result of certain ratios defined in the credit agreement.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P61_S0	Verisk and ISO are co-borrowers under the credit facility.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P61_S1	Borrowings may be used for general corporate purposes, including working capital and capital expenditures, acquisitions and share repurchase programs.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P61_S2	As of December 31, 2013, we had no borrowings outstanding under the credit facility, compared to $10.0 million outstanding at December 31, 2012.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P61_S3	We repaid the $10.0 million of outstanding borrowings from 2012 in January 2013.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P61_S4	We did not have any additional borrowings during the year ended December 31, 2013.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P61_S5	As of December 31, 2013, we have an available borrowing capacity, net of outstanding letters of credit, of $973.1 million under the credit facility.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P61_S6	We expect to finance a portion of the cash purchase price of the EVT acquisition with borrowings from our credit facility.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P61_S7	EVT is expected to close by July 2014.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P62_S0	The credit facility contains certain customary financial and other covenants that, among other things, impose certain restrictions on indebtedness, liens, investments, and capital expenditures.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P62_S1	These covenants also place restrictions on mergers, asset sales, sale/leaseback transactions, payments between us and our subsidiaries, and certain transactions with affiliates.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P62_S2	The financial covenants require that, at the end of any fiscal quarter, we have a consolidated interest coverage ratio of at least 3.0 to 1.0 and that during any period of four fiscal quarters, we maintain a consolidated funded debt leverage ratio below 3.5 to 1.0.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P62_S3	We were in compliance with all debt covenants under the credit facility as of December 31, 2013.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P62_S4	We had long-term private placement loan facilities under uncommitted master shelf agreements with New York Life and Prudential Capital Group that expired during 2013.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P62_S5	We did not renew these agreements and no longer have financing capacity thereunder.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P62_S6	During the year ended December 31, 2013, we repaid $180.0 million of outstanding borrowings under the private placement facilities that matured during the year with cash from operations.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P62_S7	The notes outstanding under these long-term private placement loan facilities mature over the next three years.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P62_S8	The weighted average rate of interest with respect to our outstanding borrowings under these facilities was 6.36% and 6.26% for the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012 and amounts outstanding were $1.9 million and $3.6 million, respectively.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P63_S0	These notes contain certain covenants that limit our ability to create liens, enter into sale/leaseback transactions and consolidate, merge or sell assets to another company.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P63_S1	These notes also contain financial covenants that require that, at the end of any fiscal quarter, we have a consolidated interest coverage ratio of at least 3.0 to 1.0 and a leverage ratio below 3.0 to 1.0 at the end of any fiscal quarter.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P63_S2	We were in compliance with all debt covenants under our master shelf agreements as of December 31, 2013.

1442145_14_ITEM7_P64_S0	Operating Activities Net cash provided by operating activities increased to $506.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to $468.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P64_S1	The increase in cash provided by operating activities was primarily due to an increase in cash receipts from customers, partially offset by an increase in interest payments related to our bond offerings.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P64_S2	In the second quarter of 2012, we pre-funded $72.0 million to our pension plan.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P64_S3	This prefunding was partially offset by the tax benefit associated with those deductible contributions and the deferral of our fourth quarter 2012 tax payment to 2013 as a result of a temporary federal tax relief program related to Hurricane Sandy.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P64_S4	This tax payment would have typically been paid in the fourth quarter of 2012, but due to this relief, the payment was made in the first quarter of 2013.

1442145_14_ITEM7_P65_S3	The decrease in net cash used in investing activities was primarily due to the fact that we had acquisitions in 2012 with a combined net cash purchase price of $808.3 million versus minor acquisition activity in 2013.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P65_S4	Net cash used in investing activities was $883.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 and $204.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P65_S5	The increase in net cash used in investing activities was principally due to an increase in acquisition payments of $647.8 million, primarily related to the acquisitions of MediConnect and Argus in the first and third quarters of 2012, respectively, an increase in escrow funding associated with these acquisitions of $19.2 million and an increase in purchases of fixed assets of $14.5 million during the year ended December 31, 2012 .

1442145_14_ITEM7_P65_S7	Net cash used in financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2013 was primarily related the repurchase of common stock of $277.4 million and debt repayments of $190.0 million, partially offset by proceeds from stock option exercises and the related excess tax benefit of $190.3 million.
1442145_14_ITEM7_P65_S8	Net cash provided by financing activities was $313.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 and net cash used in by financing was $34.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 .
1442145_14_ITEM7_P65_S9	Net cash used in financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2012, was primarily related to an increase in total net debt of $357.2 million, stock option exercises and the related tax benefit associated with these exercises of $129.1 million, partially offset by stock repurchases of $162.3 million.
