1442145_15_ITEM6_P4_S0	(1) During the second quarter of 2011, we reevaluated the probability of D2Hawkeye and Strategic Analytics achieving the specified predetermined EBITDA and revenue targets for exceptional performance in fiscal year 2011 and reversed the contingent consideration related to these acquisitions.
1442145_15_ITEM6_P4_S1	During the third quarter of 2010, we reevaluated the probability of TierMed achieving the specified predetermined EBITDA and revenue targets and reversed its contingent consideration related to this acquisition.
1442145_15_ITEM6_P5_S0	(2) On March 11, 2014, we sold our mortgage services business.
1442145_15_ITEM6_P5_S1	See Note 10 of our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K. (3) EBITDA is the financial measure which management uses to evaluate the performance of our segments.
1442145_15_ITEM6_P5_S2	EBITDA is defined as net income before interest expense, provision for income taxes, depreciation and amortization of fixed and intangible assets.
1442145_15_ITEM6_P5_S3	Because EBITDA is calculated from net income, this presentation includes EBITDA from discontinued operations of our mortgage services business.
1442145_15_ITEM6_P5_S4	In addition, this Management s Discussion and Analysis includes references to EBITDA margin, which is computed as EBITDA divided by revenues from continuing and discontinued operations.
1442145_15_ITEM6_P6_S0	of our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K.
1442145_15_ITEM6_P7_S0	Although EBITDA is a non-GAAP financial measure, EBITDA is frequently used by securities analysts, lenders and others in their evaluation of companies, EBITDA has limitations as an analytical tool, and should not be considered in isolation, or as a substitute for an analysis of our results of operations or cash flow from operating activities reported under GAAP.
1442145_15_ITEM6_P7_S1	Management uses EBITDA in conjunction with traditional GAAP operating performance measures as part of its overall assessment of company performance.
1442145_15_ITEM6_P8_S0	Other companies in our industry may calculate EBITDA differently than we do, limiting its usefulness as a comparative measure.
1442145_15_ITEM6_P8_S1	(5) Subsequent to our corporate reorganization on October 6, 2009, share repurchases are recorded as treasury stock within stockholders equity (deficit), as we intend to reissue shares from treasury stock in the future.
1442145_15_ITEM6_P8_S2	For the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 , we repurchased $675.4 million and $278.9 million, respectively, of treasury stock.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P0_S0	The following discussion should be read in conjunction with our historical financial statements and the related notes included elsewhere in this annual report on Form 10-K, as well as the discussion under Selected Consolidated Financial Data.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P1_S0	This discussion contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P1_S1	Our actual results may differ materially from those discussed in or implied by any of the forward-looking statements as a result of various factors, including but not limited to those listed under Risk Factors and Special Note Regarding Forward-Looking Statements.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P2_S0	We enable risk-bearing businesses to better understand and manage their risks and opportunities associated with those risks.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P2_S1	We provide value to our customers by supplying proprietary data that, combined with our analytic methods, creates embedded decision support solutions.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P2_S2	We are the largest aggregator and provider of data pertaining to U.S. property and casualty, or P C, insurance risks.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P2_S3	We offer solutions for detecting fraud in the U.S. P C insurance, financial services and healthcare industries and sophisticated methods to predict and quantify loss in diverse contexts ranging from natural catastrophes to supply chain to health insurance.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P2_S4	Our customers use our solutions to make better risk decisions with greater efficiency and discipline.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P2_S5	We refer to these products and services as solutions due to the integration among our products and the flexibility that enables our customers to purchase components or the comprehensive package of products.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P2_S6	These solutions take various forms, including data, statistical models or tailored analytics, all designed to allow our clients to make more logical decisions.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P2_S7	We believe our solutions for analyzing risk positively impact our customers revenues and help them better manage their costs.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P3_S0	On May 23, 2008, in contemplation of our IPO, Insurance Service Office, Inc., or ISO, formed Verisk Analytics, Inc., or Verisk, a Delaware corporation, to be the holding company for our business.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P3_S1	Verisk was initially formed as a wholly-owned subsidiary of ISO.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P3_S2	On October 6, 2009 in connection with our IPO, we effected a reorganization whereby ISO became a wholly-owned subsidiary of Verisk.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P3_S3	On October 1, 2010, we completed a follow-on public offering.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P3_S4	We did not receive any proceeds from the sale of common stock in the offering.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P4_S0	The primary purpose of the offering was to manage and organize the sale by Class B insurance company shareholders while providing incremental public float.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P4_S1	Concurrently with the closing of the offering, we repurchased shares of common stock, for an aggregate purchase price of $192.5 million, directly from selling shareholders owning Class B common stock.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P4_S2	We converted all Class B shares to Class A shares in 2011 and currently have no outstanding Class B shares.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P4_S3	We organize our business in two segments: Risk Assessment and Decision Analytics.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P5_S0	Our Risk Assessment segment provides statistical, actuarial and underwriting data for the U.S. P C insurance industry.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P5_S1	Our Risk Assessment segment revenues represented approximately 37.2% and 38.7% of our revenues for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 , respectively.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P5_S2	Effective December 31, 2012, we combined the statistical agency and data services and actuarial services into industry-standard insurance programs within our Risk Assessment segment.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P6_S0	Our Decision Analytics segment revenues represented approximately 62.8% and 61.3% of our revenues for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 , respectively.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P7_S0	In January 2014, we entered into an agreement to acquire 100% of the stock of Eagleview Technology Corporation, or EVT, the parent company of Pictometry International Corp., and Eagle View Technologies, Inc. for a net cash purchase price of $650 million, which would have been funded by the Company's operating cash and borrowings from our credit facility.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P7_S1	EVT is a provider of geo-referenced aerial image capture and visual-centric data analytics and solutions to insurers, contractors, government, and commercial customers in the United States.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P7_S2	On December 16, 2014, we ended our efforts to acquire EVT following the vote by the Federal Trade Commission, or FTC, to challenge the transaction.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P8_S0	On March 11, 2014, we sold our mortgage services business, Interthinx, Inc., or Interthinx.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P9_S0	From 2009 to 2011, the mortgage services business was in both Risk Assessment segment within the insurance services revenue category and Decision Analytics segment in the financial services revenue category.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P9_S1	In 2012, we reclassified the appraisal mortgage tools from Risk Assessment to our Decision Analytics segment in the financial services revenue category.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P9_S2	Therefore, in 2012 and 2013, the mortgage services business is within Decision Analytics segment.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P9_S3	Results of operations for the mortgage services business are reported as a discontinued operation for the year ended December 31, 2014 and for all prior periods presented.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P9_S4	See Note 10 of our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K. As necessary, the amounts have been retroactively adjusted in all periods presented to give recognition to the discontinued operations.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P10_S0	We believe our business s ability to generate recurring revenue and positive cash flow is the key indicator of the successful execution of our business strategy.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P10_S1	We use year over year revenue growth and EBITDA margin as metrics to measure our performance.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P10_S2	EBITDA and EBITDA margin are non-GAAP financial measures (see Note 3.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P10_S3	Selected Financial Data section of Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations).
1442145_15_ITEM7_P11_S0	We use year over year revenue growth as a key performance metric.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P11_S1	We assess revenue growth based on our ability to generate increased revenue through increased sales to existing customers, sales to new customers, sales of new or expanded solutions to existing and new customers and strategic acquisitions of new businesses.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P11_S2	We use EBITDA margin as a metric to assess segment performance and scalability of our business.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P12_S0	We assess EBITDA margin based on our ability to increase revenues while controlling expense growth.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P12_S1	Revenues We earn revenues through subscriptions, long-term agreements and on a transactional basis.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P12_S2	Subscriptions for our solutions are generally paid in advance of rendering services either quarterly or in full upon commencement of the subscription period, which is usually for one year and automatically renewed each year.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P12_S3	As a result, the timing of our cash flows generally precedes our recognition of revenues and income and our cash flow from operations tends to be higher in the first quarter as we receive subscription payments.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P12_S4	Examples of these arrangements include subscriptions that allow our customers to access our standardized coverage language, our claims fraud database or our actuarial services throughout the subscription period.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P13_S0	In general, we experience minimal revenue seasonality within the business.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P13_S1	Our long-term agreements are generally for periods of three to five years.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P13_S2	We recognize revenue from subscriptions ratably over the term of the subscription and most long-term agreements are recognized ratably over the term of the agreement.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P13_S3	Certain of our solutions are also paid for by our customers on a transactional basis.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P13_S4	For example, we have solutions that allow our customers to obtain property-specific rating and underwriting information to price a policy on a commercial building, or compare a P C insurance, medical or workers compensation claim with information in our databases.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P13_S5	For the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 , 27.7% and 26.4% of our revenues, respectively, were derived from providing transactional solutions.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P13_S6	We earn transactional revenues as our solutions are delivered or services performed.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P13_S7	In general, transactions are billed monthly at the end of each month.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P13_S8	Approximately 89.6% and 88.2% of the revenues in our Risk Assessment segment for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 , respectively, were derived from subscriptions and long-term agreements for our solutions.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P13_S9	Our customers in this segment include most of the P C insurance providers in the United States.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P13_S10	Approximately 61.9% and 64.4% of the revenues in our Decision Analytics segment, for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 , respectively, were derived from subscriptions and long-term agreements for our solutions.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P14_S0	In this segment, customer bases are within the insurance, healthcare, financial services and specialized markets verticals.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P15_S0	Principal Operating Costs and Expenses Personnel expenses are the major component of both our cost of revenues and selling, general and administrative expenses.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P15_S1	Personnel expenses, which represented 56.8% and 59.7% of our total expenses for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 , respectively, include salaries, benefits, incentive compensation, equity compensation costs, sales commissions, employment taxes, recruiting costs, and outsourced temporary agency costs.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P15_S2	We allocate personnel expenses between two categories, cost of revenues and selling, general and administrative costs, based on the actual costs associated with each employee.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P15_S3	We categorize employees who maintain our solutions as cost of revenues, and all other personnel, including executive managers, sales people, marketing, business development, finance, legal, human resources, and administrative services, as selling, general and administrative expenses.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P15_S4	A significant portion of our other operating costs, such as facilities and communications, are also either captured within cost of revenues or selling, general and administrative expense based on the nature of the work being performed.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P15_S5	While we expect to grow our headcount over time to take advantage of our market opportunities, we believe that the economies of scale in our operating model will allow us to grow our personnel expenses at a lower rate than revenues.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P15_S6	Historically, our EBITDA margin has improved because we have been able to increase revenues without a proportionate corresponding increase in expenses.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P15_S7	However, part of our corporate strategy is to invest in new solutions which may offset margin expansion.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P15_S8	Our cost of revenues consists primarily of personnel expenses.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P15_S9	Cost of revenues also includes the expenses associated with the acquisition and verification of data, the maintenance of our existing solutions and the development and enhancement of our next-generation solutions.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P15_S10	Our cost of revenues excludes depreciation and amortization.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P15_S11	Our selling, general and administrative expense also consists primarily of personnel costs.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P15_S12	A portion of the other operating costs such as facilities, insurance and communications are also allocated to selling, general and administrative costs based on the nature of the work being performed by the employee.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P15_S13	Our selling, general and administrative expenses excludes depreciation and amortization.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P15_S14	We serve customers in three primary vertical markets: property/casualty insurance, healthcare, and financial services.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P15_S15	The industry trends in each of those markets can affect our business.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P15_S16	A significant change in property/casualty insurers profitability could positively or negatively affect demand for our solutions.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P15_S17	For insurers, the keys to profitability include investment income and premium growth.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P16_S0	Investment income remains under pressure as a result of low interest rates.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P17_S0	Growth in property/casualty insurers direct written premiums is cyclical, with total industry premium growth receding from a peak of 14.8% in 2002 to a trough of negative 3.1% in 2009 and subsequently recovering to 4.4% in 2012 and then receding to 4.3% in 2013 and 3.8% through nine-months 2014.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P17_S1	Based on our experience, insurers more closely scrutinize their spending in periods of more challenging growth.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P17_S2	In recent years, we have signed multi-year contracts with certain customers, and pricing is fixed at the beginning of each multi-year period; pricing for other customers is still linked to prior years' premiums.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P18_S0	Trends in catastrophe and noncatastrophe weather losses can have an effect on our customers profitability and therefore their appetite for buying analytics to help them manage their risks.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P18_S1	The apparent increase in the frequency and severity of weather events that cause losses for insurers could lead to increased demand for our catastrophe modeling, catastrophe loss information, and repair cost solutions.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P18_S2	A significant decrease in the number or severity of catastrophes could negatively affect our revenues.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P18_S3	We also have a portion of our revenue related to the number of claims processed due to losses which can be impacted by seasonal storm activity.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P18_S4	The need by our customers to fight insurance fraud both in claims and at policy inception could lead to increased demand for our underwriting and claims solutions.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P19_S0	Trends in the U.S. healthcare market can affect a portion of our revenues in the Decision Analytics segment.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P19_S1	That market is undergoing significant change as the result of healthcare reform legislation.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P19_S2	The specific trends we see affecting our current healthcare business include payment reform, expansion of insurance coverage, and efforts at cost containment.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P19_S3	Payment reform will likely drive the market to value-based reimbursement and require healthcare providers to bear increased financial risk and responsibility for quality outcomes.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P19_S4	The expansion of insurance eligibility will increase Medicaid rolls and promote participation in statewide health exchanges.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P19_S5	And as the government seeks to control fraud, waste, and abuse, efforts to contain costs will likely become more prevalent.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P19_S6	Although such changes have the potential to disrupt the healthcare marketplace, we believe the requirements for reform could increase demand for our analytic solutions in the areas of population management, quality measurement provider/payer risk sharing and value-based payment management, Medicare Advantage revenue management and compliance, risk adjustment, and detection of prepayment fraud and abuse.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P20_S0	We experience seasonality in our Medicare Advantage business tied to third and fourth quarters of our fiscal year, related to CMS deadlines.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P21_S0	U.S. and global market trends can influence the revenue composition and growth trajectory of our financial services vertical.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P21_S1	Recent focus of global regulators on Basel-III compliance and US regulators on compliance to recently adopted 2009 Dodd-Frank laws on anti-money laundering, stress testing and capital adequacy have led to a significant shift of our data-hosting solution toward the meeting of those specific needs of our bank clients.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P21_S2	We expect that a rising interest rate environment is likely to put a significant margin pressure on our bank clients, and can resultantly impact their marketing budgets for growth.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P21_S3	However, a strengthening American economy is likely to spur increased lending and could likely offset some of that budgetary risk.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P22_S0	Trends associated with the strengthening U.S. dollar relative to several other international currencies (U.K., Canadian, Australian and New Zealand) is putting a downward pressure on our revenues from bank clients from overseas markets.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P22_S1	Lastly, a longer term shift of advertising spend from TV and radio toward digital media has resulted in a greater opportunity for our partnerships and media effectiveness line of businesses.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P23_S0	Description of Acquisitions We acquired seven businesses since January 1, 2012.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P23_S1	As a result of these acquisitions, our consolidated results of operations may not be comparable between periods.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P23_S2	On December 8, 2014, we acquired 100% of the stock of Maplecroft.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P24_S0	Using a proprietary data aggregation and analytical approach, Maplecroft enables its customers to assess, monitor, and forecast a growing range of worldwide risks, including geopolitical and societal risks.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P24_S1	Within our Decision Analytics segment, this acquisition positions us as a provider of value chain optimization tools, providing comprehensive quantitative risk analytics and platforms by which customers can visualize, quantify, mitigate, and manage their risk.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P25_S0	Maplecroft is headquartered in Bath, England.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P26_S0	to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K for the preliminary purchases price allocations.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P27_S0	On October 31, 2014, we acquired the net assets of Dart Consulting Limited, or Dart.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P27_S1	Dart is a provider of benchmarking and advisory solutions to financial services institutions in Australia, New Zealand, and other key Asia-Pacific markets.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P27_S2	As part of our Decision Analytics segment, Dart provides benchmarking solutions and professional services critical to financial services institutions in the management of lending and payment portfolios.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P28_S0	On January 29, 2014, we acquired the net assets of Inovatus, LLC, or Inovatus.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P28_S1	The assets primarily consisted of software and are embedded in our existing models focusing on reducing fraud and premium leakage for personal auto insurance carriers.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P28_S2	The technology is included in our Decision Analytics segment as part of its solutions to leverage data and analytics to help insurance companies improve results.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P29_S0	On December 20, 2012, we acquired the net assets of Insurance Risk Management Solutions, or IRMS.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P29_S1	IRMS provided integrated property risk assessment technology underlying one of our GIS (geographic information system) underwriting solutions.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P29_S2	At the end of 2012, this long-term contract (since 1992) with IRMS was expiring and precipitated a change in our business relationship.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P29_S3	Instead of continuing forward with a new services agreement, we acquired the technology and service assets of IRMS as this will enable us to better manage, enhance and continue to use the solutions as part of our Risk Assessment segment.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P29_S4	This acquisition had minimal revenue and operating expense impact for the year ending December 31, 2012, given the timing of the acquisition.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P29_S5	See Note 9. to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K. On August 31, 2012, we acquired Argus Information Advisory Services, LLC, or Argus, a provider of information, competitive benchmarking, scoring solutions, analytics, and customized services to financial institutions and regulators in North America, Latin America, and Europe.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P29_S6	Argus leverages its comprehensive payment data sets and provides proprietary solutions to a client base that includes credit and debit card issuers, retail banks and other consumer financial services providers, payment processors, insurance companies, and other industry stakeholders.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P29_S7	Within our Decision Analytics segment, this acquisition enhances our position as a provider of data, analytics, and decision-support solutions to financial institutions globally.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P30_S0	to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K. On July 2, 2012, we acquired the net assets of Aspect Loss Prevention, LLC, or ALP, a provider of loss prevention and analytic solutions to the retail, entertainment, and food industries.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P30_S1	Within our Decision Analytics segment, this acquisition further advances our position as a provider of data, crime analytics, and decision-support solutions.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P31_S0	to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K. On March 30, 2012, we acquired 100% of the stock of MediConnect Global, Inc., or MediConnect, a service provider of medical record retrieval, digitization, coding, extraction, and analysis.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P31_S1	Within our Decision Analytics segment, MediConnect further supports our objective to be the leading provider of data, analytics, and decision-support solutions to the healthcare and property casualty industries.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P32_S0	to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P33_S0	On March 11, 2014, we sold our mortgage services business, Interthinx, for a price of $151.2 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P33_S1	Results of operations for the mortgage services business are reported as a discontinued operation for the year ended December 31, 2014 and for all prior periods presented.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P33_S2	See Note 10 to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K. Year Ended December 31, 2014 Compared to Year Ended December 31, 2013 Consolidated Results of Continuing Operations Revenues Revenues were $1,746.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 compared to $1,595.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , an increase of $151.0 million or 9.5%.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P34_S0	In December 2014 , we acquired Maplecroft within our Decision Analytics segment, a recent acquisition.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P34_S1	Maplecroft provided an increase of $0.6 million in revenues for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1442145_15_ITEM7_P34_S2	Excluding this recent acquisition, revenues increased $150.4 million or 9.4% .
1442145_15_ITEM7_P35_S0	Revenue growth within Decision Analytics was primarily driven by our financial services, healthcare, and insurance categories.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P35_S1	Both categories, industry-standard insurance programs and property-specific rating and underwriting information, within Risk Assessment contributed to its revenue growth.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P35_S2	Refer to the Results of Continuing Operations by Segment within this section for further information regarding our revenues.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P35_S3	Cost of Revenues Cost of revenues was $716.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 compared to $622.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , an increase of $94.1 million or 15.1% .
1442145_15_ITEM7_P35_S4	Our recent acquisition of Maplecroft within the Decision Analytics segment, accounted for an increase of $0.5 million in cost of revenues for the year ended December 31, 2014 which were primarily related to salaries and employee benefits.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P35_S5	Excluding the impact of our recent acquisition, our cost of revenues increased $93.6 million or 15.0%.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P35_S6	The increase was primarily due to increases in salaries and employee benefits cost of $38.1 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P35_S7	Other increases include data costs and data processing fees of $46.3 million (mostly related to our Decision Analytics segment), rent expense of $8.2 million, and information technology expense of $1.5 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P35_S8	These are offset by a decrease in other operating costs of $0.5 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P35_S9	Selling, General and Administrative Expenses Selling, general and administrative expenses, or SGA, were $227.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 compared to $229.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , a decrease of $1.7 million or 0.7% .
1442145_15_ITEM7_P35_S10	Excluding costs associated with our recent acquisition of $0.1 million, SGA decreased $1.8 million or 0.8%.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P35_S11	The decrease was primarily due to lower salaries and employee benefits of $7.3 million mostly related to the executive transition that took place in 2013, travel expenses of $0.9 million, and a decrease in other general expenses of $2.5 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P35_S12	These decreases were offset by an increase in professional fees of $4.6 million, primarily related to our attempted acquisition of EVT, and information technology expense of $4.3 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P35_S13	Depreciation and Amortization of Fixed Assets Depreciation and amortization of fixed assets was $85.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 compared to $66.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , an increase of $19.3 million or 29.2%.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P36_S0	Depreciation and amortization of fixed assets includes depreciation of furniture and equipment, software, computer hardware, and related equipment.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P36_S1	The majority of the increase relates to software and hardware costs to support data capacity expansion and revenue growth.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P36_S2	Amortization of Intangible Assets Amortization of intangible assets was $56.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 compared to $63.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , a decrease of $6.8 million or 10.8%.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P36_S3	The decrease was primarily related to intangible assets associated with prior acquisitions that have been fully amortized.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P36_S4	Investment Income and Others Investment income and others, was a gain of $0.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 as compared to a gain of $0.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , a decrease of $0.4 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P36_S5	Interest Expense Interest expense was $70.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 compared to $76.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , a decrease of $6.1 million or 8.1%.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P37_S0	debt of $180.0 million during 2013, consisting of $45.0 million that matured in April 2013, $100.0 million that matured in August 2013 and $35.0 million that matured in October 2013.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P37_S1	Provision for Income Taxes The provision for income taxes was $219.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 compared to $196.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , an increase of $23.4 million or 11.9%.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P37_S2	The effective tax rate was 37.2% for the year ended December 31, 2014 compared to 36.5% for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1442145_15_ITEM7_P37_S3	The EBITDA margin for our consolidated results including discontinued operations, was 48.8% for the year ended December 31, 2014 compared to 44.6% for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1442145_15_ITEM7_P37_S4	The discontinued operations including the gain on the sale of our mortgage services business increased our margin by 2.8% for the year ended December 31, 2014.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P37_S5	Results of Continuing Operations by Segment Decision Analytics Revenues Revenues for our Decision Analytics segment were $1,096.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 compared to $977.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , an increase of $118.7 million or 12.1%.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P37_S6	Our recent acquisition accounted for an increase of $0.6 million in revenues for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1442145_15_ITEM7_P37_S7	Excluding Maplecroft, our Decision Analytics revenue increased $118.1 million or 12.1% .
1442145_15_ITEM7_P37_S8	As described, our results in the Decision Analytics segment do not include the discontinued operations of our mortgage services business, which was part of our financial services vertical.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P37_S9	Our revenue by category for the periods presented is set forth below for the years ended December 31:
1442145_15_ITEM7_P38_S0	Our insurance revenue increased $59.6 million or 11.1% primarily due to an increase within our loss quantification solutions and in catastrophe modeling services for existing customers.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P38_S1	Underwriting and claims solutions as well contributed to the growth.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P38_S2	Our financial services revenue increased $15.7 million or 19.3% , primarily due to the continued demand for our analytic solutions and services within this category.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P38_S3	Our healthcare revenue increased $44.1 million or 16.2% primarily due to an increase in transactions within our revenue and quality intelligence solutions and due to an increase in payment accuracy solutions.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P38_S4	Our specialized markets revenue decreased $0.7 million or 0.8% , and excluding the Maplecroft acquisition revenue within this category, our specialized markets revenue decreased $1.3 million or 1.5% as a result of lower activity related to government contracts partially offset by growth in our supply chain services.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P38_S5	Cost of Revenues Cost of revenues for our Decision Analytics segment was $508.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 compared to $428.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , an increase of $80.4 million or 18.8% .
1442145_15_ITEM7_P38_S6	Excluding the impact of Maplecroft, our recent acquisition, of $0.5 million, our cost of revenues increased by $79.9 million or 18.7%.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P38_S7	This increase is primarily due to a net increase in salary and employee benefits of $28.3 million, data costs and data processing fees of $45.5 million (primarily related to our healthcare services) and rent expense of $7.2 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P38_S8	These increases were offset by decreases in information technology expenses of $1.1 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P39_S0	Selling, General and Administrative Expenses Selling, general and administrative expenses for our Decision Analytics segment were $153.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 compared to $151.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , an increase of $1.9 million or 1.3% .
1442145_15_ITEM7_P39_S1	Excluding the impact of Maplecroft, our recent acquisition, of $0.1 million, SGA increased $1.8 million or 1.2%.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P39_S2	The increase was primarily due to an increase in professional consulting fees of $4.5 million, which includes expenses of $6.9 million related to the EVT transaction offset by lower other consulting expenses.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P39_S3	Other increases include information technology expenses of $3.5 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P39_S4	These increases are offset by decrease in salaries and employee benefits of $4.3 million, travel cost of $0.5 million and other general and administrative expenses of $1.4 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P39_S5	The EBITDA margin for our Decision Analytics segment including our discontinued operations, was 44.2% for the year ended December 31, 2014 and 38.0% for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1442145_15_ITEM7_P39_S6	The discontinued operations, including the gain on sale of the mortgage services business increased our margin by 4.6% for the year ended December 31, 2014.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P39_S7	Risk Assessment Revenues Revenues for our Risk Assessment segment were $650.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 as compared to $618.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , an increase of $32.3 million or 5.2% .
1442145_15_ITEM7_P39_S8	The overall increase within this segment primarily resulted from an increase in prices derived from continued enhancements to the content of our industry-standard insurance programs solutions as well as selling expanded solutions to existing customers.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P39_S9	Our revenue by category for the periods presented is set forth below for the years ended December 31:
1442145_15_ITEM7_P40_S0	Cost of Revenues Cost of revenues for our Risk Assessment segment was $208.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 compared to $194.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , an increase of $13.7 million or 7.0% .
1442145_15_ITEM7_P40_S1	The increase was primarily due to an increase in salaries and employee benefits costs of $9.8 million, which includes severance costs of $4.8 million that occurred in the fourth quarter in 2014.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P40_S2	Other increases were related to information technology expenses of $2.6 million, rent expense of $1.0 million, and data and consulting costs of $0.8 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P40_S3	These increases were offset by a decrease in other general expenses of $0.5 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P40_S4	Selling, General and Administrative Expenses Selling, general and administrative expenses for our Risk Assessment segment were $73.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 compared to $77.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , a decrease of $3.6 million or 4.6% .
1442145_15_ITEM7_P40_S5	The decrease was primarily due to a decrease in salaries and employee benefits of $3.0 million, a decrease in travel cost of $0.4 million and other general expenses of $1.1 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P40_S6	These decreases were offset by an increase in information technology of $0.8 million and professional consulting fees of $0.1 million.

1442145_15_ITEM7_P41_S1	The increase in margin is primarily attributed to operating leverage in the segment as well as cost efficiencies.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P42_S0	Year Ended December 31, 2013 Compared to Year Ended December 31, 2012 Consolidated Results of Continuing Operations Revenues Revenues were $1,595.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to $1,407.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2012, an increase of $187.9 million or 13.3%.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P43_S0	In 2012, we acquired MediConnect, ALP, and Argus, collectively referred to as recent acquisitions, which we define as acquisitions not owned for a significant portion of both the current period and/or prior period and would therefore impact the comparability of the financial results.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P43_S1	MediConnect was included as a recent acquisition only for the first quarter of 2013; ALP was included as a recent acquisition in the first and second quarters of 2013; Argus was included as a recent acquisition in the first, second and third quarters of 2013 as full quarter comparable revenues did not exist until certain quarters of 2012 due to the timing of the acquisitions.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P43_S2	These recent acquisitions were within our Decision Analytics segment and provided an increase of $68.1 million in revenues for the year ended December 31, 2013.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P43_S3	Excluding recent acquisitions, revenues increased $119.8 million or 8.5%, which included an increase in our Decision Analytics segment of $81.0 million or 9.8% and an increase in our Risk Assessment segment of $38.8 million or 6.7%.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P43_S4	Revenue growth within Decision Analytics was primarily driven by increases in our healthcare revenue category and contributions from our insurance revenue category.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P43_S5	Both categories, industry-standard insurance programs and property-specific rating and underwriting information, within Risk Assessment contributed to its revenue growth.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P43_S6	Refer to the Results of Continuing Operations by Segment within this section for further information regarding our revenues.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P43_S7	Cost of Revenues Cost of revenues was $622.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to $516.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2012, an increase of $105.8 million or 20.5%.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P43_S8	Recent acquisitions all within the Decision Analytics segment, accounted for an increase of $36.8 million in cost of revenues for the year ended December 31, 2013 which were primarily related to salaries and employee benefits.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P43_S9	Excluding the impact of our recent acquisitions, our cost of revenues increased $69.0 million or 13.4%.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P43_S10	The increase was primarily due to increases in salaries and employee benefits cost of $36.6 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P43_S11	Other increases include data costs and data processing fees of $17.7 million, information technology expense of $7.4 million, travel and travel related costs of $3.2 million and other operating costs of $4.1 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P43_S12	Selling, General and Administrative Expenses Selling, general and administrative expenses, or SGA, were $229.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to $220.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2012, an increase of $8.9 million or 4.1%.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P43_S13	Recent acquisitions accounted for an increase of $3.8 million, which was primarily related to professional fees.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P43_S14	Excluding costs associated with our recent acquisitions, SGA increased $5.1 million or 2.3%.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P43_S15	The increase was primarily due to an increase in professional fees of $3.0 million, travel and travel related items of $0.8 million, salaries and employee benefits of $0.7 million, and other general and administrative expenses of $0.6 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P43_S16	The increase in salaries and benefits of $0.7 million includes an increase of $5.1 million in annual salaries increases, medical costs and commissions, offset by a decrease in our stock option expense of $4.1 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P43_S17	Our stock option expense decreased as a result of lower accelerated vesting of equity awards granted to employees at age 62.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P43_S18	Other decreases include a decrease in pension expense of $0.3 million, primarily due to our pension plan freeze.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P43_S19	Depreciation and Amortization of Fixed Assets Depreciation and amortization of fixed assets was $66.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to $46.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2012, an increase of $19.6 million or 41.9%.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P44_S0	Depreciation and amortization of fixed assets includes depreciation of furniture and equipment, software, computer hardware, and related equipment.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P44_S1	The majority of the increase relates to software and hardware costs to support data capacity expansion and revenue growth.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P45_S0	Amortization of Intangible Assets Amortization of intangible assets was $63.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to $52.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2012, an increase of $11.5 million or 22.1%.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P45_S1	The increase was primarily related to amortization of intangible assets associated with recent acquisitions of $16.0 million, partially offset by $4.5 million of amortization of intangible assets associated with prior acquisitions that have been fully amortized.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P46_S0	Investment Income and Others Investment income and realized gain on securities, net, was a gain of $0.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 as compared to a gain of $0.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2012, an increase of $0.5 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P46_S1	Interest Expense Interest expense was $76.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to $72.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2012, an increase of $3.6 million or 5.0%.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P46_S2	This increase is primarily due to the issuance of our senior notes in September 2012 with an aggregate principal balance of $350.0 million, partially offset by the repayment of $180.0 million of private placement debt during the year.

1442145_15_ITEM7_P46_S4	The effective tax rate was 36.5% for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to 36.5% for the year ended December 31, 2012.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P46_S5	The EBITDA margin for our consolidated results including discontinued operations, was 44.6% for the year ended December 31, 2013 compared to 45.4% for the year ended December 31, 2012.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P46_S6	For the year ended December 31, 2013, the recent acquisitions mitigated our margin expansion by 0.2%.

1442145_15_ITEM7_P46_S10	As described, our results in the Decision Analytics segment give effect to discontinued operations of our mortgage services business, which was part of our financial services vertical.

1442145_15_ITEM7_P47_S0	Our insurance revenue increased $45.7 million or 9.3%, and excluding recent acquisitions (ALP) revenue of $1.2 million for the first and second quarters within this category, our insurance revenue increased $44.5 million or 9.0%, primarily due to an increase within our underwriting solutions, an increase in catastrophe modeling services for existing customers, as well an increase in insurance fraud solutions revenue, and an increase in loss quantification solutions.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P48_S0	This financial services revenue reflects Argus' increased solutions which became part of organic revenue in the fourth quarter.

1442145_15_ITEM7_P48_S2	Our specialized markets revenue increased $0.3 million or 0.3% as a result of modest increase in our supply chain services, offset by a decrease in weather and climate risk solutions.

1442145_15_ITEM7_P52_S1	In management s opinion, the quarterly data has been prepared on the same basis as the audited consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K, and reflects all necessary adjustments for a fair presentation of this data.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P53_S0	The results of historical periods are not necessarily indicative of the results of operations for a full year or any future period.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P54_S0	Liquidity and Capital Resources As of December 31, 2014 and 2013 , we had cash and cash equivalents and available-for-sale securities of $43.2 million and $169.7 million, respectively.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P55_S0	Subscriptions for our solutions are billed and generally paid in advance of rendering services either quarterly or in full upon commencement of the subscription period, which is usually for one year.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P55_S1	Subscriptions are automatically renewed at the beginning of each calendar year.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P56_S0	We have historically generated significant cash flows from operations.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P56_S1	As a result of this factor, as well as the availability of funds under our syndicated revolving credit facility, we believe we will have sufficient cash to meet our working capital and capital expenditure needs, and to fuel our future growth plans.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P57_S0	We have historically managed the business with a working capital deficit due to the fact that, as described above, we offer our solutions and services primarily through annual subscriptions or long-term contracts, which are generally prepaid quarterly or annually in advance of the services being rendered.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P58_S0	When cash is received for prepayment of invoices, we record an asset (cash and cash equivalents) on our balance sheet with the offset recorded as a current liability (fees received in advance).
1442145_15_ITEM7_P58_S1	This current liability is deferred revenue that does not require a direct cash outflow since our customers have prepaid and are obligated to purchase the services.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P59_S0	In most businesses, growth in revenue typically leads to an increase in the accounts receivable balance causing a use of cash as a company grows.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P59_S1	Unlike these businesses, our cash position is favorably affected by revenue growth, which results in a source of cash due to our customers prepaying for most of our services.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P59_S2	Our capital expenditures as a percentage of revenues for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 , were 8.4% and 9.1%, respectively.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P59_S3	We estimate our capital expenditures for 2015 will be approximately $150.0 million, which primarily include expenditures on our technology infrastructure and our continuing investments in developing and enhancing our solutions.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P59_S4	Expenditures related to developing and enhancing our solutions are predominately related to internal use software and are capitalized in accordance with ASC 350-40, Accounting for Costs of Computer Software Developed or Obtained for Internal Use.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P59_S5	We also capitalize amounts in accordance with ASC 985-20, Software to be Sold, Leased or Otherwise Marketed .
1442145_15_ITEM7_P59_S6	We have also historically used a portion of our cash for repurchases of our common stock from our stockholders.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P59_S7	For the years ended December 31, 2014 , 2013 and 2012 , we repurchased $675.4 million (exclusive of $100.0 million of unsettled purchase price associated with the ASR Program; see Note 15 of our consolidated financial statements in this annual report on Form 10-K), $278.9 million and $162.6 million, respectively, of our common stock.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P60_S0	In prior years, we provided pension and postretirement benefits to certain qualifying active employees and retirees.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P60_S1	On February 29, 2012, we instituted a hard freeze, which eliminated all future compensation and service credits, to all participants in the pension plans.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P60_S2	In April 2012, we completed a voluntary prefunding to our qualified pension plan of $72.0 million, which resulted in a contribution of $78.8 million for the year, of which $28.2 million was the minimum contribution requirement for 2012.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P60_S3	As a result of the prefunding, we do not expect to make any contribution in 2015 with respect to our qualified pension plan.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P60_S4	Under the postretirement plan, we provided certain healthcare and life insurance benefits to qualifying participants; however, participants are required to pay a stated percentage of the premium coverage.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P60_S5	We expect to contribute approximately $1.1 million to the postretirement plan in 2015 .
1442145_15_ITEM7_P60_S6	We had total debt, excluding capital lease obligations, of $1,425.8 million and $1,265.1 million at December 31, 2014 and 2013 , respectively.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P60_S7	The debt at December 31, 2014 was primarily issued under senior notes and long-term private placement loan facilities to finance our stock repurchases and acquisitions.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P61_S0	On April 6, 2011, we completed an issuance of senior notes in the aggregate principal amount of $450.0 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P61_S1	These senior notes are due on May 1, 2021 and accrue interest at a rate of 5.800% per annum.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P61_S2	Interest is payable semi-annually on May 1st and November 1st of each year.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P61_S3	On December 8, 2011, we completed a second issuance of senior notes in the aggregate principal of $250.0 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P61_S4	These senior notes are due on January 15, 2019 and accrue interest at a rate of 4.875% per annum.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P61_S5	Interest is payable semi-annually on January 15th and July 15th of each year.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P61_S6	On September 12, 2012, we completed a third issuance of senior notes in the aggregate principal amount of $350.0 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P61_S7	These senior notes are due on September 12, 2022 and accrue interest at a rate of 4.125% per annum.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P61_S8	Interest is payable semi-annually on March 12th and September 12th of each year.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P61_S9	The senior notes are fully and unconditionally guaranteed, jointly and severally, on an unsecured and unsubordinated basis by ISO and certain subsidiaries that guarantee our syndicated revolving credit facility (credit facility), or any amendment, refinancing or replacement thereof.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P62_S0	including for general corporate purposes, share repurchases, and acquisitions.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P63_S0	The indenture governing the senior notes restricts our ability and our subsidiaries ability to, among other things, create certain liens, enter into sale/leaseback transactions and consolidate with, sell, lease, convey or otherwise transfer all or substantially all of our assets, or merge with or into, any other person or entity.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P63_S1	On October 21, 2014, we amended our committed senior unsecured credit facility with a syndicate of banks to increase the borrowing capacity under the credit facility from $975.0 million to $990.0 million and extend the maturity date from October 2018 to October 2019.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P63_S2	We amortize all one-time fees and third party costs associated with the execution and amendment of this credit facility through the maturity date.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P64_S0	Interest is payable at a maturity rate of LIBOR plus 1.125% to 1.625%, depending on the result of certain ratios defined in the credit agreement.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P64_S1	Verisk and ISO are co-borrowers under the credit facility.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P64_S2	Borrowings may be used for general corporate purposes, including working capital and capital expenditures, acquisitions and share repurchase programs.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P64_S3	During the year ended December 31, 2014 , we borrowed $225.0 million under the credit facility and repaid $65.0 million.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P64_S4	As of December 31, 2014 and 2013 , we had $160.0 million and $0 outstanding borrowings under the credit facility, respectively.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P64_S5	In January and February 2015, we repaid a total of $140.0 million of the $160.0 million outstanding borrowings under the credit facility.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P64_S6	As of December 31, 2014 , we have an available borrowing capacity, net of outstanding letters of credit, of $827.8 million under the credit facility.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P65_S0	The credit facility contains certain customary financial and other covenants that, among other things, impose certain restrictions on indebtedness, liens, investments, and capital expenditures.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P65_S1	These covenants also place restrictions on mergers, asset sales, sale/leaseback transactions, payments between us and our subsidiaries, and certain transactions with affiliates.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P65_S2	The financial covenants require that, at the end of any fiscal quarter, we have a consolidated interest coverage ratio of at least 3.0 to 1.0 and that during any period of four fiscal quarters, we maintain a consolidated funded debt leverage ratio below 3.5 to 1.0.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P65_S3	We were in compliance with all debt covenants under the credit facility as of December 31, 2014.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P65_S4	We also had long-term private placement loan facilities under uncommitted master shelf agreements with New York Life and Prudential Capital Group that expired during 2013.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P65_S5	We did not extend these agreements.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P65_S6	As of December 31, 2014 and 2013, we had $220.0 million outstanding under these facilities for both periods.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P65_S7	The weighted average rate of interest with respect to our outstanding borrowings under these facilities was 6.36% for each of the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 and amounts outstanding was $1.9 million at the end of each period.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P66_S0	These notes contain certain covenants that limit our ability to create liens, enter into sale/leaseback transactions and consolidate, merge or sell assets to another company.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P66_S1	These notes also contain financial covenants that require that, at the end of any fiscal quarter, we have a consolidated interest coverage ratio of at least 3.0 to 1.0 and that we maintain a consolidated funded debt leverage ratio below 3.0 to 1.0 at the end of any fiscal quarter.
1442145_15_ITEM7_P66_S2	We were in compliance with all debt covenants under our master shelf agreements as of December 31, 2014 .
