1442145_16_ITEM7_P73_S3	Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates Our management s discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations are based on our consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P73_S4	The preparation of these financial statements require management to make estimates and judgments that affect reported amounts of assets and liabilities and related disclosures of contingent assets and liabilities at the dates of the financial statements and revenue and expenses during the reporting periods.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P73_S5	These estimates are based on historical experience and on other assumptions that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P73_S6	On an ongoing basis, management evaluates its estimates, including those related to revenue recognition, goodwill and intangible assets, pension and other post retirement benefits, stock based compensation, and income taxes.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P73_S7	Actual results may differ from these assumptions or conditions.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P74_S0	Revenue Recognition The Company s revenues are primarily derived from sales of services and revenue is recognized as services are performed and information is delivered to our customers.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P74_S1	Revenue is recognized when persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, delivery has occurred or services have been rendered, fees and/or price are fixed or determinable and collectability is reasonably assured.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P74_S2	Revenues for subscription services are recognized ratably over the subscription term, usually one year.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P74_S3	Revenues from transaction-based fees are recognized as information is delivered to customers, assuming all other revenue recognition criteria are met.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P74_S4	The Company also has term based software licenses where the only remaining undelivered element is post-contract customer support or PCS, including unspecified upgrade rights on a when and if available basis.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P74_S5	The Company recognizes revenue for these licenses ratably over the duration of the license term.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P74_S6	The PCS associated with these arrangements is coterminous with the duration of the license term.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P74_S7	The Company also provides hosting or software solutions that provide continuous access to information and include PCS and recognizes revenue ratably over the duration of the license term.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P74_S8	In addition, the determination of certain of our services revenues requires the use of estimates, principally related to transaction volumes in instances where these volumes are reported to us by our clients on a monthly basis in arrears.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P74_S9	In these instances, we estimate transaction volumes based on average actual volumes reported by our customers in the past.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P74_S10	Differences between our estimates and actual final volumes reported are recorded in the period in which actual volumes are reported.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P74_S11	We have not experienced significant variances between our estimates of these services revenues reported to us by our customers and actual reported volumes in the past.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P74_S12	We invoice our customers in annual, quarterly, or monthly installments.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P74_S13	Amounts billed and collected in advance are recorded as deferred revenues on the balance sheet and are recognized as the services are performed and revenue recognition criteria are met.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P75_S0	The fair value of equity awards is measured on the date of grant using a Black-Scholes option-pricing model, which requires the use of several estimates, including expected term, expected risk-free interest rate, expected volatility and expected dividend yield.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P75_S1	Stock based compensation cost is measured at the grant date, based on the fair value of the awards granted, and is recognized as expense over the requisite service period.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P75_S2	Option grants and restricted stock awards are generally expensed ratably over the four-year vesting period.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P75_S3	We follow the substantive vesting period approach for awards granted after January 1, 2005, which requires that stock based compensation expense be recognized over the period from the date of grant to the date when the award is no longer contingent on the employee providing additional service.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P75_S4	We estimate expected forfeitures of equity awards at the date of grant and recognize compensation expense only for those awards expected to vest.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P75_S5	The forfeiture assumption is ultimately adjusted to the actual forfeiture rate.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P76_S0	Goodwill and Intangibles Goodwill represents the excess of acquisition costs over the fair value of tangible net assets and identifiable intangible assets of the businesses acquired.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P76_S1	Goodwill and intangible assets deemed to have indefinite lives are not amortized.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P77_S0	assets determined to have definite lives are amortized over their useful lives.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P77_S1	Goodwill and intangible assets with indefinite lives are subject to impairment testing annually as of June 30, or whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount may not be fully recoverable, using the guidance and criteria described in the accounting standard for Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets .
1442145_16_ITEM7_P77_S2	This testing compares carrying values to fair values and, when appropriate, the carrying value of these assets is reduced to fair value.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P78_S0	As of December 31, 2015 , we had goodwill and net intangible assets of $4,511.6 million, which represents 80.3% of our total assets.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P78_S1	During 2015 , we performed an impairment test as of June 30, 2015 and confirmed that no impairment charge was necessary.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P79_S0	There are many assumptions and estimates used that directly impact the results of impairment testing, including an estimate of future expected revenues, earnings and cash flows, useful lives and discount rates applied to such expected cash flows in order to estimate fair value.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P79_S1	We have the ability to influence the outcome and ultimate results based on the assumptions and estimates we choose for determining the fair value of our reporting units.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P79_S2	To mitigate undue influence, we set criteria and benchmarks that are reviewed and approved by various levels of management and reviewed by other independent parties.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P80_S0	The determination of whether or not goodwill or indefinite-lived acquired intangible assets have become impaired involves a significant level of judgment in the assumptions and estimates underlying the approach used to determine the value of our reporting units.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P80_S1	Changes in our strategy or market conditions could significantly impact these judgments and require an impairment to be recorded to intangible assets and goodwill.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P80_S2	As part of this regular process, the Company conducted the annual impairment test of our newly acquired energy reporting unit at June 30, 2015, at which time the fair value exceeded its carrying value by less than 5%.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P80_S3	This outcome is consistent with the Company s expectation due to the proximity of the impairment test date of June 30 to the acquisition date of May 19, 2015.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P80_S4	Our valuation has not indicated any impairment of our goodwill asset of $3,134.8 million as of December 31, 2015 .
1442145_16_ITEM7_P80_S5	For the year ended December 31, 2015 , there were no impairment indicators related to our intangible assets.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P80_S6	There was a significant estimate this year related to the acquisition of Wood Mackenzie.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P80_S7	The preliminarily estimated fair values of the tangible and intangible assets acquired and liabilities assumed in connection with the purchase of Wood Mackenzie have been recognized in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets based on known facts that existed on the date of acquisition.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P80_S8	The excess of the purchase price over the preliminary fair values of the net tangible and intangible assets was recorded as goodwill.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P81_S0	We determined the estimated fair values of the assets and liabilities of Wood Mackenzie with the assistance of valuations performed by third party specialists, discounted cash flow analysis and estimates made by management.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P81_S1	These estimates and assumptions are subject to change during the measurement period (up to one year from the acquisition date) and may have a significant impact on the consolidated financial statements.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P81_S2	See Note 9 of our consolidated financial statements included in this Form 10-K for further information.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P82_S0	On February 29, 2012, we instituted a hard freeze, which eliminates all future compensation and service credits, to all participants in the pension plans.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P82_S1	See Note 17 to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K. We account for our pension and postretirement benefit plans in accordance with the accounting standard for Employers Accounting for Defined Benefit Pension and Other Postretirement Plans .
1442145_16_ITEM7_P82_S2	This standard requires that employers recognize on a prospective basis the funded status of their defined benefit pension and other postretirement benefit plans on their consolidated balance sheets and recognize as a component of other comprehensive income (loss), net of tax, the gains or losses and prior service costs or credits that arise during the period but are not recognized as components of net periodic benefit (credit) cost.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P83_S0	Certain assumptions are used in the determination of our annual net period benefit (credit) cost and the disclosure of the funded status of these plans.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P83_S1	The principal assumptions concern the discount rate used to measure the projected benefit obligation and the expected return on plan assets.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P83_S2	We revise these assumptions based on an annual evaluation of long-term trends and market conditions that may have an impact on the cost of providing retirement benefits.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P83_S3	In determining the discount rate, we utilize quoted rates from long-term bond indices, and changes in long-term bond rates over the past year, cash flow models and other data sources we consider reasonable based upon the life expectancy and mortality rate of eligible employees.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P83_S4	As part of our evaluation, we calculate the approximate average yields on securities that were selected to match our separate projected cash flows for both the pension and postretirement plans.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P83_S5	Our separate benefit plan cash flows are input into actuarial models that include data for corporate bonds rated AA or better at the measurement date.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P83_S6	The output from the actuarial models are assessed against the prior year s discount rate and quoted rates for long-term bond indices.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P83_S7	For our pension plans at December 31, 2015 , we determined this rate to be 4.73% , an increase of 0.74% from the 3.99% rate used at December 31, 2014 .
1442145_16_ITEM7_P83_S8	Our postretirement rate is 3.25% at December 31, 2015 , an increase of 0.25% from the 3.00% used at December 31, 2014 .
1442145_16_ITEM7_P84_S0	The expected return on plan assets is determined by taking into consideration our analysis of our actual historical investment returns to a broader long-term forecast adjusted based on our target investment allocation, and the current economic environment.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P85_S0	As of December 31, 2015 , the pension plan assets were allocated 39.60% debt, 60.00% equity securities and 0.40% other.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P85_S1	The VEBA Plan target allocation is 100% debt.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P85_S2	We have used our target investment allocation to derive the expected return as we believe this allocation will be retained on an ongoing basis that will be commensurate with the projected cash flows of the plan.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P85_S3	The expected return for each investment category within our target investment allocation is developed using average historical rates of return for each targeted investment category, considering the projected cash flow of the qualified pension plan and postretirement plan.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P85_S4	The difference between this expected return and the actual return on plan assets is generally deferred and recognized over subsequent periods through future net periodic benefit (credits) costs.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P85_S5	We believe these considerations provide the basis for reasonable assumptions with respect to the expected long-term rate of return on plan assets.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P86_S0	The measurement date used to determine the benefit obligation and plan assets is December 31.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P86_S1	The future benefit payments for the postretirement plan are net of the federal medical subsidy.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P87_S0	As a result of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act and the Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act of 2010, the tax treatment of federal subsidies paid to sponsors of retiree health benefit plans that provide prescription drug benefits that are at least actuarially equivalent to the corresponding benefits provided under Medicare Part D was effectively changed.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P87_S1	This legislative change reduces future tax benefits of the coverage we provided to participants in the postretirement plan.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P87_S2	We are required to account for this change in the period during which the law is enacted.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P87_S3	A one percent change in discount rate and future rate of return on plan assets would have the following effects:
1442145_16_ITEM7_P88_S0	Income Taxes In projecting future taxable income, we develop assumptions including the amount of future state, federal and foreign pretax operating income, the reversal of temporary differences, and the implementation of feasible and prudent tax planning strategies.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P88_S1	These assumptions require significant judgment about the forecasts of future taxable income and are consistent with the plans and estimates we use to manage the underlying businesses.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P89_S0	The calculation of our tax liabilities also involves dealing with uncertainties in the application and evolution of complex tax laws and regulations in other jurisdictions.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P89_S1	We account for uncertain tax positions in accordance with Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes an interpretation of ASC 740 , which addresses the determination of whether tax benefits claimed or expected to be claimed on a tax return should be recorded in the financial statements.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P89_S2	Under this interpretation, we may recognize the tax benefit from an uncertain tax position only if it is more likely than not that the tax position will be sustained upon examination by the taxing authorities, based on the technical merits of the position.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P90_S0	We recognize and adjust our liabilities when our judgment changes as a result of the evaluation of new information not previously available.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P90_S1	Due to the complexity of some of these uncertainties, the ultimate resolution may result in a payment that is materially different from our current estimate of the tax liabilities.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P90_S2	These differences will be reflected as increases or decreases to income tax expense in the period in which they are determined.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P91_S0	We estimate unrecognized tax positions of $0.5 million that may be recognized by December 31, 2016, due to expiration of statutes of limitations and resolution of audits with taxing authorities, net of additional uncertain tax positions.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P91_S1	As of December 31, 2015 , we have gross federal, state, and foreign income tax net operating loss carryforwards of $56.6 million, which will expire at various dates from 2016 through 2035.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P91_S2	Such net operating loss carryforwards expire as follows:
1442145_16_ITEM7_P92_S0	The net deferred income tax liability of $396.4 million consists primarily of timing differences involving depreciation and amortization.
1442145_16_ITEM7_P92_S1	Recent Accounting Pronouncements For a discussion of recent accounting pronouncements, refer to Note 2(s) to the audited consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this annual report on Form 10-K.
1442145_16_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Interest Rate Risk We are exposed to market risk from fluctuations in interest rates.
1442145_16_ITEM7A_P0_S1	At December 31, 2015 , we had borrowings outstanding under our credit facility of $870.0 million , which bear interest at variable rates based on LIBOR plus 1.125% to 1.625% , depending on certain ratios defined in the credit agreement.
1442145_16_ITEM7A_P0_S2	A change in interest rates on variable rate debt impacts our pre-tax income and cash flows, but does not impact the fair value of the instruments.
1442145_16_ITEM7A_P0_S3	Based on our overall interest rate exposure at December 31, 2015 , a one percent change in interest rate would result in a change in annual pre-tax interest expense of approximately $8.7 million based on our current borrowing levels.
1442145_16_ITEM7A_P1_S0	Our foreign-based businesses and results of operations are exposed to movements in the U.S. dollar to British pounds and other foreign currency exchange rates.
1442145_16_ITEM7A_P1_S1	A portion of our revenue is denominated in British pounds and other foreign currencies.
1442145_16_ITEM7A_P1_S2	If the U.S. dollar strengthens against British pounds and other foreign currencies, our revenues reported in U.S. dollars would decline.
1442145_16_ITEM7A_P1_S3	With regard to operating expense, our primary exposure to foreign currency exchange risk relates to operating expense incurred in British pounds and other foreign currencies.
1442145_16_ITEM7A_P1_S4	If British pounds and other foreign currencies strengthen, costs reported in U.S. dollars will increase.
1442145_16_ITEM7A_P1_S5	Movements in the U.S. dollar to British pounds and other foreign currency exchange rates did not have a material effect on our revenue for the year ended December 31, 2015 .
1442145_16_ITEM7A_P1_S6	A hypothetical ten percent change in average exchange rates versus the U.S. dollar would not have resulted in a material change to our earnings.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P0_S0	Consolidated Financial Statements as of December 31, 2015 and 2014 and for the Years Ended December 31, 2015, 2014 and 2013.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P1_S0	MANAGEMENT S REPORT ON INTERNAL CONTROLS OVER FINANCIAL REPORTING Our management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as defined in Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) under the Exchange Act.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P1_S1	Our internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of the financial statements for external purposes in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P1_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, a system of internal control over financial reporting can provide only reasonable assurance and may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P1_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that internal controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P2_S0	Under the supervision and with the participation of our management, including our principal executive officer and principal financial officer, we conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting based on the framework set forth in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission in 2013.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P2_S1	Based on this assessment, management concluded that our internal control over financial reporting was effective at December 31, 2015 .
1442145_16_ITEM8_P3_S0	Management excluded from its assessment the internal control over financial reporting at Wood Mackenzie Limited ("Wood Mackenzie"), which was acquired on May 19, 2015, Infield Systems Limited ("Infield"), which was acquired on November 6, 2015, and The PCI Group ("PCI"), which was acquired on November 20, 2015.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P3_S1	The excluded financial statements of the acquisitions constitute approximately 4.9% of total assets and 10.2% of total revenues collectively included within our consolidated financial statement amounts as of and for the year ended December 31, 2015.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P3_S2	Due to the timing of the acquisitions, management did not assess the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting for Wood Mackenzie, Infield and PCI.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P3_S3	Deloitte Touche LLP, the independent registered public accounting firm that audited the consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K has also audited the effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015 , as stated in their report which is included herein.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P4_S0	We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Verisk Analytics, Inc. and subsidiaries (the "Company") as of December 31, 2015 and 2014, and the related consolidated statements of operations, comprehensive income, changes in stockholders equity, and cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2015.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P4_S1	Our audits also included the financial statement schedule listed in the Index at Item 15.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P4_S2	These financial statements and financial statement schedule are the responsibility of the Company's management.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P4_S3	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the financial statements and financial statement schedule based on our audits.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P4_S4	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1442145_16_ITEM8_P4_S5	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P5_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P5_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P5_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P5_S3	In our opinion, such consolidated financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Verisk Analytics, Inc. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2015 and 2014, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended December 31, 2015, in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P5_S4	Also, in our opinion, such financial statement schedule, when considered in relation to the basic consolidated financial statements taken as a whole, presents fairly, in all material respects, the information set forth therein.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P6_S0	Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission and our report dated February 23, 2016 expressed an unqualified opinion on the Company s internal control over financial reporting.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P7_S0	We have audited the internal control over financial reporting of Verisk Analytics, Inc. and subsidiaries (the "Company") as of December 31, 2015, based on criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P7_S1	As described in Management s Report on Internal Controls over Financial Reporting, management excluded from its assessment the internal control over financial reporting at Wood Mackenzie Limited, which was acquired on May 19, 2015, Infield Systems Limited, which was acquired on November 6, 2015, and The PCI Group, which was acquired on November 20, 2015.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P7_S2	The financial statements of these acquisitions constitute 4.9% of total assets and 10.2% of revenues collectively of the consolidated financial statements of the Company as of and for the year ended December 31, 2015.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P7_S3	Accordingly, our audit did not include the internal control over financial reporting at WoodMackenzie Limited, Infield Systems Limited or The PCI Group.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P7_S4	The Company s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in the accompanying Management s Report on Internal Controls over Financial Reporting.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P7_S5	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P7_S6	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1442145_16_ITEM8_P7_S7	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P7_S8	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk, and performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P7_S9	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P8_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed by, or under the supervision of, the company s principal executive and principal financial officers, or persons performing similar functions, and effected by the company s board of directors, management, and other personnel to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P8_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company's assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P8_S2	Because of the inherent limitations of internal control over financial reporting, including the possibility of collusion or improper management override of controls, material misstatements due to error or fraud may not be prevented or detected on a timely basis.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P8_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of the effectiveness of the internal control over financial reporting to future periods are subject to the risk that the controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P8_S4	In our opinion, the Company maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2015, based on the criteria established in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (2013) issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P8_S5	We have also audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated financial statements and financial statement schedule as of and for the year ended December 31, 2015 of the Company and our report dated February 23, 2016 expressed an unqualified opinion on those financial statements and financial statement schedule.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P9_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P10_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P11_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P12_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P13_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P14_S0	The accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial statements.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P15_S0	VERISK ANALYTICS, INC. NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Amounts in thousands, except for share and per share data, unless otherwise stated) 1.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P15_S1	Organization: Verisk Analytics, Inc. and its consolidated subsidiaries ( Verisk or the Company ) enable risk-bearing businesses to better understand and manage their risks.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P15_S2	The Company provides its customers proprietary data that, combined with analytic methods, create embedded decision support solutions.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P16_S0	The Company is one of the largest aggregators and providers of data pertaining to property and casualty ( P C ) insurance risks in the United States of America ( U.S. ).
1442145_16_ITEM8_P16_S1	The Company offers predictive analytics and decision support solutions to customers in rating, underwriting, claims, catastrophe and weather risk, global risk analytics, natural resources intelligence, economic forecasting, and many other fields.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P17_S0	Verisk was established to serve as the parent holding company of Insurance Services Office, Inc. ( ISO ) upon completion of the initial public offering ( IPO ), which occurred on October 9, 2009.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P17_S1	ISO was formed in 1971 as an advisory and rating organization for the P C insurance industry to provide statistical and actuarial services, to develop insurance programs and to assist insurance companies in meeting state regulatory requirements.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P17_S2	For over the past decade, the Company broadened its data assets, entered new markets, placed a greater emphasis on analytics, and pursued strategic acquisitions.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P18_S0	Verisk trades under the ticker symbol VRSK on the NASDAQ Global Select Market.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P19_S0	Basis of Presentation and Summary of Significant Accounting Policies: The accompanying consolidated financial statements have been prepared on the basis of accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America ( U.S. GAAP ).
1442145_16_ITEM8_P19_S1	The preparation of financial statements in conformity with these accounting principles requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting periods.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P19_S2	Significant estimates include acquisition purchase price allocations, the fair value of goodwill, the realization of deferred tax assets, acquisition related liabilities, fair value of stock based compensation, assets and liabilities for pension and postretirement benefits, and the estimate for the allowance for doubtful accounts.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P19_S3	Actual results may ultimately differ from those estimates.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P20_S0	As of December 31, 2013, the Company's mortgage services business qualified as assets held-for-sale.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P20_S1	The mortgage services business was sold on March 11, 2014.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P20_S2	The results of operations for the Company's mortgage services business are reported as a discontinued operation for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 (See Note 10).
1442145_16_ITEM8_P21_S0	Significant accounting policies include the following: (a) Intercompany Accounts and Transactions The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Verisk.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P21_S1	All intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P22_S0	The following describes the Company s primary types of revenues and the applicable revenue recognition policies.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P22_S1	The Company s revenues are primarily derived from sales of services and revenue is recognized as services are performed and information is delivered to customers.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P22_S2	Revenue is recognized when persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, delivery has occurred or services have been rendered, fees and/or price is fixed or determinable, and collectability is reasonably assured.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P22_S3	Revenue is recognized net of applicable sales tax withholdings.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P23_S0	Industry-Standard Insurance Programs Industry-standard insurance programs, statistical agent and data services and actuarial services are sold to participating insurance company customers under annual agreements covering a calendar year where the price is determined at the inception of the agreement.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P23_S1	In accordance with Accounting Standards Codification ( ASC ) 605, Revenue Recognition, the Company recognizes revenue ratably over the term of these annual agreements, as services are performed and continuous access to information is provided over the entire term of the agreements.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P24_S0	The Company provides property-specific rating information through reports issued for specific commercial properties, for which revenue is recognized when the report is delivered to the customer, provided that all other revenue recognition criteria are met.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P24_S1	In addition, the Company provides hosting or software solutions that provide continuous access to information about the properties being insured and underwriting information in the form of standard policy forms to be used by customers.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P24_S2	As the customer has a contractual right to take possession of the software without significant penalty, revenues from these arrangements are recognized ratably over the contract period from the time when the customer had access to the solution in accordance with ASC 985-605, Software Revenue Recognition ( ASC 985-605 ).
1442145_16_ITEM8_P24_S3	The Company recognizes software license revenue when the arrangement does not require significant production, customization or modification of the software and the following criteria are met: persuasive evidence of an agreement exists, delivery has occurred, fees are fixed or determinable, and collections are probable.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P24_S4	These software arrangements include post-contract customer support ( PCS ).
1442145_16_ITEM8_P24_S5	The Company recognizes software license revenue ratably over the duration of the annual license term as vendor specific objective evidence ( VSOE ) of PCS, the only remaining undelivered element, cannot be established in accordance with ASC 985-605.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P24_S6	The PCS associated with these arrangements is coterminous with the duration of the license term.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P25_S0	Insurance Insurance services primarily consist of term-based software licenses.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P25_S1	These software arrangements include PCS, which includes unspecified upgrades on a when-and-if available basis.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P25_S2	The Company recognizes software license revenue ratably over the duration of the annual license term as VSOE of PCS, the only remaining undelivered element, cannot be established in accordance with ASC 985-605.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P25_S3	The PCS associated with these arrangements is coterminous with the duration of the license term.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P25_S4	In certain instances, the customers are billed for access on a monthly basis for the term-based software licenses and the Company recognizes revenue accordingly.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P25_S5	There are also services within insurance, which are comprised of transaction-based fees recognized as information is delivered to customers, provided that all other revenue recognition criteria have been met.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P26_S0	Financial Services Financial services include various types of services to customers.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P26_S1	The Company primarily recognizes revenue ratably for these services over the term of the agreements, as services are performed and continuous service is provided over the entire term of the agreements.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P26_S2	In addition, there are certain services which are comprised of transaction-based fees; in these instances, revenue is recognized as information is delivered to customers, provided that all other revenue recognition criteria have been met.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P27_S0	Healthcare The Company provides software hosting arrangements to customers whereby the customer does not have the right to take possession of the software.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P27_S1	As these arrangements include PCS throughout the hosting term, revenues from these multiple element arrangements are recognized in accordance with ASC 605-25, Revenue Recognition Multiple Element Arrangements ( ASC 605-25 ).
1442145_16_ITEM8_P27_S2	The Company recognizes revenue ratably over the duration of the license term, which ranges from one to five years, since the contractual elements do not have stand alone value.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P27_S3	There are also services within healthcare, which are comprised of transaction-based fees recognized as information is delivered to customers, provided that all other revenue recognition criteria have been met.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P28_S0	The Company provides hosting solutions that give continuous access to research information such as data analytics and commercial intelligence for the energy, chemicals, metals and mining verticals.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P28_S1	For the hosting arrangements, whereby the customer does not have the right to take possession of the software, which include PCS throughout the hosting term, revenues from these multiple element arrangements are recognized in accordance with ASC 605-25.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P28_S2	The Company recognizes revenue ratably over the duration of the license term, since the contractual elements do not have stand alone value.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P29_S0	Specialized markets consist of term-based software licenses.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P29_S1	These software arrangements include PCS, which includes unspecified upgrades on a when-and-if available basis.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P29_S2	The Company recognizes software license revenue ratably over the duration of the annual license term as VSOE of PCS, the only remaining undelivered element, cannot be established in accordance with ASC 985-605.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P30_S0	the duration of the license term.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P30_S1	In certain instances, the customers are billed for access on a monthly basis for the term-based software licenses and the Company recognizes revenue accordingly.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P30_S2	In addition, specialized markets are comprised of transaction-based fees recognized as information is delivered to customers, provided that all other revenue recognition criteria have been met.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P31_S0	The Company services long-term contract arrangements with certain customers.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P31_S1	For these arrangements, revenue is recognized in accordance with ASC 605-35, Revenue Recognition Construction-Type and Production-Type Contracts ( ASC 605-35 ), using the percentage-of-completion method, which requires the use of estimates.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P31_S2	In such instances, management is required to estimate the input measures, based on hours incurred to date compared to total estimated hours of the project, with consideration also given to output measures, such as contract milestones, when applicable.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P31_S3	Adjustments to estimates are made in the period in which the facts requiring such revisions become known.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P31_S4	Accordingly, recognized revenues and profits are subject to revisions as the contract progresses to completion.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P31_S5	The Company considers the contract substantially complete when there is compliance with all performance specifications and there are no remaining costs or potential risk.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P32_S0	There are also services within energy and specialized markets, which are comprised of transaction-based fees recognized as information is delivered to customers, provided that all other revenue recognition criteria have been met.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P33_S0	The Company invoices its customers in annual, quarterly, monthly or milestone installments.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P33_S1	Amounts billed and collected in advance of earnings are recorded as Deferred revenues in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets and are recognized as the services are performed and the applicable revenue recognition criteria are met.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P34_S0	(d) Fixed Assets and Finite-lived Intangible Assets Property and equipment, internal-use software and finite-lived intangibles are stated at cost less accumulated depreciation and amortization, which are computed on a straight-line basis over their estimated useful lives.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P35_S0	Leasehold improvements are amortized over the shorter of the useful life of the asset or the lease term.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P36_S0	The Company s internal software development costs primarily relate to internal-use software.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P36_S1	Such costs are capitalized in the application development stage in accordance with ASC 350-40, Internal-use Software .
1442145_16_ITEM8_P36_S2	The Company also capitalizes software development costs upon the establishment of technological feasibility for a product in accordance with ASC 985-20, Software to be Sold, Leased, or Marketed ( ASC 985-20 ).
1442145_16_ITEM8_P36_S3	Software development costs are amortized on a straight-line basis over a three -year period, which management believes represents the useful life of these capitalized costs.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P37_S0	In accordance with ASC 360, Property, Plant Equipment , whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of long-lived assets and finite-lived intangible assets may not be recoverable, the Company reviews its long-lived assets and finite-lived intangible assets for impairment by first comparing the carrying value of the assets to the sum of the undiscounted cash flows expected to result from the use and eventual disposition of the assets.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P37_S1	If the carrying value exceeds the sum of the assets undiscounted cash flows, the Company estimates and recognizes an impairment loss by taking the difference between the carrying value and fair value of the assets.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P38_S0	The Company leases various property, plant and equipment.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P38_S1	Leased property is accounted for under ASC 840, Leases ( ASC 840 ).
1442145_16_ITEM8_P38_S2	Accordingly, leased property that meets certain criteria is capitalized and the present value of the related lease payments is recorded as a liability.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P39_S0	Amortization of assets accounted for as capital leases is computed utilizing the straight-line method over the shorter of the remaining lease term or the estimated useful life (principally three to four years for computer equipment and automobiles).
1442145_16_ITEM8_P39_S1	All other leases are accounted for as operating leases.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P39_S2	Rent expense for operating leases, which may have rent escalation provisions or rent holidays, is recorded on a straight-line basis over the non-cancelable lease period in accordance with ASC 840.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P40_S0	The initial lease term generally includes the build-out period, where no rent payments are typically due under the terms of the lease.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P40_S1	The difference between rent expensed and rent paid is recorded as deferred rent.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P40_S2	Construction allowances received from landlords are recorded as a deferred rent credit and amortized to rent expense over the term of the lease.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P41_S0	(f) Investments The Company s investments at December 31, 2015 and 2014 included registered investment companies and equity investments in non-public companies.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P41_S1	The Company accounts for short-term investments in accordance with ASC 320, Investments-Debt and Equity Securities ( ASC 320 ).
1442145_16_ITEM8_P41_S2	There were no investments classified as trading securities at December 31, 2015 or 2014 .
1442145_16_ITEM8_P41_S3	All investments with readily determinable market values are classified as available-for-sale.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P41_S4	While these investments are not held with the specific intention to sell them, they may be sold to support the Company s investment strategies.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P41_S5	All available-for-sale investments are carried at fair value.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P41_S6	The cost of all available-for-sale investments sold is based on the specific identification method, with the exception of mutual fund-based investments, which is based on the weighted average cost method.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P42_S0	Dividend income is accrued on the ex-dividend date.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P43_S0	The Company performs reviews of its investment portfolio when individual holdings have experienced a decline in fair value below their respective cost.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P43_S1	The Company considers a number of factors in the evaluation of whether a decline in value is other-than-temporary including: (a) the financial condition and near term prospects of the issuer; (b) the Company s ability and intent to retain the investment for a period of time sufficient to allow for an anticipated recovery in value; and (c) the period and degree to which the market value has been below cost.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P43_S2	Where the decline is deemed to be other-than-temporary, a charge is recorded to Investment income and others in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations, and a new cost basis is established for the investment.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P43_S3	The Company s equity investments in non-public companies are included in Other assets in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P43_S4	Those securities are carried at cost, as the Company owns less than 20% of the stock and does not otherwise have the ability to exercise significant influence.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P43_S5	These securities are written down to their estimated realizable value when management considers there is an other-than-temporary decline in value based on financial information received and the business prospects of the entity.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P44_S0	(g) Fair Value of Financial and Non-financial Instruments The Company follows the provisions of ASC 820-10, Fair Value Measurements ( ASC 820-10 ), which defines fair value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value under U.S. GAAP and expands fair value measurement disclosures.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P45_S0	The Company follows the provisions of ASC 820-10 for its financial assets and liabilities recognized or disclosed at fair value on a recurring basis.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P46_S0	The Company follows the provisions of ASC 820-10 for its non-financial assets and liabilities recognized or disclosed at fair value.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P47_S0	(h) Accounts Receivable and Allowance for Doubtful Accounts Accounts receivable is generally recorded at the invoiced amount.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P47_S1	The allowance for doubtful accounts is estimated based on an analysis of the aging of the accounts receivable, historical write-offs, customer payment patterns, individual customer creditworthiness, current economic trends, and/or establishment of specific reserves for customers in adverse financial condition.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P47_S2	The Company assesses the adequacy of the allowance for doubtful accounts on a quarterly basis.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P48_S0	The Company has determined local currencies are the functional currencies of the foreign operations.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P48_S1	The assets and liabilities of foreign subsidiaries are translated at the period-end rate of exchange and statement of operations items are translated at the average rates prevailing during the year.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P48_S2	The resulting translation adjustment is recorded as a component of Accumulated other comprehensive losses in the accompanying consolidated statements of changes in stockholders equity.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P48_S3	The Company follows ASC 718, Stock Compensation ( ASC 718 ).
1442145_16_ITEM8_P48_S4	Under ASC 718, stock based compensation cost is measured at the grant date, based on the fair value of the awards granted, and is recognized as expense over the requisite service period.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P48_S5	Other equity awards, including restricted stock, are valued at the closing price of the Company s common stock on the grant date.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P48_S6	Restricted stock generally has a service vesting period of four years and the Company recognizes the expense ratably over this service vesting period.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P49_S0	The Company estimates expected forfeitures of equity awards at the date of grant and recognizes compensation expense only for those awards expected to vest.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P49_S1	The forfeiture assumption is ultimately adjusted to the actual forfeiture rate.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P49_S2	Changes in the forfeiture assumptions may impact the total amount of expense ultimately recognized, as well as the timing of expense recognized over the requisite service period.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P50_S0	(k) Research and Development Costs Research and development costs, which are primarily related to the personnel and related overhead costs incurred in developing new services for customers, are expensed as incurred.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P50_S1	Such costs were $22,737 , $25,508 and $21,426 for the years ended December 31, 2015 , 2014 and 2013 , respectively, and were included in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P51_S0	(l) Advertising Costs Advertising costs, which are primarily associated with promoting the Company s brand, names and solutions provided, are expensed as incurred.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P51_S1	Such costs were $7,125 , $6,360 and $8,457 for the years ended December 31, 2015 , 2014 and 2013 , respectively.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P52_S0	(m) Income Taxes The Company accounts for income taxes under the asset and liability method under ASC 740, Income Taxes ( ASC 740 ), which requires the recognition of deferred tax assets and liabilities for the expected future tax consequences of events that have been included in the financial statements.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P52_S1	Under this method, deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined based on the differences between the financial statements and tax basis of assets and liabilities using enacted tax rates in effect for the year in which the differences are expected to reverse.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P52_S2	The effect of a change in tax rates on deferred tax assets and liabilities is recognized in income in the period that includes the enactment date.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P52_S3	Deferred tax assets are recorded to the extent these assets are more likely than not to be realized.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P52_S4	In making such determination, the Company considers all available positive and negative evidence, including future reversals of existing taxable temporary differences, projected future taxable income, tax planning strategies and recent financial operations.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P53_S0	Valuation allowances are recognized to reduce deferred tax assets if it is determined to be more likely than not that all or some of the potential deferred tax assets will not be realized.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P54_S0	The Company follows ASC 740-10, Income Taxes ( ASC 740-10 ) , which clarifies the accounting for uncertainty in income taxes recognized in the financial statements.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P54_S1	ASC 740-10 provides that a tax benefit from an uncertain tax position may be recognized based on the technical merits when it is more likely than not that the position will be sustained upon examination, including resolutions of any related appeals or litigation processes.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P54_S2	Income tax positions must meet a more likely than not recognition threshold in accordance with ASC 740-10.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P54_S3	This standard also provides guidance on measurement, derecognition, classification, interest and penalties, accounting in interim periods, disclosure and transition.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P54_S4	The Company recognizes interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits within the income tax expense line in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P54_S5	Accrued interest and penalties are included within Other liabilities on the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P55_S0	(n) Earnings Per Share Basic and diluted earnings per share ( EPS ) are determined in accordance with ASC 260, Earnings per Share , which specifies the computation, presentation and disclosure requirements for EPS.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P55_S1	Basic EPS excludes all dilutive common stock equivalents.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P55_S2	It is based upon the weighted average number of common shares outstanding during the period.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P56_S0	Diluted EPS, as calculated using the treasury stock method, reflects the potential dilution that would occur if the Company s dilutive outstanding stock options and stock awards were issued.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P57_S0	The Company accounts for its pension and postretirement benefits under ASC 715, Compensation Retirement Benefits ( ASC 715 ).
1442145_16_ITEM8_P57_S1	ASC 715 requires the recognition of the funded status of a benefit plan in the balance sheet, the recognition in other comprehensive income (loss) of gains or losses and prior service costs or credits arising during the period, but which are not included as components of periodic benefit cost, and the measurement of defined benefit plan assets and obligations as of the balance sheet date.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P58_S0	The Company utilizes a valuation date of December 31.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P59_S0	The Company provides warranty coverage for certain of its solutions.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P59_S1	The Company recognizes a product warranty obligation when claims are probable and can be reasonably estimated.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P59_S2	As of December 31, 2015 and 2014 , product warranty obligations were not material.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P60_S0	In the ordinary course of business, the Company enters into numerous agreements that contain standard indemnities whereby the Company indemnifies another party for breaches of confidentiality, infringement of intellectual property or gross negligence.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P60_S1	Such indemnifications are primarily granted under licensing of computer software.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P60_S2	Most agreements contain provisions to limit the maximum potential amount of future payments that the Company could be required to make under these indemnifications; however, the Company is not able to develop an estimate of the maximum potential amount of future payments to be made under these indemnifications as the triggering events are not subject to predictability.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P61_S0	The Company accrues for costs relating to litigation, claims and other contingent matters when such liabilities become probable and reasonably estimable.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P61_S1	Such estimates are based on management s judgment.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P61_S2	Actual amounts paid may differ from amounts estimated, and such differences will be charged to operations in the period in which the final determination of the liability is made.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P62_S0	(r) Goodwill Goodwill represents the excess of acquisition costs over the fair value of tangible net assets and identifiable intangible assets of the businesses acquired.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P62_S1	Goodwill and intangible assets deemed to have indefinite lives are not amortized.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P62_S2	Intangible assets determined to have finite lives are amortized over their useful lives.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P62_S3	Goodwill and intangible assets with indefinite lives are subject to impairment testing annually as of June 30 or whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount may not be fully recoverable.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P62_S4	The Company completed the required annual impairment test as of June 30, 2015 , which resulted in no impairment of goodwill in 2015 .
1442145_16_ITEM8_P62_S5	This test compares the carrying value of each reporting unit to its fair value.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P62_S6	If the fair value of the reporting unit exceeds the carrying value of the net assets, including goodwill assigned to that reporting unit, goodwill is not impaired.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P62_S7	If the carrying value of the reporting unit s net assets, including goodwill, exceeds the fair value of the reporting unit, then the Company will determine the implied fair value of the reporting unit s goodwill.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P62_S8	If the carrying value of a reporting unit s goodwill exceeds its implied fair value, then an impairment loss is recorded for the difference between the carrying amount and the implied fair value of the goodwill.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P63_S0	In April 2015, the Financial Accounting Standard Board ("FASB") issued Accounting Standards Update ("ASU") 2015-03, Simplifying the Presentation of Debt Issuance Costs ("ASU No. 2015-03").
1442145_16_ITEM8_P63_S1	The amendments in this update require that debt issuance costs related to a recognized debt liability be presented in the balance sheet as a direct deduction from the carrying amount of that debt liability, consistent with debt discounts.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P64_S0	ASU No. 2015-03 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2015, and interim periods within those fiscal years.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P64_S1	The Company has elected not to early adopt.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P64_S2	The adoption of ASU No. 2015-03 is not expected to have a material impact on the Company's consolidated financial statements.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P65_S0	In April 2015, the FASB issued ASU 2015-05, Customer's Accounting for Fees Paid in a Cloud Computing Arrangement ("ASU No. 2015-05").
1442145_16_ITEM8_P65_S1	This guidance is intended to help entities evaluate the accounting for fees paid by a customer in a cloud computing arrangement, primarily to determine whether the arrangement includes a sale or license of software.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P66_S0	ASU No. 2015-05 is effective for annual periods, including interim periods within those annual periods, beginning after December 15, 2015.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P66_S1	The Company has elected to adopt ASU No. 2015-05 in 2016.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P66_S2	The adoption of ASU No. 2015-05 is not expected to have a material impact on the Company's consolidated financial statements.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P67_S0	In August 2015, the FASB issued ASU 2015-14, Revenue from Contracts with Customers - Deferral of the Effective Date ("ASU No. 2015-14").
1442145_16_ITEM8_P67_S1	The amendments in this update defer the effective date of ASU No. 2014-09, Revenue from Contracts with Customers ("ASU No. 2015-09"), for all entities by one year.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P67_S2	Public business entities will apply the guidance in ASU No. 2015-09 for annual reporting periods beginning after December 15, 2017.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P67_S3	The Company is currently evaluating ASU No. 2015-09 and has not determined the impact this standard may have on its financial statements nor decided upon the method of adoption.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P68_S0	In August 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-15, Presentation and Subsequent Measurement of Debt Issuance Costs Associated with Line-of-Credit Arrangements ("ASU No. 2015-15").
1442145_16_ITEM8_P68_S1	ASU No. 2015-15 clarifies that ASU No. 2015-03, Simplifying the Presentation of Debt Issuance Costs , does not address the presentation or subsequent measurement of debt issuance costs related to line-of-credit arrangements.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P68_S2	As a result, an entity may present debt issuance costs related to line-of-credit arrangements as an asset instead of as a direct deduction from the carrying amount of the debt.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P68_S3	The Company has elected not to early adopt ASU No. 2015-15.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P68_S4	The adoption of ASU No. 2015-15 is not expected to have a material impact on the Company's consolidated financial statements.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P69_S0	In September 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-16, Simplifying the Accounting for Measurement-Period Adjustments ("ASU No. 2015-16").
1442145_16_ITEM8_P69_S1	ASU No. 2015-16 requires, for business combinations, that the acquirer record, in the same period's financial statements, the effect on earnings of changes in depreciation, amortization, or other income effects, if any, as a result of the change to the provisional amounts, calculated as if the accounting had been completed at the acquisition date.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P69_S2	ASU No. 2015-16 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2015.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P69_S3	Early adoption is permitted for reporting periods for which financial statements have not been issued.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P69_S4	The Company has elected to early adopt ASU No. 2015-16 on a prospective basis.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P69_S5	Adoption of this guidance did not have a material impact on the results of operations or financial position (see Note 9).
1442145_16_ITEM8_P70_S0	In November 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-17, Balance Sheet Classification of Deferred Taxes ("ASU No. 2015-17").
1442145_16_ITEM8_P70_S1	This ASU requires that deferred tax assets and liabilities be classified as non-current in a statement of financial position.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P70_S2	The Company early adopted ASU No. 2015-17 effective December 31, 2015 on a prospective basis.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P70_S3	Adoption of this ASU resulted in a reclassification of the net current deferred tax asset to the net non-current deferred tax asset in the accompanying consolidated balance sheet as of December 31, 2015.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P70_S4	No prior periods were retrospectively adjusted.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P70_S5	The Company applied this guidance to its current fiscal year ending December 31, 2015.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P70_S6	Adoption of this guidance did not have a material impact on the results of operations or financial position (see Note 12).
1442145_16_ITEM8_P71_S0	Concentration of Credit Risk: Financial instruments that potentially expose the Company to credit risk consist primarily of cash and cash equivalents, available for sale securities and accounts receivable, which are generally not collateralized.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P71_S1	The Company maintains its cash and cash equivalents in higher credit quality financial institutions in order to limit the amount of credit exposure.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P71_S2	The total domestic cash balances are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation ( FDIC ) to a maximum amount of $250 per bank at December 31, 2015 and 2014 .
1442145_16_ITEM8_P71_S3	At December 31, 2015 and 2014 , the Company had cash balances on deposit that exceeded the balance insured by the FDIC limit by approximately $85,000 and $16,316 with six banks.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P71_S4	At December 31, 2015 and 2014 , the Company also had cash on deposit with foreign banks of approximately $52,092 and $21,886 , respectively.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P72_S0	The Company considers the concentration of credit risk associated with its trade accounts receivable to be commercially reasonable and believes that such concentration does not result in the significant risk of near-term severe adverse impacts.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P73_S0	The Company s top fifty customers represent approximately 36% of revenues for 2015 , 41% for 2014 and 38% for 2013 with no individual customer accounting for more than 2% of revenues during the year ended December 31, 2015 , and 5% for 2014 and 3% for 2013 .
1442145_16_ITEM8_P73_S1	No individual customer comprised more than 3% of accounts receivable at December 31, 2015 and 7% at December 31, 2014 .
1442145_16_ITEM8_P74_S0	Cash and Cash Equivalents: Cash and cash equivalents consist of cash in banks, commercial paper, money-market funds, and other liquid instruments with original maturities of 90 days or less at the time of purchase.

1442145_16_ITEM8_P77_S0	Fair Value Measurements: Certain assets and liabilities of the Company are reported at fair value in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P77_S1	Such assets and liabilities include amounts for both financial and non-financial instruments.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P77_S2	To increase consistency and comparability of assets and liabilities recorded at fair value, ASC 820-10 establishes a three-level fair value hierarchy to prioritize the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P77_S3	ASC 820-10 requires disclosures detailing the extent to which companies measure assets and liabilities at fair value, the methods and assumptions used to measure fair value and the effect of fair value measurements on earnings.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P78_S0	In accordance with ASC 820-10, the Company applied the following fair value hierarchy: Level 1 Assets or liabilities for which the identical item is traded on an active exchange, such as publicly-traded instruments.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P78_S1	Level 2 Assets and liabilities valued based on observable market data for similar instruments.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P78_S2	Level 3 Assets or liabilities for which significant valuation assumptions are not readily observable in the market; instruments valued based on the best available data, some of which is internally-developed, and considers risk premiums that a market participant would require.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P78_S3	The following table provides information for such assets and liabilities as of December 31, 2015 and 2014 .
1442145_16_ITEM8_P78_S4	The fair values of cash and cash equivalents (other than money-market funds which are recorded on a reported net asset value basis disclosed below), accounts receivable, accounts payable and accrued liabilities, deferred revenues, Business Combinations ( ASC 805 ), short-term debt, and short-term debt expected to be refinanced approximate their carrying amounts because of the short-term nature of these instruments.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P78_S5	The following table summarizes fair value measurements by level for cash equivalents and registered investment companies that were measured at fair value on a recurring basis:
1442145_16_ITEM8_P79_S0	(1) Registered investment companies are classified as available-for-sale securities and are valued using quoted prices in active markets multiplied by the number of shares owned.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P79_S1	The Company has not elected to carry its long-term debt at fair value.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P79_S2	The carrying value of the long-term debt represents amortized cost.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P79_S3	The Company assesses the fair value of its long-term debt based on quoted market prices if available, and if not, an estimate of interest rates available to the Company for debt with similar features, the Company s current credit rating and spreads applicable to the Company.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P79_S4	The fair value of the long-term debt would be a Level 2 liability if the long-term debt was measured at fair value on the consolidated balance sheets.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P79_S5	The following table summarizes the carrying value and estimated fair value of the long-term debt as of December 31, 2015 and 2014 respectively:

1442145_16_ITEM8_P81_S1	Amortization expense related to development of software for sale in accordance with ASC 985-20 was $9,228 , $4,497 and $3,623 for the years ended December 31, 2015 , 2014 and 2013 , respectively.

1442145_16_ITEM8_P83_S0	On May 19, 2015, the Company acquired 100 percent of the stock of Wood Mackenzie Limited ("Wood Mackenzie") for a net cash purchase price of $2,889,629 , including $78,694 of an indemnity escrow, which the Company financed through a combination of debt and equity offerings, borrowings under the Company's new credit facility, and cash on hand.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P83_S1	Due to the fact that a portion of the purchase price was funded in pounds sterling and the remainder in U.S. dollars, the Company entered into a foreign currency hedging instrument to purchase pounds sterling.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P83_S2	The Company recorded a gain on the hedge of $85,187 within "Gain on derivative instruments" in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P83_S3	The proceeds from the gain were utilized to partially fund the acquisition of Wood Mackenzie.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P84_S0	Wood Mackenzie is a global provider of data analytics and commercial intelligence for the energy, chemicals, metals and mining verticals.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P84_S1	This acquisition advances the Company s strategy to expand internationally and positions the Company in the global energy market.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P85_S0	Wood Mackenzie is included in the energy and specialized markets vertical, formerly named the specialized markets vertical, of the Decision Analytics segment.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P85_S1	On November 6, 2015, the Company acquired 100 percent of the stock of Infield Systems Limited ("Infield").
1442145_16_ITEM8_P86_S0	Infield is a provider of business intelligence, analysis, and research to the oil, gas, and associated marine industries.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P86_S1	Infield has become part of Wood Mackenzie and continues to provide services to enhance Wood Mackenzie's upstream and supply chain capabilities in the Decision Analytics segment.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P86_S2	The Company paid a net cash purchase price of $13,804 .
1442145_16_ITEM8_P86_S3	The preliminary purchase price allocation of the acquisition is presented as Others in the table below.

1442145_16_ITEM8_P99_S0	Goodwill and Intangible Assets: Goodwill represents the excess of acquisition costs over the fair value of tangible net assets and identifiable intangible assets of the businesses acquired.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P99_S1	Goodwill and intangible assets deemed to have indefinite lives are not amortized.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P99_S2	Intangible assets determined to have finite lives are amortized over their useful lives.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P99_S3	The Company completed the required annual impairment test as of June 30, 2015 , 2014 and 2013 , which resulted in no impairment of goodwill.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P99_S4	Based on the results of the impairment assessment as of June 30, 2015 , the Company determined that the fair value of its reporting units exceeded their respective carrying value.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P99_S5	There were no goodwill impairment indicators after the date of the last annual impairment test.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P99_S6	The following is a summary of the change in goodwill from December 31, 2013 through December 31, 2015 , both in total and as allocated to the Company s operating segments:

1442145_16_ITEM8_P106_S1	The tax effects of significant items comprising the Company s deferred tax assets as of December 31 are as follows:
1442145_16_ITEM8_P107_S0	During November 2015, the FASB issued ASU No. 2015-17, which simplifies the presentation of deferred income taxes.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P107_S1	This ASU requires that deferred tax assets and liabilities be classified as non-current in a statement of financial position.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P107_S2	The Company early adopted ASU No. 2015-17 effective December 31, 2015 on a prospective basis.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P107_S3	Adoption of this ASU resulted in a reclassification of the net current deferred tax asset to the net non-current deferred tax asset in the accompanying consolidated balance sheet as of December 31, 2015.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P107_S4	No prior periods were retrospectively adjusted.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P107_S5	The Company applied this guidance to its current fiscal year ended December 31, 2015.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P107_S6	Adoption of this guidance had no material impact on the results of operations or financial position.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P108_S0	The net deferred income liability of $396,430 consists primarily of timing differences involving depreciation and amortization.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P109_S0	The ultimate realization of the deferred tax assets depends on the Company s ability to generate sufficient taxable income in the future.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P109_S1	The Company has provided for a valuation allowance against the deferred tax assets associated with the net operating losses of certain subsidiaries.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P109_S2	The Company s net operating loss carryforwards expire as follows:
1442145_16_ITEM8_P110_S0	A valuation allowance has been established based on the Company s evaluation of the likelihood of utilizing these benefits before they expire.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P110_S1	The Company has determined that the generation of future taxable income from certain subsidiaries to fully realize the deferred tax assets is uncertain.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P110_S2	Other than these items, the Company has determined, based on the Company s historical operating performance, that taxable income of the Company will more likely than not be sufficient to fully realize the deferred tax assets.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P110_S3	It is the practice of the Company to permanently reinvest the undistributed earnings of its foreign subsidiaries in those operations.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P110_S4	As of December 31, 2015 , the Company has not made a provision for U.S. or additional foreign withholdings taxes on approximately $102,837 of the unremitted earnings.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P110_S5	The Company does not rely on these unremitted earnings as a source of funds for its domestic business as it expects to have sufficient cash flow in the U.S. to fund its U.S. operational and strategic needs.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P110_S6	Consequently, the Company has not provided for U.S. federal or state income taxes or associated withholding taxes on these undistributed foreign earnings.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P111_S0	The Company follows ASC No. 740-10, which prescribes a comprehensive model for the financial statement recognition, measurement, presentation and disclosure of uncertain tax positions taken or expected to be taken in income tax returns.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P111_S1	For each tax position, the Company must determine whether it is more likely than not that the position will be sustained upon examination based on the technical merits of the position, including resolution of any related appeals or litigation.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P111_S2	A tax position that meets the more likely than not recognition threshold is then measured to determine the amount of benefit to recognize within the financial statements.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P111_S3	No benefits may be recognized for tax positions that do not meet the more likely than not threshold.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P111_S4	A reconciliation of the beginning and ending amount of unrecognized tax benefit is as follows:
1442145_16_ITEM8_P112_S0	Of the total unrecognized tax benefits at December 31, 2015 , 2014 and 2013 , $11,444 , $5,771 and $4,658 , respectively, represent the amounts that, if recognized, would have a favorable effect on the Company s effective tax rate in any future periods.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P112_S1	The total gross amount of accrued interest and penalties at December 31, 2015 , 2014 and 2013 was $2,815 , $2,818 and $2,619 , respectively.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P112_S2	The Company s practice is to recognize interest and penalties associated with income taxes as a component of Provision for income taxes in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P112_S3	The Company does not expect a significant increase in unrecognized benefits related to federal, foreign, or state tax exposures within the coming year.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P112_S4	In addition, the Company believes that it is reasonably possible that approximately $472 of its currently remaining unrecognized tax positions, each of which is individually insignificant, may be recognized by the end of 2016 as a result of a combination of audit settlements and lapses of statute of limitations, net of additional uncertain tax positions.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P113_S0	The Company is subject to tax in the U.S. and in various state and foreign jurisdictions.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P113_S1	The Company joined by its domestic subsidiaries, files a consolidated income tax return for the Federal income tax purposes.
1442145_16_ITEM8_P113_S2	With few exceptions, none of which are material to the Company s consolidated financial statements at December 31, 2015, the Company is no longer subject to U.S. federal, state, and local or non-US income tax examinations by tax authorities for tax years before 2011.
