1442145_17_ITEM3_P2_S4	On April 18, 2016, the parties filed a joint motion to stay all proceedings pending the resolution of the United States Supreme Court s decision in Spokeo v. Robins, No. 13-1339.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P2_S5	After Spokeo was decided on May 16, 2016, plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed their federal court complaint and filed a virtually identical complaint in Ohio State court on May 27, 2016.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P2_S6	Defendants removed that complaint to the United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio on July 1, 2016, which on defendant s motion dismissed the complaint for failure to allege Article III standing and remanded the case to Ohio state court on September 27, 2016.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P2_S7	The parties agreed to resolve this matter for a non-material amount in the Settlement Agreement and Release executed on November 30, 2016.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P3_S0	Xactware Solutions, Inc. Patent Litigation On October 8, 2015, we were served with a summons and complaint in an action titled Eagle View Technologies, Inc. and Pictometry International Group, Inc. v. Xactware Solutions, Inc. and Verisk Analytics, Inc. filed in the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P4_S0	On November 30, 2015, plaintiffs filed a First Amended Complaint ( First Amended Complaint ) adding Patent Nos. 376 and 737 to the Patents in Suit.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P4_S1	The First Amended Complaint seeks an entry of judgment by the Court that defendants have and continue to directly infringe and/or indirectly infringe, by way of inducement the Patents in Suit, permanent injunctive relief, damages, costs and attorney s fees.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P4_S2	At this time, it is not possible to determine the ultimate resolution of, or estimate the liability related to this matter.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P5_S0	Litigation On April 20, 2015, we were served with a putative class action titled John Weber v. Interthinx, Inc. and Verisk Analytics, Inc.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P5_S1	The plaintiff, a former employee of our former subsidiary Interthinx, Inc. in Missouri, filed the class action complaint in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Missouri on behalf of all review appraisers and individuals holding comparable positions with different titles who were employed by Interthinx for the last three years nationwide and who were not paid overtime wages.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P5_S2	The class complaint claims that the review appraiser employees were misclassified as exempt employees and, as a result, were denied certain wages and benefits that would have been received if they were properly classified as non-exempt employees.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P5_S3	It pleads a Collective Action under section 216(b) of the Fair Labor Standards Act for unpaid overtime and seeks overtime wages, liquidated damages, declaratory relief, interest, costs and attorneys fees.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P6_S0	On March 11, 2014, we sold 100 percent of the stock of Interthinx, Inc.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P6_S1	The parties agreed to resolve this matter with our contribution of a non-material amount in the Class Action Settlement Agreement executed on November 8, 2016.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P6_S2	The hearing for the preliminary approval of the settlement is scheduled for February 21, 2017.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P7_S0	Litigation On August 1, 2014, we were served with an Amended Complaint filed in the United States District Court for the District of Colorado titled Snyder, et. al. v. ACORD Corp., et al.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P7_S1	The action is brought by nineteen individual plaintiffs, on their own behalf and on behalf of a putative class, against more than 120 defendants, including us and ISO.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P7_S2	Except for us, ISO and the defendant Acord Corporation, which provides standard forms to assist in insurance transactions, most of the other defendants are property and casualty insurance companies that plaintiffs claim conspired to underpay property damage claims.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P7_S3	Plaintiffs claim that we and ISO, along with all of the other defendants, violated state and federal antitrust and racketeering laws as well as state common law.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P7_S4	On September 8, 2014, the Court entered an Order striking the Amended Complaint and granting leave to the plaintiffs to file a new complaint.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P7_S5	On October 13, 2014, plaintiffs filed their Second Amended Complaint, which was re-filed by plaintiffs to correct errors as the Third Amended Complaint.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P7_S6	The Third Amended Complaint similarly alleges that the defendants conspired to underpay property damage claims, but does not specifically allege what role we or ISO played in the alleged conspiracy.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P7_S7	It claims that we and ISO, along with all of the other defendants, violated state and federal antitrust and racketeering laws as well as state common law, and seeks all available relief including, injunctive, statutory, actual and punitive damages as well as attorneys fees.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P7_S8	On January 15, 2016, the Court granted defendants motions to dismiss all claims asserted in the Third Amended Complaint.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P7_S9	Plaintiffs filed a motion for reconsideration of this dismissal on February 16, 2016.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P7_S10	The Court granted defendants motion to strike the motion for reconsideration on March 2, 2016 and gave plaintiffs leave to file another motion for reconsideration in accordance with the rules which plaintiffs filed on March 11, 2016 and, which was denied by the Court on April 25, 2016.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P7_S11	On April 1, 2016, plaintiffs also filed a Notice of Appeal of the Court s January 15, 2016 Order, which dismissed all claims in the Third Amended Complaint.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P7_S12	Plaintiffs also filed an appeal of the Court s denial of the motion for reconsideration, which the Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit consolidated with the appeal of the Court s January 15, 2016 dismissal.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P7_S13	Appellants filed their brief in support of the consolidated appeal on July 21, 2016 and Appellees filed their brief in response on September 21, 2016.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P8_S0	At this time, it is not possible to determine the ultimate resolution of, or estimate the liability related to this matter.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P9_S0	On February 19, 2016, we were served with a notice of a summons and complaint filed on January 29, 2016 against ISO in the U.S. District Court for the District of Connecticut titled Halloran et al. v. Harleysville Preferred Insurance Co. et al.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P10_S0	As alleged in the First Amended Complaint, the putative class action is brought by four policyholders on behalf of a class of similarly situated policyholders in eastern Connecticut who allege that their homeowner s insurance carriers have denied or will deny their claims for damage to their homes caused by defective concrete.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P10_S1	The lawsuit alleges a breach of contract claim against certain insurers and seeks declaratory relief as to more than 100 other insurers.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P10_S2	It also alleges that ISO as the drafter of the standardized policy language at issue violated the Connecticut Unfair Trade Practices ("CUTPA") and the Connecticut Unfair Insurance Practices Act ("CUIPA").
1442145_17_ITEM3_P11_S0	The plaintiffs ask that the Court certify a class of persons similarly situated and seek relief in the form of the cost for the replacement of their concrete foundations and a declaratory judgment that all of the defendant insurance carriers are obligated to provide coverage for claims resulting from the defective concrete as well as, attorneys fees, costs and interest.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P12_S0	On March 17, 2016 plaintiffs filed their first amended complaint asserting federal jurisdiction under the Class Action Fairness Act, adding a number of insurer defendants and amending their damages claim to include punitive damages.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P12_S1	After defendants indicated that they would be filing motions to dismiss the first amended complaint at a Rule 16 Conference on April 12, 2016, the Court gave plaintiffs until May 6, 2016 to move for leave to file a second amended complaint.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P13_S0	On May 6, 2016, plaintiffs filed a Motion to amend the first amended complaint with a proposed second amended complaint, which did not name ISO or us as a defendant.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P13_S1	No opposition was filed to the motion to amend, which was granted on October 4, 2016.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P13_S2	Instead of filing a second amended complaint, plaintiffs, in a joint motion for the modification of the case schedule filed on October 13, 2016, expressed their intention to move for leave to file a third amended complaint in order to drop certain additional defendants and to add other named plaintiffs.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P13_S3	Plaintiffs motion for leave to file a third amended complaint which does not name us as a defendant is pending before the District Court.
1442145_17_ITEM3_P14_S0	At this time, it is not possible to determine the ultimate resolution of, or estimate the liability related to this matter.
1442145_17_ITEM5_P0_S0	Market Information Verisk trades under the ticker symbol VRSK on the NASDAQ Global Select Market.
1442145_17_ITEM5_P0_S1	Our common stock was first publicly traded on October 7, 2009.
1442145_17_ITEM5_P0_S2	As of February 17, 2017 , the closing price of our common stock was $84.90 per share, as reported by the NASDAQ Global Select Market.
1442145_17_ITEM5_P0_S3	As of February 17, 2017 , there were approximately 40 stockholders of record.
1442145_17_ITEM5_P0_S4	We believe the number of beneficial owners is substantially greater than the number of record holders, because a large portion of common stock is held in street name by brokers.
1442145_17_ITEM5_P0_S5	We have not paid or declared any cash dividends on our common stock during the two most recent fiscal years and we currently do not intend to pay dividends on our common stock.
1442145_17_ITEM5_P0_S6	We have a publicly announced share repurchase plan and repurchased a total of 50,636,328 shares since our IPO through December 31, 2016 .
1442145_17_ITEM5_P0_S7	As of December 31, 2016 , we had 377,087,266 shares of treasury stock.

1442145_17_ITEM6_P0_S0	The following selected historical financial data should be read in conjunction with, and are qualified by reference to, Item 7.
1442145_17_ITEM6_P0_S1	Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations and the consolidated financial statements and notes thereto included elsewhere in this annual report on Form 10-K. The consolidated statement of operations data for the years ended December 31, 2016 , 2015 and 2014 and the consolidated balance sheet data as of December 31, 2016 and 2015 are derived from the audited consolidated financial statements included elsewhere in this annual report on Form 10-K. The consolidated statement of operations data for the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012 and the consolidated balance sheet data as of December 31, 2014 , 2013 and 2012 are derived from consolidated financial statements that are not included in this annual report on Form 10-K. Results for the year ended December 31, 2016 are not necessarily indicative of results that may be expected in any other future period.
1442145_17_ITEM6_P0_S2	Between January 1, 2012 and December 31, 2016 , we acquired 15 businesses (most notably Wood Mackenzie on May 19, 2015), which may affect the comparability of our consolidated financial statements.
1442145_17_ITEM6_P0_S3	Our consolidated financial statements have been retroactively adjusted in all periods presented to give recognition to the discontinued operations of our heathcare business and mortgage services business.
1442145_17_ITEM6_P0_S4	The following table sets forth our statement of operations for the years ended December 31:
1442145_17_ITEM6_P1_S0	The financial operating data below sets forth the information we believe is useful for investors in evaluating our overall financial performance for the years ended December 31:
1442145_17_ITEM6_P2_S0	The following table sets forth our consolidated balance sheet data as of the years ended December 31:
1442145_17_ITEM6_P3_S0	(1) On June 1, 2016 and March 11, 2014, we sold our healthcare business and mortgage services business, respectively.
1442145_17_ITEM6_P3_S1	Results of operations for the healthcare and mortgage services businesses are reported as discontinued operations for the year ended December 31, 2016 and for all prior periods presented.
1442145_17_ITEM6_P3_S2	As necessary, the amounts have been retroactively adjusted in all periods presented to give recognition to the discontinued operations.
1442145_17_ITEM6_P4_S0	See Note 10 of our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K. (2) EBITDA is the financial measure that management uses to evaluate the performance of our segments.
1442145_17_ITEM6_P4_S1	EBITDA is defined as net income before interest expense, provision for income taxes, and depreciation and amortization of fixed and intangible assets.
1442145_17_ITEM6_P4_S2	Because EBITDA is calculated from net income, this presentation includes EBITDA from discontinued operations of our healthcare business and mortgage services business.
1442145_17_ITEM6_P4_S3	In addition, references to EBITDA margin, which is computed as EBITDA divided by revenues from continuing and discontinued operations.
1442145_17_ITEM6_P4_S4	See Note 18 of our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K.
1442145_17_ITEM6_P5_S0	Although EBITDA is a non-GAAP financial measure, EBITDA is frequently used by securities analysts, lenders and others in their evaluation of companies, EBITDA has limitations as an analytical tool, and should not be considered in isolation, or as a substitute for an analysis of our results of operations or cash flow from operating activities reported under GAAP.
1442145_17_ITEM6_P5_S1	Management uses EBITDA in conjunction with traditional GAAP operating performance measures as part of its overall assessment of company performance.
1442145_17_ITEM6_P6_S0	EBITDA does not reflect our cash expenditures, or future requirements for capital expenditures or contractual commitments.
1442145_17_ITEM6_P7_S0	EBITDA does not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs.
1442145_17_ITEM6_P8_S0	Although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and amortized often will have to be replaced in the future and EBITDA does not reflect any cash requirements for such replacements.
1442145_17_ITEM6_P9_S0	Other companies in our industry may calculate EBITDA differently than we do, limiting its usefulness as a comparative measure.
1442145_17_ITEM6_P9_S1	(4) Subsequent to our corporate reorganization on October 6, 2009, share repurchases are recorded as treasury stock within stockholders equity, as we intend to reissue shares from treasury stock in the future.
1442145_17_ITEM6_P9_S2	For the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015 , we repurchased $333.3 million and $120.5 million, respectively, of treasury stock.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P0_S0	The following discussion should be read in conjunction with our historical financial statements and the related notes included elsewhere in this annual report on Form 10-K, as well as the discussion under Selected Consolidated Financial Data.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P1_S0	This discussion contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P1_S1	Our actual results may differ materially from those discussed in or implied by any of the forward-looking statements as a result of various factors, including but not limited to those listed under Risk Factors and Special Note Regarding Forward-Looking Statements.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P2_S0	We enable our customers to make better decisions about risk, investments, and operations with greater precision, efficiency, and discipline.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P2_S1	We also help customers across the globe protect and grow the value of people, property and financial assets.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P2_S2	We provide value to our customers by supplying proprietary data that, combined with our analytic methods, creates embedded decision support solutions.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P3_S0	We are one of the largest aggregators and providers of data pertaining to U.S. property and casualty, or P C, insurance risks.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P3_S1	We offer predictive analytics and decision support solutions to customers in rating, underwriting, claims, catastrophe and weather risk, global risk analytics, natural resources intelligence, and many other fields.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P3_S2	Our customers use our solutions to make better decisions with greater efficiency and discipline.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P3_S3	We refer to these products and services as solutions due to the integration among our products and the flexibility that enables our customers to purchase components or the comprehensive package of products.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P3_S4	These solutions take various forms, including data, statistical models or tailored analytics, all designed to allow our customers to make more logical decisions.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P3_S5	We believe our solutions for analyzing risk positively impact our customers revenues and help them better manage their costs.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P3_S6	We organize our business in two segments: Risk Assessment and Decision Analytics.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P4_S0	Our Risk Assessment segment provides statistical, actuarial and underwriting data for the U.S. P C insurance industry.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P4_S1	Our Risk Assessment segment revenues represented 36.3% and 39.1% of our revenues for the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015 , respectively.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P4_S2	Our Decision Analytics segment provides solutions to our customer in insurance, energy and specialized markets, and financial services.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P4_S3	Our Decision Analytics segment revenues represented approximately 63.7% and 60.9% of our revenues for the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015 , respectively.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P5_S0	On June 1, 2016 and March 11, 2014, we sold our healthcare business, Verisk Health, and mortgage services business, Interthinx, respectively.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P5_S1	Results of operations for the healthcare and mortgage services businesses are reported as discontinued operations for the year ended December 31, 2016 and for all prior periods presented.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P5_S2	See Note 10 of our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K. As necessary, the amounts have been retroactively adjusted in all periods presented to give recognition to the discontinued operations.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P6_S0	We believe our business s ability to grow recurring revenue and generate positive cash flow is the key indicator of the successful execution of our business strategy.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P6_S1	We use year-over-year revenue and EBITDA growth as metrics to measure our performance.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P6_S2	EBITDA and EBITDA margin are non-GAAP financial measures (see Note 2 within Item 6.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P7_S0	Selected Financial Data section of Management s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations).
1442145_17_ITEM7_P7_S1	The respective GAAP financial measures are net income and net income margin.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P8_S0	We use year-over-year revenue growth as a key performance metric.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P8_S1	We assess revenue growth based on our ability to generate increased revenue through increased sales to existing customers, sales to new customers, sales of new or expanded solutions to existing and new customers, and strategic acquisitions of new businesses.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P8_S2	We use EBITDA growth as a proxy for the cash generated by the business.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P8_S3	EBITDA growth serves as a measure of our ability to balance the size of revenue growth with cost management and investing for future growth.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P8_S4	We use EBITDA margin as a metric to assess segment performance and scalability of our business.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P9_S0	We assess EBITDA margin based on our ability to increase revenues while controlling expense growth.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P9_S1	Revenues We earn revenues through subscriptions, long-term agreements and on a transactional basis, recurring and non-recurring.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P9_S2	Subscriptions for our solutions are generally paid in advance of rendering services either quarterly or in full upon commencement of the subscription period, which is usually for one year and automatically renewed each year.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P9_S3	As a result, the timing of our cash flows generally precedes our recognition of revenues and income and our cash flow from operations tends to be higher in the first quarter as we receive subscription payments.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P9_S4	Examples of these arrangements include subscriptions that allow our customers to access our standardized coverage language, our claims fraud database or our actuarial services throughout the subscription period.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P10_S0	In general, we experience minimal revenue seasonality within the business.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P10_S1	Our long-term agreements are generally for periods of three to five years.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P10_S2	We recognize revenue from subscriptions ratably over the term of the subscription and most long-term agreements are recognized ratably over the term of the agreement.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P10_S3	Certain of our solutions are also paid for by our customers on a transactional basis.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P10_S4	For example, we have solutions that allow our customers to obtain property-specific rating and underwriting information to price a policy on a commercial building, or compare a P C insurance, medical or workers compensation claim with information in our databases.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P10_S5	We also provide advisory services, which help our customers get more value out of our analytics and their subscriptions.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P10_S6	For the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015 , 16.5% and 17.2% of our revenues were derived from providing transactional recurring and non-recurring solutions, respectively.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P10_S7	We earn these revenues as our solutions are delivered or services performed.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P10_S8	In general, they are billed monthly at the end of each month.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P10_S9	For the the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015 , 92.0% and 90.1% of the revenues in our Risk Assessment segment were derived from subscriptions and long-term agreements for our solutions, respectively.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P10_S10	Our customers in this segment include most of the P C insurance providers in the U.S.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P10_S11	For the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015 , 78.6% and 78.1% of the revenues in our Decision Analytics segment were derived from subscriptions and long-term agreements for our solutions, respectively.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P10_S12	Principal Operating Costs and Expenses Personnel expenses are a major component of both our cost of revenues and selling, general and administrative expenses.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P10_S13	Personnel expenses, which represented 47.7% and 46.5% of our total expenses for the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015 , respectively, include salaries, benefits, incentive compensation, equity compensation costs, sales commissions, employment taxes, recruiting costs, and outsourced temporary agency costs.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P10_S14	We allocate personnel expenses between two categories, cost of revenues and selling, general and administrative costs, based on the actual costs associated with each employee.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P10_S15	We categorize employees who maintain our solutions as cost of revenues, and all other personnel, including executive managers, sales people, marketing, business development, finance, legal, human resources, and administrative services, as selling, general and administrative expenses.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P10_S16	A significant portion of our other operating costs, such as facilities and communications, are either captured within cost of revenues or selling, general and administrative expense based on the nature of the work being performed.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P10_S17	While we expect to grow our headcount over time to take advantage of our market opportunities, we believe that the economies of scale in our operating model will allow us to grow our personnel expenses at a lower rate than revenues.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P11_S0	Historically, our EBITDA margin has improved because we have been able to increase revenues without a proportionate corresponding increase in expenses.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P11_S1	However, part of our corporate strategy is to invest in new solutions, which may offset margin expansion.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P11_S2	Our cost of revenues consists primarily of personnel expenses.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P11_S3	Cost of revenues also includes the expenses associated with the acquisition and verification of data, the maintenance of our existing solutions and the development and enhancement of our next-generation solutions.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P11_S4	Our cost of revenues excludes depreciation and amortization.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P11_S5	Our selling, general and administrative expense also consists primarily of personnel costs.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P11_S6	A portion of the other operating costs such as facilities, insurance and communications are allocated to selling, general and administrative costs based on the nature of the work being performed by the employee.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P11_S7	Our selling, general and administrative expenses excludes depreciation and amortization.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P11_S8	We serve customers in three primary vertical markets: P C insurance, energy, and financial services.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P11_S9	The industry trends in each of those markets can affect our business.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P11_S10	A significant change in P C insurers profitability could affect the demand for our solutions.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P11_S11	For insurers, the keys to profitability include investment income and premium growth.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P12_S0	Investment income remains under pressure as a result of low interest rates.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P12_S1	Growth in P C insurers direct written premiums is cyclical, with total industry premium growth receding from a peak of 14.8% in 2002 to a trough of negative 3.1% in 2009 and subsequently recovering to 4.4% in 2012, 4.3% in 2013, 4.4% in 2014 and 3.7% in 2015.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P12_S2	Based on our experience, insurers more closely scrutinize their spending in periods of more challenging growth.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P12_S3	In recent years, we have signed multi-year contracts with certain customers, and pricing is fixed at the beginning of each multi-year period; pricing for other customers is still linked to prior years' premiums.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P13_S0	Trends in catastrophe and non-catastrophe weather losses can have an effect on our customers profitability, and therefore, their appetite for buying analytics to help them manage their risks.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P13_S1	Any increase or decrease in frequency or severity of weather events over time could lead to an increased or decreased demand for our catastrophe modeling, catastrophe loss information, and repair cost solutions.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P13_S2	Likewise, any structural changes in the reinsurance and related brokerage industry from the recent influx of alternative capital or newer technologies could affect demand for our products.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P13_S3	We also have a portion of our revenue related to the number of claims processed due to losses, which can be impacted by seasonal storm activity.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P13_S4	The need by our customers to fight insurance fraud - both in claims and at policy inception - could lead to increased demand for our underwriting and claims solutions.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P13_S5	Trends in the energy, chemicals, and metals and mining sectors and activity in financial markets can influence our revenues.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P13_S6	Movements of commodity prices affect the profitability of our customers, which include energy, chemicals, and metals and mining companies, while stock markets and mergers and acquisitions, or M A, are some of the principal drivers affecting our financial institution customers.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P13_S7	Among the trends influencing commodity prices are supply and demand factors, regulatory requirements, fiscal impacts, regional market structures, and geopolitical risks.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P14_S0	Following the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, or OPEC, meeting in November 2016, oil prices have begun to recover indicating an uplift across the energy sector.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P14_S1	After a prolonged slump in the metals and mining sector, there are emerging signs of optimism in the copper, aluminum and lithium markets among others.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P14_S2	M A activity is also beginning to improve with high profile asset sales from Shell, Total, and BP among others.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P14_S3	In addition, we have seen some large investments being made, notably the Glencore and Qatar deal with Rosneft, and the separate GE-Baker Hughes proposed transaction.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P14_S4	Furthermore, Wood Mackenzie expects final investment decisions in the oil and gas sector to significantly increase in 2017, albeit from recent lows.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P14_S5	However, volatility in commodity prices means uncertainty for our customers, which can impact their demand for our data and services.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P15_S0	Notwithstanding the unsettled view of the U.S. leadership towards the Paris global accord on climate change, over the longer term Wood Mackenzie expects a period of change in the energy mix.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P15_S1	The ongoing incentivizing of growth in renewable energy and other low carbon technologies around the world will help drive this, while fossil fuels are expected to remain a core part of energy demand for the foreseeable future.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P15_S2	We will continue to evolve our offerings to meet the needs of our customers in an increasingly complex market.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P15_S3	Market trends continue to influence our financial services vertical in important ways.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P15_S4	Most notable among the recent trends affecting the vertical includes a significant increase in the number of alternative lenders and alternative payment instruments in the market.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P15_S5	We are adapting our offerings to address the needs of alternative lenders, backed by our deep expertise and datasets covering the performance of customers across a full range of credit histories.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P15_S6	As well, our unique ability to analyze the customer adoption rates of new alternative payment instruments from our syndicated study datasets is enabling us to serve as the go to solution for the industry s analytic needs in the space.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P16_S0	downward pressure on our revenues from such customers.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P16_S1	However, we are also observing a growing appetite for our expense-focused solutions and regulatory-focused solutions among those customers.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P16_S2	Lastly, we are seeing a greater number of companies entering the media effectiveness space, which encourages potential competitors to challenge our position in this space.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P16_S3	We stand confident of our position at this stage, given the unique nature and strength of our partnerships coupled by the comprehensiveness of our data, particularly as it relates to seeing the full wallet spend of a consumer.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P17_S0	Description of Acquisitions We acquired twelve businesses since January 1, 2014.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P17_S1	These acquisitions affect the comparability of our consolidated results of operations between periods.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P17_S2	On November 23, 2016, we acquired the net assets of IntelliStance, LLC, or MarketStance, a provider of market intelligence data and analytics to the property/casualty insurance market.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P17_S3	MarketStance has become part of ISO within the Risk Assessment segment.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P18_S0	MarketStance has built a proprietary analytics model to provide actionable insights on customer's profitability and that enhances our offerings.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P18_S1	See Note 9 to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K for further discussions.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P19_S0	On November 11, 2016, we acquired 100 percent of the stock of The GeoInformation Group Limited, or GeoInformation, a provider of geographic data solutions.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P19_S1	GeoInformation offers mapping services and geospatial data and analytic solutions to companies and public sector organizations.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P19_S2	GeoInformation's resources complement the risk management and predictive analytics capabilities internationally within the Risk Assessment segment.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P19_S3	See Note 9 to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K for further discussions.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P20_S0	On October 20, 2016, we acquired 100 percent of the stock of Analyze Re, Inc., or Analyze Re, a software analytics provider for the reinsurance and insurance industries.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P20_S1	Re has become part of our insurance vertical within the Decision Analytics segment and enables us to provide our customers with additional real-time pricing, exposure management, and enterprise portfolio roll-up capabilities.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P20_S2	See Note 9 to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K for further discussions.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P21_S0	On August 19, 2016, we acquired the net assets of data and subscriptions business of Quest Offshore Resources, Inc, or Quest Offshore, which supplies market intelligence to the offshore oil and gas sector.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P21_S1	The data and subscriptions business has become part of Wood Mackenzie within the Decision Analytics segment and complements its existing upstream analysis expertise.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P21_S2	See Note 9 to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K for further discussions.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P22_S0	On July 26, 2016,we acquired 100 percent of the stock of Greentech Media, Inc., or Greentech Media, an information services provider for the electricity and renewables sector.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P22_S1	Greentech Media has become part of Wood Mackenzie within the Decision Analytics segment and enables Wood Mackenzie to provide its customers with market intelligence across several categories, including solar generation, energy storage, and smart grids that react to changes in supply and demand.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P23_S0	See Note 9 to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K for further discussions.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P24_S0	On April 14, 2016, we acquired 100 percent of the stock of Risk Intelligence Ireland Limited, or RII, a provider of fraud detection, compliance, risk control, and process automation services to the Irish insurance industry.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P24_S1	RII enhances the ability of the Company's Risk Assessment segment to serve the international insurance market.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P24_S2	See Note 9 to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K for further discussions.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P25_S0	On November 20, 2015, we acquired 100 percent of the stock of The PCI Group, or PCI.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P25_S1	PCI is a consortium of five specialist companies that offer integrated data and subscriptions research in the chemicals, fibers, films, and plastics sectors.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P25_S2	PCI has become part of Wood Mackenzie, and continues to provide services to enhance Wood Mackenzie's chemicals capabilities in the Decision Analytics segment.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P26_S0	See Note 9 to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K for the final purchase price allocations.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P27_S0	On November 6, 2015, we acquired 100 percent of the stock of Infield Systems Limited, or Infield.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P27_S1	Infield is a provider of business intelligence, analysis, and research to the oil, gas, and associated marine industries.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P27_S2	Infield has become part of Wood Mackenzie and continues to provide services to enhance Wood Mackenzie's upstream and supply chain capabilities in the Decision Analytics segment.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P28_S0	See Note 9 to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K for the final purchase price allocations.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P29_S0	On May 19, 2015, we acquired 100 percent of the stock of Wood Mackenzie.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P30_S0	Wood Mackenzie is a global provider of data analytics and commercial intelligence for the energy, chemicals, metals and mining verticals.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P30_S1	This acquisition advances our strategy to expand internationally and positions ourselves in the global energy market.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P31_S0	Wood Mackenzie is included in the energy and specialized markets vertical, formerly named the specialized markets vertical, of the Decision Analytics segment.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P31_S1	See Note 9 to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K for the final purchase price allocations.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P31_S2	On December 8, 2014, we acquired 100 percent of the stock of Maplecroft.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P32_S0	Using a proprietary data aggregation and analytical approach, Maplecroft enables its customers to assess, monitor, and forecast a growing range of worldwide risks, including geopolitical and societal risks.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P32_S1	Within our Decision Analytics segment, this acquisition positions us as a provider of value chain optimization tools, providing comprehensive quantitative risk analytics and platforms by which customers can visualize, quantify, mitigate, and manage their risk.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P33_S0	Maplecroft is headquartered in Bath, England.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P33_S1	See Note 9 to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K for further discussions.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P34_S0	On October 31, 2014, we acquired the net assets of Dart Consulting Limited, or Dart.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P34_S1	Dart is a provider of benchmarking and advisory solutions to financial services institutions in Australia, New Zealand, and other key Asia-Pacific markets.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P34_S2	As part of our Decision Analytics segment, Dart provides benchmarking solutions and professional services critical to financial services institutions in the management of lending and payment portfolios.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P35_S0	On January 29, 2014, we acquired the net assets of Inovatus, LLC, or Inovatus.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P35_S1	The assets primarily consisted of software and are embedded in our existing models focusing on reducing fraud and premium leakage for personal auto insurance carriers.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P35_S2	The technology is included in our Decision Analytics segment as part of its solutions to leverage data and analytics to help insurance companies improve results.

1442145_17_ITEM7_P36_S2	Results of operations for the healthcare and mortgage services businesses are reported as discontinued operations for the year ended December 31, 2016 and for all prior periods presented.

Year Ended December 31, 2016 Compared to Year Ended December 31, 2015 Consolidated Results of Continuing Operations Revenues Revenues were $1,995.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 compared to $1,760.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , an increase of $234.5 million or 13.3%.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P36_S4	Excluding revenues of $151.0 million from Wood Mackenzie (for the first and second quarters), Infield, PCI, RII, Greentech Media, Quest Offshore, Analyze Re, GeoInformation, and MarketStance, collectively referred to as our recent acquisitions, our revenue growth was $83.5 million or 4.9% .
1442145_17_ITEM7_P36_S5	Revenues within our Decision Analytics segment, excluding our recent acquisitions of Wood Mackenzie (for the first and second quarters), Infield, PCI, Greentech Media, Quest Offshore and Analyze Re, increased by $49.3 million or 4.8%.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P36_S6	Revenue growth within Decision Analytics was primarily driven by our financial services and insurance categories.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P36_S7	Revenues in our Risk Assessment segment, excluding our recent acquisitions of RII, GeoInformation and MarketStance, increased by $34.2 million or 5.0%.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P36_S8	Both categories, industry-standard insurance programs and property-specific rating and underwriting information, within Risk Assessment contributed to its revenue growth.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P36_S9	Refer to the Results of Continuing Operations by Segment within this section for further information regarding our revenues.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P36_S10	Cost of Revenues Cost of revenues was $714.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 compared to $612.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , an increase of $102.4 million or 16.7% .
1442145_17_ITEM7_P36_S11	Our recent acquisitions accounted for an increase of $56.1 million in cost of revenues, primarily related to salaries and employee benefits.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P36_S12	Excluding the impact of our recent acquisitions, our cost of revenues increased $46.3 million or 7.8%.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P36_S13	The increase was primarily due to increases in salaries and employee benefits cost of $27.2 million and an ESOP charge of $14.5 million .
1442145_17_ITEM7_P36_S14	Other increases include information technology expense of $5.3 million and data costs and data processing fees of $0.9 million.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P36_S15	These increases were offset by a decrease in other operating costs of $1.6 million.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P37_S0	Selling, General and Administrative Expenses Selling, general and administrative expenses, or SGA, were $301.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 compared to $278.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , an increase of $23.3 million or 8.3% .

1442145_17_ITEM7_P37_S3	The increase was primarily due to increases in salaries and employee benefits of $5.6 million, an ESOP charge of $4.3 million , and professional consulting fees of $3.0 million.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P37_S4	These increases were offset by a decrease in information technology expense of $0.9 million and other general and administrative of $0.9 million.

1442145_17_ITEM7_P37_S6	The increase in depreciation and amortization of fixed assets includes depreciation and amortization related to our recent acquisitions of $11.3 million.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P37_S7	The remaining increase primarily relates to hardware and software development costs placed into production to support data capacity expansion and revenue growth.

1442145_17_ITEM7_P37_S9	The increase in amortization of intangible assets was primarily related to our recent acquisitions of $20.1 million.

1442145_17_ITEM7_P37_S11	The decrease was primarily related to a gain of $15.6 million in connection with the exercise and payout of common stock warrants for the year ended December 31, 2015 .
1442145_17_ITEM7_P37_S12	This decrease was partially offset by increases attributable to interest income of $6.5 million generated from the subordinated promissory note related to the divestiture of our healthcare business.

1442145_17_ITEM7_P37_S14	Interest Expense Interest expense was $120.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 compared to $121.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , a decrease of $1.4 million or 1.1%.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P37_S15	The decrease is primarily due to the net payments of our credit facility of $770.0 million mostly funded by the net proceeds from the divestiture of our healthcare business.

1442145_17_ITEM7_P38_S3	Our net income margin for the year ended December 31, 2016 was positively impacted by the discontinued operations, including the gain on sale of our healthcare business of 5.5% and lowered by an ESOP charge of 0.6%.

1442145_17_ITEM7_P47_S3	The non-recurring derivative gain offset by the transaction costs related to the Wood Mackenzie acquisition and the warrant exercise and payout positively impacted our net income margin by 3.2%, which was offset by the impact from the discontinued operations of 3.2% for year ended December 31, 2015 .
1442145_17_ITEM7_P47_S4	The discontinued operations, including the gain on the sale of our mortgage services business decreased our margin by 1.9% for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1442145_17_ITEM7_P48_S0	The EBITDA margin for our consolidated results, including discontinued operations, was 51.0% for the year ended December 31, 2015 compared to 48.8% for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1442145_17_ITEM7_P48_S1	The non-recurring derivative gain, offset by the transaction costs related to the Wood Mackenzie acquisition and the warrant exercise and payout, positively impacted our EBITDA margin by 3.6%, which was offset by the impact from the discontinued operations of 4.2% for year ended December 31, 2015 .
1442145_17_ITEM7_P48_S2	The discontinued operations, including the gain on the sale of our mortgage services business, decreased our margin by 2.1% for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1442145_17_ITEM7_P48_S3	Results of Continuing Operations by Segment Decision Analytics Revenues Revenues for our Decision Analytics segment were $1,072.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 compared to $780.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , an increase of $292.0 million or 37.4%.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P48_S4	Our recent acquisitions accounted for an increase of $219.6 million in revenues for the year ended December 31, 2015 .
1442145_17_ITEM7_P48_S5	Excluding recent acquisitions, our Decision Analytics revenue increased $72.4 million or 9.3%.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P48_S6	Our revenue by category for the periods presented is set forth below for the years ended December 31:
1442145_17_ITEM7_P49_S0	Our insurance revenue increased $48.4 million or 8.1% primarily due to an increase within our loss quantification solutions, insurance anti-fraud claims revenue, underwriting solutions, and catastrophe modeling services.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P50_S0	Our energy and specialized markets revenue increased $223.9 million or 263.6%, primarily due to the recent acquisitions.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P50_S1	Excluding the recent acquisitions' revenue of $219.6 million, our specialized markets revenue increased $4.3 million or 5.1%, primarily due to growth in our environmental health and safety services and weather risk solutions, and was partially offset by lower activity related to government contracts.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P51_S0	Our financial services revenue increased $19.7 million or 20.5%, primarily due to a media effectiveness project revenue that occurred in the first quarter and the continued demand for our analytic solutions and services.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P52_S0	Cost of revenues for our Decision Analytics segment was $412.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 compared to $307.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , an increase of $104.2 million or 33.8%.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P52_S1	Our recent acquisitions within the Decision Analytics segment, accounted for an increase of $82.4 million in cost of revenues of which $6.0 million were non-recurring equity compensation associated with the Wood Mackenzie acquisition and the remaining amount was primarily related to salaries and employee benefits.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P52_S2	Excluding the impact of our recent acquisitions, our cost of revenues increased by $21.8 million or 7.1%.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P52_S3	This increase is primarily due to increases in salary and employee benefits of $14.7 million, rent expense of $2.4 million, data costs and data processing fees of $1.4 million, travel expense of $1.1 million, and other operating costs of $2.3 million.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P52_S4	These increases were offset by a decrease in information technology expense of $0.1 million.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P52_S5	Selling, General and Administrative Expenses Selling, general and administrative expenses for our Decision Analytics segment were $196.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 compared to $113.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , an increase of $83.0 million or 73.3%.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P52_S6	Our recent acquisitions within the Decision Analytics segment accounted for an increase of $83.7 million in SGA of which $20.7 million were non-recurring transaction costs associated with the Wood Mackenzie acquisition and the remaining amount was primarily related to salaries and employee benefits.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P52_S7	Excluding costs associated with our recent acquisitions, SGA decreased $0.7 million or 0.5%.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P52_S8	The decrease was primarily due to a decrease in professional fees of $3.2 million.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P52_S9	This decrease was offset by increases in salary and employee benefits of $1.1 million, information technology expense of $0.6 million, travel expense of $0.4 million, rent expense of $0.2 million, and other general expenses of $0.2 million.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P53_S0	The EBITDA margin for our Decision Analytics segment including our discontinued operations, was 46.9% for the year ended December 31, 2015 and 44.2% for the year ended December 31, 2014.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P53_S1	The non-recurring derivative gain, net of transaction costs related to the Wood Mackenzie acquisition and the warrant exercise and payout, positively impacted our EBITDA margin by 5.4%, which was offset by the impact from the discontinued operations of 5.9% for year ended December 31, 2015.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P53_S2	The discontinued operations, including the gain on sale of the mortgage services business, decreased our margin by 1.8% for the year ended December 31, 2014.

1442145_17_ITEM7_P54_S1	The overall increase within this segment primarily resulted from an increase in prices derived from continued enhancements to the content of our industry-standard insurance programs solutions as well as selling expanded solutions to existing customers.

1442145_17_ITEM7_P56_S1	The decrease was primarily due to a decrease in salaries and employee benefits costs of $8.8 million related to a slight reduction in headcount that occurred in the fourth quarter of 2014.

1442145_17_ITEM7_P56_S3	These decreases were offset by increases in data costs and data processing fees of $1.0 million and travel expenses of $0.9 million.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P57_S0	Selling, general and administrative expenses for our Risk Assessment segment were $81.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 compared to $73.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , an increase of $8.0 million or 10.8% .
1442145_17_ITEM7_P57_S1	The increase was primarily due to increases in salaries and employee benefits of $6.6 million, rent expense of $0.9 million, information technology expense of $0.5 million, travel expense of $0.3 million and other general expenses of $0.1 million.

1442145_17_ITEM7_P58_S1	The increase in margin is primarily attributed to operating leverage in the segment as well as cost efficiencies.

1442145_17_ITEM7_P61_S0	Liquidity and Capital Resources As of December 31, 2016 and 2015 , we had cash and cash equivalents and available-for-sale securities of $138.5 million and $141.9 million, respectively.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P62_S0	Subscriptions for our solutions are billed and generally paid in advance of rendering services either quarterly or in full upon commencement of the subscription period, which is usually for one year.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P62_S1	Subscriptions are automatically renewed at the beginning of each calendar year.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P63_S0	We have historically generated significant cash flows from operations.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P63_S1	As a result of this factor, as well as the availability of funds under our syndicated revolving credit facility, we believe we will have sufficient cash to meet our working capital and capital expenditure needs, and to fuel our future growth plans.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P64_S0	We have historically managed the business with a working capital deficit due to the fact that, as described above, we offer our solutions and services primarily through annual subscriptions or long-term contracts, which are generally prepaid quarterly or annually in advance of the services being rendered.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P65_S0	When cash is received for prepayment of invoices, we record an asset (cash and cash equivalents) on our balance sheet with the offset recorded as a current liability (deferred revenues).
1442145_17_ITEM7_P65_S1	This current liability is deferred revenue that does not require a direct cash outflow since our customers have prepaid and are obligated to purchase the services.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P66_S0	In most businesses, growth in revenue typically leads to an increase in the accounts receivable balance causing a use of cash as a company grows.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P66_S1	Unlike these businesses, our cash position is favorably affected by revenue growth, which results in a source of cash due to our customers prepaying for most of our services.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P66_S2	Our consolidated capital expenditures as a percentage of consolidated revenues for the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015 , were 7.4% and 8.0%, respectively.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P66_S3	We estimate our capital expenditures for 2017 will be approximately $160.0 million, which primarily consists of expenditures on our technology infrastructure and our continuing investments in developing and enhancing our solutions.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P66_S4	Expenditures related to developing and enhancing our solutions are predominately related to internal-use software and are capitalized in accordance with ASC 350-40, Accounting for Costs of Computer Software Developed or Obtained for Internal Use.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P66_S5	We also capitalize amounts in accordance with ASC 985-20, Software to be Sold, Leased or Otherwise Marketed .
1442145_17_ITEM7_P66_S6	We have also historically used a portion of our cash for repurchases of our common stock from our stockholders.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P66_S7	For the years ended December 31, 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , we repurchased $326.8 million, $20.4 million and $778.5 million, respectively, of our common stock.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P66_S8	Financing and Financing Capacity We had total debt, excluding capital lease obligations, the discounts and debt issuance costs on our senior notes and our committed senior unsecured Syndicated Revolving Credit Facility, or the Credit Facility, of $2,400.0 million and $3,170.0 million at December 31, 2016 and 2015 , respectively.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P66_S9	The debt at December 31, 2016 primarily consists of senior notes issued in 2015, 2012 and 2011 and borrowings outstanding under the Credit Facility described below.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P66_S10	Interest on the senior notes is payable semi-annually each year.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P66_S11	The discount and debt issuance costs were recorded as "Long-term debt" in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets, and will be amortized to "Interest expense" in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations within this Form 10-K over the life of the respective senior note.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P67_S0	The indenture governing the senior notes restricts our ability to, among other things, create certain liens, enter into sale/leaseback transactions and consolidate with, sell, lease, convey, or otherwise transfer all or substantially all of our assets, or merge with or into, any other person or entity.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P67_S1	As of December 31, 2016 , we had senior notes with an aggregate principal amount of $2,300.0 million outstanding, and we were in compliance with our debt covenants.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P67_S2	We have a credit facility with Bank of America N.A., JP Morgan Chase, N.A., Sun Trust Bank, Wells Fargo Bank, N.A., Citizens Bank, N.A., Morgan Stanley, N.A., HSBC Bank USA, N.A., Royal Bank of Canada, BNP Paribas, TD Bank, N.A., The Northern Trust Company, and Capital One N.A.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P67_S3	On May 26, 2016, we entered into the Second Amendment to the Credit Facility, which reduced the borrowing capacity from $1,750.00 million to $1,500.0 million and amended the pricing grid.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P68_S0	The Credit Facility may be used for general corporate purposes, including working capital needs and capital expenditures, acquisitions and the share repurchase program, or the Repurchase Program.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P69_S0	The Credit Facility contains certain financial and other covenants that, among other things, impose certain restrictions on indebtedness, liens, investments, and capital expenditures.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P69_S1	These covenants also place restrictions on mergers, asset sales, sale/leaseback transactions, payments between us and our subsidiaries, and certain transactions with affiliates.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P69_S2	The financial covenants require that, at the end of any fiscal quarter, we have a consolidated interest coverage ratio of at least 3.0 to 1.0 and that we maintain, during any period of four fiscal quarters, a consolidated funded debt leverage ratio of 3.5 to 1.0.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P69_S3	We were in compliance with all covenants under the Credit Facility as of December 31, 2016 .
1442145_17_ITEM7_P70_S0	Interest on borrowings under the Credit Facility is payable at an interest rate of LIBOR plus 1.125% to 1.625% , depending upon the consolidated funded debt leverage ratio.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P70_S1	During the year ended December 31, 2016, we had borrowings of $140.0 million and repayments of $910.0 million under the credit facility.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P70_S2	As of December 31, 2016 and 2015 , we had outstanding borrowings under the Credit Facility of $100.0 million and $870.0 million , respectively.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P70_S3	In January and February 2017, we repaid a total of $70.0 million of the $100.0 million outstanding borrowings at December 31, 2016 under the Credit Facility.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P71_S0	On March 10, 2015, in connection with our agreement to acquire Wood Mackenzie, we entered into a commitment letter for a $2,300.0 million 364 -day bridge financing arrangement with Bank of America N.A. and Morgan Stanley Bank N.A. acting as joint lead arrangers.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P71_S1	This financing arrangement was only to be utilized in the event we did not complete the debt and equity offerings relating to its acquisition of Wood Mackenzie by a certain date, and was terminated upon the closing of the acquisition.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P71_S2	See Note 9 to our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K. We paid fees associated with this financing arrangement of $ 9.1 million .
1442145_17_ITEM7_P71_S3	Due to the completion of the debt and equity offerings, this arrangement was terminated and the full $ 9.1 million of fees were recorded to "Interest expense" for the year ended December 31, 2015.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P71_S4	The following table summarizes our cash flow data for the years ended December 31:
1442145_17_ITEM7_P72_S0	Operating Activities Net cash provided by operating activities decreased to $546.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 compared to $623.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 .
1442145_17_ITEM7_P72_S1	The decrease of $77.6 million in net cash provided by operating activities was primarily due to the additional income tax payments of $99.9 million related to the gain on the sale of our healthcare business and a one time cash funding of our ESOP plan of $18.8 million, partially offset by an increase in cash receipts from customers driven by an increase in revenues and operating profit as well as additional operating cash flow from the acquisition of Wood Mackenzie in May 2015.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P73_S0	Net cash provided by operating activities increased to $623.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 compared to $489.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2014.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P73_S1	The increase in net cash provided by operating activities was primarily due to an increase in cash receipts from customers driven by an increase in revenues and operating profit and additional operating cash flow from Wood Mackenzie, partially offset by acquisition fees related to the acquisition of Wood Mackenzie and interest payments on our senior notes that were issued in May 2015.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P73_S2	Investing Activities Net cash provided by investing activities of $ 493.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 was primarily related to proceeds from the sale our healthcare business of $714.6 million , partially offset by capital expenditures of $156.5 million and acquisitions including escrow payments of $74.1 million.

1442145_17_ITEM7_P74_S0	Net cash used in investing activities of $35.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 was primarily related to capital expenditures of $146.8 million and acquisitions of $35.2 million, partially offset by proceeds from the sale our mortgage business of $151.2 million.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P74_S1	Financing Activities Net cash used in financing activities of $1,032.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 was primarily related to a $770.0 million repayments of borrowings under our Credit Facilities and share repurchases of $326.8 million, partially offset by proceeds from stock option exercises and other option-related items of $69.4 million.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P74_S2	Net cash provided by financing activities of $2,481.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 was primarily related to the net proceeds from the debt and equity offerings of $1,244.0 million and $720.8 million, respectively, and other borrowings from our old and new credit facilities of 830.0 million and proceeds from stock option exercises and other option-related items of $76.5 million, partially offset by repayments of short-term and long-term debt of $340.0 million, and repurchases of common stock $20.4 million.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P74_S3	Net cash used in financing activities of $579.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 was primarily related to the repurchase of common stock of $778.5 million, partially offset by proceeds from stock option exercises and other stock option related items of $45.6 million and borrowing from our old credit facility of $160.0 million.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P74_S4	The following table summarizes our contractual obligations at December 31, 2016 and the future periods in which such obligations are expected to be settled in cash:
1442145_17_ITEM7_P75_S0	(1) Our funding policy is to contribute at least equal to the minimum legal funding requirement.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P75_S1	(2) Other long-term liabilities consist of our employee-related deferred compensation plan.

1442145_17_ITEM7_P75_S3	(3) Unrecognized tax benefits of approximately $16.8 million have been recorded as liabilities in accordance with ASC 740, which have been omitted from the table above, and we are uncertain as to if or when such amounts may be settled, with the exception of those amounts subject to a statute of limitation.
1442145_17_ITEM7_P75_S4	Related to the unrecognized tax benefits, we also have recorded a liability for potential penalties and interest of $3.4 million.
