1442145_18_ITEM8_P159_S0	Income Taxes: Domestic and foreign income from continuing operations before income taxes was as follows:
1442145_18_ITEM8_P160_S0	The components of the provision for income taxes from continuing operations for the years ended December 31 were as follows:
1442145_18_ITEM8_P161_S0	On December 22, 2017, President Trump signed comprehensive tax legislation commonly referred to as the Tax Cuts and Job Act ("Tax Act").
1442145_18_ITEM8_P161_S1	The Tax Act makes complex changes to the tax law which will impact the 2017 year, including but not limited to 1) a re-measurement of deferred tax assets and liabilities as a result of the corporate tax rate change from 35.0% to 21.0% , 2) 100% bonus depreciation on qualifying property placed in service after September 27, 2017, and 3) requiring a one-time repatriation tax on foreign earnings.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P162_S0	Based on the initial analysis of the Tax Act, the Company has made reasonable estimates of its 2017 impact and has recorded provisional adjustments as follows: 1) Due to the federal corporate rate reduction, a re-measurement of deferred tax assets and liabilities resulted in the recording of a benefit of approximately $89.1 million .
1442145_18_ITEM8_P162_S1	2) 100% bonus depreciation on qualifying assets resulted in an estimated decrease to the current income tax payable of approximately $8.0 million .
1442145_18_ITEM8_P162_S2	3) The Company is not expected to be impacted by the one-time repatriation tax on foreign earnings.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P162_S3	The Tax Act will also affect 2018 and forward, including but not limited to 1) a reduction in the federal corporate rate from 35.0% to 21.0% , 2) elimination of the corporate alternative minimum tax, 3) creation of a new minimum tax - the base erosion anti-abuse tax ("BEAT"), 4) a general elimination of U.S. federal income taxes on dividends from foreign subsidiaries, 5) a new provision designed to tax global intangible low-taxed income ("GILTI"), 6) a new limitation on deductible interest expense, 7) the repeal of Section 199 domestic production activity deduction, 8) a new limitation on the deductibility of certain executive compensation, 9) limitations on net operating losses ("NOL s") generated after December 31, 2017, 10) a special deduction for Foreign Derived Intangible Income ("FDII") and various other items.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P162_S4	The Company has evaluated the above provisions and other than the reduction in corporate tax rate, it does not believe that the new provisions will have a material impact on the provision for income taxes.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P163_S0	The reconciliation between the Company s effective tax rate on income from continuing operations and the statutory tax rate is as follows for the years ended December 31:
1442145_18_ITEM8_P164_S0	The decrease in the effective tax rate in 2017 compared to 2016 was primarily due to lowered federal income tax rates as a result of U.S. Tax Reform and the adoption of ASU No. 2016-09, partially offset by legislation enacted in the U.K.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P164_S1	The tax effects of significant items comprising the Company s deferred tax assets as of December 31 are as follows:
1442145_18_ITEM8_P165_S0	The net deferred income liability of $321.9 million consists primarily of timing differences involving depreciation and amortization.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P166_S0	The ultimate realization of the deferred tax assets depends on the Company s ability to generate sufficient taxable income in the future.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P166_S1	The Company has provided a valuation allowance against the deferred tax assets associated with the interest expense deduction limitation in the U.K.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P166_S2	The Company has also provided for a valuation allowance against the deferred tax assets associated with the net operating losses of certain subsidiaries.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P166_S3	The Company s net operating loss carryforwards expire as follows:
1442145_18_ITEM8_P167_S0	A valuation allowance has been established based on the Company s evaluation of the likelihood of utilizing these benefits before they expire.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P168_S0	to fully realize the deferred tax assets is uncertain.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P168_S1	Other than these items, the Company has determined, based on the Company s historical operating performance, that taxable income of the Company will more likely than not be sufficient to fully realize the deferred tax assets.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P169_S0	As of December 31, 2017, the Company has not made a provision for U.S. or additional foreign withholdings taxes for any additional outside basis difference inherent in its foreign subsidiaries, as these amounts continue to be indefinitely reinvested in foreign operations.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P169_S1	Determining the amount of unrecognized deferred tax liability related to any additional outside basis difference in these entities is not practicable.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P169_S2	The Company does not rely on these unremitted earnings as a source of funds for its domestic business as it expects to have sufficient cash flow in the U.S. to fund its U.S. operational and strategic needs.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P170_S0	The Company follows ASC No. 740-10, which prescribes a comprehensive model for the financial statement recognition, measurement, presentation and disclosure of uncertain tax positions taken or expected to be taken in income tax returns.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P170_S1	For each tax position, the Company must determine whether it is more likely than not that the position will be sustained upon examination based on the technical merits of the position, including resolution of any related appeals or litigation.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P170_S2	A tax position that meets the more likely than not recognition threshold is then measured to determine the amount of benefit to recognize within the financial statements.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P170_S3	No benefits may be recognized for tax positions that do not meet the more likely than not threshold.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P170_S4	A reconciliation of the beginning and ending amount of unrecognized tax benefit is as follows:
1442145_18_ITEM8_P171_S0	Of the total unrecognized tax benefits as of December 31, 2017 , 2016 and 2015 , $13.2 million , $13.8 million and $11.4 million , respectively, represent the amounts that, if recognized, would have a favorable effect on the Company s effective tax rate in any future periods.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P171_S1	The total gross amount of accrued interest and penalties for the years ended December 31, 2017 , 2016 and 2015 was $4.5 million , $3.4 million and $2.8 million , respectively.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P171_S2	The Company s practice is to recognize interest and penalties associated with income taxes as a component of Provision for income taxes in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P171_S3	The Company does not expect a significant increase in unrecognized benefits related to federal, foreign, or state tax exposures within the coming year.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P171_S4	In addition, the Company believes that it is reasonably possible that approximately $0.5 million of its currently remaining unrecognized tax positions, each of which is individually insignificant, may be recognized by the end of 2018 as a result of a combination of audit settlements and lapses of statute of limitations, net of additional uncertain tax positions.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P172_S0	The Company is subject to tax in the U.S. and in various state and foreign jurisdictions.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P172_S1	The Company joined by its domestic subsidiaries, files a consolidated income tax return for the Federal income tax purposes.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P172_S2	With few exceptions, none of which are material to the Company s consolidated financial statements as of December 31, 2017 , the Company is no longer subject to U.S. federal, state, and local or non-US income tax examinations by tax authorities for tax years before 2013.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P172_S3	The Internal Revenue Service is conducting an audit of Wood Mackenzie, Inc. for the period January 1, 2014 through May 19, 2015, as well as Verisk Analytics, Inc. Subsidiaries for tax year ended December 31, 2014.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P172_S4	In New Jersey, the Company is being audited for the years ended December 31, 2011 through 2014 with a statute extension until March 31, 2018.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P172_S5	The Company is also under audit in Illinois for the year ended December 31, 2014.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P172_S6	The Company does not expect that the results of these examinations will have a material effect on its financial position, results of operations or cash flow.

1442145_18_ITEM8_P177_S0	Senior Notes As of December 31, 2017 and 2016 , the Company had senior notes with an aggregate principal amount of $2,300.0 million outstanding.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P177_S1	Interest on senior notes is payable semiannually.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P177_S2	The discount and debt issuance costs were recorded in "Long-term debt" in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets and these costs will be amortized to "Interest expense" in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations over the life of the respective senior note.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P178_S0	The indenture governing senior notes restricts the Company's ability to, among other things, create certain liens, enter into sale/leaseback transactions and consolidate with, sell, lease, convey or otherwise transfer all or substantially all of the Company's assets, or merge with or into, any other person or entity.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P178_S1	As of December 31, 2017 and 2016 , the Company was in compliance with the financial debt covenants governing the senior notes.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P179_S0	The Company has a committed senior unsecured Syndicated Revolving Credit Facility (the "Credit Facility") with Bank of America N.A., JP Morgan Chase, N.A., Sun Trust Bank, Wells Fargo Bank N.A., Citizens Bank, N.A., Morgan Stanley, N.A., HSBC Bank USA, N.A., Royal Bank of Canada, BNP Paribas, TD Bank, N.A., The Northern Trust Company, and Capital One N.A.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P179_S1	On May 18, 2017, the Company entered into the third amendment to the Credit Facility, which, among other things, extended the maturity date one year to May 15, 2022.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P180_S0	The Credit Facility may be used for general corporate purposes, including working capital needs and capital expenditures, acquisitions and the share repurchase program (the "Repurchase Program").
1442145_18_ITEM8_P181_S0	The Credit Facility contains certain financial and other covenants that, among other things, impose certain restrictions on indebtedness, liens, investments, and capital expenditures.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P181_S1	These covenants also place restrictions on mergers, asset sales, sale/leaseback transactions, payments between the Company and its subsidiaries, and certain transactions with affiliates.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P181_S2	The financial covenants require that, at the end of any fiscal quarter, the Company has a consolidated interest coverage ratio of at least 3.0 to 1.0 and that it maintains, during any period of four fiscal quarters, a consolidated funded debt leverage ratio of less than 3.5 to 1.0.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P181_S3	The Company was in compliance with all financial covenants under the Credit Facility as of December 31, 2017 .
1442145_18_ITEM8_P181_S4	Interest on borrowings under the Credit Facility is payable at an interest rate of LIBOR plus 1.125% to 1.625% , depending upon the consolidated funded debt leverage ratio.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P181_S5	A commitment fee on any unused balance is payable periodically and may range from 12.50 to 25.00 basis points based upon the consolidated funded debt leverage ratio.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P181_S6	As of December 31, 2017 and 2016 , the Company had outstanding borrowings under the Credit Facility of $715.0 million and $100.0 million , respectively.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P181_S7	Private Placements As of December 31, 2015, the Company had no outstanding private placement debt.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P181_S8	The Company prepaid this debt and the contractual costs for the prepayment was $4.8 million , which was recorded to "Interest expense" in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations for the year ended December 31, 2015.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P182_S0	Bridge Financing On March 10, 2015, in connection with the Company's acquisition of Wood Mackenzie, the Company entered into a commitment letter for a $2,300.0 million 364 -day bridge financing arrangement with Bank of America N.A. and Morgan Stanley Bank N.A. acting as joint lead arrangers.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P182_S1	This financing arrangement was terminated upon the closing of the acquisition.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P182_S2	The Company paid fees associated with this financing arrangement of $9.1 million .
1442145_18_ITEM8_P182_S3	Due to the completion of the debt and equity offerings, this arrangement was terminated and the full $9.1 million of fees were recorded to "Interest expense" in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations for the year ended December 31, 2015.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P182_S4	The Company was in compliance with all financial covenants at December 31, 2017 and 2016 .

1442145_18_ITEM8_P184_S3	The preferred shares have preferential rights over the common shares with respect to dividends and net distribution upon liquidation.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P184_S4	The Company did not issue any preferred shares as of December 31, 2017 .
1442145_18_ITEM8_P185_S0	Share Repurchase Program Since May 2010, the Company has authorized repurchases of up to $2,800.0 million of its common stock through its Repurchase Program.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P185_S1	Since the introduction of share repurchase as a feature of the Company's capital management strategies in 2010, the Company has repurchased shares with an aggregate value of $2,433.8 million .
1442145_18_ITEM8_P185_S2	As of December 31, 2017 , the Company had $366.2 million available to repurchase shares.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P185_S3	The Company has no obligation to repurchase stock under this program and intends to use this authorization as a means of offsetting dilution from the issuance of shares under the ISO 401(k) Savings and Employee Stock Ownership Plan ("KSOP"), the Verisk 2013 Equity Incentive Plan (the "2013 Incentive Plan"), the Verisk 2009 Equity Incentive Plan (the 2009 Incentive Plan ), and the ISO 1996 Incentive Plan (the 1996 Incentive Plan ), while providing flexibility to repurchase additional shares if warranted.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P185_S4	This authorization has no expiration date and may be increased, reduced, suspended, or terminated at any time.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P185_S5	Shares that are repurchased under the Repurchase Program will be recorded as treasury stock and will be available for future issuance.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P185_S6	During the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2016 , the Company repurchased 3,356,360 and 4,325,548 shares of common stock as part of the Repurchase Program at a weighted average price of $80.39 and $77.06 per share, respectively.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P185_S7	The Company utilized cash from operations and borrowings from its Credit Facility to fund these repurchases.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P185_S8	As of December 31, 2017 , the Company s treasury stock consisted of 379,124,108 shares of common stock.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P185_S9	During the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2016 , the Company reissued 1,319,518 and 1,816,339 shares of common stock, under the 2013 Incentive Plan, 2009 Incentive Plan and the 1996 Incentive Plan, from the treasury shares at a weighted average price of $8.13 and $7.23 per share, respectively.

1442145_18_ITEM8_P191_S0	Compensation Plans: KSOP The Company has established the KSOP for the benefit of eligible employees in the U.S. and Puerto Rico.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P191_S1	The KSOP includes both an employee savings component and an employee stock ownership component.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P191_S2	The purpose of the combined plan is to enable the Company s employees to participate in a tax-deferred savings arrangement under Internal Revenue Service Code Sections 401(a) and 401(k) (the Code ), and to provide employee equity participation in the Company through the employee stock ownership plan ( ESOP ) accounts.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P191_S3	Under the KSOP, eligible employees may make pre-tax and after-tax cash contributions as a percentage of their compensation, subject to certain limitations under the applicable provisions of the Code.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P191_S4	The maximum pre-tax contribution that can be made to the 401(k) account as determined under the provisions of Code Section 401(g) is eighteen thousand dollars for 2017 , 2016 and 2015 .
1442145_18_ITEM8_P191_S5	Certain eligible participants (age 50 and older) may contribute an additional six thousand dollars on a pre-tax basis for 2017 , 2016 and 2015 .
1442145_18_ITEM8_P191_S6	After-tax contributions are limited to 10.0% of a participant s compensation.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P191_S7	The quarterly matching contributions are primarily equal to 75.0% of the first 6.0% of the participant s contribution.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P192_S0	The Company established the ESOP component as a funding vehicle for the KSOP.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P192_S1	The common shares acquired by the KSOP were pledged as collateral under an intercompany loan agreement ("ESOP loan") between the KSOP and Company.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P192_S2	The Company accounted for its ESOP in accordance with ASC 718-40, Employee Stock Ownership Plans ( ASC 718-40 ) and ASC 480-10, Distinguishing Liabilities from Equity ( ASC 480-10 ).
1442145_18_ITEM8_P192_S3	As of December 31, 2015, the KSOP no longer had any outstanding ESOP loan balance with the Company.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P193_S0	For the year ended December 31, 2015 , the Company instructed the KSOP to release 145,007 shares of common stock at a weighted average per price of $72.06 to fund the quarterly matching contributions.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P193_S1	Upon maturity of the ESOP loan, the Company issued common stock under the KSOP from the Company's treasury shares to fund the 401(k) matching contributions.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P193_S2	For the year ended December 31, 2016 , the Company issued 181,198 shares of common stock at a weighted average per price of $79.97 to fund the quarterly matching contributions.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P193_S3	The Company also contributed a total of $18.8 million of cash to the KSOP for the year ended December 31, 2016 .
1442145_18_ITEM8_P193_S4	For the year ended December 31, 2017 , the Company opted to fund the 401(k) matching contributions in cash in lieu of issuance of common stock from treasury shares and made cash contributions of $15.6 million .
1442145_18_ITEM8_P193_S5	KSOP compensation expense including the discontinued operations funded by the Company's common stock for 2016 and 2015 was $14.5 million and $14.1 million , respectively.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P193_S6	At December 31, 2017 , 2016 and 2015 , the fair value of Verisk common stock was $96.00 , $81.17 , and $76.88 per share, respectively.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P194_S0	In 2005, the Company established the ISO Profit Sharing Plan (the Profit Sharing Plan ), a defined contribution plan, to replace the qualified pension plan for all eligible employees hired on or after March 1, 2005.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P194_S1	The Profit Sharing Plan is a component of the KSOP.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P194_S2	Eligible employees participated in the Profit Sharing Plan if they completed 1,000 hours of service each plan year and were employed on December 31 of that year.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P194_S3	The Company can make a discretionary contribution to the Profit Sharing Plan based on the annual performance of the Company.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P194_S4	Participants vest once they have completed four years and 1,000 hours of service.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P194_S5	For the years ended December 31, 2017 , 2016 and 2015 , there were no profit sharing contributions.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P195_S0	Equity Compensation Plans All of the Company s outstanding stock options and restricted stock are covered under the 2013 Incentive Plan, 2009 Incentive Plan or the 1996 Incentive Plan.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P195_S1	Awards under the 2013 Incentive Plan may include one or more of the following types: (i) stock options (both nonqualified and incentive stock options), (ii) stock appreciation rights, (iii) restricted stock, (iv) restricted stock units, (v) performance awards, (vi) other share-based awards, and (vii) cash.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P195_S2	Employees, directors and consultants are eligible for awards under the 2013 Incentive Plan.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P195_S3	The Company issued common stock under these plans from the Company's treasury shares.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P195_S4	The number of shares of common stock available for issuance under the 2013 Incentive Plan is 15,700,000 and such amount shall be reduced on a 1 -for-1 basis for every share issued that is subject to an option or stock appreciation right and on a 2.5 -for-1 basis for every share issued that is subject to an award other than an option or stock appreciation right.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P196_S0	subject to options or stock appreciation rights, and on an 2.5 -for-1 basis if the shares were subject to awards other than options or stock appreciation rights.

1442145_18_ITEM8_P198_S2	The fair value of the restricted stock is determined using the closing price of the Company's common stock on the grant date.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P198_S3	The restricted stock is not assignable or transferable until it becomes vested.

1442145_18_ITEM8_P201_S0	The expected term for the stock options granted for a majority of the awards granted was estimated based on studies of historical experience and projected exercise behavior.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P201_S1	However, for certain awards granted, for which no historical exercise pattern exists, the expected term was estimated using the simplified method.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P202_S0	The risk-free interest rate is based on the yield of U.S. Treasury zero coupon securities with a maturity equal to the expected term of the equity award.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P202_S1	The volatility factor is calculated using historical daily closing prices over the most recent period that is commensurate with the expected term of the stock option awards.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P202_S2	The expected dividend yield was based on the Company s expected annual dividend rate on the date of grant.

1442145_18_ITEM8_P210_S0	The Company also offers eligible employees the opportunity to participate in an employee stock purchase plan ("ESPP").
1442145_18_ITEM8_P210_S1	Under the ESPP, participating employees may authorize payroll deductions of up to 20.0% of their regular base salary and up to 50.0% of their short-term incentive compensation, both of which in total may not exceed twenty-five thousand dollars in any calendar year, to purchase shares of the Company s common stock at a 5.0% discount of its fair market value at the time of purchase.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P210_S2	In accordance with ASC 718, the ESPP is noncompensatory as the purchase discount is 5.0% or less from the fair market value, substantially all employees that meet limited employment qualifications may participate, and it incorporates no option features.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P211_S0	During the years ended December 31, 2017 , 2016 and 2015 , the Company issued 29,605 , 29,867 and 25,599 shares of common stock at a weighted average discounted price of $81.38 , $76.75 and $70.27 , respectively.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P212_S0	The Company has a frozen qualified defined benefit pension plan for certain of its employees through membership in the Pension Plan for Insurance Organizations (the Pension Plan ), a multiple-employer trust.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P212_S1	Prior to the freeze, the Company applied a cash balance formula to determine future benefits.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P212_S2	Under the cash balance formula, each participant has an account, which was credited annually based on salary rates determined by years of service, as well as the interest earned on the previous year-end cash balance.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P212_S3	The Company also has a non-qualified frozen supplemental cash balance plan ( SERP ) for certain employees.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P212_S4	The SERP is funded from the general assets of the Company.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P212_S5	The Pension Plan s funding policy is to contribute annually at an amount between the minimum funding requirements set forth in the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 and the maximum amount that can be deducted for federal income tax purposes.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P212_S6	The minimum contribution requirement was and is expected to be $0 in 2017 and 2018 , respectively.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P212_S7	The Company contributed $0.9 million and $1.0 million to the SERP in 2017 and 2016 , respectively, and expects to contribute $0.8 million in 2018 .
1442145_18_ITEM8_P213_S0	The Company also provides certain healthcare and life insurance benefits for both active and retired employees.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P213_S1	The Postretirement Health and Life Insurance Plan (the Postretirement Plan ), which has been frozen, is contributory, requiring participants to pay a stated percentage of the premium for coverage.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P213_S2	The Company does not expect to contribute to the Postretirement Plan in 2018 .

1442145_18_ITEM8_P219_S0	The following table presents the estimated future benefit payments for the respective plans.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P219_S1	The future benefit payments for the Postretirement Plan are net of the federal Medicare subsidy.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P220_S0	The healthcare cost trend rate for 2017 was 8.75% gradually decreasing to 4.50% in 2035.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P220_S1	Assumed healthcare cost trend rates have a significant effect on the amounts reported for the healthcare plan.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P220_S2	However, a 1.00% change in assumed healthcare cost trend rates would have an immaterial effect to our postretirement benefit obligation.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P220_S3	The subsidy from the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003 reduced the Company s accumulated postretirement benefit obligation by approximately $1.6 million and $2.1 million as of December 31, 2017 and 2016 , and the net periodic benefit cost by approximately $2.0 thousand , $54.0 thousand and $7.0 thousand in fiscal 2017 , 2016 and 2015 , respectively.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P220_S4	The expected return on the Pension Plan assets as of December 31, 2017 and 2016 was 7.00% and 7.25% , respectively, which was determined by taking into consideration the Company s analysis of its actual historical investment returns to a broader long-term forecast after adjusting for the target investment allocation and reflecting the current economic environment.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P221_S0	The Company s investment guidelines target investment allocation of 60% equity securities and 40% debt securities.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P221_S1	The Pension Plan assets consist primarily of investments in various fixed income and equity funds.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P221_S2	Investment guidelines are established with each investment manager.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P221_S3	These guidelines provide the parameters within which the investment managers agree to operate, including criteria that determine eligible and ineligible securities, diversification requirements and credit quality standards, where applicable.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P221_S4	Investment managers are prohibited from entering into any speculative hedging transactions.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P222_S0	The investment objective is to achieve a maximum total return with strong emphasis on preservation of capital in real terms.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P222_S1	The domestic equity portion of the total portfolio should range between 40% and 60% .
1442145_18_ITEM8_P222_S2	The international equity portion of the total portfolio should range between 10% and 20% .
1442145_18_ITEM8_P222_S3	The fixed income portion of the total portfolio should range between 20% and 40% .
1442145_18_ITEM8_P222_S4	The asset allocation at December 31, 2017 and 2016 , and target allocation for 2018 by asset category are as follows:
1442145_18_ITEM8_P223_S0	The Company has used the target investment allocation to derive the expected return as the Company believes this allocation will be retained on an ongoing basis that will be commensurate with the projected cash flows of the plan.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P224_S0	The expected return for each investment category within the target investment allocation is developed using average historical rates of return for each targeted investment category, considering the projected cash flow of the Pension Plan.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P224_S1	The difference between this expected return and the actual return on plan assets is generally deferred and recognized over subsequent periods through future net periodic benefit costs.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P224_S2	The Company believes that the use of the average historical rates of returns is consistent with the timing and amounts of expected contributions to the plans and benefit payments to plan participants.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P224_S3	These considerations provide the basis for reasonable assumptions with respect to the expected long-term rate of return on plan assets.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P225_S0	The Company also maintains a voluntary employees beneficiary association plan (the VEBA Plan ) under Section 501(c)(9) of the Internal Revenue Code to fund the Postretirement Plan.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P225_S1	The asset allocation for the VEBA Plan at December 31, 2017 and target allocation for 2018 are 100% in debt securities.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P226_S0	There were no transfers among Levels 1, 2 or 3 for the years ended December 31, 2017 and 2016 .
1442145_18_ITEM8_P227_S0	Fair Value Measurements for further discussion with respect to fair value hierarchy.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P227_S1	The following table summarizes the fair value measurements by level of the Pension Plan and Postretirement Plan assets:
1442145_18_ITEM8_P228_S0	(1) Valued at the closing price of shares for domestic stocks within the managed equity accounts, and valued at the net asset value ( NAV ) of shares for mutual funds at either the closing price reported in the active market or based on yields currently available on comparable securities of issuers with similar credit ratings for corporate bonds held by the Pension Plan in these managed accounts.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P228_S1	(2) The pooled separate accounts invest in domestic and foreign stocks, bonds and mutual funds.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P228_S2	The fair values of these stocks, bonds and mutual funds are publicly quoted and are used in determining the NAV of the pooled separate account, which is not publicly quoted.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P229_S0	(3) Investments for which readily determinable prices do not exist are valued by the General Partner using either the market or income approach.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P230_S0	In establishing the estimated fair value of investments, including those without readily determinable values, the General Partner assumes a reasonable period of time for liquidation of the investment, and takes into consideration the financial condition and operating results of the underlying portfolio company, nature of investment, restrictions on marketability, holding period, market conditions, foreign currency exposures, and other factors the General Partner deems appropriate.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P231_S0	collateralized mortgage obligations, and other obligations that are secured by mortgages or mortgage backed securities, and valued at the closing price reported in the active market.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P231_S1	(5) The funds invested in common stocks and other equity securities issued by domestic and foreign real estate companies, including real estate investment trusts ("REIT") and similar REIT-like entities.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P231_S2	The fair values of these stocks, bonds and mutual funds are publicly quoted and are used in determining the NAV of the funds, which is not publicly quoted.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P232_S0	Segment Reporting ASC 280-10, Disclosures About Segments of an Enterprise and Related Information ( ASC 280-10 ), establishes standards for reporting information about operating segments.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P232_S1	ASC 280-10 requires that a public business enterprise reports financial and descriptive information about its reportable operating segments.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P232_S2	Operating segments are components of an enterprise for which separate financial information is available that is evaluated regularly by the chief operating decision maker ( CODM ) in deciding how to allocate resources and in assessing performance.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P232_S3	The Company s President and CEO is identified as the CODM as defined by ASC 280-10.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P232_S4	To align with the internal management of the Company s business operations based on service offerings, the Company is organized into the following two operating segments, which are also the Company s reportable segments: Decision Analytics:
1442145_18_ITEM8_P233_S0	The Company develops solutions that its customers use to analyze key processes in managing risk.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P233_S1	The Company s combination of algorithms and analytic methods incorporates its proprietary data to generate solutions.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P233_S2	In most cases, the Company s customers integrate the solutions into their models, formulas or underwriting criteria in order to predict potential loss events, ranging from hurricanes to earthquakes.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P234_S0	The Company develops catastrophe and extreme event models and offers solutions covering natural and man-made risks, including acts of terrorism.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P234_S1	The Company also develops solutions that allow customers to quantify costs after loss events occur.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P234_S2	Fraud solutions include data on claim histories, analysis of claims to find emerging patterns of fraud, and identification of suspicious claims in the insurance sector.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P234_S3	The Company further leverages predictive models and proprietary data to advise customers to make asset investment and portfolio allocation decisions in the global energy market.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P235_S0	On June 1, 2016, the Company sold its healthcare business, Verisk Health.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P235_S1	Results of operations for the healthcare business are reported as discontinued operations for the year ended December 31, 2016 and for all prior periods presented.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P235_S2	Refer to Note 9 for more information.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P236_S0	The Company is the leading provider of statistical, actuarial and underwriting data for the U.S. P C insurance industry.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P236_S1	The Company s databases include cleansed and standardized records describing premiums and losses in insurance transactions, casualty and property risk attributes for commercial buildings and their occupants and fire suppression capabilities of municipalities.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P236_S2	The Company uses this data to create policy language and proprietary risk classifications that are industry standards and to generate prospective loss cost estimates used to price insurance policies.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P237_S0	The two aforementioned operating segments represent the segments for which separate discrete financial information is available and upon which operating results are regularly evaluated by the CODM in order to assess performance and allocate resources.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P237_S1	The Company uses EBITDA as the profitability measure for making decisions regarding ongoing operations.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P237_S2	EBITDA is net income before interest expense, provision for income taxes, depreciation and amortization of fixed and intangible assets.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P237_S3	Operating expenses consist of direct and indirect costs principally related to personnel, facilities, software license fees, consulting, travel, and third-party information services.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P237_S4	Indirect costs are generally allocated to the segments using fixed rates established by management based upon estimated expense contribution levels and other assumptions that management considers reasonable.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P237_S5	The Company does not allocate interest expense and provision for income taxes, since these items are not considered in evaluating the segment s overall operating performance.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P238_S0	The CODM does not evaluate the financial performance of each segment based on assets or geographical locations.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P238_S1	On a geographic basis, revenues from countries outside of the U.S. accounted for 21.7% , 22.6% and 18.2% of the Company's consolidated revenues for the years ended December 31, 2017 , 2016 and 2015 , respectively.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P238_S2	No individual country outside of the U.S. accounted for 10.0% or more of the Company's consolidated revenues for the years ended December 31, 2017 , 2016 and 2015 .
1442145_18_ITEM8_P239_S0	The following table provides the Company s revenue and EBITDA by reportable segment for the years ended December 31, as well as a reconciliation to operating income for all periods presented in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations:

1442145_18_ITEM8_P242_S0	Related Parties: The Company considers its stockholders that own more than 5% of the outstanding stock within the class to be related parties as defined within ASC 850, Related Party Disclosures .
1442145_18_ITEM8_P242_S1	The Company had no material transactions with related parties owning more than 5% of the entire class of stock as of December 31, 2017 and 2016 , except for transactions with the KSOP as disclosed in Note 15.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P242_S2	Compensation Plans in the accompanying consolidated financial statements.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P242_S3	In addition, the Company had no revenues from related parties for the years ended December 31, 2017 , 2016 and 2015 .
1442145_18_ITEM8_P243_S0	Commitments and Contingencies: The Company s operations are conducted on leased premises.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P243_S1	Approximate minimum rentals under long-term noncancelable leases for all leased premises, computer equipment and automobiles are as follows:
1442145_18_ITEM8_P244_S0	Most of the leases require payment of property taxes and utilities and, in certain cases, contain renewal options.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P245_S0	Operating leases consist of office space.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P245_S1	Capital leases consist of computer equipment, office equipment, and leased automobiles.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P245_S2	Rent expense on operating leases approximated $39.0 million , $39.5 million and $37.3 million in 2017 , 2016 and 2015 , respectively.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P245_S3	In addition, the Company is a party to legal proceedings with respect to a variety of matters in the ordinary course of business, including the matters described below.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P245_S4	With respect to ongoing matters, the Company is unable, at the present time, to determine the ultimate resolution of or provide a reasonable estimate of the range of possible loss attributable to these matters or the impact they may have on the Company s results of operations, financial position or cash flows.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P245_S5	This is primarily because the matters are generally in early stages and discovery has either not commenced or been completed.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P245_S6	Although the Company believes it has strong defenses and intends to vigorously defend these matters, the Company could in the future incur judgments or enter into settlements of claims that could have a material adverse effect on its results of operations, financial position or cash flows.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P246_S0	Litigation On September 9, 2015, the Company was served with a nationwide putative class action complaint filed in the Court of Common Pleas, Cuyahoga County in Ohio naming the Company s subsidiary Intellicorp Records, Inc. ( Intellicorp ) titled Sherri Legrand v. Intellicorp Records, Inc. and The Cato Corporation et al.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P247_S0	District Court for the Northern District of Ohio on October 8, 2015.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P247_S1	Plaintiffs filed their First Amended Class Action Complaint on November 5, 2015 ( Amended Complaint ), which like the prior complaint claims violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ("FCRA") and alleges two putative class claims against Intellicorp, namely (i) a section 1681k(a) claim on behalf of all individuals who were the subjects of consumer reports furnished by Intellicorp, which contained public record information in the Government Sanctions section of the report on or after September 4, 2013 and continuing through the date the class list is prepared, and (ii) a section 1681e(b) claim on behalf of all individuals who were the subjects of consumer reports furnished by Intellicorp, which contained public record information in the Government Sanctions section of the report where the address or social security number of the subject of the report do not match the social security number or address contained in the government database on or after September 4, 2013 and continuing through the date the class list is prepared.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P247_S2	Count I of the Amended Complaint alleges that defendant Cato violated the FCRA by procuring consumer reports on the plaintiff and other class members without making the stand-alone disclosure required by FCRA section 1681b(b)(2)(A)(i).
1442145_18_ITEM8_P247_S3	Counts II and III allege that Intellicorp violated the FCRA section 1681e (b) by failing to follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum accuracy of the adverse information included in its consumer reports and FCRA section 1681k (a) by failing to maintain strict procedures to assure that the public record information reported, which was likely to have an adverse effect on the consumer was complete and up to date, respectively.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P247_S4	The Amended Complaint alleges that defendants acted willfully and seeks statutory damages for the classes in an amount not less than one hundred dollars and not more than one thousand dollars per violation, punitive damages, equitable relief, costs and attorney s fees.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P247_S5	On April 24, 2017, the parties agreed to resolve the litigation in a Settlement Agreement and Release and plaintiffs filed their Motion for Preliminary Approval of the settlement on the same day.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P248_S0	The settlement provides for a non-material cash payment by the Company, as well as certain non-monetary relief.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P248_S1	The District Court granted the Motion for Preliminary Approval on April 25, 2017 and issued its Final Approval Order on October 31, 2017.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P249_S0	Xactware Solutions, Inc. Patent Litigation On October 8, 2015, the Company was served with a summons and complaint in an action titled Eagle View Technologies, Inc. and Pictometry International Group, Inc. v. Xactware Solutions, Inc. and Verisk Analytics, Inc. filed in the United States District Court for the District of New Jersey.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P249_S1	The complaint alleges that the Company s Roof InSight, Property InSight and Aerial Sketch products infringe seven patents owned by Eagle View and Pictometry namely, Patent Nos. 436, 840, 152, 880, 770, 732 and 454.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P249_S2	On November 30, 2015, plaintiffs filed a First Amended Complaint adding Patent Nos. 376 and 737 to the Patents in Suit.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P249_S3	The First Amended Complaint seeks an entry of judgment by the Court that defendants have and continue to directly infringe and/or indirectly infringe, by way of inducement the Patents-in-Suit, permanent injunctive relief, damages, costs and attorney s fees.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P249_S4	On May 17, 2017, the District Court so ordered a Joint Stipulated Order of Partial Dismissal with Prejudice dismissing all claims or assertions pertaining to Pictometry Patents Nos. 880 and 732 and certain enumerated claims or assertions pertaining to Eagle View Patents Nos. 436, 840, 152, 770, 454, 376 and 737 (collectively the Patents in Suit ).
1442145_18_ITEM8_P250_S0	At this time, it is not reasonably possible to determine the ultimate resolution of, or estimate the liability related to this matter.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P251_S0	Litigation On August 1, 2014, the Company was served with an Amended Complaint filed in the United States District Court for the District of Colorado titled Snyder, et. al. v. ACORD Corp., et al.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P251_S1	The action is brought by nineteen individual plaintiffs, on their own behalf and on behalf of a putative class, against more than 120 defendants, including the Company and ISO.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P251_S2	Except for the Company, ISO and the defendant Acord Corporation, which provides standard forms to assist in insurance transactions, most of the other defendants are property and casualty insurance companies that plaintiffs claim conspired to underpay property damage claims.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P252_S0	Plaintiffs claim that the Company and ISO, along with all the other defendants, violated state and federal antitrust and racketeering laws as well as state common law.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P252_S1	On September 8, 2014, the Court entered an Order striking the Amended Complaint and granting leave to the plaintiffs to file a new complaint.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P252_S2	On October 13, 2014, plaintiffs filed their Second Amended Complaint, which was re-filed by plaintiffs to correct errors as the Third Amended Complaint.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P252_S3	The Third Amended Complaint similarly alleges that the defendants conspired to underpay property damage claims, but does not specifically allege what role the Company or ISO played in the alleged conspiracy.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P252_S4	It claims that the Company and ISO, along with all the other defendants, violated state and federal antitrust and racketeering laws as well as state common law, and seeks all available relief including injunctive, statutory, actual and punitive damages as well as attorneys fees.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P252_S5	On January 15, 2016, the Court granted defendants motions to dismiss all claims asserted in the Third Amended Complaint.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P252_S6	Plaintiffs filed a motion for reconsideration of this dismissal on February 16, 2016.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P252_S7	The Court granted defendants motion to strike the motion for reconsideration on March 2, 2016 and gave plaintiffs leave to file another motion for reconsideration in accordance with the rules which plaintiffs filed on March 11, 2016 and, which was denied by the Court on April 25, 2016.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P252_S8	On April 1, 2016, plaintiffs also filed a Notice of Appeal of the Court s January 15, 2016 Order, which dismissed all claims in the Third Amended Complaint.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P252_S9	Plaintiffs also filed an appeal of the Court s denial of the motion for reconsideration, which the Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit consolidated with the appeal of the Court s January 15, 2016 dismissal.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P252_S10	Appellants filed their brief in support of the consolidated appeal on July 21, 2016 and Appellees filed their brief in response on September 21, 2016.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P252_S11	On April 6, 2017, the Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit affirmed the Court s dismissal of the Third Amended Complaint.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P252_S12	Appellants filed a motion for en banc reconsideration of the 10th Circuit s affirmance of the dismissal of the Third Amended Complaint which was denied on May 26, 2017.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P252_S13	Appellants filed their petition for a writ of certiorari in the Supreme Court on August 24, 2017 which was denied on October 30, 2017.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P252_S14	Plaintiffs filed a Petition for Rehearing to the Supreme Court on November 27, 2017 which was denied on January 8, 2018.

(the Company ) for the year ending December 31, 2017 , as filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission (the Report ), for the purpose of complying with Rule 13a-14(b) or Rule 15d-14(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 (the Exchange Act ) and Section 1350 of Chapter 63 of Title 18 of the United States Code.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P288_S0	Scott G. Stephenson, the Chief Executive Officer of the Company, and Lee M. Shavel, the Chief Financial Officer of the Company, each hereby certifies that, to the best of his knowledge: 1.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P288_S1	the Report fully complies with the requirements of Section 13(a) or 15(d) of the Exchange Act; and 2.
1442145_18_ITEM8_P289_S0	the information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations of the Company.
1442145_18_ITEM9A_P0_S0	Evaluation of Disclosure Controls and Procedures We are required to maintain disclosure controls and procedures (as that term is defined in Rules 13a-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the Exchange Act )) that are designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed in our reports under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized, and reported within the time periods specified in the Securities and Exchange Commission s rules and forms, and that such information is accumulated and communicated to our management, including our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, as appropriate, to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosures.
1442145_18_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Any controls and procedures, no matter how well designed and operated, can provide only reasonable assurance of achieving the desired control objectives at the reasonable assurance level.
1442145_18_ITEM9A_P1_S0	Our management, with the participation of the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, has evaluated the effectiveness of the Company s disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e)) as of the end of the period covered by this annual report on Form 10-K for the Company and our subsidiaries other than our recent acquisitions in 2017 (See Note 8 of our consolidated financial statements included in this annual report on Form 10-K).
1442145_18_ITEM9A_P1_S1	Management excluded from its assessment the internal control over financial reporting of these acquisitions and collectively represents approximately 2.0% of total assets (excluding goodwill and intangible assets which were integrated into the Company's systems and control environment) and 1.9% of revenues as of and for the year ended December 31, 2017 .
1442145_18_ITEM9A_P1_S2	Based upon the foregoing assessments, our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer have concluded that, as of December 31, 2017 , our disclosure controls and procedures were effective at the reasonable assurance level.
1442145_18_ITEM9A_P2_S0	Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting as of December 31, 2017 is set forth in Item 8.
1442145_18_ITEM9A_P2_S1	Attestation Report of the Registered Public Accounting Firm The Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting as of December 31, 2017 is set forth in Item 8.
1442145_18_ITEM9A_P3_S0	We are in the process of integrating our recent acquisitions in 2017 into our overall internal control over financial reporting process.
1442145_18_ITEM9A_P3_S1	Other than this ongoing integration, there have been no changes in our internal control over financial reporting identified in connection with the evaluation of such internal control that occurred during the fourth quarter of 2017 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting.
